content: Jabir bin Abdullah said that when the Prophet was on his camel in Dhul-Hulaifa, he started saying 'Labbaik', which means 'Here I am'.

title: Prophet's Advice on Hajj
content: 'Umar told me to get ready for Hajj because it is one of the two kinds of Jihad. The Prophet (ﷺ) sent my brother, 'Abdur Rahman, and me to Tan'im for Umra. He made me ride a camel with packsaddle.

title: Anas's Simple Hajj
content: Anas bin Malik went to Hajj on a donkey. He wasn't being stingy with money. The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) also went to Hajj on a donkey, and it carried his luggage too.

title: Aisha's Umrah
content: `Aisha told the Prophet she had not performed an Umrah. He said to `Abdur-Rahman, 'Take your sister and let her walk around the Kaaba from Tan'im.' `Abdur-Rahman helped `Aisha ride a camel and she walked around the Kaaba.

title: Best Deeds According to Prophet
content: Abu Huraira asked the Prophet what the best deed is. The Prophet (ﷺ) said it's to believe in Allah and His messenger. Abu Huraira asked again, 'What's next?' The Prophet (ﷺ) replied, 'To join a fight for Allah.' Then he was asked again, 'And what's next?' He said, 'To make a complete Hajj pilgrimage'.

title: Jihad for Women
content: I asked the Prophet: 'We think fighting in Allah's cause is the best thing to do.' He said: 'For women, the best fight is a successful Hajj pilgrimage'.

title: Hajj Forgives All Sins
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: If someone goes to Hajj and doesn't have sex with their wife during that time, and they don't do anything bad or sinful, then when they come back, all their sins will be forgiven. It's like being born again.

title: Miqat Points for Umra
content: Zaid bin Jubair visited Abdullah bin Umar at his house. He asked where to assume Ihram for Umra. Abdullah said that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) had set three points as Miqat: Qarn for people from Najd, Dhul-Hulaifa for people from Medina, and Al-Juhfa for people from Sham.

title: Provisions for Hajj
content: Some people from Yemen would travel to Mecca for Hajj without enough food. They said they relied on Allah. When they arrived in Medina, they asked the locals for help. Allah revealed a message saying: 'Bring some food with you when traveling, but the best provision is being careful of Allah's rules.'

title: Miqat Places for Hajj
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) chose special places for people to put on Ihram before going to Mecca. The Miqat places are: Dhul-Hulaifa for the people of Medina, Al-Juhfa for those from Sham (Syria and Lebanon), Qarn-al-Manazil for Najd, Yalamlam for Yemen. These places are for people living there or passing through on their way to Hajj or Umra. If you live near one of these places, you can put on Ihram when you leave your home. People from Mecca can put on Ihram in Mecca.

title: Ihram for Pilgrims
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said that people from Medina should put on Ihram clothes at a place called Dhul-Hulaifa. People from Sham (a region) should do the same at Al-Juhfa, and those from Najd at Qarn. He also said that people from Yemen should put on Ihram clothes at Yalamlam.

title: Miqat Places for Pilgrims
content: Ibn Abbas said that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) fixed certain places as Miqats. These are: Dhul Hulaifa for people from Medina, Al-Juhfa for those from Sham (Syria and surrounding areas), Qarn Ul-Manazil for Najd, Yalamlam for Yemen. People living in these areas should put on Ihram (special state of purity) at their home or when they reach these places if they're traveling to perform Hajj or Umra. Those who live in Mecca can assume Ihram from there.

title: Prophet's Prayer Times
content: Salim's father said the Prophet had decided on specific times for prayer. He didn't mention what those times were, though.

title: Miqats for Pilgrims
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said that the Miqat for people from Medina is Dhul-Hulaifa. For those from Sham, it's Mahita (Al-Juhfa). And for those from Najd, it's Qarn. Some people claim that for Yemenis, the Miqat is Yalamlam.

title: Miqat Places for Pilgrims
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) fixed some places as special points for people to put on their Ihram clothes before going to Mecca. These places are Dhul-Hulaifa for the people of Medina, Al-Juhfa for those from Sham (a region), Yalamlam for Yemen, Qarn for Najd, and Mecca itself for its residents. People who live in these areas can put on Ihram clothes at home. Others should go to one of these special points with the intention of performing Hajj or Umra before putting on Ihram.

title: Miqat Points for Pilgrims
content: Ibn Abbas said the Prophet set up special points for people to put on their Ihram. For Medina, it's Dhul-Hulaifa. For Sham (the north), it's Al-Juhfa. For Najd, it's Qarn-al-Manazil. And for Yemen, it's Yalamlam. People living near these places should put on Ihram from there. Others who travel through these areas to perform Hajj or Umra can also use them. But people already in Mecca can start their Ihram from Mecca itself.

title: Miqat for People of Najd
content: When Basra and Kufa were captured, the people went to Umar. They said, 'The Prophet (ﷺ) fixed Qarn as a special place for the people from Najd to stop before going to Mecca.' Umar said, 'Take Dhatu-Irq as your Miqat instead. It's on your usual way and opposite to Qarn.'

title: Allah's Messenger Prays at Al-Batha'
content: Abdullah bin Umar said that the Prophet made his camel sit down at a place called Al-Batha' in Dhul-Hulaifa. He then prayed there. Abdullah bin Umar did the same.

title: Prophet's Hajj Route
content: Ibn Umar said the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) went to Mecca using a route called Ash-Shajara and returned via Muarras. When he came to Mecca, he prayed at the Mosque of Ash-Shajara. On his way back, he prayed at Dhul-Hulaifa in the middle of a valley and stayed there till morning.

title: Prayer at Al-Aqiq Valley
content: Umar said that the Prophet received a message from Allah. A messenger came to him and asked him to pray in the valley of Al-Aqiq, which is a special place. The messenger also told the Prophet to wear Ihram clothes for Hajj and Umra at the same time.

title: Prophet's Resting Place
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said that he had a dream while resting in a valley at Dhul-Hulaifa. In the dream, he was told: 'You are in a blessed valley.' When he woke up, he stopped his camel and rested there. This place is below a mosque in the middle of the valley.

title: Prophet's Answer on Umrah
content: Ya'la asked 'Umar to show him the Prophet when he was being inspired. The Prophet (ﷺ) was with some companions at Ji'rana. A man came and asked, 'What if someone wears perfume while going for Umra?' The Prophet (ﷺ) kept quiet for a moment. Then he got inspiration. 'Umar signaled Ya'la to come closer. When Ya'la looked inside the tent, he saw the Prophet's face was red and he was sleeping. After the Prophet woke up, he asked where the person who asked about Umra was. He was brought in front of the Prophet. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Wash the perfume off your body three times. Remove your cloak. For Umra, do what you would do for Hajj.'

title: Ibn Umar's Hair Care
content: Sa'id bin Jubair said that Ibn 'Umar used to put oil in his hair. Ibrahim asked him about it and he told him a story from Aswad who said that Aisha saw the Prophet when he was not allowed to wear perfume or new clothes, and she noticed the scent of oil on his hair.

title: Ibn Umar's Hair Care
content: Sa'id bin Jubair told me that Ibn 'Umar used to oil his hair. I asked Ibrahim about this and he said: Aisha reported that she saw the Prophet (ﷺ) with scented oil in his hair while he was not allowed to wear perfume as a Muhrim.

title: Aisha's Story About Ihram
content: I used to put perfume on the Prophet when he wanted to go for Hajj. I also put perfume on him after he finished his rituals and walked around the Ka'ba.

title: Assuming Ihram for Hajj
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) had his hair tied together when he started the ritual of Ihram for a journey to perform Hajj.

title: Assuming Ihram at Dhul-Hulaifa
content: My father told me that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) never put on his special clothes for Hajj or Umrah except at the Mosque of Dhul-Hulaifa.

title: Muhrim's Clothing
content: A man asked the Prophet what a Muhrim should wear. The Prophet (ﷺ) said: 'He shouldn't wear a shirt, turban, trousers or headcloak as a Muhrim. If he can't find slippers, he may wear leather socks but cut off any part that covers his ankles. He also shouldn't wear scented clothes made with saffron or Wars perfume'.

title: Usama and Al-Fadl with Prophet
content: 'Ubaidullah bin 'Abdullah told me that Ibn Abbas said: Usama rode behind the Prophet from Arafat to Muzdalifa, then Al-Fadl rode behind him from Muzdalifa to Mina. Both of them said the Prophet kept reciting Talbiya until he threw pebbles at Jamrat-Al-'Aqaba.

title: Usama and Al-Fadl's Journey
content: 'Ubaidullah bin 'Abdullah said that Ibn Abbas told him: Usama rode with the Prophet from Arafat to Muzdalifa. Then Al-Fadl rode with the Prophet from Muzdalifa to Mina. Both of them said that the Prophet kept saying a prayer until he threw stones at Jamrat-Al-'Aqaba.

title: Prophet's Journey to Hajj
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) and his companions left Medina. He had combed his hair, put on special clothes, and was ready for the journey. They rode their camels until they reached a place called Baida', where they said a prayer called Talbiya. Then they decorated their camels with colored garlands. This happened on the 25th of Dhul-Qa'da. When they arrived in Mecca on the 4th of Dhul-Hijja, the Prophet went around the Ka'ba and between two hills called Safa and Marwa. He had a special camel that he had decorated with garlands, so he didn't finish his special clothes yet. He told his companions to go around the Ka'ba and between Safa and Marwa, cut their hair short, and finish their special clothes. But those who had decorated their camels were allowed to wait until later. People who brought their wives with them could be with them, and they could use perfume and regular clothes.

title: Prophet's Journey to Makkah
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) went to Medina and prayed four times. He then traveled to Dhul Hulaifa, where he prayed two more times. He stayed there overnight and left early in the morning when it was time to go on his journey. When he mounted his camel, he started saying 'Labbaik Allahumma Labbaik' (I am here for You, God).

title: Prophet's Prayer Routine
content: Anas bin Malik said the Prophet offered four rak'at of Zuhr prayer in Medina and two rak'at of Asr prayer at Dhul-Hulaifa. He stayed there overnight until morning.

title: Prophet's Prayers in Medina
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) offered four rak'at of the Zuhr prayer in Medina and two rak'at of the Asr prayer in Dhul-Hulaifa. I heard his companions reciting Talbiya loudly together.

title: Allah's Messenger's Talbiya
content: Abdullah bin Umar said: The Prophet Muhammad 's (ﷺ) call to Allah during Hajj was: 'I'm here, O Allah. I have no one else but You. All good things and power come from You. There is no one else like You.'

title: Prophet's Talbiya Prayer
content: I know what the Prophet used to say when he was on Hajj. He would say: 'Here I am, God, here I am. There is no partner with you. The praise and blessings are all for you. You have no partner.'

title: Prophet Muhammad's Hajj Journey
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) came to Medina and prayed four times. He then went to Dhul-Hulaifa and prayed again before spending the night there. The next day, he rode a horse and when they reached Al-Baida', he praised Allah and said some special words. They recited a prayer to show they were going for Hajj or Umra. When they arrived in Mecca, the Prophet told those who didn't have an animal for sacrifice to finish their Ihram (special state) until the 8th day of Dhul-Hijja. On that day, people put on Ihram again for Hajj. The Prophet (ﷺ) sacrificed many camels himself while standing. When he was in Medina, he also sacrificed two rams.

title: Ibn Umar's Pilgrimage Routine
content: When Ibn Umar finished his morning prayer at Dhul-Hulaifa, he would prepare his mount. He would ride it and face the Ka'bah while sitting on it. Then he would recite Talbiya until they reached the boundaries of Makkah. Once inside, he wouldn't say Talbiya again until nightfall near Dhi-Tuwa. After morning prayer, he would take a bath.

title: Ibn Umar's Ihram Ritual
content: When Ibn Umar wanted to go to Mecca, he would first pray in the Mosque of Al-Hulaifa. Then he'd oil himself with a special oil and ride his camel. When they stood up straight, he'd announce that he was going into Ihram. He said this is what the Prophet (ﷺ) used to do.

title: Ibn Abbas and Ad-Dajjal
content: Mujahid was with Ibn Abbas when people talked about the Dajjal. They said he would come with 'Kafir' written between his eyes. Ibn Abbas replied, 'I never heard this from the Prophet.' He then mentioned that the Prophet once said something like: I just saw Moses entering a valley and reciting Talbiyah.

title: Assuming Ihram for Umra
content: Aisha said: We went on Hajj with the Prophet. Some people had animals to sacrifice and assumed Ihram for both Hajj and Umra. The Prophet (ﷺ) told them not to finish their special clothes until they finished both rituals. I was menstruating when we arrived in Mecca, so I didn't do the usual walks around the Kaaba or between Safa and Marwa. I asked the Prophet about this, and he said: 'Undo your hair, assume Ihram for Hajj only, and leave Umra.' So I did that. After doing Hajj, the Prophet sent me to Tan'im with my brother. There, I performed another Umra. The Prophet (ﷺ) said: 'This Umra is instead of the one you missed.'

title: Prophet's Command to Ali
content: Jabir said the Prophet told Ali to keep wearing his Ihram clothes. Then Suraqa shared more about this event.

title: Ali's Journey to Mecca
content: `Ali came to the Prophet from Yemen. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked `Ali, 'Why did you start wearing Ihram?' `Ali said, 'I wore it for the same reason as you.' The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'If I didn't have a sacrifice animal with me, I would finish my Ihram now.'

title: Prophet's Guidance on Ihram
content: Abu Musa was sent to Yemen by the Prophet. When he returned, the Prophet asked him why he had put on special clothes for a pilgrimage (Ihram). Abu Musa said he did it like the Prophet would do. The Prophet (ﷺ) then asked if Abu Musa had brought an animal for sacrifice. He said no. So the Prophet told him to walk around the Kaaba and between Safa and Marwa, then finish his Ihram. Abu Musa did this and later got a haircut from a woman. When Umar became leader, he disagreed with what Abu Musa did, saying they should follow the Quran's rule to complete both Hajj and Umra pilgrimages.

title: Aisha's Hajj Story
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) and his companions went to Mecca for Hajj. They stopped at Sarif village. The Prophet (ﷺ) said that those without a sacrifice (Hadi) could do Umra instead of Hajj, but those with Hadi should not finish Ihram after Umra. Aisha was upset because she had her period and couldn't pray or perform Umra. The Prophet (ﷺ) told her it wouldn't harm her to keep her intention for Hajj. When she became clean from her menses, she performed Tawaf around the Kaaba. Later, the Prophet asked his companion 'Abdur-Rahman to take Aisha outside Mecca's sanctuary and let her assume Ihram for Umra. After finishing Umra and Tawaf, they returned to the Prophet at dawn. He announced their departure, and everyone left for Medina.

title: Aisha's Hajj Experience
content: Aisha said she went on a pilgrimage with the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) from Medina. When they arrived in Mecca, they performed a ritual walk around the Kaaba and then some people were allowed to stop wearing their special pilgrim clothes. The Prophet 's (ﷺ) wives, including Aisha, also stopped wearing theirs because they didn't bring animals for sacrifice. But Aisha got her period and couldn't do another ritual walk around the Kaaba. So she asked the Prophet what to do. He said she could go with her brother to a place called Tan'im and put on pilgrim clothes again for a smaller pilgrimage called Umra, then come back. Safiya, one of the other wives, was also allowed to stay with them because she had already done some rituals.

title: Assuming Ihram for Hajj
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) went to Mecca with his companions. Some of them had put on special clothes for Umra only, some for both Hajj and Umra, and others for just Hajj. The Prophet (ﷺ) also wore these special clothes for Hajj. If you're doing Hajj or both Hajj and Umra, you don't finish wearing these clothes until the day of sacrifice.

title: Uthman and Ali's Disagreement
content: Marwan bin Al-Hakam saw Uthman and Ali. Uthman told people not to do two things together: Hajj (pilgrimage) and Umra (lesser pilgrimage). When Ali saw this, he decided to wear the special clothes for both Hajj and Umra at the same time. He said 'I'm here for Umra and Hajj'. He didn't want to change what the Prophet taught.

title: Ibn Abbas Explains Old Beliefs
content: Before Islam, people thought it was a big sin to visit the Kaaba during Hajj time. They also believed that the month of Safar was special and couldn't be visited until after Hajj. The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) and his friends arrived in Mecca on the 4th day of Dhul-Hijja. He told them to change their plans from doing Hajj to just visiting the Kaaba for Umra instead. They were confused, so they asked him what they could do. The Prophet (ﷺ) said that since they had already started Ihram (special clothes), they should finish it like normal people and not follow any special rules.

title: Abu Musa's Umrah Story
content: I came to the Prophet from Yemen. I was getting ready for Hajj but he told me to finish my Ihram after doing a special prayer called Umra first.

title: Why the Prophet Didn't Finish Ihram
content: Hafsa asked the Prophet why he hadn't finished his special state of Ihram after performing Umra. The Prophet (ﷺ) replied that he had tied up his hair and decorated his animal for sacrifice, so he couldn't finish his Ihram until he had slaughtered it.

title: Ibn Abbas Explains Hajj Rules
content: Abu Jamra wanted to do a special kind of Hajj called Tamattu'. Some people told him not to. He asked Ibn Abbas, who said it was okay. Later, Abu Jamra had a dream that his Hajj would be accepted and good. He told Ibn Abbas about the dream. Ibn Abbas smiled and said 'This is what our Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) taught us.' Then he offered Abu Jamra some of his own money.

title: Hajj and Ihram Rules
content: Abu Shihab went to Mecca for Hajj. He assumed Ihram for Umra before the day of Tarwiya (8th Dhul-Hijja). Some people told him that his Hajj would be like the people of Mecca's, so he asked `Ata' about it. `Ata' said that Jabir bin Abdullah performed Hajj with the Prophet. The people had assumed Ihram for Hajj-al-Ifrad. The Prophet (ﷺ) ordered them to finish their Ihram after walking around the Kaaba and between Safa and Marwa, cut short their hair, and stay in Mecca as non-Muhrims till the day of Tarwiya. Then they would assume Ihram for Hajj again, making their original Ihram only for Umra.

title: Ali's Disagreement with Uthman
content: `Uthman and Ali disagreed about a type of Hajj at a place called 'Usfan. Ali thought `Uthman was stopping people from doing something the Prophet did. So, Ali decided to wear Ihram for both Hajj and Umra.

title: Jabir's Umrah Story
content: We came to Mecca with the Prophet. We said 'Labbaika Allahumma Labbaik' for Hajj, but the Prophet told us to do an Umra instead of a full Hajj.

title: Hajj at-Tamattu' Explained
content: In the time of Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ), some people did a special kind of Hajj called Hajj-at-Tamattu'. They would do Umra (a smaller pilgrimage) first and then Hajj. But Allah revealed a new rule that said they could join both in one year. The Prophet (ﷺ) and his companions followed this new rule. If you live outside Mecca, you can do Hajj-at-Tamattu' during the months of Shawwal, Dhul-Qa'da, or Dhul-Hijjah. But if you live in Mecca, you have to follow a different rule. When you do Hajj-at-Tamattu', you must either sacrifice an animal or fast for three days during Hajj and seven days after returning home.

title: Ibn Umar's Pre-Pilgrimage Routine
content: When Ibn Umar arrived in Mecca, he would stop and say a special prayer called Talbiya. Then he'd spend the night at Dhi-Tuwa, wake up early for Fajr prayer, take a bath, and then continue his journey.

title: Prophet's Night in Dhi-Tuwa
content: Ibn 'Umar said the Prophet passed a night at Dhi-Tuwa until dawn. Then he entered Mecca. Ibn 'Umar did the same, spending the night there before entering Mecca.

title: Entering and Leaving Mecca
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) would enter the city of Mecca from a high place called Thaniya al-Aliyya, and leave from a lower one called Thaniya al-Aswad.

title: Entering and Leaving Makkah
content: Ibn Umar said that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) entered Mecca from a high place called Kada', near Al-Batha'. He usually left Mecca from a lower place, also called Thaniya.

title: Prophet's Entry into Mecca
content: When the Prophet came to Mecca, he entered from its higher side and left from its lower side.

title: Prophet's Entry into Mecca
content: In the year of the conquest of Mecca, the Prophet entered from a place called Kada' and left from another place called Kuda, which is on the higher side of Mecca.

title: Prophet enters Mecca
content: In the year of the conquest of Mecca, Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) entered from a place called Kada'. He went to the higher part of the city. Some people used to enter through another route, but the Prophet preferred this one because it was closer to his home.

title: Prophet's Entry into Mecca
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) entered Mecca from the side of Kada', which is at a higher part of the city. He often used this route because it was closer to his home compared to other entrances.

title: Entering Mecca from Kada
content: In the year of the conquest of Mecca, the Prophet entered the city from a side called Kada. A man named `Urwa often came in through this gate because it was closer to his home.

title: Prophet Muhammad Builds Kaaba
content: Jabir bin Abdullah said: The Prophet (ﷺ) and Abbas went to the Kaaba. They were bringing stones for its construction. Abbas told the Prophet to take off his waistcloth and put it around his neck. When he took it off, he fell down on the ground with his eyes open towards the sky. He then asked for his waistcloth back and covered himself with it.

title: Rebuilding the Ka'ba
content: Aisha asked the Prophet about the Ka'ba. He said it was built smaller than Abraham's original foundation when her people rebuilt it. She suggested rebuilding it on its original foundations, but the Prophet didn't because her people were still close to their old ways.

title: The Prophet on the Wall
content: I asked the Prophet about a wall near the Ka'ba. He said it was part of the Ka'ba. I asked why it wasn't included in the building. He replied that my people, the Quraish, didn't have enough money. I also asked about its high gate. The Prophet (ﷺ) said they made it high so they could let some people in and keep others out. They were still close to their old ways of life and he was worried they might not like changes.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Plan for Ka'ba
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) told me that if the people of Mecca were not still influenced by their old ways, he would have torn down the Ka'ba and rebuilt it on its original foundation. The Quraish had made some changes to the building, so he wanted to go back to how Abraham built it.

title: The Prophet's Plan for the Ka'ba
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) told Aisha that if he had rebuilt the Ka'ba from scratch, he would have made it level with the ground and added two doors. He wanted to go back to its original foundation laid by Abraham. Later, Ibn-Az-Zubair did rebuild the Ka'ba and included a part of Al-Hijr in it. Yazid saw the original stones used by Abraham for the foundation, which looked like camel humps.

title: Mecca's Sanctuary Rules
content: When Mecca was conquered, the Prophet said: 'Allah has made this town a safe place. Don't cut down its thorny bushes, don't chase its animals, and if something falls, only pick it up if you tell everyone about it.'

title: Allah's Messenger's Home
content: 'Usama bin Zaid asked the Prophet, 'Where will you stay in Mecca?' The Prophet (ﷺ) replied, 'Has `Aqil left any property or house? He inherited some from Abu Talib with his brother Talib. Jafar and Ali didn't inherit anything because they were Muslims, but their brothers weren't. Some people thought a Muslim couldn't inherit from a non-believer. They based this on the Quran: 'Those who believed and moved to another country for Allah's cause, those who helped them and gave them a place to live, are all friends with each other.'

title: Prophet's Journey to Mecca
content: When the Prophet was about to enter Mecca, he said that if Allah wanted, they would go to Khaif Bani Kinana. This is where the pagans had taken an oath against him and his family.

title: Prophet's Warning at Mina
content: On the Day of Nahr at Mina, the Prophet said: 'Tomorrow we will stay at a place where pagans once made an agreement against my family and friends. They wanted to make them give me up.'

title: The Prophet's Warning
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: A man from Ethiopia will come and knock down the Ka'ba. He is called Dhus-Suwaiqa-tain, which means he has two thin legs.

title: Fasting on Ashura Day
content: Before Ramadan fasting was made compulsory, people used to fast on the tenth day of Muharram. They also covered the Kaaba with a cloth. When Allah made Ramadan fasting obligatory, Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: 'If you want to fast on this day, you can. If not, it's okay.'

title: Hajj Will Continue Forever
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said that people will still go on Hajj and Umra to the Kaaba even after a great disaster. He also said that the Day of Judgment won't come until people stop going on Hajj.

title: Umar's Distribution of Wealth
content: Abu Wail sat with Shaiba inside the Kaaba. Shaiba said that Umar had sat there and said, 'I want to give away all gold and silver.' Abu Wail reminded Umar that the Prophet and Abu Bakr did not do this. Umar replied, 'They are the two people I usually follow.'

title: The Prophet Sees a Man
content: Ibn Abbas said the Prophet saw a black man with thin legs picking up stones from the Kaaba one by one.

title: The Ka'ba Will Be Demolished
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said that a man from Ethiopia will destroy the Ka'ba. He is known as Dhus-Suwaiqatain, which means 'the thin-legged man'.

title: Umar Kisses the Black Stone
content: `Umar came near the Black Stone. He kissed it and said, 'I know you're just a stone and can't help or harm anyone. I wouldn't have kissed you if I hadn't seen the Prophet kissing you.'

title: Entering the Ka'ba
content: Salim's father said that Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) and some companions went into the Ka'ba. They closed the door, then Salim's father entered first when they opened it again. He met Bilal and asked if the Prophet had prayed inside. Bilal said yes, between two pillars.

title: Praying in the Ka'ba
content: Ibn Umar would walk straight into the Ka'ba and stop about three cubits from the front wall. He'd pray there, aiming for where the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) prayed. Bilal told him that spot. Anyone can pray anywhere inside the Ka'ba.

title: Prophet's Umra Visit
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) went to perform an Umra. He walked around the Kaaba and prayed two times near a special stone where Abraham had stood. Some people were hiding him from others so he wouldn't be disturbed. Someone asked Abdullah bin Abu Aufa, 'Did Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) go inside the Kaaba?' Abdullah said no.

title: Removing Idols from Ka'ba
content: When Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) came to Mecca, he didn't want to enter the Ka'ba with idols inside. He ordered them to be removed. The people took out pictures of Abraham and Ishmael holding Azlams. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'May Allah curse these people.' They never played games with Azlams like this. Then he entered the Ka'ba and said 'Allahu Akbar' at its corners but didn't pray inside.

title: Prophet's Visit to Mecca
content: When the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) and his friends arrived in Mecca, people thought they were weak because many of them had been sick with a fever. The Prophet (ﷺ) told his friends to walk quickly for the first three times around the Kaaba, but only for those rounds. He didn't want them to do it all the time because he felt sorry for them.

title: Kissing the Black Stone
content: Salim's father said that when the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) arrived in Mecca, he first kissed the Black Stone corner during his Tawaf. He walked quickly in the first three rounds of the seven rounds of Tawaf.

title: Prophet's Walking Style in Tawaf
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) walked quickly for the first three rounds of walking around the Kaaba during Hajj and Umra, then he walked normally for the remaining four rounds.

title: Umar's Visit to the Black Stone
content: Umar bin Al-Khattab stood in front of the Black Stone and said: 'I know you're just a stone, you can't help or harm anyone. I wouldn't have kissed you if I hadn't seen the Prophet doing it.' He then kissed the stone and said: 'We used to do Ramal (walk quickly) around the Kaaba because we wanted to show off to the pagans, but now they're gone.' Umar added: 'The Prophet (ﷺ) did this, so we'll keep doing it too.'

title: Touching the Black Stone
content: Ibn Umar said he never missed touching two special stones at the Kaaba. He saw the Prophet do this, even when many people were around. Ibn Umar would walk between these stones so it was easy for him to touch them.

title: Prophet's Last Hajj
content: In his last pilgrimage to Mecca, the Prophet rode a camel around the Ka'ba. He pointed at the Black Stone with a stick. Some people thought they should touch all four corners of the Ka'ba, but Ibn Abbas said it was okay to leave out two of them.

title: Prophet's Mosque Behavior
content: Salim bin Abdullah said his father told him: 'I have never seen the Prophet touch except the two corners of the mosque that face Yemen.'

title: Umar kisses the Black Stone
content: Zaid's father said that he saw Umar kissing the Black Stone. Then Umar said, 'If I hadn't seen the Prophet kiss it, I wouldn't have kissed it either.'

title: Touching the Black Stone
content: A man asked Ibn Umar about touching the Black Stone. Ibn Umar said he saw the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) touching and kissing it. The man asked what to do if there's a big crowd around the Kaaba, and Ibn Umar replied that he should stay in Yemen - he had seen the Prophet touch and kiss the stone.

title: Prophet's Tawaf on Camel
content: Ibn Abbas said the Prophet rode a camel during his walk around the Kaaba. When he reached each corner, he pointed towards it with something in his hand.

title: Prophet's Tawaf on a Camel
content: Ibn Abbas said the Prophet rode his camel around the Kaaba. When he reached the corner with the Black Stone, he pointed to it and said 'Allahu Akbar' (God is great).

title: Prophet's First Action in Mecca
content: When the Prophet arrived in Mecca, he first performed a ritual washing. Then he walked around the Ka'ba seven times. This was not just an Umra (a shorter pilgrimage), but a full Hajj. Later, other companions like Abu Bakr and Umar did the same thing during their pilgrimages. I also saw my father, Zubair, do it first by walking around the Ka'ba. My mother told me that she and others had put on special clothes for an Umra pilgrimage, but then they finished their Ihram (special state) after touching a corner of the Ka'ba.

title: Prophet's First Actions in Mecca
content: When the Prophet arrived in Mecca, he first performed a ritual washing. Then he walked around the Kaaba and did some rituals that combined both Hajj and Umra. Later, other leaders like Abu Bakr and Umar also followed this same order of actions. I saw my father Az-Zubair do it too. My mother told me she and others had done Umra first, then finished their special clothes.

title: Prophet's Hajj Rituals
content: When the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) performed a special walk around the Kaaba for either Hajj or Umra, he would walk quickly during the first three rounds and then normally in the last four. After walking around the Kaaba, he would pray two times and then walk between Safa and Marwa.

title: Prophet's Tawaf Practice
content: When the Prophet performed the Tawaf around the Kaaba, he walked quickly for the first three rounds and normally for the last four. When walking between Safa and Marwa, he ran in the middle of the water path. The wives of the Prophet used to perform Tawaf with men, but they would stay outside when entering the Kaaba until the men had left.

title: Um Salama's Story
content: I told the Prophet I was sick. He said to do a special walk around the Ka'ba while riding behind others. I did it, and at that time he was praying near the Ka'ba and reading from the Quran.

title: Prophet Muhammad Helps a Man
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) was walking around the Kaaba. He saw a man whose hands were tied to another person with a rope. The Prophet (ﷺ) cut the rope and said, 'Let him go by your side'.

title: Cutting the Rope
content: Ibn Abbas said the Prophet saw a man walking around the Kaaba with a rope tied to his waist. The Prophet (ﷺ) cut that rope.

title: No Pagans Allowed to Hajj
content: Before the last Hajj of the Prophet, Abu Bakr was in charge. He sent me and a group of people to tell everyone: 'No non-Muslim can do Hajj after this year. And no one should walk naked around the Ka'ba.'

title: Sexual Relations During Umra
content: We asked Ibn Umar if a man can have sex with his wife during the Umra pilgrimage before walking around the Kaaba. He said that when the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) arrived in Mecca, he first walked around the Kaaba seven times and then prayed behind Abraham's stone. After that, he walked between Safa and Marwa. Ibn Umar told us to follow the Prophet's example: we should not have sex with our wives until after walking between Safa and Marwa.

title: Sex During Umra
content: We asked Ibn Umar if a man can have sex with his wife during the Umra before walking around the Kaaba. He said, 'Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) did it this way: he walked around the Kaaba seven times, then prayed behind Maqam Ibrahim, and after that he walked between Safa and Marwa.' Ibn Umar added, 'You should follow Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) as a good example.' We asked Jabir bin Abdullah the same question. He said, 'Wait to have sex with your wife until you've finished walking between Safa and Marwa'.

title: Prophet's Visit to Mecca
content: When the Prophet arrived in Mecca, he walked around the Ka'ba and between Safa and Marwa. He didn't go near the Ka'ba again until after returning from Arafat.

title: Um Salama's Story
content: I told the Prophet about my illness. He said to do a special walk around the Ka'ba when people are praying in the morning, while I'm on my camel. So I did it and didn't pray two special prayers until I left the mosque.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Visit to Mecca
content: Ibn Umar said that when the Prophet arrived in Mecca, he walked around the Kaaba seven times. Then he prayed two short prayers behind a special stone called Maqam Ibrahim. After that, he went to Safa. Allah says we should follow the Prophet's example.

title: Avoid Delaying Prayer
content: Some people walked around the Ka'ba after morning prayer. They sat to listen to a speaker until sunrise. Then they stood up for their prayer, even though it's not good to delay prayer past its usual time.

title: Prayer Times to Avoid
content: I heard the Prophet say not to pray at sunrise or sunset. He forbade it.

title: Abdullah's Prayer Routine
content: Abdul Aziz said he saw Abdullah bin Az-Zubair perform a special walk around the Kaaba after morning prayer, then pray two short prayers. He also saw Abdullah pray two short prayers in the afternoon. Abdullah told Abdul Aziz that his wife Aisha said the Prophet used to do these same two short prayers whenever he came home.

title: Abdullah's Morning and Asr Prayers
content: Abdul Aziz said he saw Abdullah bin Az-Zubair do two things. First, after morning prayer, he walked around the Kaaba. Then he prayed again for just two short prayers. Abdul Aziz also saw him pray twice more in the afternoon. He told us that Aisha said her husband, the Prophet, used to do these same two short prayers whenever he came home.

title: Prophet's Tawaf with Injury
content: Ibn Abbas said that the Prophet was performing a ritual walk around the Kaaba on his camel because he had an injured foot. When he came to the corner with the Black Stone, he would point at it and say 'Allahu-Akbar' (God is great).

title: Um Salama's Story
content: I told the Prophet I was sick. He said, 'While people are doing Tawaf around the Ka'ba, you can do it on a camel behind them.' So, I did Tawaf while he was praying beside the Ka'ba and reciting the Quran.

title: Al Abbas' Request
content: Ibn Umar said that Al Abbas asked the Prophet for permission to stay in Mecca at night during the Mina days. He wanted to help pilgrims by giving them water. The Prophet (ﷺ) agreed to let him.

title: Prophet Muhammad Drinks from a Well
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) came to a place where people were getting water. He asked for some and Al-Abbas said, 'Go get it from your mother.' The Prophet (ﷺ) drank the water and then went to the Zamzam well. There, he saw people helping each other get water. He told them to keep going because they were doing something good. He also thought about taking a rope to help, but didn't want others to start competing for the task.

title: Jibril's Visit to the Prophet
content: Abu Dhar said that one night the Prophet was in Makkah. Jibril came down and opened his chest, washing it with Zamzam water. Then he brought a golden tray filled with wisdom and faith and poured it into the Prophet's chest. He closed the chest and took the Prophet's hand, leading him to the first heaven. At the gate, Jibril said 'I'm Jibril' and the gatekeeper let them in.

title: Prophet drinks Zamzam water
content: Ibn Abbas gave Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) some Zamzam water. He drank it while standing up. Some people said the Prophet was actually riding a camel when he drank it, but Ibn Abbas swore that wasn't true.

title: Allah's Messenger on Ihram
content: We were with the Prophet during his last Hajj. We wanted to do a small pilgrimage called `Umra, but he said: 'If you have an animal for sacrifice, do both Hajj and `Umra at the same time.' When we arrived in Mecca, I got my period. After doing the big pilgrimage (Hajj), the Prophet sent me with someone else to perform a small one (`Umra). He said this was instead of the one I missed. Some people did two walks between Safa and Marwa, then finished their special clothes. Others did only one walk.

title: Ibn Umar's Hajj Decision
content: Abdullah bin Abdullah bin Umar came to his son's house with his camel. His son said, 'You might be stopped from going to the Kaaba this year.' Ibn Umar replied, 'When Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) went for pilgrimage, Quraish blocked him from reaching the Kaaba. If they block me too, I'll do what he did.' He reminded them that Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) is a good example to follow. Then he said, 'I'm making you witnesses that I want to perform Hajj and Umra together.' When they arrived in Mecca, Ibn Umar only did one round of Tawaf between Safa and Marwa.

title: Ibn Umar's Hajj Decision
content: Ibn Umar wanted to go on a pilgrimage. Someone warned him that there might be fighting between two groups. Ibn Umar said, 'If this happens, I'll do what the Prophet did.' He made it clear that he was going to combine his pilgrimage with a smaller visit to the holy city. When he arrived at Al-Baida', he announced that he would perform both pilgrimage and visit together. He brought a sheep as an offering, but didn't slaughter it yet. He kept his special clothes on until the day of sacrifice. Then he slaughtered the sheep and cut his hair short. Ibn Umar said, 'The Prophet (ﷺ) did this too.'

title: Prophet's Hajj Routine
content: When the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) arrived in Mecca for Hajj, he first performed ablution and then did Tawaf of the Kaaba. He didn't just come for Umra (a smaller pilgrimage), but for both Hajj and Umra together. This was also the practice of Abu Bakr, Umar, Uthman, Muawiya, Abdullah bin Umar, and many others who followed them. When they entered Mecca, they would not start anything before doing Tawaf of the Kaaba, and they wouldn't finish their Ihram (state of ritual purity) until after completing both Hajj and Umra.

title: Prophet's Hajj Routine
content: Muhammad (ﷺ) bin `Abdur-Rahman asked `Urwa about the Prophet's first action when he arrived in Mecca. `Urwa said Aisha told him that the Prophet performed ablution, then walked around the Ka`ba. His intention was not just to perform Umra, but Hajj and Umra together. This is what Abu Bakr, Umar, Uthman, Muawiya, Abdullah bin Umar, and others did too. They all started by walking around the Ka`ba before doing anything else.

title: Tawaf Between Safa and Marwa
content: `Urwa asked Aisha about a verse in the Quran. She said it was not about choice, but about people who used to worship an idol called Manat. They would assume Ihram for the idol and think it wrong to walk around between Safa and Marwa. When they became Muslim, they asked the Prophet if they could still do this. Allah revealed a verse saying these mountains are symbols of God, so it's okay to walk around between them during Hajj or Umra.

title: Ibn Umar's Tawaf Practice
content: When the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) performed his first Tawaf around the Kaaba, he walked quickly for three rounds and then normally for the next four. When doing Tawaf between Safa and Marwa, he would run in the middle of the passage with rainwater. I asked Nafi' about Ibn Umar's practice at the Yemenite Corner. He said that Ibn Umar didn't always walk steadily there, unless many people were crowded around it.

title: Sexual Relations During Umra
content: We asked Ibn 'Umar about a man who had done the Tawaf of the Ka'ba during his Umra, but not yet the Tawaf between Safa and Marwa. He said that the Prophet did this: he went to Mecca, did seven rounds around the Ka'ba, prayed two units behind Maqam Ibrahim, then did seven more rounds between Safa and Marwa. Ibn 'Umar added that we should follow the Prophet's example. We asked Jabir bin Abdullah the same question, and he said not to be with his wife until he had finished the Tawaf between Safa and Marwa.

title: Sex During Umra
content: We asked Ibn `Umar about a man who had done the Ka`ba walk but not the Safa and Marwa walk yet. He said, 'The Prophet (ﷺ) did the seven rounds of the Ka`ba, then prayed behind Maqam Ibrahim, and finally did the seven rounds between Safa and Marwa.' We asked Jabir bin `Abdullah the same question. He said, 'He should not be with his wife until he has done the Safa and Marwa walk'.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Visit to Mecca
content: Ibn Umar said the Prophet arrived in Mecca and walked around the Kaaba. He then prayed for two short periods. After that, he walked between Safa and Marwa. Ibn Umar reminded us that we should follow the Prophet as a good example.

title: Tawaf between Safa and Marwa
content: I asked Anas bin Malik if he disliked walking around between the mountains of Safa and Marwa. He said yes, because it was a pre-Islamic tradition. Allah revealed that these mountains are special symbols of God's power. Now it is okay to walk around them during pilgrimage or Umra.

title: Prophet's Visit to Ka'ba
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) performed a walk around the Ka'ba. He also walked between two hills called Safa and Marwa, showing his strength to non-Muslims.

title: Hajj During Menstruation
content: I was on my period when I arrived in Mecca. I didn't walk around the Ka'ba or between Safa and Marwa. I told the Prophet about it, and he said: 'Do all the other Hajj rituals like everyone else, but don't walk around the Ka'ba until you're clean again.'

title: Prophet Muhammad's Hajj Instructions
content: Jabir bin Abdullah said: The Prophet (ﷺ) and his friends went to Hajj with their Ihram. Only the Prophet, Talha, and Ali had animals for sacrifice. Ali arrived from Yemen with an animal for sacrifice. He said he was following the Prophet's example. The Prophet (ﷺ) told his friends to do 'Umra while in Ihram, then cut their hair after Tawaf (walking around Kaaba). Those who didn't have a sacrifice could finish their Ihram. Some people asked how they could go to Mina with their wives. The Prophet (ﷺ) said he wouldn't have brought an animal for sacrifice if he knew earlier. Aisha got her period during Hajj, so she did everything except walking around the Kaaba. When clean again, she walked around the Kaaba. She told the Prophet she was returning after only doing Hajj. He sent someone to accompany her to Tan'im and she did 'Umra afterwards.

title: Women's Role on Eid Day
content: Hafsa said that a lady came to her and told about her sister who was married to one of the Prophet Muhammad 's (ﷺ) companions. The companion asked the Prophet if it was okay for women without veils to stay at home during Eid. The Prophet (ﷺ) said that they should cover themselves with something, like a veil from their husband or father, and join in good deeds and prayers with other believers. Menstruating women should not go to the praying place.

title: Zuhr and Asr Prayers on Tarwiya
content: Abdul Aziz asked Anas about the Prophet's prayer times. On the 8th day of Dhul-Hijja (Tarwiya), the Prophet prayed Zuhr and Asr at Mina. On the day he left Mina, he prayed Asr at Al-Abtah. Anas said to follow your leaders' example.

title: Praying with the Leaders
content: I went to Mina on a special day. I met Anas riding a donkey. I asked him where the Prophet prayed his noon prayer that day. He said, 'Look where your leaders are praying and pray there too.'

title: Prophet's Prayer at Mina
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) prayed a two-rak'at prayer in Mina. Abu Bakr, Umar, and Uthman followed the same practice when they were leaders later on.

title: Prophet's Prayer at Mina
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) led us in a two-rak'at prayer at Mina. There were many of us, and we felt safe.

title: Two Rak'ats at Mina
content: Abdullah bin Mas'ud said: I prayed two rak'ats with the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) at Mina. Later, Abu Bakr and Umar also prayed two rak'ats there. But then people started to disagree about how many rak'ats should be prayed. Abdullah wished that Allah would accept either two or four rak'ats of his prayer.

title: Prophet Muhammad Drinks on Arafat
content: Some people were unsure if the Prophet was fasting on the Day of Arafat. I, Um Al-Fadl, sent him something to drink and he did.

title: Anas' Actions at Arafat
content: I asked Anas about what he did on the day of Arafat when he was with the Prophet. He said some people used to say 'Labbaik' (a prayer) and nobody stopped them. Others used to say 'Allahu Akbar' (God is great) and nobody stopped them.

title: Ibn Umar and Hajjaj
content: Abdul Malik wrote to Al-Hajjaj that he should follow Ibn Umar's actions during the Hajj. On a hot day, Ibn Umar came to Al-Hajjaj's tent with me. He shouted for Al-Hajjaj to come out and said, 'If you want to follow the Prophet's tradition, let's go.' Al-Hajjaj asked if it was really time to leave, but Ibn Umar said yes. Al-Hajjaj wanted to take a bath first, so we waited until he came out. Then Al-Hajjaj stood between me and my father. I told him to hurry up and deliver a short sermon before going to Arafat. He looked at my father, who just confirmed that it was the right thing to do.

title: Prophet's Fasting on Arafat Day
content: On the day of Arafat, some people were unsure if the Prophet was fasting. Um Al-Fadl sent a bowl of milk to him while he was riding his camel. He drank the milk, showing that he wasn't fasting on this special day.

title: Following the Prophet's Sunna
content: Abdullah bin Umar and his son Salim were on their way to Arafat. They met Al-Hajjaj, who was taking a bath. Abdullah said, 'Let's go now.' But Al-Hajjaj wanted to finish his bath first. Salim advised him to shorten the sermon and hurry up so they could stay at Arafat as planned.

title: My Father's Lost Camel
content: My father said he was looking for his lost camel on the day of 'Arafat. He saw the Prophet standing there and thought, 'He must be a very religious person.'

title: Pre-Islamic Tawaf Practices
content: The people used to walk around the Kaaba naked, except for a few families called Hums. The Hums were from the tribe of Quraish and their relatives. They would give clothes to those who didn't have any so they could walk around the Kaaba covered up. Most people would leave Arafat right away, but the Hums would stay at Al-Muzdalifa for a bit before going to Mina. The Quran says that Allah ordered them to go from there.

title: Usama Describes the Prophet's Pace
content: I was with Usama when someone asked him about the speed of the Prophet's camel as he left Arafat during his last Hajj. Usama said that the Prophet walked slowly, but when there was space to go faster, he let his camel run quickly.

title: Prophet's Prayer at Muzdalifa
content: Usama bin Zaid said the Prophet went to a mountain pass after leaving Arafat. He answered nature's call and was asked if he would pray there. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'The prayer place is ahead of you' (at Al-Muzdalifa).

title: Abdullah's Prayer Routine
content: Abdullah bin Umar would pray Maghrib and Isha prayers together at Jam'. But he'd stop by a mountain pass where the Prophet went. He'd use the toilet, wash his hands, and then go back to Jam' to pray.

title: Allah's Messenger's Journey
content: Usama bin Zaid rode behind Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) from Arafat. When they reached a mountain pass near Al-Muzdalifa, the Prophet made his camel kneel and then went to the bathroom. Usama poured water for him to wash his face and hands. The Prophet (ﷺ) washed lightly and then said it was time for prayer, but not yet. They rode on until they reached Al-Muzdalifa, where the Prophet prayed. In the morning, Al-Faql rode behind the Prophet. He kept reciting Talbiya (a special prayer) until they reached Jamrat-Al-`Aqaba.

title: Allah's Messenger's Journey
content: Usama bin Zaid rode behind the Prophet from Arafat. When they reached a mountain pass near Al-Muzdalifa, the Prophet made his camel stop and urinated. Usama poured water for the Prophet to wash his face and hands. The Prophet (ﷺ) then said it was time for prayer and told Usama that the place of prayer was ahead. They rode on until they reached Al-Muzdalifa and prayed there. In the morning, Al-Faql rode behind the Prophet. During their journey, the Prophet kept reciting a special prayer called Talbiya until they reached Jamrat-Al-`Aqaba.

title: Hasten Not on Hajj
content: Ibn Abbas was with the Prophet on a day in Arafat. He heard people making noise and beating their camels. The Prophet (ﷺ) signaled them to be quiet, saying 'Being fast is not what makes you good'.

title: Prayer at Muzdalifa
content: Usama bin Zaid said: The Prophet (ﷺ) dismounted his camel and went to the toilet. He then washed his face and hands. Usama asked if it was time for prayer, but the Prophet said no, they would pray in a place called Al-Muzdalifa. When they got there, the Prophet did a full wash before praying Maghrib (evening) prayer. After that, people made their camels sit down where they were standing. The Prophet (ﷺ) then did another full wash and prayed 'Isha' (night) prayer without praying in between.

title: Prophet's Prayer at Jam'
content: Ibn Umar said the Prophet prayed Maghrib and Isha prayers together in Jam'. He gave a separate call to prayer for each, but did not pray any extra prayers between or after them.

title: Prayer at Muzdalifa
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) prayed the Maghrib and Isha prayers together in Al-Muzdalifa.

title: Abdullah's Hajj Routine
content: Abdullah performed the Hajj and arrived at Al-Muzdalifa around night time. He led a prayer, then two more prayers after that. After eating, he led another prayer. Abdullah said this was how the Prophet used to pray in this place on this day. The Prophet (ﷺ) would lead the Maghrib prayer when people arrived, and the Fajr prayer at dawn.

title: Weak Family Members' Travel
content: Abdullah bin Umar would send his weak family members to Mina early. They would leave Al-Muzdalifa at night, pray as much as they could, and return before the Imam left. Some reached Mina for Fajr prayer, others later. When they arrived, they threw pebbles on Jamra. Abdullah said Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) allowed this for weak people.

title: Allah's Messenger sends Ibn Abbas
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) sent me from Jam' at night to go somewhere else.

title: Ibn Abbas' Journey with Prophet
content: Ibn Abbas was among the people the Prophet sent on a journey to Al-Muzdalifa. He was chosen because he was one of the weaker members of the Prophet's family at that time.

title: Asma' Prays at Al-Muzdalifa
content: Abdullah said: Asma' arrived in Al-Muzdalifa on the night of Jam'. She stood up for prayer and prayed. Then she asked if the moon had set yet. I said no, so she prayed some more. After a while, she asked again if the moon had set. This time I said yes. So she decided it was time to leave for Mina. We traveled until we reached Jamra (Jamrat-Al-`Aqaba) and Asma' threw stones at it. Then she went back home and prayed the morning prayer. I said, 'I think we came too early.' She replied, 'Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) allowed women to do this'.

title: Prophet Muhammad Gives Permission
content: Sauda asked the Prophet for permission to leave early on a special night. She was a heavy woman and walked slowly. The Prophet (ﷺ) said it's okay for her to go.

title: Sauda's Early Departure
content: Aisha said: We stopped at Al-Muzdalifa. Sauda asked the Prophet for permission to leave early because she walks slowly. He allowed her to go before everyone else. We stayed there until dawn and then left with the Prophet. I wished I had asked him like Sauda did, it would have made me happier.

title: Prayer Times with the Prophet
content: Abdullah said he never saw the Prophet pray at any time other than its usual time. There were two exceptions: one day the Prophet prayed Maghrib and Isha prayers together, and another day he prayed Fajr prayer before its normal time.

title: Abdullah's Prayer Times
content: `Abdur-Rahman bin Yazid went to Mecca with `Abdullah. They prayed the Maghrib and `Isha prayers together, but separately for each prayer. They ate in between. The next morning, they prayed Fajr as soon as it was light enough to see. Some people said it was still night, others said it was day. `Abdullah explained that Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) had changed the times of these two prayers only at this place. He told them not to arrive at Al-Muzdalifa until the time for `Isha prayer was due. The morning prayer should be offered when it is a bit brighter. If the leader of the believers had left quickly, he would have been following the Sunna.

title: Umar's Morning Prayer
content: `Amr bin Maimun said he saw `Umar praying the morning prayer at Jam'. After finishing his prayer, `Umar stood up and said, 'Non-Muslims used to leave Jam' after sunrise. They would say,

title: Prophet Muhammad's Pilgrimage
content: Ibn Abbas said that the Prophet made his companion Al-Fadl ride behind him. The Prophet (ﷺ) kept reciting a special prayer called Talbiya until he threw pebbles at Jamrat-Al-`Aqaba.

title: Usama and Al-Fadl's Journey
content: Ibn Abbas said that Usama bin Zaid rode with the Prophet from Arafat to Muzdalifa, then from Muzdalifa to Mina. Al-Fadl also rode behind him. Both of them said that the Prophet kept saying 'Labbaik' (a prayer) all the time until he threw pebbles at Jamarat-Al-Aqaba.

title: Usama and Al-Fadl with the Prophet
content: Ibn Abbas said that Usama bin Zaid rode behind the Prophet from Arafat to Muzdalifa. Then, Al-Fadl rode behind him from Muzdalifa to Mina. Both of them said that the Prophet kept saying 'Talbiya' until he threw stones at Jamaraat-al-Aqaba.

title: Hajj at-Tamattu' Explained
content: Ibn Abbas told me to do Hajj at-Tamattu', which means doing Umra and Hajj together. He said I could sacrifice a camel, cow or sheep, or share the animal with others. Some people didn't like this way of doing Hajj. I had a dream where someone was saying 'Hajj is accepted' for both Umra and Hajj at-Tamattu'. When I told Ibn Abbas about my dream, he said it was true because it was the Prophet's tradition.

title: Ride the Sacrificial Camel
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) saw a man riding a Badana camel. He told the man to ride it again and again, saying 'Woe to you' when he said it was a Badana (a special sacrificial animal).

title: The Prophet and the Donkey
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) saw a man riding a donkey. He said, 'Ride on it.' The man replied, 'It's just a donkey.' The Prophet (ﷺ) repeated this three times: 'Ride on it'.

title: Hajj and Umra Rules
content: Ibn Umar said: The Prophet 's (ﷺ) last Hajj was special. He performed both Umra and Hajj at the same time. Some people brought animals to sacrifice, while others didn't. When they arrived in Mecca, the Prophet told them what to do. If you brought an animal, don't finish your special clothes until you complete the Hajj rituals. If you didn't bring an animal, perform a special walk around the Kaaba and touch the Black Stone first. Then cut your hair and take off your special clothes. Later, put on new special clothes for the Hajj and offer to sacrifice an animal if you can afford it. If not, fast for three days during the Hajj and seven days when you go home. The Prophet (ﷺ) did all these things himself.

title: Prophet's Hajj and Umra
content: 'Aishah told me about the Prophet's trip to Hajj and 'Umra. She said he did them together with his companions, just like Ibn Umar had done before him.

title: Ibn Umar's Decision
content: Abdullah bin Umar told his father to stay behind because he was worried that the conflict between Ibn Az-Zubair and Al-Hajjaj might stop him from reaching the Kaaba. His father said, 'If this happens, I'll follow what Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) did.' He made a statement in front of people, saying he'd done Umra as well. Then he went to Al-Baida', where he decided to do Hajj and Umra together. He brought an animal for sacrifice from Qudaid. When he arrived at Mecca, he walked around the Kaaba once for both Hajj and Umra. He didn't take off his Ihram until he'd finished both.

title: Prophet's Umrah Journey
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) went from Medina with over a thousand companions. When they reached Dhul-Hulaifa, he prepared his animal for sacrifice and marked it. He then put on special clothes to show he was going for Umra.

title: Prophet's Journey to Dhul-Hulaifa
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) went from Medina with over a thousand companions. When they reached Dhul-Hulaifa, he prepared his Hadi animal for sacrifice and marked it. He then put on special clothes for Umra (a smaller pilgrimage).

title: Twisting the Prophet's Garlands
content: I twisted garlands with my own hands for the Prophet's camel. He put them on and marked the camels, then sent them to Mecca. During this time, nothing good was forbidden to him.

title: Hafsa Asks the Prophet
content: Hafsa asked the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ), 'Why haven't you finished your Ihram like everyone else?' He replied, 'I've tied my hair back and decorated my animal for sacrifice. I won't finish my special state until I complete my Hajj.'

title: Allah's Messenger and Hadi
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) would send a sheep for sacrifice from Medina. I, Aisha, would prepare the garlands for it. He didn't avoid anything that a person who is in a state of Ihram (a sacred state) should not do.

title: Twisting the Garlands
content: I helped the Prophet with the decorations for the Ka'ba. I twisted some threads into garlands and then he marked them. He decided not to go to the Ka'ba that time, but it was okay because nothing good is forbidden for him.

title: Hadi Animals and Rules
content: `Amra bint `Abdur-Rahman told Abdullah bin Abu Bakr that Zaid bin Abu Sufyan wrote to Aisha about what Abdullah bin Abbas said. He said, 'When you send a Hadi animal to the Kaaba, it's not allowed to do things that are normally not allowed for pilgrims until you slaughter it on the 10th of Dhul-Hijja.' Aisha disagreed with Ibn Abbas and said, 'I personally tied garlands around the necks of two Hadis animals. The Prophet (ﷺ) then put them around the animals' necks with his own hands before sending them with my father. Nothing was considered forbidden for the Prophet until he slaughtered those animals.'

title: Prophet's Gift of Sheep
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) sent some sheep to be used for a special ritual called Hadi. This is based on a story told by Aisha, one of the Prophet's wives.

title: Aisha's Story About the Prophet
content: I used to make garlands for the Prophet. He would use them to decorate sheep and stay with his family without being a Muhrim (someone in a state of ritual purity).

title: Aisha's Story about the Prophet
content: I used to help prepare necklaces for the sheep that the Prophet sent to the Kaaba. He would stay there without wearing Ihram clothes.

title: Twisting Garlands for Hajj
content: I twisted the garlands of the Prophet before he went on a pilgrimage. He was getting ready to wear Ihram, which is special clothing worn during Hajj.

title: Aisha Twists Hadith Garlands
content: Aisha took some wool from her home and used it to make garlands for the Hadith.

title: Riding a Sacrificial Camel
content: Abu Huraira said the Prophet told a man to ride his sacrificial camel. The man replied that it was a special camel for sacrifice, but the Prophet still said 'ride on it'. Abu Huraira saw the man riding the camel with obedience.

title: Give Charity from Sacrifice
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) told me to give some of the skin and covering from a sacrificial animal to charity.

title: Ibn Umar's Hajj Decision
content: Nafi' told us about Ibn 'Umar. He wanted to go on Hajj during a time of trouble in Mecca. Some people said,

title: Hajj: Ihram and Sacrifice
content: I was with the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) when we left Medina for Hajj. We were going to perform only Hajj, not Umrah. When we got close to Mecca, he told those who didn't have a sacrifice animal with them to stop their special state (Ihram) after walking around the Kaaba and between Safa and Marwa. On the day of sacrificing animals, beef was brought to us. I asked what it was, and someone said that the Prophet had already sacrificed animals on behalf of his wives.

title: Abdullah Slaughters at the Manhar
content: Nafi' told us that Abdullah bin Umar used to slaughter his sacrifice at a place called the Manhar. This was also where Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) used to go for his own sacrifice.

title: Ibn Umar's Pilgrims
content: Nafi' said that Ibn Umar would send his Hadi to Mina with other pilgrims, including free men and slaves, in the last third of the night. They would take it to a place near the Prophet's slaughtering area.

title: The Prophet's Sacrifice
content: On Eid-ul-Adha, the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) slaughtered seven camels with his own hands. He also sacrificed two rams, one black and one white.

title: Slaughtering an Animal
content: Ziyad bin Jubair saw Ibn Umar walking by a man who had tied up his animal to slaughter it. Ibn Umar said, 'You should slaughter the animal while it's standing and one leg is tied up, like the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) taught us.'

title: Prophet's Journey to Makkah
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) offered four rak'at of Zuhr prayer at Medina. He then prayed two rak'at of Asr prayer at Dhil-Hulaifa and stayed there overnight. When dawn broke, he rode his camel and said 'None has the right to be worshipped but Allah.' At Al-Baida', he recited a prayer for both Hajj and Umra. In Mecca, he told his companions to stop their special state of Ihram. The Prophet (ﷺ) himself slaughtered seven camels with his own hands while they were standing still. He also sacrificed two rams at Medina.

title: Prophet's Prayer Journey
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) prayed four times in Medina: Zuhr and Asr prayers. He then traveled to Dhul-Hulaifa, where he stayed overnight. The next morning, he prayed Fajr prayer and rode his camel to Al-Baida'. There, he decided to perform both Umra and Hajj pilgrimages.

title: Supervising the Hadi Camels
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) told me to watch over some special camels called Budn. He said I should give their meat and other things like blankets and skins to those who need them. The Prophet (ﷺ) also told me not to pay a butcher to kill the camels.

title: Slaughtering the Hadi Camel
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) told me to take care of a special camel called Budn. I was in charge of giving its meat, skin, and other parts to people who needed them. The Prophet (ﷺ) said not to pay anyone for slaughtering it.

title: Distributing Charity from Sacrifices
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) offered one hundred animals as sacrifices. He told me to give their meat to those in need, then the covering sheets they wore, and finally their skins.

title: Eating Meat During Hajj
content: Jabir bin Abdullah said they never ate the meat of a camel called Budn for more than three days in Mina. The Prophet (ﷺ) allowed them to eat and take some with them when he said: 'Eat and take (meat) with you.' They ate some and took some back home.

title: Hajj: Ihram and Sacrifice
content: Aisha said we traveled with the Prophet from Medina. We wanted to do Hajj but didn't have animals for sacrifice. When we got close to Mecca, the Prophet told those without animals to finish their special state after walking around the Kaaba. Aisha continued, 'We had beef on the day of sacrifice and someone said it was because the Prophet had sacrificed cows for his wives.'

title: Shaving before Slaughtering
content: Ibn Abbas asked the Prophet about a person who shaves their head before slaughtering an animal for Hajj. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'There is no harm in doing so.'

title: No Harm in Order
content: A man asked the Prophet if it was okay to do things out of order during Hajj. He said there's no harm if you throw stones at the Jamra before doing the final walk around (Tawaf-al-Ifada). The Prophet (ﷺ) also said it's fine if you shave your head before slaughtering an animal for sacrifice, or if you sacrifice a Hadi before throwing stones.

title: Evening Rami and Shaving
content: Ibn Abbas said the Prophet was asked about a man who did Rami in the evening. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'No problem.' Another person asked if it's okay to shave his head before slaughtering an animal. The Prophet (ﷺ) replied, 'No problem'.

title: Abu Musa's Hajj Journey
content: I met the Prophet at Al-Batha. He asked if I was going for Hajj. I said yes. He asked why I had put on Ihram clothes. I said it was like his intention. The Prophet (ﷺ) said that was good and told me to walk around the Ka'ba and between Safa and Marwa. Later, a woman from Bani Qais removed lice from my head while I was still in Ihram. After that, I went for Hajj again. When people asked about this, I told them it was okay until 'Umar became caliph. He said we should follow the Quran, which says to do both Hajj and Umra together, or like the Prophet did, where he didn't finish his Ihram till his animal had been slaughtered.

title: Ibn Umar's Question
content: Hafsa asked the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ): 'Why haven't you finished your Ihram after performing Umra?' The Prophet (ﷺ) replied, 'I've tied my hair and put a garland on my Hadi. So I won't finish my Ihram until I slaughter it.'

title: Prophet Muhammad's Haircut
content: After completing the Hajj, Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) got his head shaved.

title: Mercy for Shaved Heads
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: 'O Allah, be kind to those who shave their heads.' The people asked him to also pray for mercy on those who cut their hair short. He repeated his prayer twice, then added a third time: 'And to those who cut their hair short'.

title: Forgiveness for Haircuts
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said to Allah: 'Forgive those who shave their heads.' People asked if this included those with short hair. The Prophet (ﷺ) repeated his request, and at the third time, he also included those with short hair.

title: Prophet's Head Shaving
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) and some of his companions had their heads shaved or cut short.

title: Muawiya Cuts Prophet's Hair
content: Muawiya said he cut the hair of the Prophet with a long blade.

title: Prophet's Arrival in Mecca
content: When the Prophet arrived in Mecca, he told his friends to walk around the Ka'ba and between Safa and Marwa. They were also supposed to end their special state of Ihram and either shave or cut their hair short.

title: Aisha's Hajj Experience
content: We went on Hajj with the Prophet. During the final day of the pilgrimage, Safiya got her period. I told the Prophet that she was menstruating. He asked if it would delay us leaving. We said no, because she had already done the required walk around the Kaaba on the previous day. The Prophet (ﷺ) then said we could leave.

title: Slaughtering and Rami Timing
content: Ibn Abbas asked the Prophet about slaughtering animals, shaving heads, and doing Rami before or after their due times. The Prophet (ﷺ) said there is no harm in that.

title: Prophet's Response to Hajj Questions
content: Ibn Abbas asked the Prophet about the rules of Hajj at Mina. The Prophet (ﷺ) said there was no problem with anything they had done so far. A man said he got his head shaved before slaughtering an animal, and the Prophet told him to slaughter first then it's okay. Another man said he did a ritual after midday, and the Prophet again said that was fine.

title: Hajj Rules Clarified
content: During his last Hajj, the Prophet stopped at Mina and people asked him questions. One man said he got his head shaved before slaughtering an animal. The Prophet (ﷺ) replied, 'Slaughter now and it's okay.' Another man said he slaughtered a special animal for sacrifice before throwing pebbles. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Throw the pebbles now and there's no problem.' On this day, if someone did something wrong with Hajj rules, the Prophet said to do it again and it would be fine.

title: Prophet's Guidance on Eid Day
content: Abdullah bin Amr saw the Prophet when he was giving a sermon on Eid day. A man asked, 'Is it better to shave my hair before or after slaughtering?' Another person said, 'I slaughtered my animal for sacrifice before throwing stones.' The people asked many similar questions. The Prophet (ﷺ) replied, 'Do what you want now and there's no problem with any of these actions'. When anyone asked him something on that day, he would say, 'Do it now and there's no harm in it'.

title: Walking Around the Ka'ba
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) stopped his camel and walked around the Ka'ba seven times. He did this to show respect for Allah's House.

title: Protecting Life and Honor
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) gave a sermon on the Day of Sacrifice. He asked people what day it was, and they said 'it is a sacred day'. He asked about the town and month, and they said 'they are also sacred'. The Prophet (ﷺ) said that just like this day, town, and month are protected, so should be each other's blood, property, and honor. He repeated this message several times, then looked up to Allah and said he had conveyed the message. Ibn Abbas added that the Prophet wanted those present to tell those absent about this important reminder: don't turn against each other after I'm gone, and don't kill one another.

title: Prophet's Sermon at Arafat
content: Ibn Abbas heard the Prophet delivering a sermon at Arafat. He was speaking to many people there.

title: Protection and Unity
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) delivered a sermon on the Day of Sacrifice. He asked us to identify the day, month, and town we were in. We said it was the Day of Sacrifice, the month of Dhul-Hijja, and the Sacred Town of Mecca. The Prophet (ﷺ) reminded us that our blood and belongings are sacred to each other, just like this special day, month, and place. He asked if he had clearly explained Allah's message to us, and we said yes. He then asked Allah to be a witness to what he was saying. The Prophet (ﷺ) told those who were present to share his words with those who were not there, so they could understand the importance of protecting each other. He warned us not to become disbelievers by harming each other after he was gone.

title: Sacred Day and Town
content: At Mina, the Prophet asked his companions what day it was. They said they didn't know. He replied that it was a sacred day. He then asked them about the town and month, and again they said they didn't know. The Prophet (ﷺ) explained that Allah made their blood, properties, and honor safe from each other, just like this day in this month in this town is sacred. On the 10th of Dhul-Hijja, the Prophet stood between the Jamrat and said it was a great day. He then asked Allah to be witness to his message and bid farewell to his companions.

title: Pilgrims' Water Providers
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) allowed people who gave water to pilgrims to stay in Mecca at night during the Mina nights.

title: Pilgrims' Water Providers
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) allowed people who gave water to pilgrims to stay in Mecca at night during the Mina nights.

title: Permission for Al-Abbas
content: Al-Abbas asked the Prophet if he could stay in Mecca at night during the Mina nights to help people with water. The Prophet (ﷺ) said yes, it's okay.

title: When to do Rami in Mina
content: I asked Ibn Umar when I should throw pebbles at the Jamaraat. He said, 'Wait until your leader does it.' I asked again and he replied, 'We used to wait for the sun to go down before throwing pebbles on the 11th and 12th of Dhu al-Hijjah'.

title: Abu Abdur-Rahman's Advice
content: My father Abdullah told me that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) did the Rami from the middle of the valley. I asked him, 'Some people do it from above.' He said, 'This is where the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) did it when Surat-al-Baqara was revealed to him'.

title: Throwing Pebbles at Jamra
content: Abdullah bin 'Umar threw seven pebbles at the big Jamra. He kept the Kaaba on his left and Mina on his right while throwing the stones. Abdullah said, 'The Prophet (ﷺ) did this in the same way.'

title: Ibn Mas'ud's Hajj Rituals
content: I went on Hajj with Ibn Mas'ud. He threw seven small stones at the big Jamra, keeping the Kaaba to his left and Mina to his right. Then he said, 'This is where the Prophet stood when Surah Baqarah was revealed'.

title: Ibn Mas'ud's Rami at Jamrat-ul-Aqaba
content: Ibn Mas'ud went to the Jamrat-ul-Aqaba. He walked down a valley and stopped near a tree. Then he threw seven small stones, saying 'God is great' each time. After that, he said: 'By God, this is where Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) received the revelation of Surah Al-Baqara.'

title: Ibn Umar's Hajj Rituals
content: Salim told us that Ibn Umar would throw seven small stones at the Jamrat-ud-Dunya, saying 'Allahu Akbar' each time. Then he'd walk to a flat area and face the Qibla for a long time, raising his hands in prayer. Next, he'd go to the middle Jamra, stand facing the Qibla again, and pray for a while. After that, he'd throw stones at the Jamrat-ul-Aqaba from a distance, but wouldn't stay there. Ibn Umar said this is how the Prophet did it.

title: Abdullah bin Umar's Hajj Rituals
content: Abdullah bin Umar used to throw seven small stones at Jamrat-ud-Dunya, saying 'Allahu Akbar' each time. He would then walk further and stand on a flat area facing the Kaaba, raising his hands in prayer for a long time. He did the same with Jamrat-ul-Wusta, standing again on a flat area to pray. Finally, he threw stones at Jamrat-ul-Aqaba from a valley, but didn't stay there. Abdullah bin Umar said he saw the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) doing this.

title: Stoning the Jamras in Mina
content: When Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) stoned a rock near Mina Mosque, he used seven small stones. He said 'Allahu Akbar' (God is great) each time he threw one. Then he would walk to another spot and face the direction of the Kaaba with his hands raised in prayer. He would stay for a while before moving on to the next rock. This was how he stoned all three rocks, saying 'Allahu Akbar' each time.

title: Allah's Apostle Before Tawaf-al-Ifada
content: Abdur-Rahman bin Al-Qasim said his father told him that he heard Aisha say, 'I perfumed the Prophet with my own hands before he finished his Ihram. He hadn't done the final walk around the Kaaba yet.'

title: Last Tawaf Before Leaving
content: When leaving Mecca, people must walk around the Kaaba one last time. However, women who are menstruating do not have to do this.

title: Prophet's Daily Prayer Routine
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) prayed the Zuhr, Asr, Maghrib, and Isha prayers. He then slept for a while at Al-Muhassab. Later, he rode to the Kaaba and walked around it.

title: Safiya's Menstrual Cycle
content: Prophet Muhammad 's (ﷺ) wife Safiya got her period. He was told and asked if she would delay the group. People said she had already walked around the Kaaba with him after a special prayer. He replied that this meant she wouldn't hold them back.

title: Woman's Menstrual Cycle and Travel
content: Some people in Medina asked Ibn Abbas about a woman who got her period after walking around the Kaaba. He said she could leave Mecca. They didn't agree with his answer, so they went to ask others when they returned to Medina. One of them was Um Sulaim, who told them what Safiya had said.

title: Women and Menstruation at Mecca
content: Some people in Medina asked Ibn Abbas about a woman who got her period after doing a special walk around the Kaaba. He said she could leave Mecca. They didn't agree with him, so they went to ask others when they returned to Medina. One of them was Um Sulaim, who told them what Safiya had said.

title: Menstruating Women in Mecca
content: Ibn Abbas said that a woman who had her period could leave Mecca after doing the Tawaf-al-Ifada. But then he heard Ibn Umar say she couldn't go, and later he said it was okay to leave because the Prophet allowed it.

title: Menstruating Women in Mecca
content: Ibn Abbas said a woman who is menstruating can leave Mecca after doing Tawaf-al-Ifada. However, Ibn Umar first said she couldn't go, but later said the Prophet allowed her to depart.

title: Aisha's Story of Hajj
content: We were going to Mecca for Hajj. The Prophet (ﷺ) arrived and did some rituals around the Kaaba, but he didn't finish his special clothes because he had a sheep with him. His friends and wives finished their rituals, but those who didn't have a sheep like him could stop wearing their special clothes. I got my period while we were there, so I still did all the Hajj rituals. When it was time to leave, I said to the Prophet, 'Everyone else is going home after doing both Hajj and Umra.' He asked me if I had done the Umra ritual when we first arrived in Mecca. I said no.
