So he told me to go with my brother to a place called Tan'im, put on special clothes for Umra, and wait for him there. I did that, but then another woman got her period too. The Prophet (ﷺ) said it was okay for us to leave because we had already done the final ritual of Hajj.

title: Prophet's Prayer Locations
content: Anas bin Malik said: I was asked by Abdul-Aziz about the Prophet's prayer locations on special days. He told me that on the Day of Tarwiya, the Prophet offered Zuhr prayer at Mina. On the day he left Mina, he offered Asr prayer at Al-Abtah. Anas advised to follow our leaders' example.

title: Prophet's Last Visit to Ka'ba
content: Anas bin Malik said the Prophet prayed four times a day. He then slept for a while at Al-Mahassab and rode his horse towards the Ka'ba. There, he walked around it one last time.

title: Prophet's Campsite
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) used to camp at Al-Abtah so it was easier for him to leave.

title: Al-Mahassab is Not a Ritual
content: Ibn Abbas said that staying at Al-Mahassab is not one of the rituals of Hajj. It's where the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) camped during his last pilgrimage.

title: Ibn Umar's Hajj Routine
content: When Ibn Umar came to Mecca for Hajj or Umra, he would spend the night at Dhi-Tuwa. The next day, he'd enter Mecca through a gate and go straight to the Black Stone Corner. He'd walk around the Kaaba seven times: fast walking in the first three rounds and normal speed in the last four. After finishing, he'd pray two units of prayer and then walk between Safa and Marwa before returning home. When leaving Mecca, he'd make his camel kneel down at Al-Batha, a place near Dhul-Hulaifa.

title: Praying at Al-Mahassab
content: Khalid bin Al-Harith asked 'Ubaidullah about a place called Al Mahassab. 'Ubaidullah said Nafi' told him that the Prophet, Umar and Ibn Umar used to camp there. Nafi' added that Ibn Umar would pray Zuhr, Asr and Maghrib prayers there. He probably also prayed Isha prayer there. Ibn Umar would sleep there for a while too. He said the Prophet used to do the same.

title: Ibn Umar's Makkah Visit
content: When Ibn Umar came to Makkah, he would stay overnight at Dhi-Tuwa until dawn. Then he would enter the city. On his way back, he would stop at Dhi-Tuwa again and stay there till morning. He said that the Prophet used to do the same.

title: Trade during Hajj is allowed
content: In the past, people traded at places called Dhul-Majaz and 'Ukaz. But when Islam came, they didn't want to trade there anymore. Allah sent a message saying it's okay to seek His blessings by trading during Hajj.

title: Safiya's Menstruation During Hajj
content: Safiya got her period on the night we were leaving Mecca. She was worried she would hold us back. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked if she had done a special walk around the Kaaba on the day of sacrifice. When she said yes, he told us to leave. I was still in Ihram and hadn't done the Umra yet. The Prophet (ﷺ) told me to do it from Tan'im instead.

title: Safiya's Umra Delay
content: During Hajj, Safiya got her period. She was worried she would delay the group. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked if she had done a special walk around the Kaaba on the day of sacrifice. When she said yes, he told them to leave. Aisha then asked about doing an Umra, but the Prophet said to do it from Tan'im instead.

title: Hajj and Umra: Forgiveness
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said that performing Umra can forgive sins done since the last Umra. If a person's Hajj is accepted by Allah, their reward will be going to Paradise.

title: Performing Umra Before Hajj
content: Ikrima asked Ibn Umar if it's okay to do Umra before Hajj. Ibn Umar said, 'No problem.' Ikrima then asked, 'Did the Prophet do that?' Ibn Umar replied, 'Yes, he did perform Umra before Hajj.'

title: Abdullah bin Umar's Mistake
content: Urwa and I went to the Mosque. We saw Abdullah bin Umar near Aisha's house. Some people were praying Duha prayer. Urwa asked Abdullah about their prayer, and he said it was wrong. Then Urwa asked him how many times the Prophet performed Umra. Abdullah said four times, one in Rajab. We didn't want to argue with him. But then we heard Aisha cleaning her teeth nearby. Urwa told her what Abdullah had said. Aisha replied that the Prophet never performed an Umra without her, and never did it in the month of Rajab.

title: Abdullah bin Umar's Mistake
content: Urwa and I went to the mosque. We saw Abdullah bin Umar near Aisha's house. Some people were praying Duha prayer. We asked him about it, and he said it was wrong. Urwa asked him how many times the Prophet performed Umra. He replied four times, one in Rajab. We didn't want to disagree with him. Then we heard Aisha cleaning her teeth. Urwa told her what Abdullah bin Umar had said. She said, 'The Prophet (ﷺ) never performed an Umra without me, and he never did it in the month of Rajab.'

title: Prophet Muhammad's Umra
content: 'Urwa bin Az-Zubair asked Aisha if the Prophet had ever performed an Umra in the month of Rajab. She said, 'No, the Prophet never did that.'

title: Prophet's Umra and Hajj
content: Anas told me that the Prophet performed 'Umra four times. The first time was in Dhil-Qa'da when he went to Hudaibiya, but the pagans stopped him. He did it again in the next year after making a peace treaty with them. The third time was from Al-Ji'rana where they distributed war spoils. I think he meant the battle of Hunain. Anas also said that the Prophet only performed Hajj once.

title: Prophet's Umras Explained
content: Anas was asked about the Prophet's Umra. He said: The Prophet (ﷺ) performed an Umra when the pagans made him return home. Then, he did another Umra in Al-Hudaibiya. After that, he did two more Umras, one in Dhi-l-Qa'da and another during his Hajj.

title: Prophet's Four Umras Explained
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) performed four special pilgrimages. Three of them were in the month of Dhi-l-Qa'da, but one was combined with a regular pilgrimage to Mecca. He did these pilgrimages from Al-hudaibiya, then from Al-Ji'rana where he distributed the spoils of war from the battle of Hunain, and finally another one with his Hajj.

title: Prophet's Umrah Before Hajj
content: I asked some companions about the Prophet's actions. They said he did a small pilgrimage in Dhi-l-Qa'da before doing a big pilgrimage. I also heard Al-Bara' bin 'Azib say this happened twice.

title: Ask about Hajj
content: Ibn Abbas told me that the Prophet asked an Ansari woman why she didn't come with us for Hajj. She said they only had one camel, so her husband and son rode it to work while leaving one for irrigation. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'When Ramadan comes, do Umra instead. It's like doing Hajj in reward.'

title: Assuming Ihram for Hajj or Umrah
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said to us: 'Whoever wants to do Hajj can start now, and whoever wants to do Umrah can also start. If I had brought a sacrifice with me, I would have done Umrah too.' Some of us did Umrah while others did Hajj. I was doing Umrah when the day of Arafat came, but I was still menstruating. I told the Prophet about it and he said: 'Stop your Umrah, wash and comb your hair, then do Hajj instead.' Later, he sent someone with me to a place called Tan'im, and I did another Umrah in its place.

title: Prophet's Order for Aisha
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) told `Abdur-Rahman bin Abu Bakr to let Aisha ride behind him. He also ordered her to walk around the Kaaba from at-Tan'im as part of her Umra.

title: Prophet's Instructions on Ihram
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) and his companions went to Hajj. Only the Prophet and a few others had animals with them for sacrifice. Ali came from Yemen and also had an animal for sacrifice. He said he was following the Prophet's example. The Prophet (ﷺ) told his friends to change their intention to perform Umra instead of Hajj, do certain rituals, and then stop wearing Ihram clothes. But those who had animals with them didn't have to stop wearing Ihram. Some of the men asked if they could go to Mina first because some of them were not ready for intimacy. The Prophet (ﷺ) said he wouldn't have brought an animal for sacrifice if he knew what he knows now. Aisha got her period and did all the rituals except walking around the Kaaba. After she was clean, she walked around the Kaaba and then told the Prophet that everyone else could do Umra before Hajj, not just him.

title: Assuming Ihram for Umra and Hajj
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said to his companions: 'Those who want to do Umra can start now, and those who want to do Hajj can also start. If I didn't bring a sacrifice with me, I would have done Umra.' Some people started Umra while others did Hajj. I was among those doing Umra, but before we reached Mecca, I got my period. I told the Prophet about it and he said: 'Stop your Umra, undo your hair, and do Hajj instead.' So I did that. When it was time to leave Mina, the Prophet sent someone with me to a nearby place. He let me ride behind him. I started Umra again in place of the one I stopped. I completed my Hajj and Umra without having to bring a sacrifice or give charity.

title: 'Aisha's Question About Umra
content: 'Aisha asked the Prophet: 'Why are people returning home after performing two pilgrimages, but I'm only going back to one?' The Prophet (ﷺ) replied: 'Wait until you're clean from your period. Then go to a place called at-Tan'im, put on Ihram (special clothes), and meet us at a certain spot. But the reward for Umra is based on what you spend or how hard it is for you.'

title: The Prophet's Hajj Advice
content: We were traveling to perform the Hajj. The Prophet (ﷺ) told his companions who didn't have an animal for sacrifice that they could do 'Umra instead of waiting until after the Hajj was finished. He and some others had animals, so they stayed in Ihram. I was crying because I thought I couldn't do 'Umra since I wasn't praying. The Prophet (ﷺ) said it's okay, I'm still a daughter of Adam, and I should just perform the Hajj. Maybe Allah would let me do 'Umra too. Later, he asked my brother to take me out of the sanctuary so I could put on Ihram for 'Umra. We did the Tawaf at night and then left Mina.

title: Prophet's Guidance on Umra
content: A man visited the Prophet at Ji'rana. He was wearing a special cloak with perfume stains. The man asked, 'What should I do for my Umra?' Allah inspired the Prophet and he covered himself with a cloth. Umar lifted the cloth so the student could see the Prophet sleeping. When the inspiration ended, the Prophet said, 'Find the man who asked about Umra. Remove your cloak and wash off the perfume stains. Then perform your Umra rituals like you would for Hajj: walk around the Kaaba and between Safa and Marwa'.

title: As-Safa and Al-Marwa Explained
content: I asked Aisha, the wife of the Prophet, about a verse in the Quran. I thought it meant that if you're doing Hajj or Umra, you don't have to walk around As-Safa and Al-Marwa. But Aisha said no, because the verse is actually talking about people who used to worship an idol called Manat. They didn't think they should walk around these mountains. When Islam came, Allah revealed this verse to tell them it's okay to do so. So, if you're doing Hajj or Umra and you don't walk around As-Safa and Al-Marwa, your pilgrimage is not complete in Allah's sight.

title: Prophet's Umra Visit
content: Abdullah bin Abu Aufa said the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) performed an Umra pilgrimage. He walked around the Kaaba and then to Safa and Marwa with us. We protected him from the people of Mecca so they wouldn't hurt him. A friend asked if the Prophet went inside the Kaaba, and Abdullah said no. The friend also asked about Khadija, and Abdullah said the Prophet told her she would have a special palace in Paradise where it's quiet.

title: Prophet's Umra Visit
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) went to Mecca for a special visit called `Umra. He walked around the Ka`ba with us, and then he walked between Al-Safa and Al-Marwa hills. We protected him from the people of Mecca so they wouldn't hurt him. Someone asked Abdullah bin Abu Aufa if the Prophet had gone inside the Ka`ba during this visit. He said no. Then someone asked about Khadija, the Prophet's wife. Abdullah said the Prophet told us that in Paradise, Khadija will have a special palace made of wood, and it will be quiet with no trouble.

title: Waiting for Tawaf to Finish
content: We asked Ibn Umar if a man could be with his wife after doing the Kaaba walk but before walking between Safa and Marwa. He said the Prophet did the Kaaba walk seven times, prayed behind Maqam Ibrahim, then walked between Safa and Marwa seven times. We also asked Jabir bin Abdullah the same question, and he said the man should wait until he finishes the Safa and Marwa walk before being with his wife.

title: Sexual Relations During Hajj
content: We asked Ibn `Umar about a man who did the Tawaf of the Ka`ba but not the walk between As-Safa and Al-Marwa yet. He said, 'The Prophet (ﷺ) came to Mecca, walked around the Ka`ba seven times, prayed two rak`ats behind Maqam-Ibrahim, then did the walk between As-Safa and Al-Marwa (seven times). You should follow his example.' We asked Jabir bin `Abdullah the same question. He said, 'He shouldn't be with his wife until he finishes the walk between As-Safa and Al-Marwa'.

title: Assuming Ihram for Hajj
content: Abu Musa came to the Prophet at Al-Batha'. His camel was kneeling down. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked Abu Musa if he had come to perform Hajj. Abu Musa said yes. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked what his intention was when assuming Ihram. Abu Musa said it was the same as the Prophet's. The Prophet (ﷺ) said that was good. He told Abu Musa to do Tawaf around the Kaaba, walk between Safa and Marwa, then finish Ihram. Abu Musa did this. Later, he went to a woman who cleaned his head of lice. Then he assumed Ihram again for Hajj. Abu Musa used to give verdicts saying people should follow what the Prophet did. But Caliph Umar said that if you follow the Quran, you stay in Ihram until Hajj is finished. If you follow the Prophet, he didn't finish Ihram until his sacrifice was slaughtered.

title: Asma's Umra and Hajj Story
content: Abdullah, a slave of Asma' bint Abu Bakr, told me that he heard her say: 'May Allah bless Muhammad (ﷺ). We traveled with him once to Al-Hajun. We had few animals and little food. My sister Aisha, Az-Zubair, and others performed Umra. After walking around the Ka'ba, we finished our special clothing for Umra. Later that evening, we put on special clothes again for Hajj.

title: Returning from Pilgrimage
content: When Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) came back from a journey for war or pilgrimage, he would say 'Allahu Akbar' three times. Then he would say: 'There is no God but Allah. He is one and has no partner. All power belongs to Him and all praise is for Him. We are returning with repentance, worshiping, praying, and praising our Lord. He kept His promise and helped us win, and only He defeated the enemies.'

title: Prophet Meets Bani Abdul Muttalib
content: When the Prophet arrived in Mecca, some boys from the tribe of Bani Abdul Muttalib came to meet him. He made one boy ride in front of him and another behind him.

title: Prophet's Prayer on Journey
content: When Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) went to Mecca, he prayed in a mosque called Ash-Shajra. When he returned to Medina, he would pray in the valley of Dhul-Hulaifa and stay there until morning.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Travel Habits
content: Anas said that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) never went back to his family at night after a journey. He would either return in the morning or in the afternoon.

title: Prophet's Advice on Family Visits
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) told Jabir not to visit his family at night when he came back from a journey.

title: Prophet's Love for Medina
content: When the Prophet returned from a journey, he would make his camel go faster when he saw the high places of Medina. He loved Medina so much that he made any animal he was riding go faster as soon as it came into sight.

title: Proper Door Entry
content: Al-Bara' said that a Verse was revealed about the Ansar. They would enter their houses from behind when returning from Hajj, but one of them entered through the front door and was teased for it. So Allah revealed: 'It's not right to enter homes from the back. The good person is someone who fears Allah, follows His rules, and stays away from what He forbids. Enter homes through their proper doors.'

title: Travel is a kind of hardship
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: Traveling can be difficult because it stops you from eating well, drinking enough water and sleeping properly. When your basic needs are met, go back to your family quickly.

title: Traveling with Ibn Umar
content: Zaid bin Aslam's father was traveling to Mecca with Ibn Umar. They got news that a woman named Safiya was very sick. Ibn Umar walked faster and when it started getting dark, he stopped his camel and prayed both the evening and night prayers together. He said this is what the Prophet used to do if they had to hurry while traveling.

title: Abdullah's Decision to Visit Mecca
content: When Abdullah bin Umar was going to visit the Kaaba in Mecca for a special prayer, he said: 'If I'm stopped from reaching the Kaaba, I'll do what Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) did. So, I'll put on Ihram clothes like he wore them when he visited the Kaaba during the year of Hudaibiya.'

title: Ibn Umar's Umra Decision
content: Nafi' told us that Ubaidullah and Salim said to Ibn Umar: 'Don't worry if you can't perform Hajj this year. We're afraid the army might stop you from reaching the Ka'ba.' Ibn Umar replied, 'I remember when we went with the Prophet. The non-believers blocked our way, so the Prophet slaughtered his animal and cut his hair. I'm making you witnesses that I've decided to perform Umra this year. If it's safe to go to the Ka'ba, I'll do a Tawaf around it. But if not, I'll act like the Prophet did when we were together.' Ibn Umar put on special clothes for Umra from Dhul-Hulaifa and said, 'The rules for Umra and Hajj are similar. I'm making you witnesses that I've decided to do both Umra and Hajj.' He didn't take off his special clothes until the day he slaughtered his animal. Then he said, 'I won't take off my special clothes until I do a Tawaf around the Ka'ba on the day I enter Mecca.'

title: Abdullah's Sons Advise Him
content: Some of Abdullah's sons told him that if he had stayed home instead of going for Hajj that year.

title: Prophet's First Umrah Attempt
content: Ibn Abbas said that the Prophet was not allowed to perform a special pilgrimage called 'Umra. So, he cut his hair and had sex with his wives. He also sacrificed an animal for God. The next year, he performed the 'Umra pilgrimage.

title: Hajj During Emergency
content: Abdullah bin Umar said: 'If you can't do Hajj, just walk around the Kaaba and between Safa and Marwa. Then end your special state of Ihram. You can eat and drink again. Next year, you can do Hajj properly. If you can't afford an animal for sacrifice, fast instead.'

title: Prophet Muhammad's Hadi Slaughter
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) slaughtered the animal before having his head shaved. He then told his companions to do the same.

title: Abdullah bin Umar's Hajj Decision
content: `Abdullah and Salim told `Abdullah bin `Umar not to go for Hajj. He said, 'We went with the Prophet to Mecca for Umra. The Quraish stopped us from reaching the Ka'ba. The Prophet (ﷺ) sacrificed his camels and shaved his head.'

title: Abdullah bin Umar's Decision
content: Abdullah bin Umar was going to Mecca for Umra. He said that if he couldn't reach the Kaaba, he would do what they did with the Prophet. So, he put on Ihram clothes like the Prophet did in Hudaibiya. Abdullah thought about it and said that Hajj and Umra have similar rules. He told his companions that he was making them witnesses to say that he had made Hajj obligatory for himself along with Umra. Then, he walked around the Kaaba once for both Hajj and Umra, and considered that enough. He also offered a sacrifice.

title: Dealing with Lice
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) asked Ka'b if his lice were causing him trouble. Ka'b said yes. The Prophet (ﷺ) told Ka'b to shave his head and then choose one of three options: fast for three days, feed six poor people, or sacrifice a sheep.

title: Prophet's Advice at Al-Hudaibiya
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) stood with me at Al-Hudaibiya. I had a lot of lice on my head. He asked if they were bothering me. I said yes. He told me to shave my head because of the lice. A verse from the Quran was revealed about people who are sick or have problems with their scalps, like me. The Prophet (ﷺ) then gave me three choices: fast for three days, feed six poor people some food, or sacrifice a sheep if I had one.

title: Fidya for Poor People
content: I sat with Ka'b bin 'Ujra and asked him about Fidya. He said it was a rule that applies to me, but also to others like you. I had many lice on my face because of an illness. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked if I could afford a sheep. I said no. He then told me to either fast for three days or feed six poor people half a bag of food each.

title: Ka'b's Lice Problem
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) saw Ka'b bin Ujra with lice on his face. He asked if the lice were bothering him, and Ka'b said yes. The Prophet (ﷺ) told him to shave his head because they were at Al-Hudaibiya without permission to finish their pilgrimage rituals. Allah then revealed new rules about what people could do instead of shaving, like feeding poor people or sacrificing an animal.

title: Prophet Sees Lice on Ka'b
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) saw Ka'b bin 'Ujra. The lice were falling on his face.

title: Hajj Purifies the Soul
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said: If someone goes to Hajj and doesn't have sex with his wife while there, and doesn't commit sins, he will be as clean of sin as a newborn baby.

title: Pilgrims Leave Sins Behind
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: Whoever goes on Hajj to this Kaaba and doesn't have sex with his wife, and doesn't commit sins while he's there, will come out as if he was born again - completely free of sin.

title: Abdullah's Story from Hudaibiya
content: My father was going to Mecca with his friends. They were all in a special state, but he wasn't. The Prophet (ﷺ) got news that there might be an attack, so he kept moving forward. My father and his friends were laughing together when my father saw an onager. He caught it and killed it, then asked his friends for help, but they refused. Later, they all ate the meat. They were worried about being left behind, so my father went to find the Prophet. He rode his horse fast sometimes and slow at other times until he met a man from the tribe of Bani Ghifar at midnight. The man told him where the Prophet was, so my father followed the tracks and caught up with him. My father said, 'The Prophet 's (ﷺ) friends send their greetings and ask for blessings. They're worried about being left behind.' He also offered them some meat he had hunted from an onager. The Prophet (ﷺ) allowed his friends to eat it even though they were in a special state.

title: Abu Qatada's Story
content: My father said we traveled with the Prophet in a year called Al-Hudaibiya. Some of his friends were already in a state of Ihram, but I wasn't. We heard there was an enemy group at Ghaiqa, so we went to check it out. My friends saw a wild donkey and started laughing. I chased it with my horse and caught it. They refused to help me, so I slaughtered it alone. We all ate from its meat. Then I followed the Prophet in case we got left behind. Sometimes I rode fast, sometimes slow. At midnight, I met a man from Bani Ghifar who told me where the Prophet was. He said he would rest at As-Suqya and wait for us. So I caught up with the Prophet and asked him to wait for my friends. They were worried that the enemy might get in between them and us. The Prophet (ﷺ) agreed to wait. Then I offered some of the donkey's meat, but they all had to eat it even though they were already in a state of Ihram.

title: Eating Meat in Ihram
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) was with us at a place called Al-Qaha. Some of us were wearing the Ihram clothes, but others weren't. I saw an onager and rode my horse to catch it. My whip fell down, so I picked it up myself because my friends wouldn't help me since they were in Ihram. I attacked the onager from behind a hill and killed it. When I brought it back, some of my friends said we could eat it, but others said not to. So, I asked the Prophet about it. He said it's okay to eat because it's halal.

title: Abu Qatada's Meat Problem
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) went on Hajj with his companions. He sent some of them by a different route, including Abu Qatada. The Prophet (ﷺ) told them to follow the coastline until they met up again. As they traveled, everyone put on Ihram except Abu Qatada. His friends saw wild donkeys and Abu Qatada chased one, hurting it badly. They ate some of its meat, but then felt guilty because eating game meat is not allowed when you're in a state of Ihram. So, they took the rest of the meat with them. When they met the Prophet, his friends asked him what to do. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked if anyone had told Abu Qatada to attack the donkey. They said no. Then the Prophet said it was okay for them to eat the remaining meat.

title: Refusing a Gift
content: Abdullah bin Abbas said that As-Sa'b bin Jath-thama gave the Prophet some animals at Al-Abwa' or Waddan. The Prophet (ﷺ) refused them. When he saw As-Sa'b looked sad, he explained, 'I'm not accepting because I'm in a state of Ihram.'

title: Muhrim and Killing Animals
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said, 'It is not wrong for a person in Ihram to kill five types of animals. One of the Prophet's wives also said he allowed this: A Muhrim can kill these five kinds of animals.

title: Kinds of Animals to Kill
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: It is not wrong for a person who is in a state of Ihram (a special condition before Hajj) to kill five types of animals. These are: crows, kites, mice, scorpions and dogs that have rabies.

title: Animals to Kill in Haram
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: Five animals are bad and can be killed inside the holy area. These are: crows, kites, scorpions, mice, and dogs with rabies.

title: Snake in the Cave
content: I was with the Prophet in a cave at Mina. He recited Surat-wal-Mursalat and I heard it from him directly. A snake suddenly appeared, so he told us to kill it. We tried but it escaped quickly. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'You've both escaped its evil and it's escaped yours'.

title: Prophet's View on Salamander
content: Aisha said the Prophet called the salamander a bad animal. He never told her to kill it.

title: Mecca's Sacred Status
content: Abu Shuraih said that he told `Amr bin Sa`id: 'I remember what the Prophet said after conquering Mecca. He praised Allah and then said, 'Allah made Mecca a sacred place, not people. If you believe in Allah and the Day of Judgement, don't fight or cut down trees here.' If someone says fighting is allowed because the Prophet fought here, say that Allah allowed him but not others. The Prophet (ﷺ) was only allowed to fight for a short time on that day, and now Mecca's sacred status is the same as it was before. Those who are present should tell those who are absent about this.' `Amr replied: 'Mecca doesn't protect people who do wrong things like murder or steal.'

title: Mecca's Sanctuary Rules
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said that Mecca was a special place of peace before he came and will be after him. He allowed fighting there for a short time, but only in specific situations. You can't cut down trees or pick up lost things unless you tell everyone what you've found. Al-Abbas asked if this included a certain type of grass used by goldsmiths, and the Prophet said no, except that one.

title: Jihad and Mecca's Sanctuary
content: On the day of the conquest of Mecca, the Prophet said: 'There is no more need to leave Mecca. Now, going for Jihad is what matters, and you should go immediately when called. Allah has made this place a sanctuary since the world was created, and it will stay that way until the Day of Judgment. Fighting here was not allowed before me, but I only fought here for a short time. This place is still sacred to Allah. Don't cut down its trees or chase its animals. If you find something that belongs to someone else, announce it publicly so people know who it belongs to. You can cut Al-Idhkhir grass because it's used by the blacksmiths and for other important things.'

title: Prophet Muhammad Gets Cupping
content: Ibn Abbas said the Prophet was cupped while he was in a state of Ihram. This means he had not yet performed any rituals for Hajj or Umrah, but was still considered pure and ready to perform them.

title: Prophet Muhammad Gets Cupped
content: While in a special state for pilgrimage, the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) got cupping done on his head at Liha-Jamal.

title: Prophet's Marriage to Maimuna
content: Ibn Abbas said the Prophet married Maimuna while he was in a special state for pilgrimage. Only the marriage ceremony took place.

title: What to Wear in Ihram
content: A person asked the Prophet what clothes are allowed when you're in a state of Ihram. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Don't wear shirts or trousers. Don't wear hats or hoods. If you don't have shoes, you can wear leather stockings that cover your ankles. And don't wear anything with perfume from Wars or saffron. A woman in this state should not cover her face or wear gloves.'

title: Man Crushed by Camel
content: A man was killed by his camel. The Prophet (ﷺ) said to give him a bath and dress him in clothes, but don't cover his head or use perfume. He will be raised from the dead saying 'Talbiya'.

title: Abu Aiyub's Advice
content: `Abdullah bin `Abbas and Al-Miswar disagreed about washing the head while in a state of Ihram. `Abdullah sent me to Abu Aiyub to ask how the Prophet washed his head. I found Abu Aiyub bathing, so I asked him. He lowered the cloth, poured water on his head, and rubbed it with his hands from back to front and front to back. He said he saw the Prophet do this.

title: Wearing Clothes in Hajj
content: Ibn Abbas heard the Prophet say: If a person is on pilgrimage and can't find slippers, they can wear socks that are cut short below the ankles. And if they don't have a special cloth to wrap around their waist, they can wear trousers.

title: Muhrim's Clothing
content: A man asked the Prophet what a Muhrim should wear. The Prophet (ﷺ) said: 'He shouldn't wear a shirt, turban, trousers, or a hooded cloak. He also can't wear clothes with saffron or Wars perfume. If he doesn't have slippers, he can wear Khuffs (thick socks) but cut them so they reach below his ankles'.

title: Wearing Clothes at Hajj
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said in a sermon at Arafat: If you don't have an Izar, wear trousers. If you can't get shoes, wear Khuffs (thick socks or leather ones).

title: Prophet's Ihram for Umra
content: Al-Bara said the Prophet went to Mecca to perform a special Umra. But the people of Mecca wouldn't let him in unless he promised not to bring any weapons into the city.

title: Miqat Places for Pilgrims
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said that people from Medina should start their pilgrimage in Dhul-Hulaifa. People from Najd should start in Qaran-al-Manazil, and those from Yemen should start in Yalamlam. If you're traveling through these places to perform Hajj or Umra, follow the same rules. If you live near one of these places, you can put on Ihram from where you are. Even people living in Mecca can start their pilgrimage there.

title: The Prophet Enters Mecca
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) entered Mecca in the year it was conquered. He wore a helmet on his head. When he took it off, someone said that Ibn Khatal was hiding inside the Kaaba. The Prophet (ﷺ) told people to kill him.

title: Prophet Forgives Man's Bite
content: I was with the Prophet when a man came in wearing a cloak with a strong perfume smell. Umar asked me if I wanted to see the Prophet while he was receiving a message from Allah. The Prophet (ﷺ) received the message and then told the man, 'Do what you do during Hajj for your Umra.' Meanwhile, another man bit someone's hand and broke one of their teeth, but the Prophet forgave him.

title: Resurrecting a Man at Arafat
content: A man fell off his camel while the Prophet was with him. The Prophet (ﷺ) said to wash the body with water and leaves from the Sidr tree, then cover it with two pieces of cloth. Don't use perfume or put a cap on his head. Allah will bring him back to life on Judgement Day and he'll be saying 'Talbiya'.

title: Resurrecting a Man at Arafat
content: A man was standing with the Prophet at Arafat. He fell from his camel and died. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Wash him with water and a special tree's leaves. Wrap him in two pieces of cloth. Don't use perfume or cover his head.' On the Day of Resurrection, Allah will bring him back to life. At that time, he'll be saying 'Here I am, responding to Allah's call'.

title: Man Crushed by Camel
content: A man was with the Prophet. His camel crushed his neck while he was in a special state for Hajj. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Wash him with water and a special tree's leaves. Wrap him in two clothes. Don't perfume him or cover his head.' He will be raised on Judgement Day saying 'Here I come to obey God'.

title: Vowing for a Mother
content: A woman from the tribe of Juhaina asked the Prophet if she could perform Hajj on her mother's behalf. The mother had vowed to do Hajj but died before doing it. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Yes, you can do it. If your mother owed money, would you pay it? So, pay Allah what He is owed.'

title: Hajj for an Old Man
content: A woman from a tribe asked the Prophet if she could do Hajj on her old father's behalf. The Prophet (ﷺ) said yes, it would be enough.

title: Al-Fadl's Distraction During Hajj
content: Abdullah bin Abbas said: Al-Fadl was riding behind the Prophet. A woman from the Khath'am tribe came up and Al-Fadl looked at her. She also looked at him. The Prophet (ﷺ) turned Al-Fadl's face away. The woman asked if she could do Hajj on behalf of her old father, who couldn't ride properly. The Prophet (ﷺ) said yes.

title: Al Fadl and the Old Man
content: 'Abdullah bin 'Abbas said that Al Fadl was riding behind the Prophet. A woman from the tribe of Khath'am came up. Al Fadl looked at her, she looked back. The Prophet (ﷺ) turned his face away. She asked if she could do Hajj for her old father who couldn't ride properly. The Prophet (ﷺ) said yes.

title: Prophet's Instructions to Ibn 'Abbas
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) sent me with the luggage from Jam at night to Mina.

title: Abdullah bin Abbas' Story
content: I was on my donkey and had just become a grown-up. The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) was praying in Mina. I rode past the front row, got off, and let my animal eat some grass. Then I stood with the other people behind the Prophet.

title: Allah's Messenger Performs Hajj
content: I was a seven-year-old boy when I went on the Hajj with Allah's Messenger (ﷺ). My parents were with me.

title: Umar Allows Wives to Hajj
content: I heard 'Umar bin 'Abdul 'Aziz tell about As-Sa'ib bin Yazid. He had done the Hajj while carrying the Prophet's belongings. Later, 'Umar allowed the Prophet's wives to do the Hajj too. He sent 'Uthman and 'Abdur-Rahman with them as helpers.

title: Women's Best Jihad
content: I asked the Prophet if I should join him in battles. He said that for women, the best way to serve Allah is by going on Hajj pilgrimage. Since then, I made sure not to miss Hajj.

title: Women Traveling Alone
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said a woman should not travel without her husband or another man she cannot marry. A man asked if he could go to war with his wife, who wanted to visit the holy city for Hajj. The Prophet (ﷺ) allowed them to go together.

title: Umra in Ramadan
content: When the Prophet returned from Hajj, he met a woman named Um Sinan. She said her husband had two camels and used one for Hajj, so she didn't have another camel to use. The Prophet (ﷺ) told her to perform Umra in Ramadan instead, which is just as good as performing Hajj.

title: Prophet's Advice on Travel
content: Abu Sa'id said he heard four things from the Prophet that impressed him. These are: Don't let a woman travel alone, especially for more than one day. She should go with her husband or a close relative. You can't fast on two special days: Eid al-Fitr and Eid al-Adha. Don't pray after Asr prayer until sunset, or after morning prayer until sunrise. Only visit three mosques: the mosque in Mecca, the mosque in Medina, and the mosque in Jerusalem.

title: Old Man Walking to Ka'ba
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) saw an old man walking with his sons. He asked why the old man was doing this. The people said he had made a vow to walk all the way to the Ka'ba. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'God doesn't need the old man to be so hard on himself.' He told the old man to ride instead.

title: Walking to the Ka'ba
content: `Uqba's sister made a vow to walk all the way to the Ka'ba. She asked her brother `Uqba to ask the Prophet about it. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'She can both walk and ride.'

title: Medina is a Sanctuary
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Medina is protected from one end to the other. Its trees should not be cut down and no bad ideas should be brought here. Anyone who does something wrong or introduces new, bad ideas will be cursed by Allah, the angels, and all people.'

title: Prophet Builds a Mosque
content: When Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) came to Medina, he ordered a mosque to be built. He asked the people of Bani Najjar for their land, but they said they wanted a reward from Allah instead of money. The Prophet (ﷺ) then had the graves of non-Muslims dug up and the area leveled. Date palm trees were cut down and used as building materials for the mosque.

title: Medina a Safe Sanctuary
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'I have made Medina safe for everyone between its two mountains.' He went to the tribe of Bani Haritha and saw they had left. But then he looked around and said, 'No, you are still inside the sanctuary.'

title: Medina's Sanctuary Rule
content: Ali said: We have two important rules. First, Medina is a special place where people are safe. From the Air Mountain to a certain point, no one can create new ideas that go against Allah's teachings or commit sins here. If someone does this, they'll be cursed by Allah, angels, and all people. Their good deeds won't be accepted. Second, if a Muslim gives protection to another Muslim, other Muslims must respect it. If they don't, they'll also be cursed by Allah, angels, and all people. And third, freed slaves can only take their original masters as friends with their permission. If they do otherwise, they'll be cursed too.

title: Migration to Medina
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) was told by Allah to move to a city called Yathrib. It's now known as Medina and it will get rid of bad people, just like a furnace gets rid of impurities in iron.

title: Arrival in Medina
content: When we came back from a trip with the Prophet, he said, 'We are near Medina.'

title: Medina is a Sanctuary
content: Abu Huraira said that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: 'Medina is a safe place between its two mountains. If I see deer here, I won't chase them.'

title: Medina's Future Decline
content: Abu Huraira said he heard the Prophet say: 'People will leave Medina even though it was once a great place. Only wild birds and animals will live there then. The last two people to die will be two shepherds from the Muzaina tribe. They were driving their sheep towards Medina, but when they got there, no one was left. When they reached the valley of Thaniyat-al-Wada`, they fell down dead.'

title: Conquests and Migration
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said: 'Yemen will be conquered. Some people from Medina will move there with their families. They should have stayed in Medina, but they didn't know it was better for them. The same thing will happen when Sham is conquered and when Iraq is conquered.'

title: Belief Returns to Medina
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: Belief is like a snake. When it's in danger, it goes back to its home in Medina.

title: Plotting against Medina
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: Anyone who plots against the people of Medina will be destroyed like salt dissolves in water.

title: Prophet's Warning of Affliction
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) stood on a high building in Medina and said to his companions, 'Do you see what I see?' He looked out over the city and saw areas where problems would soon happen. These problems would be as common as raindrops falling.

title: Medina's Safety from Dajjal
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said that Medina will be safe when the false Messiah, Al-Masih Ad-Dajjal, comes. At that time, there will be seven gates in Medina and two angels at each gate to guard them.

title: Angels Guarding Medina
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: There are angels watching the roads of Medina. No plague or Dajjal will be able to enter it.

title: Dajjal Will Not Enter
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: Dajjal will visit every city except Mecca and Medina. The angels will stop him from entering these two cities. Medina will have three earthquakes, and Allah will remove all non-believers and hypocrites from there.

title: Dajjal's Attempt to Enter Medina
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) told us about Ad-Dajjal. He said that Dajjal will come, but he won't be able to enter Medina through its gates. Instead, he'll go to a nearby salty area. A good man will stand up and say, 'I know you're the false prophet we've been warned about.' Dajjal will ask people if they doubt him after killing this man and bringing him back to life. They'll say no. Then Dajjal will kill the man and bring him back. The man will say he knows Dajjal's true nature now. But Dajjal says, 'I want to kill him again, but I can't'.

title: Bedouin's Pledge of Allegiance
content: A bedouin came to the Prophet and said he wanted to be Muslim. The next day, he was ill with a fever and asked the Prophet to cancel his promise to become Muslim and move to Medina. But the Prophet refused three times. He said that Medina is like a place where bad people are removed and good ones stay.

title: Hypocrites in Medina
content: Some companions of the Prophet went to battle but came back home. Some believers wanted to kill them for being hypocrites, but others said no. The Prophet (ﷺ) received a message from Allah saying why are you divided about this? He then explained that just like fire removes impurities from iron, Medina gets rid of bad people.

title: Blessings for Medina
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said to Allah, 'Give Medina twice the blessings You gave Mecca'.

title: Prophet's Love for Medina
content: When the Prophet came back from a journey and saw Medina, he would make his camel go fast. If he was on a horse, he made it gallop because he loved Medina so much.

title: Bani Salama's Decision
content: Anas said that the people of Bani Salama wanted to move closer to the mosque. But the Prophet didn't want Medina to be empty. He asked them, 'Don't you think you'll get a reward for walking to the mosque?' So they decided to stay where they were.

title: Paradise Garden near the Prophet
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said there is a garden from Paradise between his house and where he gives sermons. His pulpit is near a special lake called Al-Kauthar.

title: Abu Bakr and Bilal's Illness
content: When the Prophet arrived in Medina, Abu Bakr and Bilal got sick. Abu Bakr recited a poem when his fever was bad: 'Death is closer to me than my shoelaces.' When Bilal felt better, he recited another poem about wanting to be in a valley with nice grass and drink from a special spring. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'God, curse the people who forced us out of our land into this unhealthy place.' He then prayed for God to make them love Medina as much as they loved Mecca, or even more. He asked God to bless their food and make the climate in Medina better, moving its sicknesses away from them.

title: Umar's Prayer for Martyrdom
content: Umar said to Allah: 'Please let me die as a martyr in Your cause. Let my death be in the city of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ).'

title: Prayer and Fasting Basics
content: A bedouin man came to the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ). He asked about his prayer duties. The Prophet (ﷺ) said: 'You must pray five times a day, unless you want to pray extra.' The bedouin asked about fasting. The Prophet (ﷺ) replied: 'Fast during Ramadan, but if you want, you can fast more too.' The bedouin then asked about giving Zakat (charity). The Prophet (ﷺ) explained all the basics of Islam. The bedouin said he would not do any extra prayers or decrease his charity. The Prophet (ﷺ) said that if this was true, the man would be successful.

title: Fasting on Ashura Day
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) used to fast on the 10th day of Muharram. He told Muslims to also fast on this day, but when Ramadan fasting was made compulsory, fasting on Ashura was no longer required. Abdullah ibn Umar didn't usually fast on Ashura unless it coincided with his regular fasting days by chance.

title: Fasting on Ashura
content: Before Islam, the Quraish tribe used to fast on a special day called Ashura. The Prophet (ﷺ) said that Muslims can also fast on this day if they want, but it's not compulsory. If you don't feel like fasting, you don't have to.

title: Fasting: A Shield from Harm
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said, 'Fasting is a protection. When you fast, don't have sex with your wife and be careful how you behave. If someone fights or insults you while fasting, say twice, 'I am fasting.' The Prophet (ﷺ) said that the smell of a person who is fasting is better to Allah than the smell of musk perfume. Allah says, 'The person who gives up food, drink, and desires for My sake will be rewarded greatly. I will multiply their good deeds ten times.'

title: Afflictions and Prayer
content: Abu Wail told us that Hudhaifa said: `Umar asked people about a Hadith from the Prophet. He wanted to know how to deal with big problems in life, like losing money or family members. Hudhaifa replied that these problems are forgiven by praying, fasting and giving charity. `Umar didn't ask about those, but about bigger problems that would spread everywhere. Hudhaifa said there's a problem that will be stopped, but then it will break through again. `Umar asked if it would ever close again. Hudhaifa said no, not until the Day of Judgment.

title: Fasting Leads to Paradise
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said that there is a gate in Paradise called Ar-Raiyan. On the Day of Resurrection, only people who fast will enter through this gate. When they are asked where those who fasted are, they will stand up and no one else can enter after them.

title: Two Kinds of Charity
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said: If you give two things to help others for Allah, you will be called from the gates of Paradise. You'll be told 'Here is good fortune.' People who pray will be called from the gate of prayer. Those who fight for Allah will be called from the gate of Jihad. Those who fast will be called from the gate of Ar-Raiyan. And those who give charity will be called from the gate of charity.

title: Ramadan: Gates of Heaven Open
content: When Ramadan starts, the doors to Paradise are opened.

title: Ramadan: Gates Opened
content: When Ramadan starts, the gates of heaven are open and the gates of Hell are closed. The devils are also chained during this time.

title: Fasting in Ramadan
content: Ibn Umar said that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) told him to start fasting when you see the crescent moon for the month of Ramadan. Stop fasting when you see the crescent moon for the month of Shawwal. If it's cloudy and you can't see the moon, count Ramadan as a 30-day month.

title: Forgiveness on Qadr Night
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'If you pray on the night of Qadr with a true heart and hoping for Allah's reward, your past sins will be forgiven. If you fast in Ramadan with a true heart and hoping for Allah's reward, your past sins will be forgiven.'

title: The Prophet's Generosity in Ramadan
content: Ibn Abbas said that the Prophet was very generous. He became even more generous during Ramadan when Gabriel visited him every night. The Prophet (ﷺ) would read the Quran to Gabriel, and this made the Prophet feel extra kind and generous.

title: Fasting without Good Deeds
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'If someone doesn't stop lying and doing bad things, Allah won't accept their fasting.'

title: Fasting is a Shield
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said: 'All the good deeds people do are for them, except fasting. Fasting is for Allah and He will reward it. It protects you from going to hell and from sinning. When you're fasting, don't have sex with your wife or argue with anyone. If someone fights you, say 'I'm fasting.' The bad smell of a fasting person's mouth is better than the good smell of musk. Fasting gives two joys: one when you break your fast, and another when you meet Allah.

title: Marriage and Fasting Advice
content: 'Abdullah said to me, 'When I was with the Prophet, he told us that if you can afford it, marry. Marriage will stop you from looking at other women and keep your private parts safe from sin. If you cannot get married, then fast. Fasting will reduce your desire for sex.'

title: Ramadan Fasting Rules
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: 'Don't start fasting unless you see the new moon of Ramadan. And don't stop fasting until you see the new moon of Shawwal. If it's cloudy, count Sha'ban as 30 days.'

title: When to Fast in Ramadan
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: 'A month can have 29 nights. Don't fast until you see the moon. If it's cloudy, complete Sha'ban as a full 30 days.'

title: Months are like this
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) showed his fingers to explain that a month has 29 or 30 days. He did this three times, leaving out one thumb on the third time.

title: Fasting in Ramadan
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: 'Start fasting when you see the crescent moon for Ramadan. Stop fasting when you see the crescent moon for Shawwal. If it's cloudy, fast for thirty days of Sha'ban instead.'

title: Prophet's Vow to His Wives
content: Um Salama said the Prophet vowed not to see his wives for one month. After 29 days, he went to visit them. Someone reminded him of his vow and he explained that a month has 29 days.

title: Prophet's Vow to Stay Away
content: Anas said the Prophet had a vow to stay away from his wives for one month. He was also hurt and couldn't walk properly. So, he stayed in a special room on the top floor of his house for 29 nights. Some people told him, 'You vowed to stay away for a whole month.' The Prophet (ﷺ) replied, 'A month is only 29 days'.

title: Ramadan and Dhul-Hijja are Equal
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'The months of Ramadan and Dhul-Hijja do not become less important just because they come together.'

title: Prophet's Description of Islam
content: Ibn Umar said the Prophet told him that Muslims are not good at reading or writing. He explained that sometimes a month has 29 days and sometimes it has 30.

title: Fasting Before Ramadan
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: Don't fast one or two days before Ramadan unless you normally fast extra. If your fasting happens to be on those days, then it's okay.

title: Fasting and Eating Rules
content: Some of Prophet Muhammad 's (ﷺ) companions had a rule: if they fell asleep before breaking their fast, they wouldn't eat that night or the next day. Qais bin Sirma was fasting and asked his wife for food. She said she'd go get some, but he slept instead. When he woke up the next day, he fainted from hunger. The Prophet (ﷺ) was told about this and two verses of the Quran were revealed: it's okay to have sex with your wife at night while fasting, and you can eat until dawn breaks.

title: Understanding the White Thread
content: `Adi bin Hatim asked about a verse that said 'until the white thread appears to you, distinct from the black thread'. He took two strings, one black and one white, but couldn't see anything. He told the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) about it. The Prophet (ﷺ) explained that the verse meant the darkness of night and the whiteness of dawn.

title: Tying Threads to Fast
content: Some people wanted to fast. They tied a black thread and a white thread around their legs so they could stop eating when the difference between them was clear. Then Allah revealed more of the Quran, saying that it's night or day that should be known.

title: Eat Before Morning Prayer
content: Bilal used to call people for night prayer. The Prophet (ﷺ) said: 'Keep eating and drinking until Ibn Um Maktum calls the prayer, because he only does it when it's really dawn'.

title: Eat Before Morning Prayer
content: Bilal used to call the people for night prayer. The Prophet (ﷺ) said: 'Keep eating and drinking until Ibn Um Maktum calls the prayer. He only does this when it's really dawn.'

title: Taking Suhur and Praying Fajr
content: Sahl bin Sa'd used to have breakfast with his family. Then he would hurry to join the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) for the morning prayer.

title: Prophet's Morning Routine
content: Anas said that Zaid bin Thabit told him: 'We ate Suhur with the Prophet. Then he stood for prayer.' Anas asked, 'How long was it between eating and praying?' Zaid replied, 'It took about enough time to recite fifty verses of the Quran'.

title: Prophet's Fasting Advice
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) fasted for many days in a row. The people tried to do the same but it was hard for them. So, the Prophet told them not to fast every day without stopping. They said, 'But you don't stop fasting.' The Prophet (ﷺ) replied, 'I'm different from you because Allah provides me with food and drink.'

title: Importance of Taking Suhur
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: 'Take your meal before dawn. There is a blessing in it.'

title: Fasting on Ashura Day
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) told a man to announce that anyone who had eaten should not eat more and fast for the rest of the day, but those who hadn't eaten yet should finish their fasting until sunset on 'Ashura' (the tenth of Muharram).

title: Morning Bath After Intimacy
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) sometimes woke up in the morning after being with his wives. He would take a bath and then fast.

title: The Prophet's Morning Routine
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) sometimes woke up in the morning after having sex with his wives. He would take a bath and then fast for the day.

title: Kissing Wives While Fasting
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) would kiss and hug his wives even when he was fasting. He had more self-control than anyone else. A companion, Jabir, said that if a man gets an erection just by looking at his wife while fasting, he should finish the day without eating or drinking.

title: Kissing Wives While Fasting
content: Aisha said that the Prophet used to kiss some of his wives when he was fasting. She smiled about this.

title: Menstruation and Fasting
content: Zainab's mother said she was with the Prophet under a woolen sheet when she got her period. She left, changed clothes, and came back in. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked if she had gotten her period. She said yes. They still took baths together from one pot and he kissed her while fasting.

title: Ramadan Fasting with Prophet
content: Aisha said the Prophet sometimes took a morning bath in Ramadan even though he hadn't had a wet dream. He would still keep fasting.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Morning Routine
content: Abu Bakr and his father visited Aisha. She said that the Prophet sometimes woke up in the morning after having sex, not because of a wet dream. He would then fast on that day. They also spoke to Um Salama, who told them something similar.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Morning Routine
content: Abu Bakr and his father visited Aisha. She said that the Prophet sometimes woke up in the morning after having sex with his wife, not because of a wet dream. He would then fast on that day. They also asked Um Salama, who told them something similar.

title: Forgetting while Fasting
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: If someone eats or drinks by mistake while fasting, they should finish their fast. What they ate or drank was given to them by Allah.

title: Uthman's Ablution Routine
content: Humran saw Uthman performing ablution. He washed his hands three times, rinsed his mouth, and then put water in his nose and blew it out. Next, he washed his face three times, his right forearm up to the elbow three times, and his left forearm three times. Then, he wet his head and washed each foot three times. Uthman said that Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) performed ablution like this one. If you do an ablution like this and pray two rak'at without thinking about worldly things, your past sins will be forgiven.

title: Fasting and Sexual Intercourse
content: A man came to the Prophet. He said he was in trouble because he had sex with his wife while fasting in Ramadan. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked him what happened, then a basket of dates arrived. The Prophet (ﷺ) told the man to give the dates away as a way to make up for breaking his fast.

title: Man Breaks His Fast
content: Abu Huraira was sitting with the Prophet. A man came and said he had broken his fast by having sex with his wife. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked him if he could free a slave, but he couldn't afford it. He also couldn't fast for two months or feed sixty poor people. The Prophet (ﷺ) kept quiet. Then a big basket of dates was brought to the Prophet. He asked where the man was and told him to take the dates and give them away in charity. But the man said there was no one poorer than he, so the Prophet just told him to feed his family with the dates.

title: Fasting and Atonement
content: A man told the Prophet that he had sex with his wife while fasting in Ramadan. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked if he could free a slave, fast for two months, or feed sixty poor people. He said no to all these things. Then some dates were brought to the Prophet, and he told the man to use them to feed the poor. The man said that there was no poorer family than his own. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Then feed your family with it'.

title: Cupping for the Prophet
content: Ibn Abbas said that the Prophet was cupped while he was in a state of Ihram and also when he was fasting.

title: Prophet Fasts with Cupping
content: Ibn Abbas said the Prophet was cupped while he was fasting.

title: Cupping for Fasting Person
content: Anas bin Malik was asked if it's not good to get cupped while fasting. He said no, only if it makes you weak.

title: Prophet's Instructions for Fasting
content: We were on a journey with the Prophet. He told a man to mix powdered barley with water for him. The man said it was still daytime, but the Prophet asked again twice. Finally, the man mixed the Sawiq and gave it to the Prophet. After drinking it, the Prophet pointed east and said, 'When you see night coming from that direction, fasting people can break their fast'.

title: Hamza's Continuous Fasting
content: Hamza bin `Amr Al-Aslami told the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ): 'I fast every day.'

title: Fasting while Traveling
content: Hamza bin `Amr Al-Aslami asked the Prophet if he could fast while traveling. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'You can choose to fast or not when you're on a journey.'

title: Prophet Muhammad Breaks Fast
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) was traveling to Mecca in the month of Ramadan. He normally fasted during this time, but when he reached a place called Al-Kadid, he stopped fasting and so did his companions.

title: Hot Day on Journey
content: We went on a trip with the Prophet. It was very hot and we had to cover our heads. Only two people were fasting: the Prophet and Ibn Rawaha.

title: Fasting on Journey
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) saw a man who was fasting while traveling. He asked why the man was fasting and they said it's because he wanted to obey Allah. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'It is not good to fast when you're on a journey.'

title: Respect for Fasting and Non-Fasting
content: Anas bin Malik said: When we traveled with the Prophet, those who were fasting didn't criticize those who weren't fasting. And those who weren't fasting didn't criticize those who were fasting.

title: Prophet's Journey in Ramadan
content: Ibn Abbas said that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) went from Medina to Mecca during the month of Ramadan. He fasted until he reached a place called Usfan, then broke his fast and asked for water. After that, he didn't fast again until he arrived in Mecca. Ibn Abbas also said that when traveling, the Prophet sometimes fasted and sometimes did not. So, whoever wanted to fast could do so, and whoever didn't want to fast was allowed to break their fast.

title: Fasting or Feeding the Poor
content: Ibn Umar said that Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) had ordered people to either fast one day and give food to a poor person for another day. However, later it was announced that this order was cancelled.

title: Missing Fasting Days
content: Aisha sometimes missed fasting in Ramadan. She could only make up for these days by fasting in the month of Sha'ban. Aisha was often busy taking care of the Prophet.

title: Menstruation and Prayer
content: Abu Sa'id said the Prophet said: A woman cannot pray or fast when she is menstruating. This is a loss for her faith.

title: Fasting for the Dead
content: If someone dies and they missed fasting during Ramadan, their family or guardians must fast on their behalf to make up for those days.

title: Fasting for a Deceased Mother
content: A man asked the Prophet if he should fast on behalf of his mother who missed fasting one month. The Prophet (ﷺ) said yes, and added that Allah's debts have priority. A woman also asked about her sister who died while she had vowed to fast but didn't.

title: Break Your Fast When Night Falls
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said to `Umar bin Al-Khattab: 'When the sun sets and night starts, it's time for you to break your fast.'

title: Breaking Fast During Travel
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) was on a journey and fasting. When the sun set, he asked someone to mix Sawiq with water for them. The person replied that it was still daytime. The Prophet (ﷺ) repeated his request three times before the person got down and mixed the Sawiq. After drinking it, the Prophet said: 'When you see night falling from this side, break your fast'.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Fasting Rule
content: We were traveling with Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ). He was fasting and wanted to break his fast when the sun went down. One of us said, 'Wait till evening.' The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Get some water and mix it with Sawiq (a type of food) for us.' We did that. Then he said, 'When you see night coming from the east, then break your fast.'

title: Hastening Breaking of Fast
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: The people will stay on the right path as long as they hurry to break their fast.

title: Breaking Fast on Journey
content: I was traveling with the Prophet. He didn't eat during the day. When it started to get dark, he told a man to mix some food with water for him. The man asked if they should wait till evening. The Prophet (ﷺ) said no, when you see night coming, break your fast.

title: Fasting on a Cloudy Day
content: Asma bint Abi Bakr said that she and her family broke their fast during the time of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ). It was a cloudy day, but then the sun came out. They were asked if they had to make up for missing that day's fasting. Hisham said he didn't know for sure, but Ma'mar thought they probably did have to make it up.

title: Fasting on Ashura Day
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) sent a message to the Ansar village on Ashura day. He said: 'If you've eaten, don't eat more. Finish your fast. If you're fasting, complete it.' We started fasting on that day and making our boys fast too. When they cried for food, we gave them toys until it was time to break the fast.

title: Don't Fast Continuously
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: 'Do not fast from dawn to dusk without breaking your fast in the evening or eating before the next morning.' The people asked him, 'But you do this?' He replied, 'I'm different. Allah gives me food and drink at night.'

title: Prophet Muhammad's Rule on Fasting
content: Abdullah bin Umar said that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) forbade a type of fasting called Al-Wisal. People asked him, 'But you do it?' He replied, 'I'm not like you. I get food and drink from Allah.'

title: Don't Fast Continuously
content: Abu Sa'id said the Prophet told him not to fast all the time. If you want to make your fasting longer, stop eating and drinking just before dawn. People asked the Prophet why he himself didn't follow this rule, and he replied that during his sleep, Allah helps him eat and drink.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Mercy
content: Aisha said that the Prophet forbade his followers from fasting all day and night without eating or drinking. They asked him, 'But you do this?' He replied, 'I'm not like you. My Lord gives me food and drink'.

title: Prophet Muhammad Forbids Continuous Fasting
content: Abu Huraira said that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) forbade Muslims from fasting continuously without breaking. A Muslim asked, 'But you do it.' The Prophet (ﷺ) replied, 'I'm different. My Lord feeds me during my sleep.' When people refused to stop, the Prophet fasted with them for two days until they saw the new moon. He said, 'If I hadn't seen the moon, I would have made you fast longer as a punishment.'

title: Be Cautious with Fasting
content: Abu Huraira said the Prophet said twice: 'Be careful! Don't fast all day and night.' People asked, 'But you do that?' The Prophet (ﷺ) replied, 'My Lord gives me food and drink while I sleep. Do what you can.'

title: Don't Fast All the Time
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said to his companions: Do not fast every day and night without stopping. If you want to do this, keep fasting until morning time comes. His companions asked him, 'But you do this, O Prophet?' He replied, 'I'm different from you. During my sleep, Allah helps me eat and drink.'

title: Brotherhood and Fasting
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) made Salman a brother to Abu Ad-Darda'. Salman visited him and saw his wife wearing old clothes. He asked why she was dressed like that, and she said her husband didn't care about the world's luxuries. When Abu Ad-Darda' came home, he prepared food for Salman, but said he was fasting. Salman insisted Abu Ad-Darda' eat with him. At night, when it was time to pray, Salman told Abu Ad-Darda' to sleep and wait until later. They prayed together finally. Then Salman reminded Abu Ad-Darda', 'Your Lord has rights over you, your soul has needs, and so does your family.' Abu Ad-Darda' went to the Prophet and told him what happened. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Salman was right'.

title: Allah's Messenger's Fasting Habits
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) would sometimes fast a lot and then stop fasting for a while. I never saw him fast the whole month except in Ramadan, and he usually didn't fast as much in Sha'ban.

title: Prophet's Advice on Fasting
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) never fasted more than in the month of Sha'ban. He said to do small good deeds because Allah rewards us for every action, no matter how small. The Prophet (ﷺ) liked prayer that was done regularly, even if it was just a little bit each day.

title: The Prophet's Fasting Habits
content: Ibn Abbas said the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) never fasted a whole month except in Ramadan. He would sometimes go for so long without eating that people thought he'd never stop fasting again. At other times, he wouldn't eat for so long that people thought he'd never start fasting again.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Fasting and Prayer
content: Anas said that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) often didn't fast in one month. We thought he wouldn't fast at all, but then he would start fasting again in another month. If we wanted to see him praying at night, we could find him doing so. And if we wanted to see him sleeping, we could also find him resting.

title: Anas Describes the Prophet
content: I asked Anas about the Prophet's fasting. He said he often saw the Prophet fasting in some months and not fasting in others. He also saw the Prophet praying at night, but mostly sleeping. I never touched fabric softer than the Prophet's hand or smelled perfume sweeter than his scent.

title: Guests and Wives Have Rights
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) came to me. He said that a guest has the right to be treated well by their host, and a wife has rights too. I asked about fasting like David's way of fasting. The Prophet (ﷺ) replied that David used to fast on alternate days for half of the year.

title: Moderate Fasting is Best
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said to me, 'Abdullah, I've heard you're fasting all day and praying at night.' I replied, 'Yes.' He said, 'Don't do that. Fast for a few days, then stop for a few days. Pray and also sleep at night. Your body needs rest, your wife needs attention, and guests need care. Fasting three days a month is enough. It's like fasting all year because good deeds are rewarded ten times more.' I insisted on fasting, so he said, 'Fast like the Prophet David – half of the year. He fasted every other day.' Later, when I was old, I wished I had accepted his advice.

title: Fasting and Prayer Balance
content: Abdullah bin Amr told me that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) came to him. Abdullah had promised to fast every day and pray all night for his whole life. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'No, you can't do that.' He suggested fasting a few days and then not fasting for a few days. This way, you can still get rewards from Allah. The Prophet (ﷺ) also told Abdullah to try fasting three days a month. This would be like fasting for one year. But Abdullah wanted to do more. So the Prophet said, 'Try fasting one day and not fasting the next.' Abdullah thought he could do even better. The Prophet (ﷺ) then said, 'Fasting one day and not fasting the next is the best way. Even Prophet David did it this way.'

title: Balance Your Fasting
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) was told that I was fasting every day and praying all night. He said, 'Don't fast every day. Give yourself time to rest. Your body needs rest too.' I said I could keep going. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Then try the way of David. He would fast one day and not the next.' I asked how I could do that. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Fasting like David means fasting on alternate days.'

title: Fasting and Reciting Quran
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said to Abdullah: 'Fast for three days a month.' Abdullah replied, 'I can fast more than that.' They kept arguing until the Prophet said, 'Fast on alternate days. Read the whole Quran once a month.' Abdullah said, 'I can read more in a month,' and they argued some more. The Prophet (ﷺ) finally said, 'Read the Quran once every three days.'

title: Fasting Too Much is Bad
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said to me: 'You fast every day and pray all night?' I said yes. He said, 'If you keep doing this, your eyes will get weak and your body tired. Fasting all the time is not good.' He told me that fasting for three days a month is like fasting all year. I said I could do more. He said, 'Then fast like David did: alternate days of fasting, but never miss fighting when needed'.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Advice
content: Abdullah bin Amr told the Prophet that he was fasting a lot. The Prophet (ﷺ) came to visit him and sat on the ground, even though Abdullah had offered him a cushion. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked if three days of fasting per month were enough for Abdullah. Abdullah said no, so the Prophet suggested five days, then seven, nine, and eleven. The Prophet (ﷺ) then said that the best fast is like that of Prophet David, who fasted half the year by alternating between days of fasting and eating.

title: Prophet's Simple Advice
content: My friend, the Prophet, told me to do three things: fast for three days each month, pray two times in the middle of the day, and say a special prayer before going to sleep.

title: The Prophet Visits Um-Sulaim
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) visited a woman named Um-Sulaim. She gave him dates and ghee to eat, but he said, 'Put them back in their containers because I'm fasting.' He then prayed on his own in her house and asked Allah to bless her family. Um-Sulaim asked the Prophet for a special favor: to pray for her servant Anas. The Prophet (ﷺ) agreed and said, 'O Allah, give Anas wealth, children, and blessings.' As a result, I (Anas) became one of the richest people in Medina, and my daughter Umaina told me that when she grew up, more than 120 of our family members were alive.

title: Fasting in Last Days
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) asked a man if he had fasted the last days of Ramadan. The man said no. The Prophet (ﷺ) told him to make up for it by fasting two extra days after Ramadan was over.

title: Fasting on Fridays Forbidden
content: I asked Jabir if the Prophet forbade fasting only on Fridays. He said yes. If someone wants to fast, they should not just do it on that day.

title: Fasting on Fridays
content: Abu Huraira heard the Prophet say: 'No one should fast on a Friday unless they also fast the day before or after it.'

title: Prophet Muhammad's Advice
content: Abu Aiyub told us that the Prophet visited a woman named Juwairiya on a Friday. She was fasting, but not for two days in a row. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked her if she had fasted the day before and if she would fast tomorrow. When she said no to both, he told her to break her fast.

title: Allah's Messenger's Fasting Habits
content: I asked Aisha if the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) used to choose special days for fasting. She said no, he was very regular with his worship. He endured what most people couldn't.

title: Prophet Muhammad Drinks Milk
content: Um Al-Fadl bint Al-Harith was with the Prophet on a hot day. Some people thought he was fasting, but others didn't know if he was or not. She sent him a bowl of milk while he was riding his camel. He drank it.

title: Prophet's Fasting on Arafat Day
content: Maimuna was worried if the Prophet was fasting during a special day. She sent milk to him while he was standing at Arafat. He drank it, and people saw him.

title: No Fasting on Eid Days
content: I was with Umar bin Al-Khattab on Eid. He said the Prophet has forbidden fasting on two days: when we break our Ramadan fast and when we eat meat from our sacrifices (on Eid).

title: Prophet's Rules for Fasting
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) told Abu Sa'id that it is not allowed to fast on two special days: Eid ul Fitr and Eid ul Adha. He also said you should not wear just one piece of clothing, like a blanket, or sit with your leg tucked under while wearing only one garment. And remember, do not pray after morning and afternoon prayers.

title: Prophet's Rules for Muslims
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said that Muslims should not fast on two special days: Eid al-Fitr and Eid al-Adha. He also said it is not allowed to wear only one piece of clothing that covers the whole body, or sit with one leg up while wearing a single garment. Additionally, he said it's not permitted to pray after morning and afternoon prayers.

title: Forbidden Fasts and Sales
content: Abu Huraira said: Two types of fasting are not allowed. You cannot fast on the day of Eid al-Fitr or Eid al-Adha. Also, there are two kinds of sale that are forbidden. These were practiced before Islam. One is called Mulamasa - if you touch something for sale, you have to buy it. The other is Munabadha - if a seller throws something to you, you must buy it.

title: Fulfilling a Vow to Fast
content: A man told Ibn 'Umar that he had vowed to fast on a specific day. But that day was Eid, and Ibn 'Umar said that Allah wants people to keep their vows, but the Prophet forbade fasting on Eid.

title: Prophet's Rules for Travelers
content: Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri said he heard four important things from the Prophet. He said: A woman should not travel alone with anyone except her husband or a close relative. You can't fast on two special days, Eid al-Fitr and Eid al-Adha. Don't pray after morning prayer until the sun is up, and don't pray after Asr prayer until sunset. Only visit three mosques: Masjid-al-Haram in Mecca, Masjid-al-Aqsa in Jerusalem, and this mosque in Medina.

title: 'Aishah's Fasting in Mina
content: 'Aishah used to fast on the days of Mina. Her husband also did this.

title: Fasting on Days of Tashriq
content: Aisha and Ibn Umar said that no one is allowed to fast during the days of Tashriq, except those who do not have a sacrifice (Hadi) to offer.

title: Fasting on Days of Tashriq
content: Aisha and Ibn Umar said that no one was allowed to fast during the days of Tashriq, except those who did not have a Hadi (a sacrifice) to give.

title: Fasting for Hajj Tamattu
content: If you're doing a special kind of Hajj called Hajj-at-Tamattu', you can fast up to the day before going to Arafat. If you don't have an animal to sacrifice and haven't already fasted, then you should fast on the days after Mina (11th, 12th, and 13th of Dhul Hijjah).

title: Fasting on Ashura Day
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Anyone can fast on the day of Ashura. Whoever wants to can do it.'

title: Fasting on Ashura Day
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) told the Muslims to fast on 'Ashura day. Later, when Ramadan fasting was made compulsory, it became optional to also fast on 'Ashura or not.

title: Fasting on Ashura
content: Before Islam, the Quraish tribe used to fast on a special day called 'Ashura'. When Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) came to Medina, he also fasted on this day. He told others to fast too. Later, Allah ordered him to stop fasting on 'Ashura' and instead fast during the month of Ramadan. Now it's up to each person whether or not to fast on 'Ashura'.

title: Muawiya's Message on Ashura
content: One of the companions, Muawiya bin Abi Sufyan, spoke to people in Medina. He said that Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) had told him about a special day called 'Ashura'. The Prophet (ﷺ) said it was okay for people to choose whether or not to fast on this day. Muawiya himself chose to fast.

title: Fasting on Ashura Day
content: When the Prophet came to Medina, he saw Jews fasting on a special day called Ashura. He asked them why they were fasting and they said it was because Allah helped their ancestor Moses defeat his enemies on that day. The Prophet (ﷺ) replied that Muslims have an even stronger connection to Moses than the Jews do. So, he decided to fast on Ashura Day too and told all Muslims to do the same.

title: Fasting on Ashura Day
content: Abu Musa said the Prophet told Muslims to fast on 'Ashura day because it was a special day for the Jews, who also celebrated it as an Eid. The Prophet (ﷺ) recommended that we fast on this day.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Fasting Habits
content: Ibn Abbas said he never saw the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) fast on a day more than another, except for Ashura and Ramadan. He favored these days to fast.

title: Fasting on Ashura Day
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) ordered a man to tell people that if they had eaten, they should fast the rest of the day. If they hadn't eaten, they could continue their fasting because it was the day of 'Ashura.

title: Forgiveness in Ramadan Prayer
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said: If someone prays at night during Ramadan with a sincere heart and hoping for a reward, their past sins will be forgiven.

title: Ramadan Night Prayers
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said: If someone prays at night every day in Ramadan with a sincere heart and hoping for a reward from Allah, then all their past sins will be forgiven.
