After the Prophet passed away, people continued to pray individually during Ramadan. One year, 'Umar bin Al-Khattab saw people praying in different groups and thought it would be better if they prayed together as one group. So he made them pray behind a single reciter. 'Umar said that this was a good idea, but the prayer that is missed at night is more important than the one that is done.

title: Ramadan Prayer at Night
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) used to pray at night during Ramadan.

title: The Prophet's Night Prayer
content: 'Aisha told me that the Prophet went out at night to pray in the mosque. Some men prayed behind him. The next day, many people talked about it and came to pray with him again. On the third night, even more people came, and on the fourth night, the mosque was too full. The Prophet (ﷺ) only came out for the morning prayer. He said, 'I knew you were coming, but I didn't want to make night prayer a requirement because I thought it might be hard for you to do.' After he died, people continued to pray individually.

title: Ramadan Prayer Routine
content: Abu Salama asked Aisha about the Prophet's prayer in Ramadan. She said he prayed 11 rakats total, with four sets of four and then three for witr. Abu Salama asked if the Prophet slept before witr. Aisha replied that his eyes would sleep but not his heart.

title: Forgiveness in Ramadan
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: If someone fasts during Ramadan because they truly believe and want a reward from Allah, their past sins will be forgiven. And if someone prays all night on Laylat al-Qadr (the Night of Power) with true faith and wanting a reward from Allah, their previous sins will also be forgiven.

title: Finding the Night of Power
content: Some companions of the Prophet had dreams that the special night was in the last seven nights of Ramadan. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'It seems your dreams agree on this. If you want to find it, look in the last seven nights.'

title: Prophet's Advice on Laylatul Qadr
content: Abu Sa'id said that the Prophet told them to look for the Night of Power in the last ten nights of Ramadan. He had a dream where he was prostrating in mud and water, so they went back into seclusion with him. While they were praying, it started raining and the mosque got flooded.

title: Find the Night of Power
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said to Aisha: 'Look for the special night in the last ten days of Ramadan. It is one of the odd-numbered nights.'

title: Prophet Muhammad's I'tikaf
content: Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri said that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) used to stay in the mosque for a part of Ramadan. He would leave on the 21st day and go back home. One year, he stayed longer than usual and told people to stay with him too. He said that Allah had shown him something but he forgot what it was. He asked them to look for it in the last ten days of Ramadan, specifically on odd nights. He also mentioned a dream where he saw himself prostrating in mud and water. On the 21st day, it rained and the mosque got flooded. The Prophet (ﷺ) left the mosque with mud and water on his face after morning prayer.

title: Find the Night of Power
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said to his wife Aisha: 'Look for the Night of Qadr'.

title: Ramadan's Last Ten Nights
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) used to stay in the mosque for the last ten nights of Ramadan. He would say: 'Look for the Night of Power in these last ten nights'.

title: Finding the Night of Power
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said to Ibn Abbas: 'Look for the special night in the last ten nights of Ramadan. It could be on one of these nights: when nine, seven or five nights are left.'

title: When is Laylatul Qadr?
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said to Ibn Abbas: The Night of Power is in the last ten nights of Ramadan. It could be on one of the first nine nights or in the last seven nights. Ibn Abbas added that it might also be on the 24th night.

title: Finding the Night of Qadr
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) came out to tell us about a special night in Ramadan. But two Muslims were arguing with each other, so he didn't say anything. He told us to look for this night on the 29th, 27th or 25th day of Ramadan.

title: Ramadan's Last Ten Days
content: When Ramadan's last ten days start, the Prophet would work hard and stay up all night praying. He'd also keep his family awake for prayer time.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Ramadan Practice
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) used to stay in a special state of devotion during the last ten days of Ramadan. He would focus on prayer and reflection.

title: Prophet's Last Ramadan Practice
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) used to stay in the mosque for the last ten days of Ramadan. He would pray and focus on his faith during this time. After he passed away, his wives continued this practice.

title: Ramadan I'tikaf and Qadr Night
content: Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri said: The Prophet (ﷺ) used to stay in a special room during the middle ten days of Ramadan. One year, he stayed until the night before the morning when he would normally come out. He told his companions who were also staying with him: 'Stay here for the last ten nights. I was told about the Night of Qadr, but I forgot it. In a dream, I saw myself praying in mud and water on that night.' It rained that night and the mosque's roof leaked because it was made of palm leaves. The next morning, Abu Sa'id saw mud on the Prophet's forehead.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Hair Care
content: When the Prophet was in a special time of prayer and fasting in the mosque, he would lean his head towards me even when I had my period. I would then comb and oil his hair.

title: Prophet's Mosque Visit
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) would sometimes let his head in the house while he was in the mosque. I'd comb and oil his hair. When he was in a state of I'tikaf, he wouldn't enter the house unless it was really necessary.

title: Prophet Muhammad's kindness
content: Aisha said the Prophet would hold her close even when she was having her period. He also used to stick his head out of the mosque while he was in prayer, and Aisha would wash it when she was having her period.

title: Prophet Muhammad's kindness
content: Aisha said the Prophet used to hug her even when she was on her period. He also would stick his head out of the mosque while he was in a special time of prayer, and Aisha would wash it for him during that time.

title: Umar's Vow in the Mosque
content: Ibn Umar said that Umar asked the Prophet if he should keep his vow to stay in the mosque for one night. The Prophet (ﷺ) told him, 'Keep your promise'.

title: The Prophet's I'tikaf
content: Aisha said the Prophet used to stay in a special room during the last ten days of Ramadan. She would set up a tent for him after morning prayer. Hafsa asked Aisha if she could also have a tent, and Aisha agreed. Zainab saw this and got her own tent too. The next day, the Prophet noticed all these tents. He asked what was going on. When he found out, he said, 'Do you think they wanted to do good by doing this?' So, he stopped his special stay in Ramadan and did it again in Shawwal for ten days.

title: Prophet Muhammad's I'tikaf Decision
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) planned to stay in a special place for prayer and reflection. When he got there, he saw the tents of his wives Aisha, Hafsa, and Zainab. He asked if they were doing something good by being there. Then he decided not to stay there for prayer and instead stayed elsewhere for 10 days later in the month of Shawwal.

title: Prophet Visits Safiya at Mosque
content: Safiya, the Prophet's wife, visited him in the mosque during Ramadan. She talked with him for a while and then left. The Prophet (ﷺ) walked her to the gate. Two men greeted them as they passed by. The Prophet (ﷺ) told them not to be afraid because he was with Safiya. He said that Satan can enter anyone's body like blood flows through it, so he didn't want evil thoughts in their minds.

title: Finding the Night of Qadr
content: Abu Salama asked Abu Sa'id if he knew when the Night of Qadr was. Abu Sa'id said Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) had told them about it in a dream, but forgotten. He said to look for it on an odd night in the last ten days of Ramadan. He also said that in his dream, he saw himself prostrating in mud and water. So, whoever was with him in I'tikaf should come back and stay again. It started raining, and they stood up for prayer. Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) then prostrated in the mud and water.

title: Aisha's I'tikaf with Bleeding
content: Aisha, one of the Prophet Muhammad 's (ﷺ) wives, practiced a spiritual retreat called I'tikaf while she had her period. She would still pray and sometimes we put a tray under her to catch any blood that might come out during prayer.

title: Prophet's Fear of Satan
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) was in a mosque with his wives. They left and he wanted to walk Safiya home. Two men saw him, but didn't know what to think when the Prophet told them she was his wife. He explained that Satan is always present and can make people do bad things.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Advice
content: Safiya visited the Prophet while he was in a special state of prayer and fasting. When she left, the Prophet walked with her back to her home. An Ansari man saw them and approached. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Come here. This is Safiya.' He then explained that Satan is always present inside us, like our blood flowing through our bodies.

title: Prophet's Night of Qadr
content: Abu Sa'id said: We did a special prayer with the Prophet in Ramadan. On the twentieth day, we packed up to leave but the Prophet came and told us to go back to our places because he had seen that this was the night of Qadr. He said he saw himself prostrating in mud and water. When I went back, it started raining and the sky stayed cloudy for a while. The mosque leaked from the rain and we could see where the Prophet's face touched the ground.

title: Prophet Muhammad's I'tikaf
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) would often stay in the mosque for prayer and reflection during Ramadan. One year, his wives Aisha, Hafsa, and Zainab also wanted to do this. They set up tents in the mosque, but when the Prophet saw them, he said they shouldn't be there. He didn't want people to think it was a way to show off or be seen as special. So, the tents were taken down. That year, the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) did his I'tikaf in the last ten days of Shawwal instead.

title: Umar's Vow to Allah
content: `Umar told the Prophet that before Islam he had vowed to spend one night in prayer at the mosque. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Keep your promise.' So `Umar spent one night in I`tikaf.

title: Umar's Vow in the Mosque
content: `Umar had promised to spend time alone in the mosque before Islam. The Prophet (ﷺ) told him to keep his promise and do it.

title: Prophet's Ramadan Retreat
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) used to stay in a special room for ten days of Ramadan every year. The last time he did this, he stayed for twenty days before he passed away.

title: Ramadan: The Prophet's Retreat
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) would often stay in a special room during the last ten days of Ramadan. His wife Aisha asked if she could join him, and he said yes. Then Hafsa asked Aisha to ask for her permission too. Zainab saw what was happening and set up her own tent. When Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) went out after prayer, he saw all these tents and asked what they were. He was told it was Aisha's, Hafsa's, and Zainab's tents. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Is this what they wanted to do? I won't stay in the room.' So he left. After Ramadan ended, he stayed in the special room for ten days in the month of Shawwal.

title: Aisha Combs Prophet's Hair
content: Aisha would comb and oil the Prophet's hair while he was in a special prayer time in the mosque. He would lean forward so she could reach his head from her room.

title: Abu Huraira's Special Place
content: My friends were busy with their work or property. I was poor and stuck to the Prophet. When they forgot, I remembered what he said. One day, the Prophet told me to spread my cloak while he spoke, so I did. And now I remember everything.

title: Abdur-Rahman's Marriage
content: When Abdur-Rahman came to Medina as an immigrant, the Prophet established a bond of brotherhood between him and Sa'd bin Ar-Rabi'. Sa'd offered to share his wealth with Abdur-Rahman and let him choose one of his two wives. But Abdur-Rahman didn't need money or a wife. He asked if there was a market where he could trade, and Sa'd told him about the Qainuqa market. Abdur-Rahman went to the market every day and bought some goods. A few days later, the Prophet asked Abdur-Rahman if he had gotten married. He said yes, and the Prophet asked who his wife was. Abdur-Rahman said she was from the Ansar tribe. The Prophet (ﷺ) then asked how much he paid for her, and Abdur-Rahman replied that it was a gold piece worth as much as a date stone. The Prophet (ﷺ) told him to give a wedding feast, even if it's just with one sheep.

title: Abdur-Rahman's First Marriage
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) established a brotherhood between Abdur-Rahman and Sa'd. Sa'd was rich, so he offered to share his wealth with Abdur-Rahman and help him get married. Abdur-Rahman said thank you and went to the market. He traded for some yogurt and butter. After some time, Abdur-Rahman came home smelling nice from perfume. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked what this was about. Abdur-Rahman said he got married to an Ansari woman. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked how much he paid her dowry. Abdur-Rahman said it was a small amount of gold, worth the same as a date stone. The Prophet (ﷺ) told him to have a wedding feast, even if it's just with one sheep.

title: Markets near Makkah
content: Before Islam, there were three markets: `Ukaz, Majanna and Dhul-Majaz. Muslims thought it might be wrong to trade there after Islam came. Allah revealed a verse saying it's okay to seek His blessings during Hajj.

title: Doubtful Matters and Sin
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: Some things are clearly right or wrong. There are also some things that are not clear. If you avoid these unclear things, you will definitely stay away from the clearly wrong ones. But if you do them anyway, you might end up doing something clearly wrong. Allah does not want us to sin, and He warns us about getting close to sinning.

title: Uqba's Wife and a Claim
content: `Uqba told the Prophet that a woman said she had suckled him and his wife. The Prophet (ﷺ) turned away, smiling, and asked how he could keep his wife if they were both breastfed by the same woman.

title: Who gets custody of a child?
content: Aisha told us that `Utba bin Abu Waqqas asked his brother Sa`d to take care of a boy. The boy's mother was a slave-girl from Zam`a's family. In the year Mecca was conquered, Sa`d took the boy and said he was his nephew. But then Zam`a stood up and said the boy was actually his own brother, born on his father's bed. They both went to the Prophet. Sa`d said, 'The Prophet (ﷺ) knows I promised to take care of him.' Zam`a replied, 'He is my brother, born on my father's bed.' The Prophet (ﷺ) then said, 'The boy belongs to you, Zam`a.' He also explained that a child belongs to the man whose bed he was born on. If someone has done something wrong, they will be punished.

title: Eating Game with a Sharp Stick
content: I asked the Prophet about using a sharp stick to hunt. He said if the animal is hit by the sharp edge, we can eat it. But if it's hit on the flat side, we shouldn't eat it because it was beaten to death. I also asked him what happens if my dog finds game and another dog that didn't have Allah's name mentioned catches it too. He said not to eat the game in this case, since only one of my dogs had Allah's name mentioned.

title: Eating Food Found Outside
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) passed by a date that had fallen on the ground. He didn't eat it because he wasn't sure if someone else had given it to him as charity. Another time, the Prophet found a date on his bed and didn't eat it either.

title: Prayer Interrupted
content: Abbas' uncle asked the Prophet: 'What if you feel something during prayer? Should I stop?' The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'No, unless you hear a sound or smell something.' Az-Zuhri said, 'You only need to do ablution again if you can smell something or hear a noise'.

title: Eat Meat with Blessing
content: Some people asked the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ): 'We get meat from others but we don't know if they said Allah's name when they killed the animal.' The Prophet (ﷺ) replied, 'Say Allah's name and eat it'.

title: Leaving Prayer for a Caravan
content: Jabir said that while they were praying with the Prophet, a caravan came from Sham. People looked at it and went to join it, leaving only twelve people with the Prophet. Then Allah revealed a verse: 'But when they see some bargain or some amusement, they disperse headlong to it'.

title: Money is no longer important
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said that a time will come when people won't care how they earn their money. It could be through honest or dishonest means.

title: Money Exchange with Prophet
content: Abu Al-Minhal asked Zaid bin 'Arqam about trading money. He said the Prophet told him: 'If you exchange money directly between two people, it's okay. But if it goes through others, it's not allowed.'

title: Money Exchange with the Prophet
content: Abu Al-Minhal asked Zaid bin 'Arqam about exchanging money. He said the Prophet said: 'If you exchange money directly from one person to another, it's okay. But if you take it from someone and then sell it, that's not allowed.'

title: Abu Musa's Visit to Umar
content: Abu Musa asked 'Umar for permission to enter, but he was busy. Abu Musa went back and waited until 'Umar finished his work. When 'Umar told him to come in, Abu Musa explained that they were ordered to leave if not admitted after asking three times. 'Umar asked for a witness to prove this, so Abu Musa found Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri and took him to 'Umar. 'Umar was surprised and said he had forgotten this order from the Prophet (ﷺ). He explained that he was often busy with trading in markets.

title: Leaving Prayer for a Caravan
content: Jabir said that while we were praying on a Friday, a caravan arrived. Most people left to go and see it, but twelve of us stayed behind to finish our prayer. After they left, this verse was revealed: 'When people see something interesting, they often leave their prayer to look at it.'

title: Charity from Home Meals
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: If a woman gives food from her home without wasting it, she gets a reward. Her husband also gets a reward for earning the money to buy that food. The person who stored the food gets a similar reward too. No one's reward is reduced because of this.

title: Charity Without Permission
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: If a woman gives something from her husband's money without his permission, she will only get half the reward for doing good.

title: Good Relations for a Better Life
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said: If you want to have more money and live longer, take care of your family members.

title: Prophet Muhammad Borrows Armor
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) bought food from a Jewish man on credit. He used his iron armor as security for the loan.

title: Anas Brings Prophet Food
content: Anas went to the Prophet and gave him some barley bread with a bit of oil on it. The Prophet (ﷺ) had borrowed money from a Jew in Medina, using his armor as collateral. He got some barley for his family. Anas heard the Prophet say that he didn't have enough food for his wives - not even one small measure of wheat or grains to eat in the evening.

title: Abu Bakr's Promise
content: When Abu Bakr became Caliph, he said his family would be taken care of. He promised they would eat from the money set aside for Muslims in need. This way, he could focus on helping all Muslims.

title: Companions Worked Hard
content: The Prophet 's (ﷺ) companions did physical work. They sweated a lot and were told to take baths.

title: Value of Hard Work
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said that no one has ever eaten a better meal than the food they earn by working with their own hands. Even David, the Prophet of Allah, used to eat from his own earnings from manual labor.

title: Prophet David's Simple Life
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) David only ate food that he earned himself through his own work.

title: Better to Work Than Ask
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: It's better for you to cut wood and carry it on your back than ask someone who might say no.

title: Don't Ask for Help
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: It's better to take a rope and cut wood by yourself than ask others for help.

title: Be Lenient in Business
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: 'May Allah be kind to the person who is gentle when buying and selling, and when asking for their money back.'

title: Granting Time to the Rich
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said that before a man died, angels asked him about his good deeds. He replied that he used to let rich people pay their debts slowly, but be strict with poor people who owed money.

title: Lending with Forgiveness
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'There was a merchant who lent money to people. When someone couldn't pay back, he would tell his workers,

title: Honesty in Buying and Selling
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said: When a buyer and seller agree on a deal but haven't finished the transaction, they can change their minds. But if both are honest and tell each other about any problems with what they're selling or buying, then Allah will be pleased with them. If either one lies or hides something, then Allah won't bless their deal.

title: Bartering with Dates
content: Abu Sa'id said: We used to get mixed dates from the war spoils and trade two handfuls of those dates for one handful of good dates. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'You can't trade two handfuls of something for one handful or two coins for one coin. That's like usury.'

title: Prophet's Invitation
content: An Ansari man invited the Prophet and four others to eat. He saw that the Prophet looked hungry. The guest list grew to five, but the Prophet said it was okay for one more person to join them. The host agreed.

title: Truth in Buying and Selling
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: When a buyer and seller agree to a deal, they can cancel or confirm it until they actually exchange goods. If both tell the truth about any problems with what they're selling, their deal will be blessed. But if one lies and hides something, the blessing is lost.

title: Money's Origin Matters
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said a time will come when people won't care about how they got their money. They won't think if it was earned honestly or not.

title: Alcohol Trade Banned
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) recited the last verses of Surah Al-Baqara in the mosque. He announced that selling alcohol is now against Islamic law.

title: Dream about a Man in River
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said that he had a dream. In the dream, two men took him to a special place. They reached a river with blood in it. A man was trying to get out of the river, but another man on the bank kept throwing stones at him. The man in the river couldn't escape. When asked who this was, he was told that it was someone who eats interest.

title: Forbidden Professions
content: My father bought a slave who did cupping. I asked my father why he broke the slave's cupping tools. He said, 'The Prophet (ﷺ) forbade accepting money for dogs or blood, and also forbade tattooing and usury. He cursed people who make pictures.'

title: Don't Buy What's Sworn
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said: The seller swearing can make the buyer buy something. But that thing will not have Allah's blessing.

title: Cheating is Not Allowed
content: A man sold some goods in the market. He swore by Allah that he had been offered more money than he actually was, to trick a Muslim. Because of this, Allah revealed a verse saying that those who cheat and break their promises will have no share in the afterlife.

title: Ali's Marriage Plans
content: I got two camels from the Prophet. One was my share of the spoils and the other was from the extra money taken from the spoils. I wanted to marry Fatima, so I asked a goldsmith friend to come with me to buy some plants called Idhkhir. We would sell them for money to use for our wedding celebration.

title: Mecca's Sanctuary Rules
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said: Allah made Mecca a safe place. No one can fight there, except for me and my companions for a short time. People cannot cut down trees, pick up lost things, or disturb the animals without announcing it publicly. `Abbas asked if this rule applies to Al-Idhkhir plants used by goldsmiths and for house roofs. The Prophet (ﷺ) said no, except for those specific uses.

title: Khabbab's Debt and Faith
content: I was a blacksmith before Islam. A man named 'Asi owed me money. He said he wouldn't pay unless I stopped believing in the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ). I told him Allah would kill him, then bring him back to life. He said wait until that happens, then he'll have wealth and children and can pay me back. This made Allah reveal a message: Does this person think he knows what will happen in the future? Has he promised Allah something?

title: Allah's Messenger Eats Gourd
content: 'Is-haq bin 'Abdullah told me that Anas bin Malik said: A tailor invited the Prophet to eat a meal he had prepared. I went with the Prophet and saw him eating bread, soup made from gourd, and dried meat. The Prophet (ﷺ) took pieces of gourd from the dish. Since then, Anas liked gourd.

title: Prophet Muhammad Wears a Gift
content: A woman gave the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) a special cloth she had made. It was a square piece of fabric with decorative edges. The Prophet (ﷺ) wore it as a waist sheet because he needed something to wear. One of his companions asked if he could have it, and the Prophet agreed. Later, the Prophet sent the cloth back to him wrapped around his body. Eventually, that cloth became the companion's shroud when he died.

title: Making a Pulpit for the Prophet
content: Some people asked Sahl bin Sa'd about the pulpit. He said that the Prophet sent a message to his wife, asking her to tell their carpenter to make a wooden platform for him. She told the carpenter to use wood from the forest and he made it. When it was finished, she sent it to the Prophet. The Prophet (ﷺ) wanted it put in the mosque, so it was placed there and he sat on it.

title: Prophet's Pulpit and Date Palm
content: An Ansari woman asked the Prophet if she could make a special seat for him. He said it was okay, so she made a pulpit. On Friday, the Prophet sat on the pulpit to give his sermon. The date palm near him started crying loudly. The Prophet (ﷺ) got down from the pulpit and hugged the palm tree. It stopped crying. The Prophet (ﷺ) said that the palm had cried because it missed hearing his teachings.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Debt
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) bought food from a Jewish man on credit. He used his armor as collateral to pay for it.

title: Prophet Muhammad Helps Jabir
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) was on a military expedition with Jabir. Jabir's camel was slow and tired, so he stayed behind. The Prophet (ﷺ) got down from his own camel and poked Jabir's camel to make it move faster. He then asked Jabir if he had married. Jabir said yes, and the Prophet asked if his wife was a virgin or a grown woman. Jabir replied that she was a grown woman because he wanted someone to take care of his younger sisters. The Prophet (ﷺ) advised him to spend time with his wife so they could have a smart child. He also offered to buy Jabir's camel for one unit of gold. When the Prophet arrived at their destination, he asked Jabir if he had just arrived and told him to leave his camel outside and come pray two units of prayer with him. After praying, the Prophet sent Bilal to give Jabir the money for his camel. But then the Prophet said that Jabir could keep both his camel and its price.

title: Markets in Pre-Islamic Time
content: Before Islam, there were markets called `Ukaz, Majanna and Dhul-Majaz. When people became Muslim, they thought it was wrong to trade at these places. So Allah sent a message saying it's okay to seek His blessings during Hajj season.

title: Ibn Umar Buys Sick Camels
content: There was a man in Mecca named Nawwas. His camels were very thirsty and couldn't drink enough water. Ibn Umar bought these sick camels from someone else. When the seller told Nawwas that he had sold them to Ibn Umar, Nawwas went to Ibn Umar. He said, 'You've been tricked! You don't know who you bought them from.' Ibn Umar then told Nawwas to take the camels back. But when Nawwas went to get them, Ibn Umar said, 'Leave them there. I'm happy with what Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) decided: we shouldn't be unfair or cheat others.'

title: Abu Qatada's First Property
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) went to Hunain with his companions. He gave Abu Qatada some armor. Abu Qatada sold the armor and used the money to buy a garden near the tribe of Bani Salama. This was the first property he owned after becoming Muslim.

title: Good Friends and Bad Ones
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said that a good friend is like a musk seller. You can either buy something good from them or enjoy their nice smell. A bad friend is like a blacksmith's bellows. They might burn you or make things worse.

title: Abu Taiba's Reward
content: Anas bin Malik said that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) ordered one Sa of dates to be given to Abu Taiba for cupping him. He also told his masters to reduce Abu Taiba's tax because he was a slave.

title: Prophet Paid for Medical Help
content: Ibn Abbas said that the Prophet got medical help to stop bleeding. He then paid the person who helped him. If it was not allowed, he wouldn't have paid them.

title: Prophet's Gift for Umar
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) sent a silk shirt to Umar. When Umar put it on, the Prophet said, 'I didn't send this for you to wear. It belongs to someone who won't go to heaven. I sent it so you can sell it and use the money.'

title: Prophet's Dislike of Pictures
content: I bought a cushion with pictures on it. The Prophet (ﷺ) saw it and didn't enter the house. I asked him what was wrong, and he said the people who painted these pictures will be punished on Judgment Day because they can't bring their creations to life. He also told me that angels don't go into houses with pictures.

title: Offering Your Garden
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) asked the Bani Najjar tribe to suggest a price for their garden. The garden was partly ruined and had some date palms in it.

title: Buying and Selling
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said that when you buy something from someone, you both have the choice to cancel or confirm the deal before you part ways. If one person likes what they bought, they can quickly leave the seller's place.

title: Buying and Selling
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: When a buyer and seller agree on a deal, they can either cancel it or confirm it. They only lose their agreement if they decide to go separate ways.

title: Seller and Buyer's Options
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said: A buyer and seller can cancel or confirm a deal until they separate. If one says, 'Choose now', the other must decide then.

title: Honesty in Buying and Selling
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: When a buyer and seller agree on a price, they can either cancel or confirm the deal. If they tell the truth about the goods and show any problems with them, their bargain will be good. But if they lie and hide important facts, Allah's blessings won't be in that deal.

title: Buying and Selling Rules
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said that both the buyer and seller can cancel or confirm a deal until they part ways or it becomes optional.

title: Buying and Selling Rules
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said: When a buyer and seller agree on a deal, they both have the right to change their minds as long as they are still together. If they separate without one of them saying no, the deal is final.

title: Buying and Selling
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: A deal is not final until the buyer and seller are apart. But if the deal depends on conditions agreed upon, it's different.

title: Buying and Selling Rules
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: When a buyer and seller agree on a deal, they both have the right to cancel or confirm it. They can do this three times. If they tell the truth about any problems with what's being sold, their deal will be good and Allah will bless it. But if they lie and hide problems, they might make some money but their sale won't be blessed by Allah.

title: Prophet's Advice on a Camel
content: Ibn 'Umar was riding his uncle Umar's camel during a journey. The camel was hard to control and kept going ahead of the group. Umar would try to stop it, but it wouldn't listen. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked Umar to sell the camel to him. Umar said, 'It's for you, O Messenger.' But the Prophet told him to sell it, not give it as a gift. So Umar sold it to the Prophet. Then the Prophet gave the camel to Ibn 'Umar and said he could do what he liked with it.

title: 'Uthman and the Khaibar Deal
content: 'Abdullah bin 'Umar traded his land in Khaibar with 'Uthman's land near Medina. After they finished the deal, Abdullah left quickly to avoid canceling it. He later realized he had been unfair to 'Uthman by selling him a distant land, while 'Uthman gave him a closer one.

title: Prophet's Advice on Honesty
content: A man told the Prophet that he often got cheated when buying things. The Prophet (ﷺ) advised him to say 'No cheating' when making a purchase.

title: Army Invades the Ka'ba
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: An army will come to the Ka'ba. When they reach a place called Al-Baida', the ground will swallow them all up. I asked, 'How can this happen? Won't some people be left?' He replied, 'Everyone will sink, but then they'll be brought back to life and judged based on what's in their hearts.'

title: Congregational Prayer Rewards
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said: If you go to the mosque for prayer with a clean heart and no other reason, your reward will be higher than praying at home. For every step towards the mosque, you'll get closer to Allah or have one sin forgiven. The angels will pray for you while you're in the mosque until you leave.

title: Prophet's Advice on Names
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) was in the market when someone called out 'O Abul-Qasim'. He turned to them and asked what they wanted. The person said he had been calling another man, but the Prophet told him not to use his own name or title. Instead, people should be named after him.

title: Don't Use My Nickname
content: A man at Al-Baqi' called out to the Prophet. He said 'O Abul-Qasim!' but didn't mean to call him by his nickname. The Prophet (ﷺ) told him, 'You can use my name, but not my nickname.'

title: The Prophet's Visit to Fatima
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) went out during the day. He was quiet and didn't talk to me until he reached a market in Bani Qainuqa. There, he sat at Fatima's house and asked about her son Al-Hasan. Fatima kept the boy inside for a while. I thought she might be changing his clothes or giving him a bath. Later, the boy came out running, and the Prophet hugged and kissed him. Then he said, 'God should love this child and anyone who loves him'.

title: Prophet's Rule on Food Sales
content: In the time of the Prophet, people would buy food from caravans. The Prophet (ﷺ) said not to sell it in the same place you bought it. Wait until you take it to a market where food is sold. Also, if someone buys food and doesn't measure it exactly when they get it, they can't resell it.

title: Buying Food in Madinah
content: In the time of the Prophet, people would buy food from caravans. The Prophet (ﷺ) said not to sell it right away where you bought it. Wait until you take it to a market where food is sold. Also, if you buy something, make sure it's measured correctly before selling it.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Description
content: I met Abdullah bin Amr and asked him about the description of Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) in the Torah. He said: 'Yes, it says he is a witness to Allah's true religion, a bringer of good news to believers, and a warning to those who don't believe. It also calls him a guardian for people who can't read or write. The Torah describes him as humble, kind, and not harsh. He doesn't cause trouble in the markets and doesn't harm those who are mean to him. Instead, he forgives them and is kind. Allah will not let Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) die until he makes everyone straighten out their hearts by saying

title: Buying Food: Be Honest
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'When you buy food, don't sell it until you're sure the amount is correct.'

title: Prophet Helps with Debt
content: Jabir asked the Prophet to help his friend Abdullah who owed money to others. The Prophet (ﷺ) went to see them and said, 'Let's sort out the debts.' He asked Jabir to put their dates in separate heaps. When they arrived, the Prophet sat down among the heaps and told Jabir to measure out the dates for each person until all the debts were paid.

title: Measure Your Food for Blessings
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'When you measure your food, you will be blessed.'

title: Prophet Abraham's Sanctuary
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: 'Prophet Abraham made Mecca a safe place and asked Allah for blessings. I did the same with Medina, making it a safe place too. I asked Allah to bless its measures of food and water, just like Abraham did in Mecca.'

title: Blessing Measures in Medina
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: 'May Allah bless the measures used by the people of Medina. Bless their Mudd and Sa.' He meant the people living in Medina.

title: Buying Food Without Measuring
content: Salim's father said he saw people buying food without measuring or weighing during the Prophet's time. If they sold it before taking it home, they were punished.

title: Don't Sell Food Before Measuring
content: Ibn Abbas said that the Prophet forbade selling food before it's measured and given to you. I asked him, 'What does this mean?' He replied, 'It's like selling money for money, because the food hasn't been handed over yet.'

title: Don't Sell Before Receiving
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: When you buy food, don't sell it until you have received it and taken possession of it.

title: Prohibition of Usury
content: Malik bin Aus asked his friend Talha if he had any change. Talha said that he would have some when their storekeeper returned from the forest. Malik then told us about a conversation with Umar, who was a companion of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ). The Prophet (ﷺ) said: 'If you exchange gold for gold, it's not allowed unless you give an equal amount directly to each other. The same goes for exchanging wheat grain for wheat grain, dates for dates, and barley for barley.'

title: Prophet's Rule on Selling Food
content: Ibn Abbas said the Prophet forbade selling food before getting it. He thinks all sales should be like this.

title: Measure Food Before Selling
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: When buying food, do not sell it until you have measured it first.

title: Buying Food Without Measuring
content: Ibn Umar said that during the time of Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ), people would buy food without checking its weight or quantity. If they tried to sell it before taking it home, they were punished by being beaten.

title: Prophet visits Abu Bakr's house
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) visited Abu Bakr's house every day. When he got permission to move to Medina, he came at noon and said 'Don't stay in your home'. Abu Bakr said his two daughters were there, so the Prophet said he had been given permission to leave. Abu Bakr wanted to go with him and offered one of his camels for the journey. The Prophet (ﷺ) accepted it on the condition that he would pay its price.

title: Don't Force Someone to Buy
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: Don't tell someone they have to buy something from you instead of another seller. Let them choose where they want to shop.

title: Forbidden Business Practices
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) forbade a town person from selling goods on behalf of someone who lives in the desert. He also said it's not allowed to try to get someone to return something so you can sell them your own thing. You should respect an engagement between two people and not ask for their hand in marriage if they're already promised to someone else. A woman should not try to cause another woman to be divorced, just because she wants her husband.

title: Manumitted Slave Sold for Debt
content: Jabir bin Abdullah said: A man wanted to free his slave after he died. Later, the Prophet needed money and took the slave. He asked who would buy it from him. Nu'aim bought the slave for a certain price, and the Prophet gave him the slave.

title: Allah's Messenger Forbids Najsh
content: Ibn Umar said that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) forbade a practice called Najsh. We don't know what it was, but he told people not to do it.

title: Prohibition on Certain Sales
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) forbade a type of sale called 'Habal-al-Habala. In this deal, one person pays for a female camel that has not yet been born. The payment is based on the price of an existing female camel's offspring.

title: Forbidden Sales
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said that selling clothes by throwing them to someone without letting them see or touch is not allowed. Also, buying something just by touching it without looking at it is also forbidden.

title: Prophet's Advice on Dressing
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: 'Do not sit with your legs crossed while wearing only one piece of clothing. Do not wear a single garment and lift it up to your shoulders. Also, do not sell goods that are not yours or sell something but then take back what you gave.'

title: Prohibition on Two Types of Sale
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) forbade selling by Mulamasa and Munabadha.

title: Forbidden Clothes and Sales
content: Abu Sa'id said the Prophet forbade wearing two kinds of clothes. He also forbade two types of sales: Mulamasa and Munabadha.

title: Don't Leave Animals Unmilked
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: Don't keep camels and sheep without milking them for a long time. If you buy an animal, you can milk it and then decide to keep it or return it to the seller with one Sa of dates.

title: Returning a Sheep
content: If you buy a sheep that hasn't been milked for a long time, you can return it and get one Sa of dates instead. The Prophet (ﷺ) said not to meet the seller on the way because they might sell their goods too cheaply.

title: Fair Trade and Buying Goods
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said: Don't rush to meet a caravan coming from the desert. Don't tell buyers to cancel their purchases so you can sell your own goods instead. A town person should not cheat a desert person by selling them low-quality goods. If someone buys an animal that hasn't been milked for a long time, they have two choices: return it with some dates or keep it.

title: Buying and Milking a Sheep
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: If you buy a sheep that hasn't been milked for a long time, you can keep it if you're happy with it. But if you're not satisfied, you can return it to the seller. However, you must give them one Sa of dates as payment for the milk.

title: Punishment for Slave-Girl
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: If a slave-girl does something wrong and it's proven, her owner should punish her. He shouldn't blame or shame her after that. If she does it again, he should punish her again, but not blame her. If she keeps doing it, the owner can sell her.

title: Lashing and Selling a Slave
content: Abu Huraira and Zaid bin Khalid asked the Prophet about a slave-girl who was not married. If she had sex with someone without permission, he said to lash her once. If she did it again, lash her another time. But if she did it three times, sell her, even for a very small price.

title: Lashing and Selling a Slave
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) was asked about a slave-girl who had sex outside marriage. He said to lash her if she did it once, again if she did it twice, and sell her as a servant if she did it three times.

title: Manumitting a Slave Girl
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) came to me. I told him about a slave girl named Barirah. He said, 'Buy her and set her free.' Later that evening, he stood up and praised Allah. Then he said, 'Some people make rules not found in the Quran. If someone makes a rule not from Allah's laws, it is invalid, no matter how many they make. Allah's rules are always more important.

title: Barirah's Freedom of Choice
content: Aisha wanted to buy a slave named Barirah. The Prophet (ﷺ) went out for prayer and when he came back, Aisha told him that her masters wouldn't sell Barirah unless they kept control over her after she was freed. The Prophet (ﷺ) said that the person who frees someone gets control, not the previous owners.

title: Jarir's Pledge of Allegiance
content: I gave a promise to the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ). I promised to: believe in one God and him as his messenger, pray regularly, give charity, listen and obey, and advise other Muslims.

title: Don't be a Broker
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: 'Do not buy things from caravans without them knowing the price. A town person should not sell goods for someone who lives in the desert on their behalf.'

title: No Selling Desert Goods
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said it's not allowed for a person from the city to buy goods from someone who lives in the desert.

title: Don't Try to Outbid Someone
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: A buyer should not try to get a seller to sell something back to them so they can buy it. Also, don't cheat by selling goods from one place as if they came from another.

title: Don't Sell to Travelers
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) told us not to sell goods to people who travel from the desert. He said it's not allowed for a town dweller to sell things to someone who comes from the desert.

title: Meeting Caravans is Forbidden
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said it's not allowed to meet caravans on the road. Also, a town person can't sell goods for someone who lives in the desert.

title: No Broker for Deserts
content: I asked Ibn `Abbas about a rule. He said it means you can't act as an agent for someone from the desert to buy or sell in a town.

title: Returning Animals and Market Rules
content: If you buy an animal that hasn't been milked for a long time, you can return it. But if you keep it, you have to give the owner one Sa of dates as well. The Prophet (ﷺ) also said not to meet with someone who is selling goods on their way out of the market.

title: Don't Cancel Deals
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said: Don't try to cancel each other's purchases. Wait for the caravan to reach the market before buying from it.

title: Prophet's Rule on Selling Food
content: Abdullah said that when they met a caravan, they would buy food from them. The Prophet (ﷺ) told them not to sell the food until it reached the market.

title: Selling Food Before Buying
content: Some people were buying food at the market and selling it right away. The Prophet (ﷺ) told them not to sell it until they took it back to their own shops or homes.

title: Barira's Freedom and Wala'
content: Aisha said that Barira came to her with a problem. Barira had agreed to pay her masters nine pieces of gold, one piece each year, but she wanted Aisha to have the right to be her guardian after she was freed. However, her masters refused this offer. The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) heard about this and told Aisha to buy Barira and make sure that her guardianship would belong to Aisha when she was free. Aisha did this. Then the Prophet stood up in front of everyone and said: 'Any conditions that are not in Allah's Book are not valid, even if there were many. The decisions of Allah are always right.'

title: Aisha Buys a Slave Girl
content: Aisha wanted to buy a slave girl and set her free. But the girl's owners said they would only sell her if Aisha agreed that after she was freed, the owners would still have some control over her. Aisha told the Prophet about this. He said it shouldn't stop her from buying the girl because when someone is set free, their freedom belongs to them, not to anyone else.

title: Prophet's Rule on Fair Trade
content: Ibn Umar said the Prophet said: Trading wheat for wheat is not allowed unless you give equal amounts directly from hand to hand. The same rule applies to trading barley and dates, only allowing fair trade if it's done in person with equal amounts.

title: Prohibition on Unfair Trade
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) forbade selling fresh dates for old dried ones by weight and fresh grapes for old dried ones by weight.

title: Prophet forbids unfair trading
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) forbade a type of unfair trading called Muzabana. This is when someone sells fresh fruit without measuring it, and agrees to receive payment by weight or measure. If the buyer gets more than they paid for, the extra goes to the seller. But if the buyer gets less, the seller keeps the difference. The Prophet (ﷺ) allowed selling fruits on trees after estimating their weight.

title: Prophet Forbids Unfair Trading
content: Ibn Umar said the Prophet forbade selling fresh fruit without measuring it. If you sell something by weight or measure, and what you get is more than the fruit, you keep the extra. But if you get less, that's your loss. However, when fruits are ripe, you can sell them based on an estimate of how much they will weigh.

title: Talha's Usurious Deal
content: Malik bin Aus needed to exchange his gold for cash. Talha agreed to help him, but before giving him the money, he said he had to wait for his storekeeper to come from the forest. Meanwhile, Umar overheard their conversation and reminded Malik that selling one type of gold for another is usury unless it's done directly from hand to hand and in equal amounts.

title: Fair Trade in Gold and Silver
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said: Don't sell gold for gold unless it's the same weight. Don't sell silver for silver unless it's the same weight. But you can sell gold for silver or silver for gold if you like.

title: Equal Weights in Trading
content: Abu Sa'id heard the Prophet say: 'Don't trade gold for gold unless it's exactly the same weight. Don't trade silver unless it's exactly the same weight.'

title: Fair Trade in Gold and Silver
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: 'When selling gold or silver, make sure the weights are equal. Don't sell less for more or more for less. Only exchange what is present at the same time.'

title: No Riba in Money Exchange
content: Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri said it's okay to exchange one Dinar for another or one Dirham for another. I asked Ibn Abbas about this, and he said he didn't hear the Prophet say this or see it in the Quran. He told me that Usama informed him that the Prophet said there is no Riba (interest) if money is exchanged hand-to-hand, without a delay.

title: No Riba in Exchange
content: Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri said it's okay to exchange one Dinar for another or one Dirham for another. I asked Ibn Abbas if the Prophet had said this, and he replied that Usama told him the Prophet said there is no interest when money is exchanged directly from hand to hand.

title: No Credit Gold-Silver Trade
content: Abu Al-Minhal asked two men about trading silver for gold on credit. Both said it's not a good idea and that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) forbade this practice.

title: No Credit Gold-Silver Trade
content: Abu Al-Minhal asked two companions about trading silver for gold on credit. Both said it was not good and that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) forbade this practice.

title: Prophet's Rule on Gold and Silver
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) forbade selling gold for gold or silver for silver unless they are exactly the same weight. He allowed us to sell gold for silver, but we must be fair in our prices.

title: When to Sell Dates
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: Don't sell fresh dates until they're ripe and safe from spoilage. You can trade them for dry dates or other fresh fruits, but not any other way of selling.

title: Don't Sell Spoiled Fruits
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: Don't sell fresh fruits until they're safe from rotting or damage. Also, don't trade fresh dates for dry ones. Later, he allowed selling ripe fruit on trees for either fresh or dried dates in a special market.

title: Prohibition on Unfair Trade
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) forbade selling fresh dates for dried ones by measure and also selling fresh grapes for dried ones by measure.

title: Prohibition on Selling Unripe Dates
content: Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri said that the Prophet forbade two things: selling ripe dates for unripe ones and checking the quality of goods before buying them. Muzabana means selling ripe dates in exchange for dates still growing on trees.

title: Prophet Forbids Two Practices
content: Ibn Abbas said the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) forbade two things: Muzabana and Muhaqala. He didn't explain what they were, but he made it clear that Muslims should not do them.

title: Selling Fruits by Estimation
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) allowed the owner of 'Araya to sell fruits from trees without measuring them. He could estimate how much each person should get.

title: Prophet's Rule on Selling Fruits
content: Jabir said the Prophet forbade selling fruits before they're ripe. You can only sell them for money, like dinars or dirhams. But you can trade dates from 'Araya trees for other dates.

title: Sale of 'Araya Dates
content: Abu Huraira said the Prophet allowed selling dates from 'Araya if they are no more than five Wasaq, which is sixty Sa's in total.

title: Selling Fresh Fruits
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) forbade selling fresh dates for dried ones. However, it is allowed to sell fruits on 'Araya by estimating their value. This way, the new owners can eat the fresh dates immediately.

title: Buying Fruits with Dates
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) allowed people to buy 'Araya dates by estimating their value based on the number of dried dates. People used to trade fruits, but sometimes they would claim that the fruit was spoiled or diseased after buying it. The Prophet (ﷺ) advised them not to sell fruits before they were ripe and easy to see. Zaid bin Thabit, a companion of the Prophet, only sold his land's fruits when the Pleiades star appeared in the sky and you could tell which fruits were ripe.

title: Prohibition on Selling Unripe Fruits
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) forbade selling fruits until they are ripe. He said both the seller and buyer should not do this kind of sale.

title: Forbidding Unripe Date Sales
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said it's not allowed to sell unripe dates. They should be red and ready to eat before selling them.

title: Prophet forbids selling unripe dates
content: Jabir bin Abdullah said the Prophet told him not to sell date fruits until they are ripe and ready to eat.

title: Prophet's Rule on Selling Fruits
content: Anas bin Malik said the Prophet forbade selling fruits until they are ripe. He also said you can't sell date palms until their dates turn red and yellow. Someone asked him what 'red and yellow' means, and he replied that it means almost ripe.

title: Don't Sell Unripe Fruits
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said to Anas bin Malik: Don't sell fruits until they're almost ripe. When asked what 'almost ripe' means, he replied, 'Until they turn red.' He also said, if Allah makes the fruit bad, it's not right for one person to take money from another.

title: Buying Fruits Before They Ripen
content: If someone buys fruits before they are ripe and they go bad because of disease, the seller is responsible for the loss. The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: 'Don't sell or buy fruits until you can see if they're good to eat. And don't trade fresh dates for dried ones.'

title: Prophet's Debt to a Jew
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) bought food from a Jewish man on credit. He used his armor as collateral for the debt.

title: No Usury in Trade
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) appointed a governor of Khaibar. The governor brought him good dates from there. He asked if all the dates were like that. The governor said no, they traded one type for two others or two for three. The Prophet (ﷺ) told them not to do that, as it was usury. Instead, sell bad dates for money and use that money to buy good ones.

title: No Usury in Trade
content: The Prophet 's (ﷺ) Messenger appointed a governor of Khaibar. The governor brought him some good dates from there. He asked, 'Are all the dates like this?' The governor replied, 'No, we trade one Sa of these for two Sas of ours and two Sas of theirs for three of ours.' The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Don't do that. Instead, sell your bad dates for money and use that to buy good ones'.

title: Pollinated Date Palms
content: If you sell a date palm that has been pollinated and the contract doesn't mention its fruits, the person who did the pollination gets to keep the fruit. The same rule applies if you're buying a slave or a farm worker.

title: Selling Pollinated Date Palms
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: If you sell date palms that have already produced fruit, the buyer gets the fruit unless he agrees with the seller to keep it for himself.

title: Prohibited Trade Deals
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) forbade trading in ungathered dates for measured dried dates or fresh grapes for measured dried grapes. He also forbade trading standing crops for a set amount of food.

title: Date Palm Ownership
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: If you plant date palms and then sell them to someone, the fruits will belong to you unless you agree with the buyer that they should own the fruits.

title: Prohibited Practices
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) forbade five practices: Muhaqala, Mukhadara, Mulamasa, Munabadha and Muzabana.

title: Prophet forbids selling unripe dates
content: Anas said the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) forbade people from selling dates until they were almost ripe. We asked Anas what 'almost ripe' meant, and he said it's when they turn red or yellow. The Prophet (ﷺ) added that if Allah took away all the fruit on trees, a seller wouldn't have any right to take money from someone else.

title: The Prophet's Favorite Tree
content: Ibn Umar was with the Prophet while he ate fresh dates. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'There is a tree that looks like a good Muslim.' Ibn Umar wanted to say it was the date palm, but he kept quiet. The Prophet (ﷺ) then said, 'It is the date palm'.

title: Allah's Messenger Gets Cupped
content: Anas bin Malik said that Abu Taiba cupped Allah's Messenger (ﷺ). As a result, Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) ordered his masters to give Abu Taiba one Sa of dates. He also told them to reduce Abu Taiba's tax.

title: Taking Money from Husband
content: Hind asked the Prophet about taking money from her husband Abu Sufyan without his knowledge. The Prophet (ﷺ) said she and her sons could take what they needed reasonably and fairly.

title: Guardians of Orphaned Children
content: Aisha said that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) received a message from Allah about taking care of orphaned children. The message is: if you're rich, don't take money for looking after them, but if you're poor, you can take what's fair and reasonable for your work.

title: Pre-emption in Shared Property
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) told Jabir that when people share a property, the other person has the right to buy your part if you want to sell. But if the boundaries of the property are clear or paths and streets are marked out, then there's no pre-emption.

title: Pre-emption in Shared Property
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) decided that people can claim a share of land if it's not clearly divided. But if the boundaries are clear or there are fixed paths, then no one can claim pre-emption.

title: Three Men in a Cave
content: One day, three friends were walking when it started raining. They had to take shelter in a cave on a mountain. A big rock blocked the entrance. They said, 'Let's ask Allah to help us.' One friend said, 'I used to take care of my parents and family by giving them milk from our animals. I once delayed coming home and they were hungry. If I did that for Allah's sake, please help us.' The rock moved a bit. The second friend said, 'I fell in love with a cousin but she asked me to marry her first. I respected her wish and left her. If I did that for Allah's sake, please help us.' Two-thirds of the rock was removed. Then the third friend said, 'A worker wouldn't take his pay from me, so I used it to buy cows and a shepherd. The man came back asking for his money, but I told him to keep the animals. If I did that sincerely for Allah's sake, please help us.' The rock was completely removed.

title: Buying a Sheep
content: Abdur-Rahman bin Abu Bakr was with the Prophet. A man came with his sheep. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked if they were for sale or gifts. The man said they were for sale. The Prophet (ﷺ) bought one of the sheep.

title: Abraham and Sarah's Story
content: Prophet Abraham was traveling with his wife Sarah. They came to a village ruled by a king or a powerful man. The king asked Abraham who Sarah was. Abraham said she was his sister, but then told her not to contradict him. He sent her back to the king. When the king met Sarah, she washed and prayed before talking to him. She asked Allah for help if she had truly believed in Him and His messenger, and protected herself from everyone except her husband. The king became ill and agitated twice, but each time he recovered. Finally, he said Abraham's wife was a troublemaker and should be taken back to him with a servant girl as a gift.

title: Boy's Parentage Dispute
content: Sa'd and Abu bin Zam'a argued over a boy. Sa'd said the boy was his nephew. Abu bin Zam'a said the boy was his brother, born from their father's slave-girl. The Prophet (ﷺ) looked at the boy and saw he resembled Sa'd's uncle. He decided the boy belonged to Abu bin Zam'a. The Prophet (ﷺ) also told Sauda to stay away from the boy.

title: Suhaib's Family Ties
content: Sa'd's father said that Abdur-Rahman bin Auf told Suhaib to be careful and not claim someone else as his father. Suhaib replied that he wouldn't lie even if he was given a lot of money, because the truth is that he was kidnapped when he was a child.

title: Good Deeds Before Islam
content: Hakim bin Hizam asked the Prophet: 'I used to do good things before I was Muslim. Like helping my family and freeing slaves. Will I get a reward for those?' The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'You became Muslim with all your past good deeds.'

title: Using Dead Animals Wisely
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) saw a dead sheep. He asked people if they could use its skin. They said it was already dead. The Prophet (ﷺ) replied, 'It's okay to use its skin, but you can't eat it.'

title: Jesus' Return as a Ruler
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said: 'By the One who controls my life, Jesus, son of Mary, will soon come among you. He will be a fair leader and do three things: he'll get rid of crosses, stop people from eating pork, and end the tax that non-Muslims pay to live in Muslim areas. Then there will be plenty of money, but no one will accept charity.'

title: Umar Finds a Man Selling Alcohol
content: Ibn `Abbas told me that Umar heard about someone selling alcohol. Umar said, 'May Allah curse him!' and added, 'He should know that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said,

title: Allah's Curse on the Jews
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: Allah is unhappy with the Jews. They were told not to eat fat, but they sold it and used the money instead.

title: Making Pictures is Forbidden
content: Ibn Abbas was with a student who made pictures for a living. The student asked Ibn Abbas about his work and if it was allowed by Allah's Messenger (ﷺ). Ibn Abbas said, 'Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said that anyone who makes pictures will be punished by Allah until they can bring the picture to life. But no one can do that.' The student looked sad when he heard this. Ibn Abbas advised him to draw only things that don't move, like trees.

title: Alcohol Trade Banned
content: When the last verses of Surat-al-Baqara were revealed, the Prophet went out of his house and said that selling alcohol was now forbidden.

title: Three People Allah Will Punish
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: Allah says He will be against three types of people on the Day of Resurrection. One who breaks a promise made in His name, one who sells someone as a slave and keeps the money, and one who works someone without paying them their wages.

title: Safiya's Marriage to the Prophet
content: Anas said that Safiya was among the captives. She was first given to a man named Dihya Al-Kalbi, but then she was married to the Prophet.

title: Coitus Interruptus and Destiny
content: Abu Sa'id was sitting with the Prophet. He asked, 'What about when we have sex with our female captives? We're interested in their value.' The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'You do that? It's better not to. No one will be born if Allah doesn't want them to be.

title: The Prophet Sells a Slave
content: Jabir said the Prophet sold a slave who was owned by someone else. The owner needed money and had given permission for the sale to be made on their behalf.

title: Selling a Slave
content: Jabir bin Abdullah said that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) sold a slave who was free to go after being bought. The slave could choose his own master or be freed if he wanted.

title: Flogging an Unmarried Slave
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) was asked about a slave-girl who had sex outside of marriage. He said to flog her the first time, and if she does it again, flog her once more. If she does it a third time, sell her.

title: Flogging for Adultery
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) was asked about a slave-girl who had sex outside of marriage. He said: 'Beat her, and if she does it again, beat her once more. If she does it three or four times, sell her'.

title: Punishment for Adultery
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said that if a slave girl commits adultery and it's proven, she should be punished with lashes. If she does it again, she'll be punished with lashes once more. But if she does it three times, she can be sold as a slave.

title: Prophet's Marriage to Safiya
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) came to a place called Khaibar and won the battle. He saw that a woman named Safiya, whose husband had been killed, was still a new bride. The Prophet (ﷺ) chose her as his wife and took her with him until they reached a place where she could get married. They prepared food on a small leather sheet and invited others to join them for the wedding feast. After the feast, they continued their journey to Medina. During the trip, the Prophet would cover Safiya with a cloak when she rode behind him on his camel.

title: Forbidden Foods Announced
content: Jabir bin Abdullah said that Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: 'Allah and I have made it haram to eat or sell alcohol, dead animals, pigs, and idols. People asked about the fat of dead animals used for boats and lights. He replied, 'It's also haram.' The Prophet (ﷺ) cursed the Jews, saying Allah had forbidden them from eating fat, but they melted it down and sold it instead.

title: Forbidden Earnings
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) forbade taking money from selling a dog. He also said it's not allowed to earn money through prostitution or by being a fortune teller who claims to have special knowledge of the future.

title: Prohibited Practices
content: My father bought a slave who was a cupper. He broke the slave's cupping instruments and said that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) had forbidden taking money for blood, the price of a dog, or a prostitute's earnings. The Prophet (ﷺ) also cursed those who get tattoos or are tattooed, those who eat usury, and those who make pictures.

title: Paying in Advance for Fruits
content: When Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) came to Medina, people were paying money before receiving fruits that would be delivered later. He said: 'If you pay in advance, make sure it's for a specific amount of fruit.'

title: Paying in Advance
content: When the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) came to Medina, people were paying for dates before they were even harvested. He said that if you pay in advance, it should be based on a specific amount and weight for a set time.

title: Prophet's Advice on Payment
content: When the Prophet came to Medina, he told people that they should pay money in advance using a known measure, weight, and time period.

title: Abu Bakr and Umar's Payment
content: Two men, Abdullah bin Shaddad and Abu Burda, disagreed about how to pay for food. They asked me to ask Ibn Abi Aufa what they used to do in the time of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ). He said that when he was alive, people like Abu Bakr and Umar would pay for wheat, barley, grapes, and dates before they were delivered.

title: Paying for Goods in Advance
content: Abdullah bin Shaddad and Abu Burda disagreed about paying money before goods were delivered. They asked me to ask Ibn Abi Aufa what they used to do during the time of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ), Abu Bakr, and Umar. I went to see Ibn Abi Aufa and he said that in those days, people would pay for wheat, barley, grapes, and dates before receiving them.

title: Paying for Food in Advance
content: Abdullah bin Shaddad and Abu Burda asked me to ask Abdullah bin Abi Aufa if people used to pay for food before it was ready. He said they paid peasants from Sham for wheat, barley, and olive oil. I asked if the price was paid to those who had the food already. He said no, they didn't ask about that. Then I asked Abdur Rahman bin Abza, and he said the Prophet's companions used to send money in advance for delivery later.

title: Paying for Food in Advance
content: Some people used to pay for wheat and barley before they were delivered. They also paid in advance for oil and dried grapes.

title: Forbidding Sale of Unripe Dates
content: Abu Bakhtari asked Ibn Abbas about selling dates from palm trees. Ibn Abbas said the Prophet forbade selling dates until they were ready to eat and could be weighed. A man asked how to weigh them if still on the tree. Another man replied that you should wait until they're cut and stored.

title: Prophet's Rule on Selling Dates
content: Abu Al-Bakhtari asked Ibn Umar about selling dates before they're ripe. Ibn Umar said the Prophet forbade selling them until they're good to eat and can be measured. Abu Al-Bakhtari also asked Ibn Abbas, who gave the same answer: don't sell dates until they're ready to eat.

title: Prophet's Rules on Selling Dates
content: Abu Al-Bakhtari asked Ibn Umar about selling dates. Ibn Umar said the Prophet forbade selling dates until they are ripe and good to eat. He also said the Prophet forbade selling silver for gold on credit. Abu Al-Bakhtari asked Ibn Abbas the same question, and he gave the same answer.

title: Prophet's Rules for Date Sales
content: Abu Al-Bakhtari asked Ibn Umar about selling dates. Ibn Umar said the Prophet forbade selling date fruits until they're ripe and ready to eat. He also said the Prophet didn't allow people to buy silver on credit to sell for gold. Abu Al-Bakhtari asked Ibn Abbas the same question. Ibn Abbas replied that the Prophet forbade selling dates until they were mature and could be weighed. When asked how to weigh them, a man nearby explained it means after cutting and storing.

title: Prophet's Rules for Selling Dates
content: Abu Al-Bakhtari asked Ibn Umar about selling dates. Ibn Umar said the Prophet forbade selling dates until they are ripe and ready to eat. He also said the Prophet forbade trading silver for gold on credit. Abu Al-Bakhtari asked Ibn Abbas the same question. Ibn Abbas replied that the Prophet forbade selling dates until they are fit to be weighed. Someone nearby explained that 'weighed' means after they're cut and stored.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Debt
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) bought some food from a Jewish man on credit. He used his iron armor as a guarantee to pay back the debt.

title: Mortgaging in Salam
content: Some people were discussing a business deal called 'Salam' at the home of Ibrahim. They asked him about it, and he said that Aisha told him that the Prophet bought some food from a Jew on credit. The payment was due by a certain time, and as security for the loan, the Prophet gave the Jew his iron armor.

title: Prophet's Advice on Buying Fruits
content: When the Prophet came to Medina, people were paying for fruits in advance that would be delivered later. The Prophet (ﷺ) said: 'Buy fruits by paying now, but they must be given to you with a fixed amount within a set time.'

title: War Booty and Trade
content: Two men, Abu Burda and Abdullah bin Shaddad, sent me to ask two other men about how things were done in the past. They told us that when they were with the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ), they would get war spoils. Sometimes, farmers from Syria would come and they would pay them for wheat, barley, and oil before it was even harvested. I asked if the farmers already had crops growing, but they said no one ever asked them about that.

title: War Booty and Trade
content: Two companions, Abu Burda and Abdullah bin Shaddad, sent me to ask two other companions, Abdur Rahman bin Abza and Abdullah bin Abi Aufa, about the past. They said they used to get war spoils when fighting with the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ). When farmers from Syria came, they would pay them in advance for wheat, barley, and oil to be delivered later. I asked if these farmers owned crops already, but they said no one ever asked them that.

title: Prophet Forbids Certain Sales
content: Abdullah said the Prophet stopped people from selling camels in a certain way. This was called Habal-al-Habala. Nafi explained that it meant the seller would give the camel to the buyer after its female had given birth.

title: Pre-emption in Shared Property
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) gave a verdict that if two people share something equally, like a house or land, one person can't take more of it just because they got there first. But if the boundaries are clear and paths are marked, then this rule doesn't apply.

title: Sa'd Buys Two Houses
content: I was with my friend Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas when Al-Miswar came and put his hand on my shoulder. Then Abu Rafi', the Prophet's freed slave, asked Sa'd to buy two houses from him. Sa'd said he wouldn't pay more than four thousand Dirhams in installments. But Abu Rafi' had been offered five hundred Dinars for them. He remembered the Prophet saying that neighbors have priority because of their closeness. So he sold the houses to Sa'd.

title: Giving Gifts to Neighbors
content: I asked the Prophet about giving gifts to my two neighbors. He said, 'Give a gift to the one who lives closer to you'.

title: Honest Treasurer is Charitable
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: The person in charge of money who gives what they're told to give, is one of two people who are kind. The other kind person is the owner themselves.

title: Employment and Asking for Jobs
content: I went to the Prophet with two men from Ash`ari tribe. I told him they wanted a job, but he said we don't appoint anyone who asks strongly for it.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Early Life
content: Abu Huraira said the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) told him that Allah sent prophets to help people. The Prophet (ﷺ) said he used to take care of sheep in Mecca for some money, called Qirats.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Guide
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) and Abu Bakr hired a man from the Bani Ad-Dail tribe to guide them. He was an expert guide, but he broke his agreement with another tribe called Al-`Asi bin Wail. Despite this, the Prophet and Abu Bakr trusted him and gave him their camels. They told him to bring the camels back after three days to a place called the Cave of Thaur. The man did as they asked and brought the camels back on time. Then, the Prophet, Abu Bakr, another guide named Amir bin Fuhaira, and this hired guide all set out together from Mecca towards the sea.

title: Prophet's Journey with Guide
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) and Abu Bakr hired a man from the Bani-Ad-Dil tribe to guide them. He was not Muslim yet, but they trusted him. They gave him two camels and asked him to bring them back in three days to the Cave of Thaur.

title: Fighting in Tabuk
content: I fought with the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) in a battle called Ghazwa of Tabuk. I think that was my best deed. Later, one of my employees got into a fight and bit someone's finger, causing his own tooth to fall out. He went to complain to the Prophet, but the Prophet said no, it wasn't fair for him to expect the other person to let him bite his finger like a wild camel snaps its jaws.

title: Fighting in Tabuk and Justice
content: I fought with the Prophet in a battle. I think that was my best deed. Later, my employee got into an argument with someone. He bit the other person's finger so hard it cut it. The other person lost a tooth too. My employee went to the Prophet for help, but the Prophet said no to his complaint. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked him, 'Did you expect the other man to let his hand in your mouth?' A similar thing happened with Abu Bakr. A man bit another's hand and broke his own tooth. But Abu Bakr said the first man didn't deserve any compensation.

title: Moses and Al-Khadir Fix a Wall
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said to his companion Ubai bin Ka'b: Moses and Al-Khadir were walking together when they saw a wall that was about to fall. Al-Khadir pointed at the wall, then put out his hand and it became straight again. Moses asked him, 'If you wanted, you could have been paid for fixing it.' Al-Khadir replied, 'I would use the money to buy food.'

title: Work and Reward
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Imagine a man who hired workers for different jobs. He asked the Jews to work from morning till midday for one unit of reward. They agreed and did it. Then he asked the Christians to work from midday till afternoon prayer for one unit of reward. They also agreed. Finally, he asked Muslims to work from afternoon till sunset for two units of reward. The Jews and Christians got upset because they were working less but getting paid more. Allah said, 'Did I take anything from you?' They said no. He replied, 'This is My blessing, given to whoever I choose.'

title: Work and Reward
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said: 'Imagine you hired workers for a job. The Jews worked until midday for one unit of reward, the Christians worked until afternoon prayer time for one unit of reward, but Muslims work from afternoon prayer to sunset and get two units of reward. The Jews and Christians complained that they were working harder but getting less pay. Allah asked them if He had taken anything from their rights, and they said no. Then Allah said, 'This is My blessing, I give it to whoever I choose.'

title: Three Types of Opponents
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: Allah will be against three types of people on the Day of Judgment. One who makes a promise in Allah's name but breaks it. One who sells someone who is free and eats their money. And one who hires someone to work, takes all their effort, but doesn't pay them.

title: Guidance is like a Job
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: 'Imagine you hired workers to do a job for you. They worked until midday and then wanted out, saying they didn't want the agreed-upon pay for their work so far. You told them to finish the job and get paid what was promised. But they refused. You hired another group of workers who finished the rest of the day's work and got paid for both groups' work.
