This is like how some people accept guidance willingly, while others don't want it until it's too late.'

title: Three Men in a Cave
content: Abdullah bin Umar said he heard the Prophet say that three men from before him went into a cave. A big rock blocked their way out, so they prayed to Allah, reminding Him of good things they had done. The first man said, 'I always gave my parents milk before my family.' He asked Allah for help if he did it only for His sake. The rock moved a little, but they couldn't get out. The second man said, 'I was kind to my cousin even when she refused me.' When she needed money in a hard time, he helped her and left the gold he gave her. He asked Allah for help if he did it only for His sake. Again, the rock moved a little but they couldn't get out. The third man said, 'I paid all my workers except one. I used his wages to earn more money.' When the worker came back, he took everything and left nothing. The man asked Allah for help if he did it only for His sake. This time, the rock moved completely and they were able to walk out of the cave.

title: Earning Charity with Hard Work
content: When the Prophet ordered us to give charity, we would go to the market and work hard as porters. We earned just a small amount of food. Now, some of us have a lot of money - one hundred thousand Dirhams or Dinars.

title: Prophet's Rule on Trade
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said that it is not allowed for a person from the city to sell goods for someone who lives in the desert. This means they should not act as an agent or broker for them.

title: Khabbab's Encounter with Al-'As
content: I was a blacksmith. I did some work for Al-'As bin Wail. He owed me money, so I went to him to ask for it back. He said, 'I won't pay you unless you stop believing in Muhammad (ﷺ).' I said, 'No way! I'll never do that until you die and come back to life.' He asked, 'Will I be dead and then brought back to life?' I said, 'Yes.' Then he said, 'When that happens, I'll have property and children, and I'll pay you what I owe.' But Allah revealed a verse saying: 'Have you seen someone who doesn't believe in Our messages, and thinks they will get wealth and children?'

title: Companions Help a Sick Arab
content: Some of the Prophet's companions were traveling when they met an Arab tribe. They asked to stay as guests, but the tribe refused. Later that night, the tribe's chief was bitten by a snake and got worse. The tribe went to the companions and asked if they knew anything to help their chief. One of the companions said he could recite a special prayer, but only if they paid him for it. They agreed to pay a flock of sheep. The companion then recited Surat-ul-Fatiha over the chief, who got better right away. When the companions went back to the Prophet and told him what happened, he was happy with how they handled the situation. He said they did the right thing and asked them to divide the money they earned among themselves, including a share for him.

title: Prophet's Treatment by Cupper
content: Anas bin Malik said: The Prophet (ﷺ) was cupped. He paid the person who did it one or two Sas of food. He also asked his masters to lower his taxes.

title: Prophet Paid for Cupping
content: Ibn Abbas said that when the Prophet was treated with cupping, he paid the person who did it his wages.

title: Prophet Paid for Cupping
content: Ibn Abbas said the Prophet was cupped. He paid the person who did it for their work. If it wasn't good, he wouldn't have paid them.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Habits
content: Anas said that the Prophet used to get a medical treatment called cupping. He also made sure to pay everyone their wages on time.

title: Cupping for the Prophet
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) sent for a man who did cupping. He was paid some food in return. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked his masters to reduce this man's taxes.

title: Prohibited Earnings
content: Abu Masud said the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) considered it wrong to earn money from selling dogs, from being a prostitute, or by working as a fortune teller.

title: Prophet forbids slave girl earnings
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said that it is not allowed to earn money from the work of slave girls who are forced into prostitution.

title: Prophet Forbids Animal Copulation
content: Ibn Umar said the Prophet forbade taking money for letting animals mate.

title: Land for Jewish Farmers
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) gave the land of Khaibar to the Jews. They were allowed to work on it and take half of what they grew. The Prophet (ﷺ) also said not to rent farms out. This agreement stayed in place until `Umar asked the Jews to leave Khaibar.

title: Land for Jewish Farmers
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) gave land to the Jews in Khaibar. They worked on it and got half of what they grew. This was a special agreement, not just renting. Later, 'Umar made them leave the land.

title: Procrastination in Debt is Unfair
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said that a rich person who delays paying debts is being unfair. If your debt is given to someone else who has money, you should agree to this transfer.

title: Procrastination in Debt
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said that a rich person who delays paying debts is being unfair. If you have to transfer your debt to someone richer, you should agree to this.

title: Praying for the Dead
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) was with his companions when a dead man was brought to them. They asked him to lead the funeral prayer, but he said, 'Is this person in debt?' They replied no. He led the prayer. Another dead man was brought and they asked him again to lead the prayer. Again, he asked if the person was in debt. This time, they said yes. He asked how much debt there was and they said three Dinars. He led the prayer. A third dead man was brought and they asked him to pray for this one too. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked about his debt again and was told it was also three Dinars. He refused to lead the prayer, saying 'Pray for your companion instead.' But Abu Qatada said he would pay the debt if the Prophet led the prayer. So, the Prophet agreed and led the funeral prayer.

title: Punishment for Adultery
content: Hamza's father was sent by 'Umar to collect charity. A man had sex with his wife's slave without permission. Hamza took sureties for the man until they reached 'Umar. 'Umar punished the man with 100 lashes. When 'Umar found out the man had already been punished, he excused him because he didn't know it was wrong. Jarir asked Ibn Mas'ud about people who leave Islam. They should be allowed to repent and find sureties from their family. If someone dies after being stood surety for, the person who gave surety is free from responsibility. But if they die while still responsible, the person who gave surety remains responsible.

title: Allah is Sufficient Witness
content: An Israeli man borrowed 1,000 Dinars from another. The lender asked for witnesses and a surety. The borrower said, 'Allah is enough as a witness.' He also said, 'Allah is enough as a surety.' The lender agreed. But the borrower couldn't find a way to repay the debt on time. So he put 1,000 Dinars and a letter in a piece of wood and threw it into the sea. He prayed, 'O Allah, you know I borrowed this money from so-and-so. He asked for witnesses and a surety, but I said you're enough.' The lender found the wood and used it as firewood. When he cut it open, he found his money inside. Later, the borrower arrived with 1,000 Dinars and said he had tried to find a boat to repay the debt. But Allah had already sent him the money in the piece of wood.

title: Brotherhood and Inheritance
content: Ibn Abbas said that when the Prophet established a bond of brotherhood between emigrants and Ansaris in Medina, it meant that an emigrant would inherit from an Ansari, but not the other way around. However, when Allah revealed a new verse saying 'To every one We have appointed heirs', this changed the rule about inheritance. The bond of brotherhood was still valid for things like cooperation and advice, but now people could leave their belongings to whoever they wanted in their will.

title: Abdur-Rahman Meets Sa'd
content: Anas said that Abdur-Rahman bin Auf came to meet the Prophet. The Prophet (ﷺ) made a brotherhood between Abdur-Rahman and Sa'd bin Rabi'a.

title: No Alliances in Islam
content: Anas bin Malik said the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said, 'There is no alliance in Islam.' He made an exception for Quraish and the Ansar, forming a temporary agreement between them in his house.

title: Leading Funeral Prayers
content: Salama bin Al-Akwa' told the Prophet that a dead person was brought to him so he could lead his funeral prayer. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked if the man owed any money. When they said no, he led the prayer. Another body was brought and he asked the same question. This time they said yes. He refused to lead the prayer himself but told others to do it. Abu Qatada offered to pay off the debt so the Prophet could lead the second funeral prayer.

title: The Prophet's Promise to Jabir
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said to me, 'If the money from Bahrain comes, I'll give you some.' The Prophet (ﷺ) passed away before the money arrived. When it came, Abu Bakr asked people who had been promised something by the Prophet to come forward. I went to see him and told him what the Prophet had promised me. He gave me 500 coins. Then he said, 'Take double that amount as well'.

title: Abu Bakr's Protection
content: Aisha said: When I was old enough to remember things, my parents were Muslim. The Prophet (ﷺ) visited us twice a day. When Muslims were persecuted, Abu Bakr went to Ethiopia with his friend Ibn Ad-Daghna, the chief of the Quraish tribe. They met and Ibn Ad-Daghna asked where he was going. Abu Bakr said he wanted to travel and worship Allah. Ibn Ad-Daghna said Abu Bakr wouldn't be turned out because he helped the poor and took care of his family. He offered to protect Abu Bakr, so Quraish agreed. They told Abu Bakr to pray at home and not cause trouble. But Abu Bakr built a mosque in his house and prayed there. Women and children would gather around him, and he couldn't help crying while reading the Quran. The pagan chiefs were worried that Abu Bakr's example might influence their families. They asked Ibn Ad-Daghna to tell Abu Bakr to stop or return the protection. Ibn Ad-Daghna went to Abu Bakr and said either follow the conditions or revoke his protection. Abu Bakr chose Allah's protection over Ibn Ad-Daghna's. When this happened, the Prophet was still in Mecca and told his companions that their emigration place had been shown to him. Some of them left for Medina, while others returned from Ethiopia. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked Abu Bakr to wait because he expected permission to leave. Abu Bakr waited four months, feeding two camels with Samor tree leaves.

title: Debt of a Dead Person
content: When a person who owes money dies, the Prophet would ask if they left anything to pay their debt. If yes, he'd lead their funeral prayer. But if not, he'd tell others to pray for them too. When the Prophet became rich from battles, he said that he should help pay off debts of poor Muslims who die with debts. He also said that any wealth a person leaves after they die goes to their family.

title: Distributing Saddle Belongings
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) told Ali to give away the saddles and animal skins from a cow he had slaughtered.

title: Sharing Extra Sheep
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) gave Uqba some sheep to share with his friends. When there was one extra male kid left, Uqba told the Prophet about it. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Offer this kid as a sacrifice for you.'

title: Protecting Umaiya's Life
content: I made an agreement with Umaiya bin Khalaf that we would look after each other's families in Mecca and Medina. When writing the contract, he asked me to use my old name instead of 'Ar-Rahman'. On the day of the Battle of Badr, I protected Umaiya from being caught by the Ansar. He was a fat man, so I told him to kneel down, and I lay on top of him to shield him. But the Ansar killed him anyway, and one of them hurt my foot with their sword.

title: Prophet's Advice on Trade
content: Abu Sa'id and Abu Huraira said the Prophet appointed a governor at Khaibar. When he came to Medina, he brought dates called Janib. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked if all Khaibar dates were like this. The man replied that they traded two bad dates for one good date or three bad dates for two. The Prophet (ﷺ) said not to do this, as it's usury. Instead, sell the bad dates for money and use that money to buy Janib.

title: Prophet's Advice on Trade
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) had a governor at Khaibar. When the governor came to Medina, he brought dates called Janib. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked if all Khaibar dates were like these. The governor said no, they traded two bad dates for one good date or three bad ones for two good ones. The Prophet (ﷺ) told him not to do this, as it's a kind of usury. Instead, sell the bad dates for money and use that money to buy Janib dates.

title: Slaughtering an Animal
content: Ibn Ka'b's father had some sheep that grazed at Sala'. A slave girl saw one dying and used a stone to kill it. Ibn Ka'b's father said, 'Wait until I ask the Prophet about this.' He asked the Prophet if they could eat the meat, and the Prophet said yes.

title: Giving Back What's Due
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) was owed a camel by someone. When the person came to ask for it back, the Prophet said 'Give him his camel'. They searched and found an older camel instead of one that matched the age. The Prophet (ﷺ) still said to give it to him. The man thanked the Prophet and said he had been given what was rightfully his. The Prophet (ﷺ) then said: 'The best person is the one who gives others their rights generously.'

title: Respecting Debtors and Creditors
content: A man came to the Prophet. He was demanding his money back and being very rude. The Prophet 's (ﷺ) friends wanted to stop him, but the Prophet said, 'Let him speak.' Then he said, 'Give him a camel that is as old as his debt.' They said, 'There isn't one like that.' But the Prophet said, 'Still give it to him. The best of us are those who pay others back generously'.

title: Returning Captives to Hawazin
content: When the people from the tribe of Hawazin came to the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) after they accepted Islam, he stood up. They asked him to return their properties and captives. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'You can choose either your properties or your captives back.' He had been waiting for them for over 10 days since returning from Taif. When they realized they only had two options, they chose to have their captives back. The Prophet (ﷺ) then spoke in front of the Muslim community, praising Allah. He said, 'These people have come with regret and I think it's good to return their captives. If you want to give up your share willingly, you can do so.' The people agreed to this and said they were happy to give up their shares for the Prophet. Then, the Prophet asked them to go back and discuss it with their leaders. After that, the leaders came back and told the Prophet that everyone was willing to give up their shares.

title: Returning Captives to Hawazin Tribe
content: When the people from the tribe of Hawazin came to the Prophet after becoming Muslim, he stood up. They asked him to return their belongings and family members who were being held captive. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'You have a choice: you can either get back your belongings or your captives.' He had been waiting for them for over 10 days since returning from Taif. When they realized the Prophet would only give them one option, they chose to get their captives back. The Prophet (ﷺ) then stood in front of the Muslim community and praised Allah. 'These people have come to you with regret,' he said. 'I think it's right to return their captives to them.' He told the Muslims that whoever wanted to give up their share willingly could do so, but if they wanted to wait until they received their share from future battles, that was okay too. The Muslim community agreed to give up their shares as a favor to the Prophet.

title: Prophet Muhammad Helps a Friend
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) was on a journey with his companions. I, Jabir, was riding a slow camel that couldn't keep up. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked me who I was and why my camel was lagging behind. I told him it was because of the camel's slowness. He asked if I had a stick to hit the camel with its owner. I said yes, so he took the stick from me and hit the camel. After that, the camel started moving faster than the others. The Prophet (ﷺ) then offered to buy my camel for four gold coins. I refused, saying it was a gift for him. He insisted, saying he would pay for it later when we reached Medina. When we arrived in Medina, the Prophet asked me where I was going and why I had married a widow. I explained that my father had left daughters behind, so I wanted to marry someone who could take care of them. The Prophet (ﷺ) approved of my decision. Later, he told Bilal to pay me for the camel and give me some extra money. Bilal gave me four gold coins and one more coin as an extra gift from the Prophet.

title: Giving Up Yourself
content: A woman asked Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) for his permission to join him. A man suggested she marry him instead. The Prophet (ﷺ) agreed that the man could marry her, but only if he knew some of the Quran by heart.

title: Abu Huraira and the Thief
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) sent me to collect charity from Ramadan. A man came and started taking food without permission. I caught him and said, 'I'll take you to Allah's Messenger (ﷺ).' He said he was poor with many dependents, so I let him go. The next day, the same thing happened again. This time, I asked him to promise not to come back, but he broke his word. Again, I let him go. On the third occasion, when I caught him stealing, he promised to teach me a prayer that would keep Satan away at night. He said to recite 'There is no god except Him, the Ever-Living, the Sustainer' until the end of the verse. If I did this, Allah would send a guard to protect me from evil. I let him go again. In the morning, Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) asked what had happened with my prisoner. I told him about the man's promise and his lie. The Prophet (ﷺ) said that the man was actually Satan in disguise.

title: Prophet's Warning on Usury
content: Abu Sa'id al-Khudri said that Bilal brought some special dates to the Prophet. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked where they came from, and Bilal explained that he had exchanged two baskets of his own lower-quality dates for one basket of these better dates to give to the Prophet. The Prophet (ﷺ) strongly warned him: 'This is usury! Don't do it this way. If you want a better kind of date, sell your lower-quality ones for money and then use that money to buy the better kind.'

title: Umar's Waqf Trust
content: `Ibn Umar was in charge of managing the trust left by `Umar. He could use some of it for himself and share with his friends, as long as he wasn't trying to keep money for himself.

title: Stoning for Adultery
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) told Unais to go to the wife of a man and ask her if she had committed adultery. If she said yes, then she should be stoned to death as punishment.

title: Stoning for Adultery
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) told Unais to go to the woman's husband and ask her if she had committed adultery. If she said yes, then she should be stoned to death as punishment.

title: Beating a Drunk Man
content: When a man named An-Nuaman or his son was brought home drunk, the Prophet told everyone in the house to hit him. I was one of those who hit him with shoes and palm-leaf stalks.

title: Allah's Messenger and Sacrifice
content: I helped tie the garlands of animals for sacrifice. Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) put them around the animals' necks with his own hands, then sent them to Mecca with my father. Nothing was considered wrong until they were actually slaughtered.

title: Abu Talha Donates His Garden
content: Abu Talha had a big garden in Medina. It was near the mosque where the Prophet used to pray. The Prophet (ﷺ) would visit Abu Talha's garden and drink from its water. When Allah revealed a verse saying that spending money on things you love is part of being righteous, Abu Talha decided to give his beloved garden to charity. He asked the Prophet what he should do with it. The Prophet (ﷺ) said that giving away something valuable was not always wise, but Abu Talha wanted to follow Allah's command. So, he distributed the garden among his family members. The Prophet (ﷺ) then praised Abu Talha for making a smart decision and said that keeping some wealth can be better than giving it all away.

title: Honest Treasurer's Reward
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: A treasurer who gives money to the right person as ordered is considered a very charitable person.

title: Eating from Your Garden
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: If you plant a tree or grow seeds and someone eats from it - whether an animal, person, or bird - that's considered a charity for you.

title: No Humiliation in Houses
content: Abu Umama saw some farming tools and remembered the Prophet saying: 'If these tools enter a house, Allah will bring humiliation into it.'

title: Dogs and Good Deeds
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'If you keep a dog, one part of your good deeds is taken away every day. But if the dog helps guard animals or farms, it's allowed.'

title: Keeping a Guard Dog
content: Abu Sufyan said he heard the Prophet say that if you keep a dog for no reason, one part of your good deeds is taken away every day. He swore by Allah's name that it was true.

title: A Cow Speaks to Its Rider
content: A man was riding a cow. The cow turned to him and said, 'I wasn't made to carry you. I'm meant for ploughing.' The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) (SAW) believed this story happened.

title: Date Palm Trees Shared
content: Some people from Medina asked the Prophet to give them some date palm trees. He said no. Then they suggested that the immigrants could take care of the trees and share the fruit with them. The immigrants agreed to do this.

title: Burning the Date Palm Trees
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) got some date palm trees cut down and burned near a place called Al-Buwaira. The tribe of Bani-An-Nadir had them there. Hassan bin Thabit said: 'The leaders of Bani Lu'ai watched the fire spread easily at Al-Buwaira'.

title: Prophet Forbids Unequal Rent
content: Rafi' bin Khadij said: We worked on farms in Medina. We rented land but made the landlord get a specific part of what we grew. Sometimes that part got sick and sometimes it didn't, so the Prophet said this was not fair. At that time, people did not use gold or silver to rent land. If they gave us seeds, we would give them back something in return.

title: Sharing Land with Khaibar
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) made a deal with people from Khaibar. They would work on the land and get half of what they grew. He also gave his wives a certain amount of food every year: 100 Wasqs of dates, 80 Wasqs of other fruits, and 20 Wasqs of barley. When `Umar became the leader after him, he asked the Prophet's wives if they wanted to keep getting this food or have land and water instead. Some chose land, some chose the old way, and Aisha chose land.

title: Deal with People of Khaibar
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) made a deal with the people of Khaibar. They would get half of what they grew on the land they worked on.

title: Sharecropping: A Prophet's Advice
content: `Amr asked Tawus to stop sharecropping because people said the Prophet forbade it. But Tawus said he gives land to others and helps them. He said Ibn Abbas, a learned man, told him the Prophet didn't forbid sharecropping. Instead, the Prophet said it's better to give land for free to family members than charge a fixed rent.

title: Land for Jews in Khaibar
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) gave the land of Khaibar to the Jewish people. They had to work on it and grow food. In return, they would get half of what they produced.

title: Fair Share of Harvest
content: Rafi' and his friends rented land in Medina. They divided the harvest into two parts: one for them and one for the owner as rent. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Don't do this.'

title: Three Men in a Cave
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: Three men were walking when it started raining. They took shelter in a cave on a mountain. A big rock blocked the entrance, trapping them inside. The men thought of good deeds they had done for Allah's sake and prayed to Him. One man remembered helping his parents and children by giving them food first. He asked Allah to remove the rock if he did this deed only for His sake. Allah moved the rock a little so they could see the sky. The second man told how he was tempted to do something wrong, but his cousin stopped him from doing it. He prayed to Allah, asking Him to move the rock further. Allah listened and shifted the rock more. The third man remembered being kind to an employee who worked for him. When the employee asked for his pay, the man gave him even more than he deserved. He prayed to Allah, saying if he did this deed only for His sake, please remove the rest of the rock. And so, Allah moved the rock completely.

title: Umar's Distribution Plan
content: Umar said he would have given land to soldiers if it wasn't for future Muslim generations. He was thinking of how the Prophet distributed land in Khaibar.

title: Land Belongs to Its Owner
content: `Aisha said the Prophet said: If someone works on land that doesn't belong to anyone, they have a right to own it. `Urwa said `Umar also made this decision when he was in charge.

title: Prophet's Dream at Dhul-Hulaifa
content: Abdullah bin Umar said the Prophet was resting in a valley called Dhul-Hulaifa. He had a dream and was told, 'This is a blessed place.' Musa asked Salim to let their camels kneel where Abdullah used to stop his camel. This spot is near a mosque, halfway between it and the road.

title: Prophet's Dream in Al-'Aqiq
content: Umar said that the Prophet was at a place called Al-'Aqiq. He had a dream from Allah where an angel came and told him to pray there. The angel also said to combine two important rituals: Hajj (a big pilgrimage) with Umra (a smaller visit).

title: Expelling Jews from Khaibar
content: Ibn Umar said: 'Umar asked the Jews and Christians to leave Hijaz. After Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) conquered Khaibar, he wanted them to leave too because it was now owned by Allah, him, and Muslims. The Jews asked if they could stay on one condition: they would work hard and get half of the fruits. Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) agreed but said 'as long as we wish'. Eventually, `Umar forced them to move to Taima' and Ariha.

title: Prophet's Advice on Farming
content: Rafi's uncle Zuhair said the Prophet forbade them from renting their farms. They would get a share of the crops in exchange for rent, or pay with barley and dates. The Prophet (ﷺ) told them not to do this. Instead, they should work the land themselves, let someone else work it for free, or leave it uncultivated. Rafi agreed to follow the Prophet's advice.

title: Cultivate Your Own Land
content: Jabir said the Prophet told people to either work their own land or give it for free to a Muslim friend. If they didn't do that, the land should stay empty and not be rented out.

title: Cultivate Your Own Land
content: Jabir said the Prophet told people to either work their own land or give it for free to a Muslim brother. If they don't do this, they should leave the land empty.

title: Renting Land is Permitted
content: Amr told Tawus about a story. Tawus said it's okay to rent land for farming. Ibn Abbas said the Prophet didn't say not to, but he preferred giving land to family members for free instead of charging money.

title: Ibn Umar's Farm Rents
content: Nafi' said that Ibn 'Umar rented his farms during the time of Abu Bakr, 'Umar, and 'Uthman. He was told by Rafi' bin Khadij that the Prophet had forbidden renting farms. Ibn 'Umar went to see Rafi', accompanied by Nafi'. Rafi' confirmed that the Prophet had forbidden renting farms. Ibn 'Umar explained that they used to rent their farms for the fruit and water from nearby streams.

title: Ibn Umar's Farm Rentals
content: Nafi' said Ibn 'Umar used to rent his farms during the time of Abu Bakr, 'Umar, and 'Uthman. He was told that the Prophet had forbidden renting farms. So he went to Rafi' bin Khadij with Nafi'. Rafi' confirmed that the Prophet had indeed forbidden renting farms. Ibn 'Umar explained that they used to rent their farms for the crops by rivers and a certain amount of figs during the Prophet's lifetime.

title: Renting Land During Ramadan
content: 'Abdullah bin 'Umar said he knew that people used to rent land during the time of the Prophet. He was worried that the Prophet might have forbidden it, so he stopped renting his own land.

title: Renting Land in Islam
content: Some companions of the Prophet rented land for a share of the crops or water from streams. The Prophet (ﷺ) told them not to do this. I asked Rafi', 'What about renting for money?' He said it's okay to rent for Dinars and Dirhams. Al-Laith said that if people understood the rules, they would see how bad this practice is.

title: Renting Land in Islam
content: Rafi' bin Khadij said his two uncles told him that the Prophet's companions used to rent land for a share of the crops or by the river. The Prophet (ﷺ) forbade this practice. I asked Rafi', 'What about renting for money?' He said it was okay, but warned there were risks involved.

title: Paradise's Special Gift
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) was telling a story to a Bedouin. He said that in Paradise, someone will ask Allah if they can work the land. Allah asks, 'Don't you have everything you want?' The person says, 'Yes, but I want to work.' They're allowed to plant seeds and soon their plants grow into huge mountains overnight. Then Allah tells them, 'Take what you've grown; nothing satisfies you.' The Bedouin said, 'That person must be from Quraish or an Ansari because they farm, not us.' The Prophet (ﷺ) smiled.

title: Friday Meal with a Neighbor
content: Sahl bin Sa'd said: We liked Fridays because an old lady would cook food from plants we grew near our streams. She added barley to the pot and served it after Friday prayer. We only ate or took naps after praying on Fridays.

title: Abu Huraira's Story
content: Some people said I tell too many stories from the Prophet. They asked why the emigrants and Ansar didn't share as much. My friends were busy with work or taking care of their homes, but I was poor and just happy to be near the Prophet. So, I would remember what he said while they forgot. One day, the Prophet told me that if I spread my only blanket over my chest while he spoke, I would never forget his words. I did that, and it worked! Now, I can recall everything he said. But there are two verses in the Quran that remind me to be careful about sharing stories.

title: The Prophet Drinks with a Boy
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) was given a cup of milk. He drank from it while sitting between old men and a young boy on his right and left sides. The boy said, 'No one should drink after you.' So the Prophet gave the rest to the boy.

title: Prophet's Gift to a Bedouin
content: Anas bin Malik said that the Prophet was in his house when a sheep was milked for him. The milk was mixed with water from Anas's well. A tumbler of it was given to the Prophet, who drank from it. Abu Bakr and a bedouin were sitting next to him. When the Prophet put down the tumbler, 'Umar thought he might give it to the bedouin instead of Abu Bakr. So 'Umar said,

title: Don't Hoard Water
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: Don't keep extra water for yourself. If you do, it will stop people from letting their animals drink and graze.

title: Don't Hoard Water
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Do not keep extra water just to grow more grass.'

title: Death by Accident or Animal
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: If someone dies in a mine, well, or is killed by an animal, there's no compensation. If you find treasure on your land, give one-fifth to the government.

title: Lying in Court is Forbidden
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: 'If someone lies to take something from another person, they will meet Allah while He is angry with them.' A man named Al-Ashath had a dispute over a well. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked him to bring witnesses, but he didn't have any. Then the Prophet suggested that the other side take an oath instead of bringing witnesses. Al-Ashath said this would be easy for the other person to lie about. The Prophet (ﷺ) told them what he had just said, and soon Allah revealed a verse confirming it.

title: False Oaths are Forbidden
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said that if someone takes a false oath to take something from someone else, they will meet Allah while He is angry with them. A man named Al-Ashath had a well and his cousin claimed it was theirs. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked him to get witnesses, but he didn't have any. So the Prophet suggested the defendant take an oath instead. Al-Ashath said that would be easy for the other man to lie about. This is what Allah revealed: 'Those who trade their faith for worldly gain and break their oaths.'

title: Three People Allah Won't Help
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said that there are three people who will not be forgiven on the Day of Resurrection. They are: a person who has extra water but doesn't give it to travelers, a person who gives allegiance to a leader only for what he can get from him, and a person who lies about his goods after prayer to make them look valuable.

title: Dispute over Water Rights
content: A man from Ansar argued with Az-Zubair in front of the Prophet about water for their date-palms. The Ansari said, 'Let the water pass.' But Az-Zubair refused. The case was brought to the Prophet, who said, 'Zubair, irrigate your land first and then let the water reach your neighbor's land.' The Ansari got angry and said, 'Is it because he is your aunt's son?' The Prophet (ﷺ) became angry and said, 'Zubair, irrigate your land and stop the water at the walls around the trees.' Az-Zubair thought a verse was revealed about this situation: 'They can have no faith until they make you judge in all disputes between them'.

title: Dispute over Water Rights
content: A man from Ansar argued with Az-Zubair in front of the Prophet about a canal for irrigation. The Ansari man said, 'Let the water pass,' but Az-Zubair refused. The case was brought to the Prophet, who told Az-Zubair, 'Irrigate your land and then let the water go to your neighbor.' The Ansari got angry and said, 'Is it because he's your aunt's son?' The Prophet (ﷺ) became angry and said, 'Irrigate your land and then stop the water when it reaches the walls around the trees.' Az-Zubair thought a verse was revealed about this situation: 'They can't have faith until they make you judge in all their disputes'.

title: The Prophet's Water Advice
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) was in a dispute with Zubair. A man from the Ansar group said that Zubair got preferential treatment because he is related to the Prophet. The Prophet (ﷺ) told Zubair, 'First, water your own land and then let the water flow to the others.' Later, the Prophet added, 'Water until it reaches the walls between the trees, and then stop.' This event led to a revelation from Allah: 'People can't truly believe in you unless they accept your decisions in all disputes.'

title: Zubair and the Canal Dispute
content: An Ansari man argued with Zubair about a canal in the Harra. The Prophet (ﷺ) told Zubair to water his land first, then leave some for his neighbor. When the Ansari said it was because Zubair was the Prophet's aunt's son, the Prophet got upset and said to irrigate until the water reaches the walls between the trees. This meant giving Zubair all the water he needed.

title: Helping an Animal in Need
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said that a man was walking and got thirsty. He went down into a well to get water, then saw a dog eating mud because it was so thirsty too. The man felt sorry for the dog and went back down to get some water. He put the water in his shoe, caught it with his teeth, and gave it to the dog. Allah was pleased with this kind act and forgave the man's sins.

title: Eclipse Prayer and a Woman
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) prayed during an eclipse. He said he was worried about going to Hell. Then he saw a woman being scratched by a cat. Someone told him the cat had died from hunger because she kept it locked up.

title: Torture for Neglecting a Cat
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said that a woman was punished in Hell because she locked up her cat and it died of hunger. Allah said to the woman, 'You didn't feed or give water to your cat when you kept it locked up. You also didn't set it free to eat insects on its own.'

title: The Prophet Drinks with a Boy
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) was given a cup of milk. There were old men on his left and a young boy on his right. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked the boy if he wanted him to give the drink to the older people first. The boy said no, so the Prophet gave it to the boy instead.

title: Driving People Away
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'I will throw some people out of Paradise on the Day of Resurrection. It's like throwing away strange camels from a special water trough.'

title: Zamzam Water and Ishmael's Mother
content: Ibn Abbas said the Prophet said: 'May Allah be kind to Ishmael's mother. If she hadn't built a container for Zamzam water, it would still flow today. A tribe called Jurhum came and asked if they could live near her home. She agreed but said they couldn't use the water without permission.'

title: Three People Allah Won't Speak To
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said there are three types of people who will not be spoken to or looked at by Allah on the Day of Resurrection. They are: someone who lies about their goods, saying they were offered more money than they got; someone who takes an oath after the afternoon prayer to take something that belongs to a Muslim; and someone who doesn't share extra water with others.

title: No Private Grazing Areas
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said that only Allah and he himself can make an area for animals to graze. He made a place called An-Naqi' for this, and later Caliph Umar made two other areas, As-Saraf and Ar-Rabadha, for the same purpose.

title: Horses: Reward or Burden
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said that keeping horses can be a good thing for some people. It can bring them rewards if they use the horse for Allah's cause and take care of it properly. If the horse breaks free and moves around, its steps and waste will also count as good deeds for the owner. For others, horses are a way to earn a living without being poor or asking others for help. But if someone keeps horses just for pride or to show off, then their horses will bring them harm. Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said that donkeys are like any other animal - doing good things, no matter how small, will be rewarded.

title: Lost Things: What to Do
content: Zaid bin Khalid told me that a man asked the Prophet about what to do with things people lose. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Find out where it came from and what it's made of. Then tell everyone for a year in case the owner comes back. If not, you can keep it.' The man asked about lost sheep. The Prophet (ﷺ) replied, 'It belongs to whoever finds it or its original owner.' He then asked about lost camels. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'They have their own food and water, so they belong to whoever finds them until the owner comes back.'

title: Sell Your Labor
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: It's better to work hard and sell something you've made than ask others for help. If they give it, good. If not, Allah will still protect you from trouble.

title: Earn Your Living Honesty
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'It's better to gather firewood and carry it on your back than ask someone for help when they might not give you anything.'

title: Ali's She-Camels at Badr
content: Ali bin Abi Talib got two she-camels as his share of the war booty. He wanted to use them for his wedding banquet with Fatima. A goldsmith was with him, and Hamza bin Abdul-Muttalib was in a nearby house drinking wine. A singer was there too. Hamza saw Ali's camels and took his sword. He cut off their humps and opened their sides, taking some of their livers. Ali told the Prophet about this. The Prophet (ﷺ) went with Zaid to speak to Hamza. But when he spoke harshly to Hamza, Hamza said, 'You're just slaves of my ancestors.' The Prophet (ﷺ) left.

title: Granting Land to Ansar
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) decided to give some land in Bahrain to the Ansar. They said they wouldn't take it unless he gave an equal share to their brothers from Quraish who had migrated here. The Prophet (ﷺ) told them, 'You'll see people getting special treatment soon, so be patient until we meet again on Judgement Day.'

title: Ansar Ask for Equal Share
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) called the Ansar to give them some land from Bahrain. They asked him to also give their Quraish brothers an equal share. But the Prophet said he didn't have enough land to give away equally. He told them, 'After I'm gone, you'll see people giving preference to others. Be patient until we meet again.'

title: Camel's Right to Be Milked
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said that a camel has the right to be milked at a place with water. This is one of its rights.

title: Buying Date Palms and Slaves
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: If you buy date palms that have already produced fruit, the seller gets to keep the fruit unless you agree otherwise. The same applies if you buy a slave who has some money or property - it belongs to the seller unless you say otherwise.

title: Selling Dates Before Harvest
content: Zaid bin Thabit said that the Prophet allowed people to sell their dates from the 'Araya trees for ready-to-eat dates. They can estimate how many they have before picking them.

title: Forbidden Sales and Fruits
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) forbade selling fruits before they're ripe. He also stopped three types of sales: Al-Mukhabara, Al-Muhaqala, and Al-Muzabana. You can only sell fruits for money, except for 'Araya.

title: Buying Dates in Islam
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) allowed people to sell their 'Araya dates for ready-to-eat dates. The price of the 'Araya dates should be estimated as less than five Awsuq or exactly five Awsuq.

title: Selling Fruits for Fruits
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) forbade selling one type of fruit for another, except in a special case called 'Araya. He allowed people who own 'Araya to make such trades.

title: Prohibition on Fruit Exchange
content: Rafi' bin Khadij and Sahl bin Abi Hathma said that the Prophet forbade selling one type of fruit for another, except in a specific case. He allowed people who have 'Araya to make such sales.

title: Jabir Sells His Camel
content: I was with the Prophet on a trip. He asked me if my camel was sick and if I wanted to sell it. I said yes, so he bought it from me. When we got back to Medina, I took the camel to him in the morning and he paid me for it.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Debt
content: Ibrahim told us that `Aisha said the Prophet bought food from a Jewish man. He gave the man an iron armor as security for the debt.

title: Trust Money with Good Intent
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: If someone takes money from people to give it back, Allah will help them pay it back. But if they take the money to waste it, Allah will punish them for wasting it.

title: The Prophet's Warning on Wealth
content: I was with the Prophet. He saw a mountain and said he wouldn't want it to be turned into gold, even for three days, because he would spend all of it helping others. He said rich people will have little reward in the afterlife unless they use their money to help others. I heard a noise and wanted to go to him but he told me to stay put. When he returned, I asked what the noise was. He said Gabriel came and told him that anyone who dies loving only God will go to heaven, even if they made mistakes.

title: Gold is not a goal
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: If I had as much gold as the mountain of Uhud, it wouldn't be good for me to keep it more than three days. I would only keep some to pay off debts.

title: Respecting Debtors
content: A man asked the Prophet for his money back in a very rude way. The companions wanted to stop him, but the Prophet said it's okay because he has the right to ask for his money. He told them to buy a camel and give it to the man. They said they couldn't find a better camel than the one he was asking for. The Prophet (ﷺ) still said to buy that camel and give it to him, saying that being kind when paying back debts is a good thing.

title: Forgiveness for a Good Life
content: I heard the Prophet say that a man died and was asked about his life. He said he was a businessman who helped rich people pay back debts on time, and also helped poor people with their debt. Because of this, he was forgiven.

title: The Prophet Repays a Debt
content: A man came to the Prophet and asked for a camel that he was owed. The Prophet (ﷺ) told his companions to give him an older camel, which they did. The man said thank you and praised Allah's Messenger (ﷺ). The Prophet (ﷺ) replied, 'The best people are those who pay their debts fairly'.

title: Paying Debts with Honesty
content: The Prophet Muhammad 's (ﷺ) companions were asked to give a man his owed camel. They found a camel one year older, but the Prophet said to give it anyway. The man was happy and thanked them, saying 'May Allah reward you well'. The Prophet (ﷺ) then said that the best people are those who pay their debts in a fair and honest way.

title: Jabir's Visit to the Prophet
content: I went to the mosque where the Prophet was. He told me to pray two times. Then he paid back a debt I owed him and gave me some extra money.

title: Jabir's Father Owes Debt
content: My father was killed in the battle of Uhud. He had debts that his creditors kept asking for. I told the Prophet about it, and he suggested using my garden to pay them off. But they refused. The Prophet (ﷺ) said he'd come back the next morning. He arrived early and walked around our date palms, praying for a good harvest. We picked some dates and used them to pay the debtors. There was still some left over for us.

title: Allah's Messenger Helps a Debt
content: Jabir bin Abdullah's father died and left a debt to a Jew. Jabir asked the Prophet for help, but the Jew refused to accept fruit from Jabir's trees instead of money. The Prophet (ﷺ) went with Jabir to the Jew and suggested this again, but the Jew still said no. The Prophet (ﷺ) then told Jabir to pick some fruit and give it to the Jew as payment. After the Prophet left, Jabir picked 47 Awsuq of dates, gave 30 to the Jew, and had 17 extra for himself. When he told the Prophet about this, the Prophet asked him to tell Umar about it. Umar said that when the Prophet walked through Jabir's garden, Allah would surely bless it.

title: Seeking Refuge from Debt
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) used to say in his prayer: 'I seek refuge with Allah from all sins and debt.' Someone asked him, 'You often ask for protection from debt.' He replied, 'When someone is in debt, they lie when speaking and break promises when making them'.

title: Property Left Behind
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: If someone dies and leaves behind some belongings, they will go to their family. But if he has weak children who need help, the community will take care of them.

title: Prophet's Connection with Believers
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'I am closer to believers than they are to themselves. This is what Allah says:

title: Delaying Debt Repayment
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said: A wealthy person who delays paying back debts is being unfair.

title: Respecting Debtors and Creditors
content: A man came to the Prophet. He was owed money and spoke harshly about it. The Prophet 's (ﷺ) companions wanted to hurt him, but the Prophet said, 'Leave him alone. The person who is owed money has the right to speak.'

title: Returning Lost Belongings
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: If someone finds their lost things with a person who doesn't have any money, they can take those things back before anyone else.

title: Manumitted Slave Sold for Owner
content: Jabir bin Abdullah said: A man promised to free his slave after he died. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked, 'Who will buy the slave?' Nu'aim bought it and the Prophet took the money and gave it to the owner.

title: Lending Money with Interest
content: Abu Hurairah said the Prophet mentioned a man who asked another to lend him money. The lender agreed for a certain time, but we don't know what happened next about this loan.

title: Prophet Helps with Debt
content: My father died and left debts. I asked the creditors to forgive some of it, but they refused. I went to the Prophet for help. He said: 'Sort your dates into different kinds. Call all the creditors and wait for me.' I did this. The Prophet (ﷺ) came and sat with the dates. He measured out each person's share until he paid them all back. Nothing was missing or extra. Another time, I rode a camel to battle with the Prophet. It got tired and fell behind. The Prophet (ﷺ) hit it on its back and said: 'Sell it to me.' When we returned to Medina, I asked the Prophet for permission to go home because my wife and I had just gotten married. He asked if she was a young bride or an older woman who could take care of our daughters. I told him about our situation, so he said: 'Go home.' Later, when I went back with the camel, the Prophet gave me its price, the camel itself, and my share from the battle.

title: Jabir's Story About Debt
content: When my father died, he left behind children and debts. I asked the lenders to reduce the debt, but they refused. So, I went to the Prophet for help. He said, 'Sort out your dates into different kinds: Adha, Lean, and Ajwa. Call all the creditors and wait for me.' I did that, and when the Prophet came, he sat with the dates and gave each creditor their share. The amount of dates didn't change. On another trip with the Prophet, my camel got tired and was lagging behind. The Prophet (ﷺ) hit it on its back and said, 'Sell it to me, you can ride it until we reach Medina.' When we arrived in Medina, I asked the Prophet for permission to go home because I had just gotten married. He asked if I had married a young woman or an older one. I said I had married an older woman so she could take care of my sisters. The Prophet (ﷺ) then told me to go home. When I got there, I told my uncle about selling the camel, but he scolded me for it. So, I explained why I sold it and what the Prophet did to it. Later, I took the camel back to the Prophet in the morning, and he gave me its price, the camel itself, and some war booty money.

title: Be Honest in Bargaining
content: A man told the Prophet that he often got cheated when buying things. The Prophet (ﷺ) advised him to always say 'No deception' when making a purchase, and the man followed this advice.

title: Forbidden Actions
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: Allah has forbidden us from being unkind to our mothers, burying daughters alive, not paying what we owe others, and begging. Allah also dislikes when we talk about others without reason, ask too many questions, or waste money by spending too much.

title: Being a Good Guardian
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said: 'Each of you is in charge of something. A leader takes care of his people and is responsible for them. A husband looks after his family and is accountable for it. A wife manages her home and is responsible for it. A servant takes care of his master's belongings and is responsible for them. Even a son is responsible for taking care of his father's property.'

title: Differences in Recitation
content: Abdullah said he saw a man reciting the Quran differently from how the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) used to read it. He took the man to the Prophet, who said both were right. The Prophet (ﷺ) then told them not to argue about this, as previous nations had fought and failed because of their differences.

title: Two People Argue About Prophets
content: Two people, one Muslim and one Jew, got into a fight. The Muslim said 'By the One who made Muhammad (ﷺ) special.' The Jew replied 'By the One who made Moses special.' The Muslim hit the Jew in the face. The Jew went to the Prophet and told him what happened. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked the Muslim about it and the Muslim explained. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Don't say I'm better than Moses. On Judgment Day, everyone will fall asleep, including me. But when I wake up first, I'll see Moses standing near God's throne. I won't know if he woke up before me or was spared from sleeping.'

title: The Prophet's Advice on Oaths
content: Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri said that the Prophet was sitting when a Jew came and complained that one of his companions had slapped him. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked who it was, and then sent for the companion. When he arrived, the Prophet asked if he had hit the Jew. He said yes, and explained why: the Jew had taken an oath in the market saying 'By the One Who made Moses special.' The companion got angry and slapped the Jew. The Prophet (ﷺ) told him not to say that one prophet is better than another. On the Day of Judgment, everyone will fall asleep except for the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ), who will be the first to wake up. He said he would see Moses standing by God's Throne, but wouldn't know if Moses was still awake or had fallen asleep like everyone else.

title: Crushing a Girl's Head
content: Anas said that a Jew hurt a girl very badly. When asked who did it, she pointed to the Jew when his name was mentioned. The Prophet (ﷺ) ordered the Jew's punishment to be the same as he had done.

title: Don't Be Cheated in Buying
content: Ibn Umar told us that a man was often cheated when buying things. The Prophet (ﷺ) said to him, 'When you buy something, tell the seller not to cheat you.' From then on, the man always said this.

title: Manumitted Slave Sold Again
content: Jabir said that a man freed a slave. But the Prophet cancelled this freedom because the man didn't have any other property to support himself. So, he sold the slave back. A man named Nu'aim bought the slave from him.

title: False Oath About Property
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said that if someone takes a false oath to take something from another Muslim, Allah will be angry with them. A man named Al-Ash'ath was worried because he had a problem with a Jewish neighbor who denied his ownership of some land. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked the man for proof, but he didn't have any. So, the Prophet told the Jew to take an oath, which made the first man worry that the Jew would lie and keep his property. Allah then revealed a verse saying that those who make false oaths to get something from others will be punished.

title: Taking False Oath
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: If someone takes a false oath to get something that belongs to another Muslim, Allah will be angry with them when they meet Him. Al-Ash'ath said he was worried about this because he had a land dispute with a Jew and the Prophet asked him if he had proof of ownership. When he didn't have any proof, the Prophet told the Jew to take an oath. Al-Ash'ath was afraid that the Jew would lie and take his land. So Allah sent down a verse saying: 'Those who trade their faith for some gain will face trouble with Allah.'

title: The Prophet Helps with Debt
content: Ka'b bin Malik asked Ibn Abi Hadrad to pay back a debt in the mosque. They argued loudly until the Prophet heard them. He came out and said, 'O Ka'b!' Ka'b replied, 'Here I am.' The Prophet (ﷺ) told Ka'b to cut the debt in half. Ka'b agreed and did it. Then the Prophet told Ibn Abi Hadrad to pay back the reduced amount.

title: Umar and Hisham's Quran Reading
content: One day, Umar saw Hisham reading Surat-al-Furqan differently than he was taught by the Prophet. Umar wanted to stop him during prayer but waited until he finished. Then, Umar took Hisham to the Prophet and said, 'I heard you read it differently.' The Prophet (ﷺ) asked Hisham to recite it again. When Hisham did, the Prophet said, 'That's how it was revealed.' He then asked Umar to recite it too. When Umar did, the Prophet said, 'It was also revealed like that.' He told them that the Quran has been revealed in seven different ways, so they can read it however is easiest for them.

title: No Prayer, No House
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'I was going to order someone to call the prayer and then I would go to the homes of those who don't come to pray. I would burn their houses down.'

title: Abu bin Zam'a's Son Dispute
content: Abu bin Zam'a and Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas went to the Prophet. They argued about a boy, saying he was their son. The Prophet (ﷺ) looked at the boy and saw that he looked like another man named `Utba. He said to Abu bin Zam'a: 'You will get this boy because the son belongs to the owner of the bed.' Then he told Sauda to stay away from the boy.

title: Thumama bin Uthal's Story
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) sent some horsemen to Najd. They caught a man named Thumama bin Uthal, who was the leader of Yamama. He was tied to a pillar in the Mosque. When the Prophet came, he asked Thumama what he wanted to say. Thumama said he had good news for Muhammad (ﷺ). The Prophet (ﷺ) then told him to be released.

title: Arrest in Najd
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) sent some horsemen to Najd. They caught a man named Thumama bin Uthal from the tribe of Bani Hanifa and tied him to a pillar in the Mosque.

title: Ka'b's Debt Reduced
content: Ka'b bin Malik had a debt with Abdullah bin Abi Hadrad. Ka'b caught up with him and they started arguing loudly. The Prophet (ﷺ) passed by them and told Ka'b to reduce the debt in half. So, Ka'b reduced the debt to half and let Abdullah off paying the rest.

title: Khabbab's Debt Problem
content: A man named 'Asi owed me money from before Islam. He said he wouldn't pay unless I stopped believing in Muhammad (ﷺ). I told him I'd never stop believing until Allah made him die and come back to life again. He said that would happen, then he'd have wealth and children and could pay me. But the Prophet received a message saying: 'Have you seen someone who doesn't believe in our signs but thinks they'll get rich and have kids?'

title: Lost Money Found
content: Ubai bin Ka'b found a bag with 100 Diners. He told the Prophet about it. The Prophet (ﷺ) said to make an announcement for people to claim their money, but no one came forward after two announcements. So the Prophet said to keep the bag and use its contents if no one claims it.

title: Lost Things and Responsibility
content: A man asked the Prophet about what to do with lost things. The Prophet (ﷺ) said to make a public announcement for one year, so if someone finds it they can return it. If no one claims it, use it yourself. He also said that if you find a lost sheep or goat, keep it because its owner might be poor and need it. But if you find a camel, leave it alone because it has food and water and can take care of itself.

title: Lost Property Rules
content: If you find lost property like a container with a string tied to it, remember its description and announce it publicly for one year. If no one claims it, the person who found it can use it. This is like a trust given to them. The Prophet (ﷺ) said that if you find a lost sheep, take care of it. It might belong to you or someone else, or maybe a wolf ate it. For a lost camel, just leave it alone. It has food and water, so it will be okay until its owner finds it.

title: Lost Things: What to Do
content: Zaid bin Khalid told me that a man asked the Prophet about what to do with lost things. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'If you find something, remember how it's packed and tied. Then tell everyone for one year that you have it. If the owner comes back, give it to them. Otherwise, keep it or throw it away.' The man asked again, 'What if I lose a sheep?' The Prophet (ﷺ) replied, 'It belongs to its owner, so they can get it back. Or maybe a wolf will eat it.' He was asked about a lost camel and said, 'Don't worry about it. It has water and food, so it'll be okay until the owner finds it'.

title: An Israeli Man's Debt
content: Abu Hurairah said that the Prophet mentioned a man from Israel. This man was in debt and went to the sea, hoping a ship might have brought his money back. He found a piece of wood on the beach and took it home for firewood. When he cut it up, he found his money and a letter inside.

title: Eating Food Found on the Way
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) passed a date that had fallen on the ground. He said he wouldn't eat it because maybe someone had given it as charity, and eating it would mean taking something that wasn't his.

title: Eating Food Found at Home
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said that sometimes he finds a date on his bed when he returns home. He picks it up to eat, but then worries that it might be charity food given to him, so he throws it away.

title: Protecting Makkah's Environment
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said: Do not pull out the thorny bushes in Makkah. Don't chase its animals. If you find something that has fallen, like a piece of cloth or food, only pick it up if you tell everyone about it first. And don't cut down any grass, except for Idhkhir.

title: Rules for Mecca
content: After the Prophet won a victory in Mecca, he stood up and said: 'Allah has made it forbidden to fight in this city. Before me, no one was allowed to fight here, but now I have been given permission to do so for a short time. After me, no one will be allowed to fight here again. We should not hunt animals in Mecca or cut down its thorny bushes. If we find something that has fallen on the ground, we can pick it up only if we announce it publicly. If someone's relative is killed, they have two choices: accept compensation or take revenge. Al-Abbas said, 'But what about Al-Idhkhir? We use it in our homes and graves.' The Prophet (ﷺ) replied, 'No, not even Al-Idhkhir.' A man from Yemen asked the Prophet to write down these rules. The Prophet (ﷺ) agreed.

title: Respect Others' Animals
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: Don't milk someone else's animal without permission. Do you like it if someone comes to your shop, breaks a container and takes food? The udders of animals are like stores where owners keep their food. So don't milk someone else's animal without asking first.

title: Lost Property Rules
content: Zaid bin Khalid asked the Prophet about lost things. The Prophet (ﷺ) said to announce a lost item's description for one year, then use its value. If the owner returns later, give it back. For a lost sheep or goat, you can keep it because it belongs to someone nearby. But if something is valuable like a camel, with its own food and water, don't worry about it - its owner will find it.

title: Finding a Lost Whip
content: I was with Salman and Suhan during a battle. I found a whip and didn't want to drop it. One of them said, 'Give it back.' But I said, 'I'll find its owner or use it myself.' When we returned from the battle, we went for Hajj. We passed by Medina and asked Ubai bin Ka'b about the whip. He told us that he had found a bag with 100 Dinars in the Prophet's time. The Prophet (ﷺ) said to him, 'Announce this publicly for one year.' So, Ubai did that four times. After the fourth announcement, the Prophet said, 'Remember what it looks like and if its owner comes, give it back; otherwise, use it yourself.'

title: Lost Property and Animals
content: Zaid bin Khalid told us that a Bedouin asked the Prophet about what to do with lost property. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Announce it publicly for one year. If someone finds it and describes how it was tied, give it to them. Otherwise, use the money.' The Bedouin then asked about a lost camel. The Prophet (ﷺ) became upset and said, 'It's not your responsibility. It has water and can find food and drink on its own. Let its owner find it.' Finally, the Bedouin asked about a lost sheep. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'It belongs to you, or your brother, or someone else might have taken it'.

title: Abu Bakr Finds Milk for the Prophet
content: I was on my way when I saw a shepherd with his sheep. I asked him whose servant he was and he said it was someone from Quraish, then mentioned their name. I recognized them. I asked if the sheep had milk. He said yes. I asked to milk one for me. He agreed. We tied up a sheep and cleaned its udder. Then we clapped our hands to get rid of dust on his hands. He milked some milk into a pot. I poured water over it until it cooled down. Then I took the milk to the Prophet and said, 'Drink, O Messenger.' He drank until I was satisfied.

title: Believers' Journey to Heaven
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: When believers safely cross over Hell, they'll stop at a bridge between Hell and Paradise. There, they'll settle their differences from the world and be forgiven for all their sins. Then, they'll enter Paradise. The Prophet (ﷺ) said that everyone will know their home in Paradise better than their home on earth.

title: Allah's Mercy on Believers
content: Ibn Umar was walking with a student when another man asked him about what the Prophet said about meeting Allah. Ibn Umar replied that he heard the Prophet say: 'When a believer comes close to Allah, He will hide them behind His protection and ask if they committed certain sins. The person will admit to their mistakes, thinking they are in trouble. But Allah says:

title: Treat Your Brother Well
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said: A Muslim is like a brother to another Muslim. They should not hurt each other or hand each other over to someone who will hurt them. If you help your brother, Allah will help you. If you take your brother out of trouble, Allah will take you out of trouble on the Day of Resurrection. And if you protect your brother from harm, Allah will protect you.

title: Help Your Brother
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said: Help your brother, whether he is the one who is doing wrong or the one who is being treated unfairly.

title: Help Your Brother
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: 'Support your brother, whether he is being hurt or doing harm to others. People asked him,

title: Seven Good Deeds and Prohibitions
content: Al-Bara' bin Azib said the Prophet ordered us to do seven good things. He told us to visit people who are sick, go with them when they die, say 'May Allah be merciful to you' if someone says 'Praise be to Allah', return greetings to others, help those being treated unfairly, accept invitations from friends, and help people keep their promises.

title: Believers Support Each Other
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'When believers help each other, it's like a strong building. Its parts work together.' He then clasped his hands to show how they support each other.

title: Opression is Darkness
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: 'On the Day of Resurrection, oppression will be like a dark cloud.'

title: Fear the Oppressed
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) sent Mu'adh to Yemen and told him: 'Be careful about hurting others. If someone is treated unfairly, their prayer can reach Allah directly.'

title: Forgiveness Before Judgment
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said: If you have hurt someone's reputation or taken something from them unfairly, ask for their forgiveness before the Day of Resurrection. On that day, there will be no money to pay back what you took. If you have good actions, they will be taken away according to how much harm you caused. And if you don't have good actions, the person you hurt will get some of your bad deeds.

title: Wife's Fear of Divorce
content: Aisha said that the verse 'If a wife fears cruelty or desertion from her husband' was revealed about a situation where a man didn't like his wife and wanted to divorce her. The wife asked him not to divorce her, saying she gave up her rights.

title: The Messenger's Drink
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) was given a drink. He drank some and then asked a boy sitting next to him if he could give the rest to two old men on his other side. The boy said no, that he wouldn't let anyone else have it after Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) had drunk from it.

title: Stealing Land is Wrong
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: If someone takes land from another person without their permission, on the Day of Judgment, that person's neck will be wrapped around the earth seven times.

title: Don't Take Someone's Land
content: Abu Salama had a problem with some people about a piece of land. He told Aisha about it, and she said: 'Be fair, Abu Salama. The Prophet (ﷺ) said that if you take someone else's land unfairly, even just one small step, your neck will be wrapped around the earth seven times.'

title: Respect Others' Land
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'If you take someone else's land without permission, on the Day of Judgment, you will be punished severely.'

title: Eating Dates in Medina
content: Jabala said: We were in Medina with some people from Iraq. There was a famine and Ibn Az-Zubair gave us dates to eat. Ibn Umar would walk by and say, 'The Prophet (ﷺ) told us not to eat two dates at once unless we ask our friends first'.

title: The Prophet's Invitation
content: Abu Mas'ud told us that Abu Shu'aib, an Ansari man, had a slave who was a butcher. He asked the slave to cook enough food for five people so he could invite the Prophet and four other men. Abu Shu'aib invited the Prophet because he saw that he was hungry. Another man followed the Prophet without being invited. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked Abu Shu'aib if this man could join them, and Abu Shu'aib said yes.

title: Most Quarrelsome Person
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: The most hated person in Allah's sight is the one who argues a lot and quarrels with others.

title: The Prophet's Humble Nature
content: One day, Um Salama told that the Prophet heard people arguing outside his home. He went out and said he was just a normal person who sometimes had to make decisions between people with different stories. If he made a mistake in favor of one Muslim over another, it would be like getting a small part of punishment on Judgment Day, but the person could choose to accept or give up their claim.

title: Four Signs of Hypocrisy
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: If someone has four bad habits, they will be a hypocrite. These are: They always lie when they talk. They don't keep their promises. They break their agreements. And they behave very badly in arguments.

title: Spending from Husband's Property
content: Hind bint `Utba asked the Prophet if it was okay to spend some of her husband Abu Sufyan's money for their children. The Prophet (ﷺ) said it's fine as long as she spends it fairly and not too much.

title: Guests and Hospitality
content: We asked the Prophet what to do if we visited people who didn't treat us well. He said: 'If they're kind hosts, accept their kindness. If not, take what's right for a guest.'

title: Umar's Visit to Ansar
content: When the Prophet passed away, Umar said to Abu Bakr, 'Let's go.' They went to meet the Ansar at a shed in Bani Sa'ida. They wanted to talk to them about what would happen next.

title: Respect Your Neighbor's Space
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: 'Don't stop your neighbor from fixing a peg in their wall.' Abu Huraira reminded his friends, 'I'll tell you this story because it's important to know.'

title: Prohibition of Alcoholic Drinks
content: I was a servant in Abu Talha's house. The Prophet (ﷺ) ordered me to tell people that drinking alcohol is now forbidden. I had to pour out the wine from Abu Talha's home, and it spilled into the streets of Medina. Some people thought some people might have died with wine still inside them. But Allah sent a message saying there's no blame for those who believed in Him and did good things if they ate something that was already forbidden.

title: Respect the Roads
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said to his followers: 'Be careful not to sit on roads.' People replied that they had no choice, as this is where they meet and talk. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'If you must sit here, then follow some rules.' They asked what these rules were. He said, 'Lower your eyes when walking by others, don't harm anyone, say hello when greeted, promote good behavior, and stop bad actions.'

title: Helping an Animal in Need
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said that a man was traveling and found a well to get water from. He drank from it and then saw a thirsty dog. The man felt sorry for the dog, so he went back down into the well and got some water to give to the dog. Allah was pleased with this kind action and forgave the man's sins. Some people asked the Prophet if there is a reward for helping animals, and he said yes, there is a reward for showing kindness to any living thing.

title: Afflictions Are Near
content: Usama bin Zaid said the Prophet stood on a high building in Medina and asked if we could see what he saw. He said, 'I'm seeing many places where problems will happen.'

title: Umar Asks About Prophet's Wives
content: Abdullah bin Abbas asked Umar about two wives of the Prophet. Umar said they were Aisha and Hafsa. He explained that in the past, Quraish men had authority over their women, but when they lived with the Ansar, the Ansari women had more power. One day, Umar's wife told him that some of the Prophet's wives would not speak to him for a whole day. This scared Umar and he went to Hafsa to ask her about it. She confirmed what his wife said. Umar then went to the Prophet and found him in an upper room. He asked if he had divorced all his wives, but the Prophet said no. Umar explained how Quraish men used to control their women, but now Ansari women were more powerful. The Prophet (ﷺ) smiled when Umar told this story. Umar then sat down with the Prophet and they talked about many things. The Prophet (ﷺ) reminded Umar that the Hereafter is better than this world. After twenty-nine days, the Prophet went back to his wives, starting with Aisha. She said he had promised not to come for a month, but the Prophet explained that a month can have twenty-nine or thirty days.

title: Prophet's Month of Rest
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) had a sprained foot. He took an oath to not go to his wives for one month. When Umar visited him, he said he hadn't divorced them, but was keeping the oath. The Prophet (ﷺ) stayed in a separate room for 29 days before going back to his wives.

title: Prophet's Kindness to Jabir
content: Jabir said the Prophet came into the Mosque. I had tied my camel outside and told him, 'This is your camel.' He checked it and said, 'The camel and its price are yours'.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Urination
content: Hudhaifa saw the Prophet coming to a rubbish dump and urinating while standing up.

title: Removing a Thorny Branch
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: A man was walking and found a thorny branch on the path. He removed it. Allah thanked him for this good deed and forgave his sins.

title: Leaving Space for Public Path
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said that when people disagreed about a piece of land, seven cubits should be left as a public path so others can walk around it.

title: Prophet's Rules for Respect
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said that we should not take things from others without their permission. He also said it is wrong to hurt someone's body on purpose, like cutting or damaging it.

title: Belief and Sinful Actions
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: When someone commits adultery, they are not a believer at that moment. The same goes for drinking alcohol, stealing, or robbing while others watch. These actions show you're not following Islam.

title: Jesus Descends as Ruler
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: Jesus will come and be a fair leader. He will stop people from hurting others by breaking their symbols of disagreement. He will also stop the killing of animals for food, and no one will have to pay extra taxes.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Advice at Khaibar
content: Salama bin Al-Akwa' said that on the day of Khaibar, Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) saw people cooking donkey meat. He asked why they were doing this and told them to break the pots and throw away the food. The people asked if they could wash the pots instead of breaking them, so he agreed.

title: Prophet Muhammad Destroys Idols
content: When the Prophet arrived in Mecca, he saw 360 idols around the Kaaba. He used a stick to break them and said: 'Truth has come and lies have gone'.

title: Prophet Muhammad Teaches Aisha
content: Aisha hung a curtain with pictures on it. The Prophet (ﷺ) tore the curtain and she made two cushions from it. He used them to sit on at home.

title: Protecting Property is Martyrdom
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: If someone is killed while defending their belongings, they are considered a martyr.

title: Broken Bowl Incident
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) was with his wife when a servant came with food in a bowl. The other wife broke the bowl with her hand, but the Prophet didn't get angry. He picked up the pieces and put the food back in it. They ate together. After they finished eating, the Prophet gave the servant an unbroken bowl.

title: Juraij's Prayer and Trial
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said that there was a man named Juraij who was praying. His mother came to him twice, but he didn't answer her calls because he wanted to finish his prayer. She then prayed to Allah not to let Juraij die until he saw the faces of prostitutes. A woman tricked Juraij and accused him of having an affair with her. The people broke down his home and abused him. But when they took the baby boy, who was actually from another man, to Juraij and asked him who the father was, the baby said it was the shepherd. So the people built a new home for Juraij, but he asked them to make it of mud.

title: Abu Ubaida's Army Ration
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) sent an army to the east coast with Abu Ubaida in charge. The army had 300 men, including me, Jabir. We were running out of food when Abu Ubaida told us to collect all our remaining food. My share was dates, but I only got one date a day. I thought it wouldn't be enough, but we learned its value when even that ran out. When we reached the sea, we saw a huge fish like a small mountain. We ate from it for 18 days. Then Abu Ubaida fixed two of its ribs in the ground and had a camel pass under them without touching them.

title: Sharing Food in Need
content: One day, our food ran out and people were struggling. They asked the Prophet for permission to kill their camels for meat. He agreed. But then `Umar met them and said, 'How will you survive without your camels?' So he went back to the Prophet and asked him about it. The Prophet (ﷺ) told `Umar to call everyone together with what little food they had left. They put all the food on a big leather sheet. The Prophet (ﷺ) prayed for blessings over the food and then told everyone to bring their plates or bowls. They took turns getting some food until everyone had enough. After that, the Prophet said, 'I bear witness that there is no god but Allah, and I am His Messenger.'

title: Prophet's Asr Prayer and Slaughter
content: Rafi bin Khadij said: We used to pray the afternoon prayer with the Prophet. After that, we would slaughter a camel and divide its meat into ten parts. We would eat some of it before sunset.

title: Sharing Food in Hard Times
