They went to the Prophet who ordered retaliation. Anas' uncle asked if Ar-Rabi's tooth would be broken, and the Prophet said no, Allah's law requires retaliation. Later, they agreed to forgive her, and the Prophet said some people's oaths are answered by Allah.

title: Al-Hasan bin Ali's Peace Treaty
content: Al-Hasan bin `Ali led a large army against Muawiya. Muawiya was worried that if they fought, he would be left with no one to do important jobs or take care of their families. He sent two men to talk to Al-Hasan and ask him to make peace. They said Muawiya offered them money and asked Al-Hasan to accept the offer. Al-Hasan agreed, but only if they were responsible for what they had promised. The two men agreed, so a peace treaty was made between Al-Hasan and Muawiya.

title: Allah's Messenger Helps a Debtor
content: One day, the Prophet heard some people arguing loudly at his door. They were talking about a debt and one man was refusing to help the other. The Prophet (ﷺ) went out to them and asked which person had sworn not to help. The man who refused said 'I am that person'. The Prophet (ﷺ) then told him to forgive the debt.

title: Prophet Helps with Debt
content: Ka`b bin Malik was owed money by Abdullah bin Abu Hadrad. One day they met and Ka`b asked for his money back. They argued loudly, so the Prophet passed by and said to Ka`b, 'Take half of what he owes you'. So Ka`b took half of the debt and forgave the rest.

title: Reward for Establishing Justice
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said: For every part of our body and for each day the sun rises, there is a reward if we help people with what is fair and just.

title: Allah's Messenger and Water Rights
content: Az-Zubair told me that he had a disagreement with an Ansari man about a water stream. They both used it to irrigate their gardens. Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said, 'Let Az-Zubair use the water first, then let some flow to his neighbor.' The Ansari got angry and said, 'Is this because Zubair is your cousin?' Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) became upset and said, 'Use the water first, but then stop it at the garden walls.' This gave Az-Zubair his full right. Before that, Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) had made a fair judgment for both of them. But when the Ansari annoyed him, he gave Az-Zubair what was rightfully his according to the law. Zubair said that he thought this verse was revealed about their case: 'But no by your Lord They can have No faith Until they make you judge In all disputes between them'.

title: My Father's Debt Problem
content: My father died and left some debts. I wanted to pay them off with the dates from my garden, but the creditors didn't agree because they thought it wouldn't be enough. So, I went to the Prophet (peace be upon him) for help. He said, 'When you collect the dates, call me.' When we had collected and dried the dates in a special place, he came with Abu Bakr and Umar. They sat on the dates and asked Allah to bless them. Then they told me to invite my father's creditors to come and get their full payment. I paid everyone what they were owed, and there was still some extra - 13 bags of dates left over. Seven of those bags were 'Ajwa dates, and six were Laun or the other way around. I met the Prophet (peace be upon him) later that day and told him about it. He smiled and said to go tell Abu Bakr and Umar what had happened.

title: Ka'b bin Malik's Debt
content: Abdullah bin Ka'b told me that in the lifetime of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ), Ka'b bin Malik was arguing with Ibn Abu Hadrad about a debt in the mosque. Their voices were loud enough for the Prophet to hear from his house. He called out to Ka'b and said, 'Deduct half of the debt.' Ka'b agreed, so the Prophet told Ibn Abu Hadrad to pay him the remaining amount.

title: Treaty of Hudaibiya
content: Suhail bin Amr agreed to a treaty with the Prophet. One condition was that anyone who came to the Prophet from their side, even if they were Muslim, would be returned. The Muslims did not like this and were unhappy about it. The Prophet (ﷺ) agreed to this condition and sent back Abu Jandal to his father Suhail bin Amr. During the period of truce, some believing women emigrants came to the Prophet. When a relative asked him to return one of these women, Um Kulthum bint Uqba, the Prophet did not send her back because Allah had revealed a verse saying that believers should not be sent back to unbelievers.

title: Treaty of Hudaibiya
content: When the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) made a treaty with Suhail bin `Amr, he agreed to return anyone who came from their side, even if they were Muslim. This meant that if someone like Abu Jandal was captured by the Muslims, he would be returned to his father. The Prophet (ﷺ) followed this rule and returned many people during this time of truce. However, when a believing woman named Um Kulthum asked for protection, the Prophet did not return her because Allah had revealed a new law: women who come to the Prophet as refugees should not be sent back to their families if they are truly believers.

title: Allah's Messenger Examines New Converts
content: Aisha said that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) used to check if new Muslim women were sincere. He would say, 'I accept your promise.' He never shook hands with them or touched their hands when they made this promise.

title: Give Good Advice
content: Jarir gave a pledge of allegiance to the Prophet. The Prophet (ﷺ) told Jarir to give good advice to every Muslim.

title: Jabir's Pledge of Allegiance
content: I gave the pledge to Allah's Messenger (ﷺ). I promised to pray perfectly, pay my Zakat, and give good advice to every Muslim.

title: Selling Pollinated Date Palms
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: If someone sells date palms that have already produced fruit, the buyer gets to keep those fruits. But if the seller and buyer agree otherwise, it's okay.

title: Barirah's Freedom
content: Aisha told me that a slave named Barirah came to her for help. She wanted to be freed from her masters, but they wouldn't agree to let Aisha pay the price of freedom on one condition: that when Barirah was free, she would still belong to them. Aisha told the Prophet about this and he said, 'Buy Barirah's freedom and it will be okay - her loyalty will go to you, not her old masters.'

title: The Prophet Helps a Camel
content: Jabir was riding a tired camel. The Prophet (ﷺ) passed by and gently hit the camel to wake it up. He then prayed for good health for the camel. After that, the camel became very fast. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked Jabir to sell him the camel for one Uqiyya of gold. At first, Jabir said no. But the Prophet asked again and this time Jabir agreed. They made a deal: Jabir could ride the camel to his home in Medina. When they arrived, Jabir took the camel back to the Prophet. The Prophet (ﷺ) gave him the money he owed for the camel. Then, instead of keeping the money, the Prophet said that Jabir should keep the camel as a gift.

title: Sharing Date Palms
content: Some people from Medina asked the Prophet to divide their date-palms between them and some other Muslims who had moved there. The Prophet (ﷺ) said no. Then, the people of Medina suggested that the new Muslims could work in their gardens and they would share the fruit with them. The new Muslims agreed to do this.

title: Land Given to the Jews
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) gave the land of Khaibar to the Jewish people. They were allowed to work on it and grow food, but they had to give half of what they grew back to him.

title: Marriage Conditions are Important
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: 'When getting married, the most important things to agree on come first.'

title: Renting Land in Islam
content: Rafi' bin Khadij said: We used to work on the land for a share of what it produced. But sometimes there was no harvest, so we were told not to do this anymore. Now we can rent the land by paying money instead.

title: Rules for Fair Trading
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: Don't cheat people when selling. If something is already sold to a Muslim brother, don't offer more money for it. And don't try to get engaged to someone who's already promised to another Muslim man. Also, a married woman shouldn't ask her sister to divorce so she can marry the same man.

title: Bedouin's Case Judged by Allah
content: A man came to the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ). He asked him to judge a case according to God's laws. The other side spoke up and said it was okay for the Prophet to decide. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Go ahead.' The man explained that his son had worked for another man and slept with his wife. People told him he should be stoned to death, but instead he paid one hundred sheep and a slave girl as a ransom. He asked scholars what to do next, and they said the son should get 100 lashes and be away from home for a year, and the other woman's wife should be stoned to death. The Prophet (ﷺ) decided that was not right. He said, 'I will judge this case according to God's laws.' He told the man to return the slave girl and sheep. His son would get 100 lashes and be away for a year. Another man, Unais, went to talk to the other woman. She confessed what she had done, so the Prophet ordered her to be stoned to death.

title: Bedouin's Case Judged by Allah's Laws
content: A bedouin came to the Prophet and asked him to judge a case according to God's laws. The other man said it was okay for the Prophet to judge them, so he spoke up. He said his son had worked for this man, but had sex with his wife. People told him that his son should be stoned to death, but he paid 100 sheep and a slave girl instead. Then he asked scholars what to do, and they said his son should get 100 lashes and be sent away for a year, while the other woman's wife should be stoned to death. The Prophet (ﷺ) said he would judge them according to God's laws. He ordered that the slave girl and sheep be returned to the bedouin, his son should get 100 lashes and be sent away for a year, and Unais should go talk to the other woman. She confessed her sin, so she was stoned to death.

title: Barirah's Freedom
content: Aisha had a woman named Barirah who was going to be freed. But her masters wanted something in return: they wanted control over her after she was free. Aisha didn't agree with this, but then the Prophet came and said that when someone is freed, their new owner gets control, not the old ones.

title: Prohibited Business Practices
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) forbade four things: meeting caravans on the way to cheat them, a resident buying goods for a Bedouin, a woman asking for divorce as a condition of marriage, and trying to cancel someone else's deal. He also prohibited 'An-Najsh' and selling milk from an animal that has not been milked yet.

title: Moses and Al-Khadir's Story
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) told the story of Moses. Moses met a wise man named Al-Khadir. Al-Khadir said to Moses, 'You can't be patient with me.' Moses forgot an agreement they made, then he promised not to ask Al-Khadir anything unless it was allowed. But on their third journey together, Moses asked Al-Khadir about something without permission. This happened three times: once when Moses forgot, and twice when he broke his promise.

title: Barirah's Freedom Contract
content: Aisha met Barirah, a slave who wanted to be free. Her masters had agreed to let her go for nine Awaq of gold, paid one Uqiyya each year. But they wanted the right to keep control over her after she was freed. Aisha said she would pay them all at once if they gave up their rights. Barirah went back to her masters and told them about it, but they refused. The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) heard about this and said that any conditions not in Allah's laws are invalid. He advised Aisha to buy Barirah and let her masters agree that she would still be under their control after being freed. This way, the Wala (control) would stay with them as it should.

title: Umar Exiles Khaibar Jews
content: `Umar said that the Prophet had made a deal with the Jews of Khaibar. They could stay in their land as long as Allah allowed it. But `Abdullah bin `Umar was attacked and hurt by some people from Khaibar, so `Umar decided to exile them. A Jew came to see `Umar and said that the Prophet had joked about being kicked out of Khaibar. `Umar didn't believe him and said they were lying. He then made them leave their homes and paid them money for their properties.

title: The Hudaibiya Treaty
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) was on his way to Mecca with a group of Muslims. He wanted to perform the Umra pilgrimage, but the Quraish tribe did not want him to enter their city. Khalid bin Al-Walid, who was leading the cavalry of Quraish, tried to stop the Muslim army. The Prophet 's (ﷺ) camel stopped at Thaniya, and he said it had been stopped by Allah. He then rebuked his camel, and it got up. The Prophet (ﷺ) changed his route and went to a place called Al-Hudaibiya. There was a well with some water, but when the people drank from it, they complained of thirst. The Prophet (ﷺ) took an arrow out of his quiver and put it in the well. Water started flowing, and everyone quenched their thirst. Budail bin Warqa came to the Prophet and told him that Ka'b and 'Amir were planning to attack them. The Prophet (ﷺ) said he was not there to fight but to perform Umra. He offered a truce with Quraish, which they accepted. They agreed that if Muhammad (ﷺ) won, Quraish would have the option to convert to Islam. Suhail bin 'Amr and Mikraz bin Hafs came to negotiate with the Prophet. They wrote a peace treaty, but it was not easy. The Prophet (ﷺ) had to agree to return Abu Jandal, who was one of his companions, to Quraish. When the treaty was written, the Prophet ordered his companions to slaughter their sacrifices and shave their heads. But they did not move until he did it first. Some believing women came and reminded them of Allah's orders. The Prophet (ﷺ) then returned to Medina and Abu Basir, a new Muslim convert from Quraish, came to him. He was handed over to the two men who had come with him, but he escaped and killed one of them. He then joined Abu Jandal and together they formed a strong group that attacked Quraish caravans heading towards Sham.

title: The Hudaibiya Treaty
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) went to Al-Hudaibiya with his companions. Khalid bin Al-Walid was leading the cavalry of Quraish at a place called Al-Ghamim. The Prophet (ﷺ) told his companions to take the right path, and they reached Thaniya mountain. The Prophet 's (ﷺ) she-camel sat down, but it got up when he rebuked it. He said that the camel had not become stubborn, but was stopped by Allah. If Quraish asked for something that respected Allah's laws, he would grant it to them. The people used up all the water from a pit and complained to the Prophet. He took an arrow out of his quiver and ordered them to put it in the pit. Water started flowing from the pit, and everyone quenched their thirst. Budail bin Warqa came with some people from Khuza'a tribe and told the Prophet that Ka'b bin Luai and 'Amir bin Luai were at Al-Hudaibiya with milch camels and would fight against them. The Prophet (ﷺ) said he had not come to fight, but to perform Umra. He proposed a truce to Quraish: if they accepted Islam after his victory over the infidels, they could join the other Arabs who had become Muslim. If they did not accept the truce, he would fight them defending his cause until he was killed. Budail went back to Quraish and told them what the Prophet had said. They discussed it among themselves and decided to send 'Urwa bin Mas'ud to meet with the Prophet. 'Urwa met with the Prophet and asked him not to extirpate his relatives, but the Prophet said he would accept everything they demanded if it respected Allah's laws. The Prophet (ﷺ) proposed a peace treaty: Quraish would allow Muslims to visit the Kaaba next year, and in return, the Muslims would return anyone who came to them from Quraish, even if they had become Muslim. Suhail bin 'Amr agreed to this proposal, but only on condition that Abu Jandal was returned to him. The Prophet (ﷺ) accepted this condition, but later said that he would not break his promise and hand over Abu Jandal. When the peace treaty was written, the Prophet told his companions to get up and slaughter their sacrifices and shave their heads. But none of them got up, so the Prophet went out and did it himself. Seeing him do it, his companions got up and followed suit. Some believing women came to the Prophet and Allah revealed a verse about examining emigrant women. The Prophet (ﷺ) returned to Medina and Abu Basir, a new Muslim convert from Quraish, came to him. He was handed over to two men who were sent by Quraish, but he killed one of them and escaped. When the other man reached Medina, he told the Prophet what had happened. The Prophet (ﷺ) said that Allah had made him fulfill his obligations by returning Abu Basir to Quraish, but had saved him from them. Abu Jandal got himself released from Quraish and joined Abu Basir. They formed a strong group and attacked Quraish caravans heading towards Sham, killing the infidels and taking their properties. The people of Quraish sent a message to the Prophet requesting him to send for Abu Basir and his companions, promising that whoever came to the Prophet would be secure. The Prophet (ﷺ) sent for them, and Allah revealed verses about how He had withheld their hands from each other in Mecca after making them victorious over each other.

title: Compensation for Muslim Women
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) used to check on women who had moved from Mecca to Medina after becoming Muslims. When Allah told Muslims to return money spent on their wives, some men divorced their non-Muslim wives. Umar divorced two of his wives because they were not Muslims. Later, Muawiya married one of them and another man married the other. The pagans refused to pay back the money, so Allah ordered that if a Muslim's wife left him for a non-Muslim husband, he should get some of the money given by the new husband to his new wife.

title: Lending Money with Interest
content: Abu Huraira said that the Prophet mentioned a man who borrowed 1,000 Dinars from an Israeli. The loan was for a fixed time.

title: Freeing a Slave Woman
content: Aisha's slave woman Barirah asked for her help to be freed. Aisha said she would pay the price and keep the rights of ownership. When the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) came, he told Aisha that it was better to buy Barirah and free her instead. He then explained from the pulpit that making conditions not allowed by Allah's laws is invalid.

title: Allah's Names Bring Paradise
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: Allah has ninety-nine names. Knowing these names will get you into Paradise.

title: Umar's Endowment Advice
content: Ibn Umar said that Umar bin Al-Khattab got some land in Khaibar. He went to the Prophet and asked, 'What should I do with this new land?' The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'You can give it as a charity so its fruits help those in need.' Umar agreed and made it an endowment. It couldn't be sold or given away freely. Its yield would go to the poor, family members, freeing slaves, and for Allah's cause. Even the person taking care of it could eat from it if needed.

title: Write Your Will
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: If you have something to leave behind when you die, make a will and keep it with you for at least two nights before you pass away.

title: What Prophet Muhammad Left Behind
content: When Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) died, he didn't leave any money or slaves. He had a white mule and some arms. He also gave away a piece of land as charity.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Will
content: I asked Abdullah bin Abu Aufa if the Prophet made a will. He said no. I asked why people are told to make a will, and he replied that the Prophet left behind Allah's Book (the Quran).

title: Prophet's Will and Succession
content: Some people told Aisha that the Prophet had chosen Ali as his successor. Aisha said she didn't know about this. She explained that when the Prophet died, he was resting against her chest. He asked for a washbasin and then passed away without her noticing.

title: Prophet's Advice to Sa'd
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) visited me when I was sick in Mecca. He said, 'May Allah have mercy on you.' I asked if I could give all my money to charity. He said no. I asked about giving half or a third of it. He said yes to one third, but even that's too much. It's better for your family to inherit wealth than to beg others. Whatever you spend for Allah is considered a good deed, even small things like food for your wife. The Prophet (ﷺ) also said that Allah might give me more time so some people can benefit from me and some be harmed.

title: Bequests: A Reminder
content: Ibn Abbas said that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said to reduce what you leave behind by will. He said it's better to leave one-third, but even that is too much.

title: Prophet visits a sick friend
content: Sa'd fell ill and the Prophet visited him. Sa'd said, 'I don't want to die in this land.' The Prophet (ﷺ) replied, 'May Allah heal you and let people benefit from you.' Sa'd wanted to leave half of his property for charity, but the Prophet said, 'Half is too much.' When Sa'd suggested leaving one-third, the Prophet again said it was too much. Later, people started leaving one-third of their property in wills, which became allowed.

title: The Boy's True Father
content: Sa'd took a boy from his brother 'Utba. He said the boy was his nephew. But Abu bin Zam'a stood up and said, 'No, he is my brother.' They went to the Prophet. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Abu bin Zam'a, this boy belongs to you because he was born on your father's bed.' He also told Sauda bint Zam'a to stay away from the boy because she thought he might be her husband's son.

title: Crushing the Head of a Girl
content: Anas said that a Jew hurt a girl by crushing her head with two stones. When asked who did it, she nodded when they mentioned the Jew's name. The Prophet (ﷺ) then had the Jew punished in the same way.

title: Inheritance Laws Changed by Allah
content: Ibn Abbas said: In the past, when someone died, their children got all their belongings. But if the parents wanted to inherit something, it had to be left in a will. Then Allah changed this rule. Now, men get twice as much as women from an inheritance. Each parent gets one-sixth of what's left. A wife gets either one-eighth or one-fourth. And a husband gets half or one-fourth.

title: Best Kind of Charity
content: A man asked the Prophet what kind of charity is best. The Prophet (ﷺ) said: 'Give when you're healthy and want more money, not when you're sick or near death.' He warned that if you wait until you're dying, it's not your money to give – it belongs to your family.

title: Signs of a Hypocrite
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said that there are three signs of a hypocrite. They lie when they speak, break promises, and don't keep their word when trusted with something.

title: Hakim's Generosity Advice
content: Hakim asked the Prophet for help twice. The Prophet (ﷺ) said that wealth is like a sweet fruit. If you take it without wanting more, you'll be happy with it. But if you take it and always want more, you won't be satisfied. The Prophet (ﷺ) told Hakim that giving is better than taking. After this, Hakim promised not to ask anyone for help again after the Prophet died. He kept his promise even when Abu Bakr and Umar asked him to accept some money.

title: Responsibility in Islam
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said: Everyone is responsible for what they are in charge of. A leader is responsible for his people, a man is responsible for his family, and a woman is responsible for her home. Even a servant is responsible for taking care of their master's belongings. And a son is also responsible for looking after his father's property.

title: Sharing with Family Members
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) told Abu Talha to share his garden with his relatives. Abu Talha did as he was asked and divided the garden among them. When a verse from the Quran said 'warn your closest family', Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) called out to the big families of Quraish, saying 'O people of Quraish'.

title: Warning to Quraish Tribe
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) stood up and said: 'People of Quraish, save yourselves from Allah's punishment. I won't be able to protect you. Fatima, ask me for anything from my wealth, but I can't stop Allah's punishment.'

title: Ride the Sacrifice Camel
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) saw a man leading a camel meant for sacrifice. He told the man to ride it. The man said it was a special camel and couldn't be ridden. The Prophet (ﷺ) repeated his order, then added a warning: 'Woe to you' if you don't listen.

title: Riding a Badana
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) saw a man riding a Badana. He told the man to ride it again, and said 'Woe to you' on his second or third time doing so.

title: Giving Charity for the Dead
content: Sa'd's mother died while he was away. He asked the Prophet if giving charity on her behalf would help her. The Prophet (ﷺ) said yes, so Sa'd gave his garden in charity as a gift to Allah.

title: Giving Charity for Repentance
content: I asked the Prophet if I could give all my money to charity so that Allah would accept my repentance. He said it's better for me to keep some of my wealth, and I agreed to do that.

title: Abu Talha Donates His Garden
content: Anas said that when the verse 'You won't be good people unless you spend what you love' was revealed, Abu Talha went to the Prophet and offered him his favorite garden. The Prophet (ﷺ) said it was a valuable gift and asked Abu Talha to share it with his relatives. Abu Talha did this, but later one of his relatives sold their share to Mu'awiyya for money.

title: Guardians and Inheritance
content: Ibn `Abbas said that some people think the order in a certain Verse has been cancelled. But Allah says it's not cancelled, people just stopped following it. There are two kinds of guardians: one inherits and should give to relatives, orphans, and the needy. The other doesn't inherit but should speak kindly and say 'I can't give you this' when distributing wealth.

title: Giving Charity for a Deceased
content: A man asked the Prophet if he could give charity on behalf of his mother who had died suddenly. The Prophet (ﷺ) said yes, and told him to go ahead and give charity in her name.

title: Fulfilling a Mother's Vow
content: Sa'd bin Ubada asked the Prophet for advice. His mother had made a promise to Allah but hadn't kept it before she died. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Keep your word and fulfill her vow'.

title: Giving Charity for a Mother
content: Sa'd's mother died when he was away. He asked the Prophet if giving charity on her behalf would help her. The Prophet (ﷺ) said yes, so Sa'd gave his garden as charity in her name and had the Prophet witness it.

title: Guardians and Orphan Girls
content: Aisha said that the verse 'And if you fear that you will not deal fairly with the orphan girls then marry (other) women of your choice' is about a guardian who wants to marry an orphan girl because she's beautiful and rich. He might not give her a fair dowry like other women get. The Prophet (ﷺ) was asked about this, so Allah revealed another verse saying 'They ask your instruction...'. This means if the guardian doesn't want to marry the orphan when she's not attractive or wealthy, he shouldn't try to marry her just because she's beautiful and rich. He must treat her fairly by giving a full dowry.

title: Umar's Garden Charity
content: One day, Umar told the Prophet that he wanted to give some of his property in charity. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Give it as an endowment with its land and trees. They should never be sold or given away for free. But you can use the fruit to help people in need.' Umar did this, and the garden was used to free slaves, feed the poor, and support guests and travelers. The person taking care of it could eat from it reasonably, but not too much, and a friend could also eat from it if they were hungry.

title: Guardianship of Orphans
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said that a Verse was revealed about guardians who take care of orphans. If the guardian is poor, he can take some money from the orphan's wealth if it's fair and reasonable according to the rules of inheritance.

title: Seven Destructive Sins
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said to avoid seven big sins. People asked what they were. He said: Don't worship anyone except Allah, don't practice magic, don't kill someone unless it's allowed by law, don't take money that has extra interest, don't take an orphan's money, don't give up and run from a fight when you're supposed to be fighting, and don't accuse a woman who is good and honest of something bad.

title: Anas Serves the Prophet
content: When the Prophet came to Medina, he didn't have a servant. Anas' step-father took him to the Prophet and said, 'He's a smart boy, let him help you.' So, Anas helped the Prophet at home and on trips. If Anas did something, the Prophet never asked why. And if Anas didn't do something, the Prophet also never asked why.

title: Abu Talha's Generous Gift
content: Anas bin Malik told us that Abu Talha had a lot of date-palms in Medina. He loved his garden, Bairuha', which was near the mosque where the Prophet used to visit and drink from its water. When the Quran said 'You won't be good until you give what's precious to you,' Abu Talha wanted to share his garden with others. He asked the Prophet if he could use it for charity, hoping for a reward from Allah. The Prophet (ﷺ) said 'Well done!' and suggested that Abu Talha should share it among his family members. Abu Talha did as advised and gave the garden to his relatives.

title: Giving Charity for the Dead
content: A man asked the Prophet if giving charity on behalf of his mother who had died would benefit her. The Prophet (ﷺ) said yes, and the man gave a garden in charity as a witness to this act.

title: The Prophet Buys a Garden
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) wanted to build a mosque. He asked the owners of a nearby garden if they would sell it to him. They said, 'We won't sell it to anyone but Allah.' The Prophet (ﷺ) bought the garden for his mosque.

title: Umar's Endowment Advice
content: Ibn Umar said that one day, `Umar came to the Prophet and said, 'I just got some land in Khaibar. What do you think I should do with it?' The Prophet (ﷺ) replied, 'You can keep it for charity if you want.' So, `Umar made the land a gift to be used for helping those in need. He set some rules: no one could sell or give it away as a present, and its money would go towards helping poor people, family members, freeing slaves, supporting wars, and feeding guests and travelers. The person taking care of the land could eat from it fairly and also help his friends without becoming rich.

title: Umar's Charity Gift
content: `Umar told the Prophet about some land he got in Khaibar. The Prophet (ﷺ) said to him, 'If you want, you can give it to help those in need.' So `Umar gave that land as a charity, and its money would be used for the poor, people who don't have much, his relatives, and guests.

title: Building a Mosque in Medina
content: When the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) came to Medina, he asked the people of Bani An-Najjar if they would sell him their garden. They said no, and refused to accept any payment except from Allah himself.

title: Giving Charity and Buying Back
content: Ibn Umar told me that one day Prophet Muhammad 's (ﷺ) companion, Omar, gave a horse to someone to use for fighting in the way of Allah. The horse had been given to Omar by Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) himself. Later, Omar found out that the person he gave the horse to was selling it instead of using it for its intended purpose. So Omar asked Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) if he could buy back the horse. But Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said no, because once you give something in charity, you should not take it back.

title: Allah's Messenger's Will
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: 'My family will not get any money from me. Whatever I leave behind is for charity, except for what my wives need to live and the salaries of my workers.'

title: Umar's Endowment Rule
content: When Umar created a charity fund, he said its manager could eat from it and also give food to his friends. But they couldn't store any money or food for themselves. He also reminded people that the Prophet said whoever dug the well of Ruma would go to Paradise, and he had done that. Whoever helped with the army in Tabuk would also go to Paradise, and Umar had helped with that too.

title: The Prophet Buys a Garden
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) asked the people of Bani An-Najjar to tell him how much they wanted for their garden. They said they didn't want money from anyone but Allah. Later, two men took some property that belonged to someone who had died in a place with no Muslims. They claimed they lost a valuable bowl, and the Prophet made them swear an oath. But then people found the bowl in Makkah and said it was theirs. Two other witnesses stood up and said their testimony was more important than the first two men's. The Prophet (ﷺ) then received a revelation from Allah about what to do when someone dies.

title: The Prophet Helps with Debts
content: Jabir's father was killed in battle and left behind six daughters and unpaid debts. Jabir went to the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) and asked for help. The Prophet (ﷺ) told him to collect all the dates from their farm and put them into separate piles. When the creditors arrived, they were very demanding. The Prophet (ﷺ) walked around one of the piles three times, then sat on it and called out to the creditors. He started measuring out the dates and giving them to the creditors until all of Jabir's father's debts were paid off.

title: Best Deeds According to the Prophet
content: I asked the Prophet what is the best thing to do. He said to pray on time. I asked again, and he said to take care of your parents. Then I asked about something else good to do, and he said to fight for Allah's cause.

title: No More Migration
content: After Mecca was conquered, there is no need to leave for Medina. Instead, Muslims should be ready to fight when called upon by their leaders and have good intentions in their actions.

title: Jihad for Women
content: Aisha asked the Prophet: 'Don't we fight in Allah's Cause?' He said: 'For women, the best way to fight is by doing Hajj correctly.'

title: Jihad's Equal Reward
content: A man asked the Prophet for a deed as good as fighting in Jihad. The Prophet (ﷺ) said he couldn't find one. Then he thought and said, 'Can you pray all day and fast every day while your friend is fighting?' The man said that was hard to do. Abu Huraira added that even small actions, like a horse grazing, can earn reward for the fighter.

title: Who is the Best Person?
content: Someone asked the Prophet who was the best person. The Prophet (ﷺ) said a good Muslim who works hard for Allah with everything he has, including his life and money. They asked about the next best person. The Prophet (ﷺ) said someone who lives in the mountains, worships Allah, and doesn't cause trouble for others.

title: Mujahid's Reward in Paradise
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said, 'A person who fights for Allah is like someone who always prays and fasts. If this fighter is killed, Allah will send him to Heaven. If he returns home safely, Allah will give him rewards and wealth.'

title: Prophet's Dream of Fighters
content: Anas bin Malik narrated that one day the Prophet visited Umm Haram bint Milhan. She offered him food and then started looking for lice in his head. The Prophet (ﷺ) fell asleep, woke up smiling, and said some of his followers were shown to him as brave fighters on a ship. They looked like kings sitting on thrones. Umm Haram asked the Prophet to pray that she could join them. The Prophet (ﷺ) prayed for her, but said she was already among the first ones who would be fighting in Allah's cause.

title: Prophet's Dream of Fighters
content: Anas bin Malik told us that the Prophet visited his friend Umm Haram. She gave him food and then looked for lice in his hair. The Prophet (ﷺ) fell asleep, woke up smiling, and said some of his followers were fighting for Allah in a dream. They were like kings on thrones. Umm Haram asked the Prophet to pray for her to join them. He prayed for her and went back to sleep. When he woke up again, he smiled and told her about the same dream. She asked him to pray for her again, and this time he said she would be among the first ones. Later, during Mu'awiya's rule, Umm Haram sailed on a ship and died after getting off it.

title: Believe, Pray, Fast, Enter Paradise
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: If you believe in Allah and His Messenger, pray correctly, and fast during Ramadan, you will go to Heaven. Whether you fight for Allah or stay home, it doesn't matter. Some people asked if they could share this good news with others. The Prophet (ﷺ) said that there are 100 levels of happiness in Heaven, and the distance between each one is huge. He encouraged them to ask Allah for the best level, called Al-firdaus, which is near Allah's Throne.

title: Two Men in a Dream
content: Samura said that the Prophet had a dream where two men took him to a tree and then to an even better house. One of them said, 'This is the home of people who die as martyrs.'

title: Fighting for Allah's Cause
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said that one effort to fight in Allah's name is better than everything in the world.

title: Paradise is Better
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said that a small place in Paradise is better than the whole world. He also said that doing one good deed, no matter when, is better than everything on earth.

title: Afternoon Effort Better Than Wealth
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said that doing something good for Allah in the morning and afternoon is better than having all the wealth in the world.

title: Martyrs Prefer Heaven
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: 'No one who dies and goes to a good place in the afterlife would want to come back to this world, even if they were given everything. But a martyr might wish to return to be killed again for Allah's cause.'

title: Fighting for Allah's Cause
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said that fighting for Allah is more important than all the world and its things. A small place in Paradise is better than everything on earth. If a woman from Paradise appears, she shines so brightly that it fills the space between Heaven and Earth with light. Her head covering is worth more than everything on earth.

title: Desire to Fight for Allah
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: 'If I had money to give everyone who wants to fight for Allah, I would go with any army. I wish to die and be brought back to life so I can die again fighting for Allah, then come back to life again and do it all over.'

title: Prophet's Words on Martyrs
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) gave a sermon and said: Zaid took the flag and was killed in battle. Then Ja'far took the flag and was also killed. After that, Abdullah bin Rawaha took the flag but he too was killed. Finally, Khalid bin Al-Walid took the flag, even though he wasn't supposed to be in charge. But Allah helped him win. The Prophet (ﷺ) said it would not have been good for those martyrs to come back and live with us.

title: Um Haram's Dream and Death
content: Um Haram said the Prophet slept in her house. He woke up smiling and told her he had a dream. In his dream, some of his followers were sailing on a green sea like kings. Um Haram asked him to pray for her to be with them. The Prophet (ﷺ) prayed for her and went back to sleep. He had the same dream again and she asked him to pray for her again. This time he said she would be among the first group. Later, Um Haram went on a naval expedition with her husband 'Ubada bin As-Samit. When they returned, she was given a riding animal but it threw her off and she died.

title: Um Haram's Dream and Death
content: Anas bin Malik told us that Um Haram said: The Prophet (ﷺ) slept in my house. He woke up smiling. I asked him, 'What makes you smile?' He said, 'Some of my followers were shown to me sailing on a green sea.' I asked him, 'O Messenger of Allah! Make me one of them.' He prayed for me and went back to sleep. When he woke up again, he smiled and told his dream. I asked him the same question and he gave the same answer. I said, 'Make me one of them.' He said, 'You are among the first group.' Later, Um Haram went on a naval expedition with her husband Ubada bin As-Samit. When they returned to Sham, she was given a riding animal but it threw her off and she died.

title: Prophet's Mission to Bani Amir
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) sent a group of seventy men from the tribe of Bani Sulaim to the tribe of Bani Amir. When they arrived, Anas' uncle went ahead and asked for permission to deliver the Prophet's message. The pagans agreed, but while he was speaking, one of them stabbed him to death. Anas' uncle said 'Allah is greater!' before being killed. The rest of the group were attacked and killed, except for a lame man who escaped up a mountain. Gabriel told the Prophet that the martyrs had met Allah and He was pleased with them. The Prophet (ﷺ) then prayed for forty days to curse those responsible from the tribes of Ral, Dhakwan, Bani Lihyan, and Bani Usaiya.

title: Wounded Finger in Battle
content: During a battle, the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) got hurt on his finger. He said, 'This small injury is for Allah's cause.'

title: Wounded in Allah's Cause
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said: Whoever gets hurt while fighting for Allah will come back to life on the Day of Resurrection with their wound still there, but it won't smell bad - it'll smell like musk.

title: Heraclius on Prophets
content: Abu Sufyan told Abdullah bin Abbas that Heraclius said: 'I asked you about your battles with the Prophet. You said you had some wins and some losses. This is how prophets are tested, but they always win in the end.'

title: Anas bin An-Nadr's Bravery
content: My uncle Anas was not in the Battle of Badr. He said to the Prophet: 'If Allah lets me fight, I'll be brave.' At Uhud, when Muslims were running away, he prayed: 'I'm sorry for what my friends did, and I reject what our enemies did.' Then he went forward and met Sa'd bin Mu'adh. Anas said: 'Sa'd, I can smell the scent of Paradise coming from in front of us.' Later, Sa'd said that when they found Anas after his death, there were over 80 wounds on his body. We thought a verse was revealed about him because it says: 'Among believers are those who keep their promises to Allah...' His sister's tooth was broken by an enemy woman. The Prophet (ﷺ) ordered retaliation, but Anas said: 'By the One Who sent you with truth, my sister's tooth won't be broken.' The enemies accepted compensation instead of revenge. The Prophet (ﷺ) then said: 'There are people whose oaths are made true by Allah when they take them'.

title: Anas bin An-Nadr's Bravery
content: Anas' uncle was absent from the Battle of Badr. He said to the Prophet: 'If I get a chance, I'll fight bravely.' At Uhud, when Muslims were running away, he prayed for forgiveness and denounced the enemy. Then he went forward, but was killed by many wounds. His sister recognized him only by his fingers. The Quran says that some believers are true to their promise with Allah. Anas' sister broke a woman's tooth in revenge, but the Prophet ordered retaliation. Anas said: 'My sister's tooth won't be broken.' The opponents accepted compensation, and the Prophet said: 'Some people's oaths are fulfilled by Allah when they take them'.

title: Missing Verse in Al-Ahzab
content: Zaid bin Thabit said that when the Quran was compiled from different manuscripts, one verse from Surah Al-Ahzab was missing. He remembered it because he used to hear the Prophet recite it. Zaid found the verse with Khuza'ima bin Thabit Al-Ansari, who the Prophet considered equal in witness to two men. The missing verse said: 'Among the believers are those who keep their promises to Allah.'

title: Embracing Islam First
content: A man came to the Prophet. He was wearing a metal mask and wanted to know if he should fight or become Muslim first. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Become Muslim first, then fight.' The man became Muslim and was killed as a martyr. The Prophet (ﷺ) said that even though he did very little work, he would get a great reward.

title: Mother's Question About Haritha
content: Um Ar-Rubai', the mother of Haritha bin Suraqa, came to the Prophet and asked about her son. He had been killed in battle at Badr. She said she would be patient if he was in Paradise, but would cry if not. The Prophet (ﷺ) told her that there are special gardens in Paradise and her son is in the best one.

title: Fighting for the Right Reason
content: A man asked the Prophet about a person who fights in war. He said one might fight for money, another for fame, and another to show off. The Prophet (ﷺ) explained that only someone who wants Allah's message of Islam to be stronger is truly fighting for Allah.

title: Dust for Allah's Cause
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: If someone walks around with dust on their feet because of helping others or working for Allah, they will not be punished in the afterlife.

title: Abu Sa'id's Story
content: Ibn `Abbas sent me and Ali to meet Abu Sa'id. We found him watering his garden with his brother. He sat down with us and said, 'When we built the mosque of the Prophet, I carried one brick at a time while Ammar carried two. The Prophet (ﷺ) saw Ammar and gently removed the dust from his head. He said, 'May Allah be kind to Ammar. He will be killed by a group who don't listen. They'll invite him to obey Allah, but he'll invite them to Hellfire'.

title: Gabriel visits the Prophet
content: After the battle of Al-Khandaq, the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) returned home. He took a bath and then Gabriel came to him. Gabriel's head was covered in dust. He said, 'You've stopped fighting? I haven't finished yet.' The Prophet (ﷺ) asked where he should go next. Gabriel pointed towards the tribe of Bani Quraiza. So the Prophet went there.

title: Curse on Those Who Killed Companions
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) prayed for 30 days to ask Allah to punish those who had killed his friends at Bir-Mauna. He asked Allah to be angry with the tribes of Ral, Dhakwan, and Usaiya because they disobeyed Allah and him. A verse from the Quran was revealed about the people who were killed at Bir-Mauna, but it was later removed.

title: Drinking Alcohol Before Battle
content: Jabir bin Abdullah said that some people drank alcohol on the morning of the battle of Uhud and were killed in the same day. When asked if they died later in the day, it was confirmed that they had been martyred early.

title: Prophet's Reaction to a Body
content: My father was brought to the Prophet. His body was badly hurt. I wanted to see his face but my friends stopped me. We heard someone crying and thought it might be their daughter or sister, Amr. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked why she was crying. He said, 'Don't cry because angels are still protecting him.'

title: Paradise is Better
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: 'No one who enters Paradise wants to go back to the world. But a fighter for Allah might want to return so he can be killed again and again, because of the respect Allah gives him.'

title: Paradise is Under Swords
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said: 'Remember that Paradise is under the shade of swords.'

title: Solomon and the Women
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said that Solomon, son of David, wanted to have children with many women. He planned for each woman to give birth to a brave fighter who would help Allah's cause. A companion reminded him to say 'Allah willing', but he forgot. As a result, only one woman became pregnant and gave birth to a half-man.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Generosity
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) was known for being kind, brave, and generous. One time, when the people of Medina were scared, he rode a horse to calm them down and said, 'This horse is very fast'.

title: The Prophet's Generosity
content: Jubair bin Mut'im was with the Prophet when some people from Hunain returned. They begged him so much that he stood under a tree and his cloak was taken away. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Give me back my cloak. If I had as many camels as these trees, I would give them to you.'

title: Sa'd's Prayer for Protection
content: Sa'd used to teach his sons a prayer that Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) would say after every prayer. The prayer is: 'I ask God to protect me from being cowardly, and from becoming old and weak again. I also ask Him to keep me safe from the troubles of this life and from punishment in the grave.'

title: Prophet's Daily Prayer
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) used to say: 'O Allah, I ask for Your protection from being helpless, lazy, or cowardly. I also ask for Your protection from the troubles of life and death, and from punishment in the grave.'

title: Talha Remembers Uhud
content: I was with Talha, Sa'd, Al-Miqdad, and Abdur Rahman. We were talking about the day of the battle of Uhud. But only Talha was sharing a story from Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ).

title: Conquest of Mecca
content: On the day of the Conquest, the Prophet said: 'There is no need to move to a new place for safety after we've won. Now, your duty is to fight and be ready when called upon by the Muslim leader.'

title: Two Men Enter Paradise
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said that Allah welcomes two men with a smile. One man fights for Allah and gets killed. The other man kills him, but then also dies fighting for Allah. Both men enter Paradise because Allah forgives them.

title: Abu Huraira's Share at Khaibar
content: I went to the Prophet while he was in Khaibar. I asked for a share of the land, but one of his companions said not to give me any. He claimed that I had killed a Muslim and that Allah did not punish him because of it.

title: Abu Talha's Fasting Habit
content: Anas bin Malik said that before the Prophet passed away, Abu Talha never fasted because he was busy with Jihad. After the Prophet died, I saw Abu Talha fasting every day except on Eid al-Fitr and Eid al-Adha.

title: Who are considered martyrs
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said that five types of people are considered as martyrs. They die from: plague, a serious stomach illness, drowning, falling from a building, or fighting for Allah's cause.

title: Death from Plague is Martyrdom
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said that if a Muslim dies from the plague, it's considered martyrdom.

title: Blindness is not a reason
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) sent for Zaid to write down a new rule. The rule said that sitting at home and praying does not make you equal to those who fight in the way of Allah, unless you are disabled or blind. Anyone else must work hard and fight.

title: Blind Man's Desire to Fight
content: Marwan bin Al-Hakam told me that Zaid bin Thabit said the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) dictated a verse: 'Not all believers are equal. Some stay at home, while others fight for Allah.' When Ibn Um-Maktum, who was blind, heard this, he said he wished to join the fight. The Prophet 's (ﷺ) thigh was on top of Zaid's lap as they received a new revelation from Allah: 'Except those who are disabled or unable to fight due to injury or blindness'.

title: Be Patient in Battle
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: When you face your enemy, be patient.

title: Prophet Visits the Trench
content: One day, Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) went to see people digging a trench. It was very cold and they were tired and hungry because they didn't have slaves to help them. He saw how hard they were working and said, 'God, forgive these people.' They replied that they had promised him they would keep fighting for Islam as long as they lived.

title: Digging the Trench
content: The people of Medina were digging a trench around their city. They carried heavy loads on their backs and said, 'We have promised to fight for Islam as long as we live.' The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) replied, 'Only good things come from Allah's reward in the afterlife. Bless the Emigrants and the Ansar with your kindness.'

title: Prophet's Gratitude to Allah
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) carried some earth and said, 'We would not have known what to do without Your guidance.'

title: Prophet Carrying Earth
content: On the day of battle, I saw the Prophet carrying a basket of earth. The earth covered his stomach. He said: 'Without Allah's help, we wouldn't know what to do, or give charity, or pray. Please make us calm and strong when we face our enemies. These people have wronged us, but we won't give up if they try to harm us.'

title: Returning from Tabuk
content: Anas said: We came back to Madinah with the Prophet after the battle of Tabuk.

title: Sharing Rewards in Jihad
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said that some people were with him in a battle even though they didn't join physically. They stayed behind due to a valid reason, so they shared the reward of the jihad.

title: Fasting for Allah's Pleasure
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: If someone fasts one day for Allah, He will keep their face away from Hellfire for a distance of seventy years' walking.

title: Two Things for Allah
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'If someone spends two things in the way of Allah, they will be called by the gatekeepers of Paradise. They will say,

title: Worldly Wealth Can Be Trouble
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) stood on the pulpit and said that he worried about what would happen to his followers after he was gone. He mentioned how they might be tempted by worldly wealth and pleasures. A man asked, 'Can good things lead to bad?' The Prophet (ﷺ) stayed silent for a moment, then wiped sweat from his face and asked where the questioner was. He repeated, 'Is wealth good?' three times, saying no. He explained that wealth can be like food that makes animals sick if they eat too much of it. He said that Muslim wealth should be earned honestly and spent on helping others, but if not, it will be a problem on Judgment Day.

title: Helping a Warrior
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said: If someone helps a fighter go to war for Allah, they get the same reward as the fighter. And if someone takes care of the family of that fighter while they are away, they also get the same reward.

title: Prophet's Kindness to Um Sulaim
content: Anas said the Prophet never visited any house in Medina except Um Sulaim's when he was asked why, he replied: 'I feel sorry for her because her brother died with me'.

title: Thabit bin Qais at Yamama
content: Anas bin Malik visited Thabit bin Qais during the battle of Yamama. Anas saw that Thabit was perfuming himself with a fragrant paste called Hunut, and asked him why he wasn't fighting yet. Thabit said he would join soon, but kept applying the perfume. When the people fled from the battlefield, Thabit told them to clear a path for him so he could fight. He said they wouldn't have run away if Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) was with them.

title: Prophet's Trust in Zubair
content: Jabir said the Prophet asked who could get him information about their enemy on the day of the Battle of Al-Ahzab. Az-Zubair volunteered to do it twice. The Prophet (ﷺ) then said that every prophet had a helper, and his helper was Az-Zubair.

title: Prophet's Disciple
content: Jabir bin Abdullah said the Prophet called people to scout. Az-Zubair went twice when called. The Prophet (ﷺ) then said, 'Each prophet had a helper. My helper is Zubair bin Al-Awwam'.

title: Leading Prayer Together
content: When I was leaving with my friend, the Prophet said to us: 'You two should say the call to prayer and then get ready for it. The older one of you should lead the prayer.'

title: Goodness on Horses' Foreheads
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said that good will always be present on the foreheads of horses until the Day of Judgment.

title: Goodness on Horses' Foreheads
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said that good qualities will stay on horses' foreheads until the Day of Judgment.

title: Blessing in Horse Foreheads
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said that there is a blessing in the foreheads of horses.

title: Goodness in Horses' Foreheads
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Horses that go to war will always have goodness on their foreheads until the Day of Judgment. They bring either a reward or treasure.'

title: Reward for a Horse Owner
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: If someone takes care of a horse to help others in Allah's cause, they will be rewarded on the Day of Judgment. The reward includes what the horse eats and drinks, as well as its waste.

title: Abu Qatada's Onager Incident
content: Abu Qatada went on a journey with the Prophet. He was left behind with some companions who were in a special state for pilgrimage, but Abu Qatada wasn't. They saw an onager before he did. When they saw it, they didn't talk until Abu Qatada saw it too. He rode his horse and asked to take a whip, but they refused. So, he took the whip himself and killed the onager. They ate its meat, but later regretted eating it. When they met the Prophet, they asked him about it. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked if they had any of the meat left. Abu Qatada said yes, they had a leg left. The Prophet (ﷺ) then took the leg and ate it.

title: Prophet's Horse in Our Garden
content: Sahl said the Prophet had a horse called Al-Luhaif or Al-Lukhaif that was kept in our garden.

title: Allah's Right and Our Right
content: I was riding a donkey with the Prophet. He asked me: 'Do you know what Allah wants from us, and what we can ask of Him?' I said I didn't know. The Prophet (ﷺ) said: 'Allah wants us to only worship Him, not anyone else. And our right is that Allah won't punish us if we only worship Him.' I wanted to tell others about this good news, but the Prophet told me not to.

title: Prophet's Horse Ride
content: There was a feeling of fear in Medina. The Prophet (ﷺ) borrowed a horse called Mandub and rode away on it. When he returned, he said he didn't see anything to be afraid of. He thought the horse was very fast.

title: Three Things Bring Bad Luck
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: 'Bad luck can come from three things: a horse, a woman, or a house.'

title: Three Things That Bring Bad Luck
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: 'If there's something that brings bad luck, it's a woman, a horse, and a house.'

title: Horses and Their Purpose
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said that horses can be kept for three reasons. Some people keep them as a way to earn reward, by using them for good like going on jihad or keeping them in a safe place where they eat grass. If the horse breaks free and moves around, even if it's just a little bit, its waste and footprints will still count as good deeds for that person. But if someone keeps a horse only to show off and be proud, then the horse will bring them harm. Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) was asked about donkeys and he said that there is one rule that applies to all animals: doing even a small good thing will have its reward, but doing a small bad thing will also have its punishment.

title: Jabir's Journey with the Prophet
content: Jabir bin Abdullah told me that he went on a journey with the Prophet. When they were returning, the Prophet said to Jabir, 'If you want to go back home quickly, hurry up.' Jabir was riding a strong camel, but it suddenly stopped because it was tired. The Prophet (ﷺ) hit the camel once with his whip and it started moving fast again. Later, when they arrived in Medina, Jabir sold the camel to the Prophet for some gold. When he gave the money to the Prophet, the Prophet said, 'You can keep both the money and the camel.'

title: Prophet's Visit to Medina
content: Anas bin Malik said that there was a feeling of fear in Medina. The Prophet (ﷺ) borrowed a horse called Mandub from Abu Talha and rode it. When he returned, he said he didn't see anything scary and the horse was very fast.

title: War Booty Distribution
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) decided that from any captured wealth, the horse gets two parts and its rider gets one part.

title: Bara's Story at Hunain
content: Someone asked Bara if he had run away from the Prophet during the battle of Hunain. Bara said no, the Prophet didn't run away. The Hawazin people were good archers and they fought back when we attacked them. But the Prophet stayed and collected the war spoils. I saw him on his white mule with Abu Sufyan holding its reins. He said, 'I am a true prophet, I'm the son of Abdul Muttalib'.

title: Prophet's Recitation on Journey
content: When the Prophet got ready to ride his camel, he would start reciting a prayer called Talbiya at the mosque of Dhul-Hulaifa before leaving.

title: Prophet Meets People on Horse
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) was riding a horse without a saddle. His sword was hanging from his shoulder as he approached the people.

title: Prophet's Horse Ride
content: Anas bin Malik said the Prophet rode Abu Talha's horse when people in Medina were scared. The horse moved slowly, but was good at running. When he returned, the Prophet said his horse was very fast.

title: Prophet's Horse Race
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) organized a horse race between two groups of horses. One group was made to run from Al-Hafya to Thaniyat Al-Wada', which is about five or six miles away. The other group ran from Thaniyat to the mosque of Bani Zuraiq, which is only one mile away. I, `Abdullah bin `Umar, took part in this horse race.

title: Horse Racing with the Prophet
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) organized a horse racing event. The race was from Ath-Thaniya to the mosque of Bani Zuraiq. Abdullah bin Umar took part in the race, but it's not clear if he won or lost.

title: Racing Horses with the Prophet
content: Ibn 'Umar said: The Prophet (ﷺ) arranged a horse race for horses that had been made lean. They started from Al-Hafya' and ran to Thaniyat-al-Wada', which is about six or seven miles away. Then, he arranged another race for healthy horses starting from Thaniyat-al-Wada' and running to the mosque of Bani Zuraiq, which is only one mile away. Ibn 'Umar participated in this horse race.

title: Prophet's Camel
content: The Prophet 's (ﷺ) camel was named Al-Adba.

title: Al-Adba: A Humbling Lesson
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) had a very fast camel called Al-Adba. One day, a Bedouin came with an even younger camel that beat Al-Adba in a race. The Muslims were upset, but the Prophet noticed their concern and said, 'It's Allah's way to bring down those who think they're above others.'

title: What the Prophet Left Behind
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) did not leave any money or property when he died. He left a white mule and his arms, which were given to him by Allah's will. He also left some land that was meant for charity.

title: Prophet's Courage at Hunain
content: Al-Bara told a man that Abu 'Umara didn't run away during the battle of Hunain. He said, 'No, by Allah, the Prophet didn't run. Some people were in a hurry and left, but the Hawazin tribe was shooting arrows at them. The Prophet (ﷺ) was on his white mule, with Abu Sufyan holding its reins. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'I am truly the Prophet, I am the son of Abdul Muttalib'.

title: Aisha's Request for Jihad
content: I asked the Prophet if I could go to war. He said my work is going on Hajj pilgrimage.

title: Best Way to Fight
content: One day, the Prophet's wives asked him about Jihad. He said, 'The best way to fight for me is to perform Hajj.'

title: Prophet's Joyful Dream
content: Anas said the Prophet visited a woman and slept. When he woke up, he smiled. She asked him why he was smiling. He said he had a dream about his followers sailing on a green sea for Allah's Cause. They looked like kings sitting on thrones. The woman asked if she could join them in their journey. The Prophet (ﷺ) prayed to Allah to make her one of them. Later, the woman went on a sea journey with other women, including Mu'awiya's wife. Unfortunately, she fell off her camel and died.

title: Prophet's Dream of Sailors
content: Anas said that the Prophet went to visit a woman and fell asleep. When he woke up, he was smiling. The woman asked him what made him smile. He said he had a dream about his followers sailing on a green sea for Allah's cause. They looked like kings sitting on thrones. She asked him to pray for her to join them in their journey. He prayed and then fell asleep again. When he woke up, he smiled again and she asked him the same question. He said she would be among the first group of his followers sailing on the sea, not the last. Later, she married a man named 'Ubada bin As-Samit and sailed with another woman for Allah's cause. On her way back, her riding animal threw her off and broke her neck, causing her death.

title: Prophet's Journey Decision
content: When the Prophet wanted to go on a trip, he would choose one of his wives by drawing lots. One time, before going to war, the lot fell on me, so I went with him after we had been told to wear veils.

title: Women Help at Uhud
content: Anas said that during the Battle of Uhud, he saw Aisha and Um Sulaim carrying water skins. They poured water into people's mouths, then went back to refill their skins and came back again with more water.

title: Umar Gives a Garment
content: `Umar was giving clothes to the women of Medina. One woman suggested he give a special garment to his wife, Um Kulthum, who is the daughter of the Prophet's daughter. But `Umar said no, because another woman, Um Salit, had helped them on the day of Uhud by carrying water skins.

title: Helping Wounded Companions
content: Ar-Rubayyi 'bint Mu'auwidh said: We were with the Prophet. We gave water to those who were hurt, helped them get better, and brought back those who had died from the battle.

title: Helping in Battles
content: Ar-Rubai' bint Mu'auwidh said: We used to join the Prophet's battles. We'd bring water, serve food and help carry the dead or injured back to Medina.

title: Removing an Arrow
content: Abu Musa told me about a man named Abu 'Amir who was hurt by an arrow in his knee. I helped him remove the arrow, and water came out. When I told this to the Prophet, he prayed for forgiveness for Abu 'Amir.

title: Prophet's Night Vigil
content: One night, the Prophet was awake. When he arrived in Medina, he said, 'I wish a good Muslim from my friends would stay with me tonight.' We heard someone moving their arms. He asked, 'Who is there?' The person replied, 'It's Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas. I've come to protect you.' So the Prophet fell asleep.

title: Don't Love Money
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: If someone loves money and clothes too much, they will be unhappy if they don't get them. They will also be unhappy if they do get them because they'll always want more.

title: Don't love wealth too much
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: If a person loves money and things more than anything else, they will be unhappy if they don't get what they want. They will also be unhappy in the afterlife. On the other hand, someone who fights for Allah's cause with courage and simplicity is happy wherever they are placed in battle. If they ask to leave their post, it won't be allowed. And if they try to help others, their help won't be accepted.

title: Jabir Serves Anas
content: Anas was traveling with Jabir. Although Jabir was older, he helped Anas. Jarir saw the Ansar showing great respect to the Prophet. He vowed to serve any of them if he met one.

title: Prophet's Visit to Khaibar
content: I went with the Prophet to a place called Khaibar. When we returned, he saw the Uhud mountain and said it was a mountain that loved us and we loved it. He pointed to Medina and asked Allah to make the area between its two mountains a safe place, just like Abraham made Mecca safe. He then prayed for blessings in our food.

title: Fasting and Reward
content: We were on a journey with the Prophet. The sun was strong, so we had to rely on our own clothes for shade. Those who were fasting stayed still, while those who weren't helped take care of the camels, brought them water, and looked after anyone who was sick or hurt. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Today, those who didn't fast got all the reward'.

title: Charity is Everywhere
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: Charity is needed every day. Helping someone with their animal, like giving them a ride or lifting their bags, counts as charity. Saying something kind to someone and going to the mosque for prayer are also considered charity. Even helping someone find their way on the road is charity.

title: Guarding Muslims for a Day
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said that helping to protect Muslims from enemies in Allah's name for just one day is better than having all the wealth and things on earth. Even a small spot in Paradise is worth more than everything on earth. And traveling even a short distance to help others in Allah's cause is also better than owning the whole world.

title: The Prophet's Journey to Khaibar
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) asked Abu Talha for a servant to help him on his trip. Abu Talha chose me, and I rode behind him. When we stopped, the Prophet would pray: 'I seek refuge with You from trouble and sadness.' We reached Khaibar and conquered it. The Prophet (ﷺ) saw Safiya, whose husband had been killed. He took her as his wife. At a place called Sa`d-As-Sahba', he married her in front of me. We left for Medina. On the way, the Prophet made space for Safiya to sit behind him on his camel. When we approached Medina, he looked at Uhud Mountain and said it loved us. He then blessed Medina.

title: Prophet's Dream of Sea Voyage
content: Um Haram told me that the Prophet took a nap in her house. He woke up smiling and said he had seen people from his followers on a sea journey, looking like kings sitting on thrones. Um Haram asked him to pray for her to be with them. The Prophet (ﷺ) said she was already among them. This happened three times. When 'Ubada bin As-Samit married Um Haram, they went for Jihad together and when they returned, an animal was given to her to ride but she fell off and died.

title: Prophet's Dream of Sea Voyage
content: Um Haram told me that the Prophet took a nap in her house. He woke up smiling and said he had a dream about his followers on a sea journey who looked like kings sitting on thrones. Um Haram asked him to pray for her to be with them, and each time he fell asleep again, he smiled and said she was already among them.

title: Don't Think You're Better
content: Sa'd thought he was better than others. The Prophet (ﷺ) said: 'You won't get ahead or make a living without the help of those who are less well-off.'

title: Jihad and Victory
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: Groups of people will go for Jihad. They'll be asked if anyone has met the Prophet. If they say yes, they'll get victory from Allah. Later, they'll be asked again if anyone has met his companions. Again, they'll get victory. Then, they'll be asked a third time about meeting the companions' companions. Each time, those who have met the previous generation will get victory.

title: Fighting and True Faith
content: A group of Muslims and non-Muslims fought. After the fight, someone said a Muslim had done an excellent job killing non-Muslims alone. The Prophet (ﷺ) said this man was going to Hell. A person wanted to see what happened to him. He followed the man, who got badly hurt and decided to kill himself by leaning on his sword. This man then went back to the Prophet and said he believed in him as a messenger of God. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked what had happened, and this man told him about the other man's actions. The Prophet (ﷺ) explained that people can seem good but actually be bad, and vice versa.

title: Encouraging Archery Skills
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) passed by a group of people from the tribe of Bani Aslam who were practicing archery. He said, 'Keep practicing archery because your ancestor Isma'il was very good at it.' One side stopped throwing arrows when they saw the Prophet with them. They asked, 'Why should we throw if you're on our side?' The Prophet (ﷺ) replied, 'Throw and know that I am with both of you'.

title: Throw Arrows at Enemies
content: On the day of the Battle of Badr, when we stood against the Quraish army, the Prophet said: 'When they come near us, throw arrows at them.'

title: Playing in the Mosque
content: Some Ethiopians were playing near the Prophet. Umar saw them and picked up a stone to hit them. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Let them play.' They were playing in the mosque.

title: Abu Talha and the Prophet
content: Abu Talha was a good archer. He and the Prophet used to share one shield when fighting. When Abu Talha shot his arrows, the Prophet would look at where they landed.

title: Prophet's Injury Treated
content: When the Prophet was hurt in a battle, his helmet broke and blood covered his face. One of his teeth was broken too. Ali brought water to clean him, but it made the bleeding worse. Fatima, the Prophet's daughter, took ashes from a burnt mat and put them on the wound. The bleeding stopped.

title: Umar Narrates About Fai Booty
content: `Umar said: The properties taken from Bani An-Nadir were not won by the Muslims in battles. These properties belonged to the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ), who used them for his family's expenses and for buying horses and arms for Allah's cause.

title: Prophet's Generosity to Sa'd
content: Ali said he never saw the Prophet say 'Let my parents sacrifice their lives for you' to anyone except Sa'd. The Prophet (ﷺ) told Sa'd, 'Throw the arrows.'

title: Prophet Muhammad visits Aisha
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) came to my house. Two girls were singing a song about the war between two tribes. Abu Bakr scolded me, saying it was wrong for them to sing in front of him. The Prophet (ﷺ) turned his face away and said 'Leave them'. When Abu Bakr looked away, I asked the girls to leave. It was Eid day and people often played with shields and spears. I wanted to see this display, so the Prophet let me stand behind him. He was saying 'Carry on!' to the players. When I got tired, he asked if that was enough. I said yes, and he told me to leave.

title: Prophet Muhammad at Aisha's House
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) came to my house. Two girls were singing a song about an old war between tribes. The Prophet (ﷺ) lay down and turned away. Abu Bakr scolded me, saying it was like having the devil in front of him. But the Prophet told Abu Bakr to leave them alone. When Abu Bakr wasn't looking, I asked the girls to go away. It was a special day when people would play with shields and spears. I wanted to see this display, so the Prophet let me stand behind him. He said 'keep going' as we watched together. When I got tired, he asked if that was enough, and I said yes.

title: The Prophet's Bravery at Night
content: One night in Medina, the people were scared. They went to find out what was happening. The Prophet (ﷺ) met them on his way back. He was riding a horse without a saddle, and he said, 'Don't be afraid!' He also said that this horse is very fast.

title: Conquered Lands Had Simple Swords
content: Abu Umama said that some people conquered many countries. Their swords were not decorated with gold or silver, but with leather, lead, and iron.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Encounter
content: Jabir bin Abdullah was with the Prophet when they were on a journey. They stopped in a valley to rest during the hottest part of the day. The Prophet (ﷺ) hung his sword on a tree and everyone took a nap. When he woke up, he saw a Bedouin holding his unsheathed sword. The Bedouin challenged the Prophet, saying 'Who will save you from me?' The Prophet (ﷺ) calmly said 'Allah' three times without punishing the man.

title: Prophet's Wound at Uhud
content: Sahl was asked about the Prophet's injury on the day of the battle of Uhud. He said that the Prophet's face was hurt, one of his front teeth was broken, and his helmet was damaged. Fatima cleaned the blood from the wound while Ali held water for her. When she saw the bleeding wasn't stopping, she burned a mat made of palm leaves until it turned to ashes. She put the ashes on the wound and the bleeding stopped.

title: Prophet's Last Leftovers
content: When the Prophet passed away, he didn't leave behind any wealth. He left his arms, a white mule, and some land in Khaibar to be given to charity.

title: The Prophet's Encounter
content: Jabir bin Abdullah was in a battle with the Prophet. During the day, they stopped to rest in a valley with many thorny trees. The Prophet (ﷺ) rested under one tree and hung his sword on it. He then fell asleep. When he woke up, he saw a man standing near him who had not been there before. The man took the Prophet's sword out of its scabbard and said 'Who will save you?' The Prophet (ﷺ) replied 'Allah'. The man put the sword back and sat down. The Prophet (ﷺ) did not punish him.

title: Killing an Onager
content: Abu Qatada was with the Prophet when they were on their way to Mecca. Some of them were in a special state for pilgrimage, but Abu Qatada wasn't. He saw a wild donkey and wanted to ride his horse to catch it. His companions wouldn't lend him a whip or spear, so he took one himself and killed the donkey. When they caught up with the Prophet, some of them had eaten the meat while others hadn't. The Prophet (ﷺ) said that Allah had provided them with food.

title: Prophet's Prayer at Badr
content: On the day of the battle of Badr, the Prophet was in a tent. He said to Allah: 'I ask you to keep your promise and covenant.' If you want to destroy us, we will never worship you again after today. Abu Bakr took his hand and said: 'This is enough, Prophet.' The Prophet (ﷺ) wore armor and went out. He told the people that their enemies would run away and show their backs. But he also reminded them that the Day of Judgment was coming, which would be even harder than this defeat.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Debt
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) died while his armor was being held by a Jewish man as payment for thirty measures of barley.

title: Miser and Charitable Person
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: A miser is like someone wearing a tight iron jacket. When they want to help others, the jacket gets even tighter and their arms are stuck close to their body. But when a charitable person wants to give, their jacket opens up and covers them completely.

title: Prophet's Ablution Routine
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) went out to answer nature. When he returned, I brought him water. He washed his face and mouth with it. Then he rinsed his nose by putting water in it and blowing it out. Next, he washed his hands. Because his sleeves were tight, he put his hands under the cloak to wash them. Finally, he passed wet hands over his head and leather socks.

title: Wearing Silk for Health
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) allowed Abdur-Rahman and Zubair to wear silk shirts because they had a skin disease that made them itch.

title: Wearing Silk in Battle
content: Two companions, Abdur Rahman and Zubair, complained to the Prophet about lice causing them itching. The Prophet (ﷺ) allowed them to wear silk clothes for comfort. I saw them wearing silk during a holy battle.

title: Wearing Silk Allowed
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) allowed Abdur-Rahman bin Auf and Zubair bin Al-Awwam to wear silk clothing.

title: Wearing Silk for Itching
content: Anas said that AbdurRahman and Zubair were allowed to wear silk because they had an itchy skin condition.

title: Prophet Muhammad Eats a Sheep
content: Umaiya Ad-Damri said he saw the Prophet eating from a sheep. He cut off some meat and then went to pray without washing his hands again. Az-Zuhri also told this story, adding that when the Prophet finished cutting the meat, he put down the knife.

title: Paradise for Naval Expedition
