The Jew said, 'There is no other religion except Hanif.' Zaid asked, 'What is Hanif?' The Jew said, 'Hanif means the way of Abraham. He was neither a Jew nor a Christian and only worshiped Allah.' Zaid met a Christian scholar next. He told him the same thing as before. The Christian said, 'You can't join our religion unless you accept Allah's Curse.' Zaid replied, 'I don't want to be cursed by Allah. Can you tell me of another religion?' The Christian also said, 'There is no other religion except Hanif.' When Zaid heard that Abraham was the one who only worshiped Allah, he left and said, 'O Allah! I'm a witness that I follow Abraham's way.'

title: Zaid bin Amr's Kindness
content: Asma bint Abi Bakr saw Zaid bin Amr standing by the Ka'ba. He said, 'Only I follow Abraham's way.' He used to save little girls from being killed. If someone wanted to kill his daughter, Zaid would say, 'I'll take care of her instead.' When she grew up, he'd offer her back to her father.

title: Prophet Carries Stones
content: When the Ka'ba was rebuilt, the Prophet and his uncle Abbas went to help carry stones. Abbas told the Prophet to put his waist cloth over his neck for protection. But as soon as he did this, the Prophet fell unconscious on the ground with his eyes open towards the sky. When he came round, he said 'My waist cloth! My waist cloth!' Then he tied it around his waist again.

title: Praying around the Ka'ba
content: When Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) was alive, there was no wall around the Ka'ba. People used to pray by walking around it. Later, when Caliph Umar became leader, he built a wall around the Ka'ba. The wall was low, so later Caliph Ibn Az-Zubair made it higher.

title: Fasting on 'Ashura'
content: Before Islam, people from the tribe of Quraish used to fast on a special day called Ashura. The Prophet (ﷺ) also used to fast on this day. When he moved to Medina, he continued fasting and asked Muslims to do the same. Later, when Ramadan became a time for fasting, it was up to each person whether or not to fast on Ashura.

title: Ibn Abbas Explains Umra
content: People used to think performing Umra during Hajj was a bad thing. They said it's okay to do Umra after the wounds on camels have healed and their footprints are gone. The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) and his friends arrived in Mecca on the fourth of Dhul-Hijja, wearing Ihram for Hajj. The Prophet (ﷺ) told them to perform Umra instead of Hajj. His friends asked how to finish Ihram properly. The Prophet (ﷺ) said they should remove all restrictions completely.

title: Flood in Makkah Valley
content: Before Islam, a big flood came to the valley between two mountains near the Ka'ba.

title: Abu Bakr Teaches a Lesson
content: Abu Bakr met a woman named Zainab who was performing Hajj without speaking. He told her it's not allowed to be silent during Hajj, as it was done before Islam. She asked him his name and tribe, and he said he was Abu Bakr from the Quraish tribe. She then asked how long their good life under Islam would last, and Abu Bakr replied that it will continue as long as their leaders follow Islamic rules.

title: A Muslim Woman's Story
content: A black lady slave converted to Islam and had a hut in the mosque. She'd visit Aisha and talk about her past. One day, she said: 'God saved me from being an unbeliever.' When asked what she meant, she explained that once her masters accused her of stealing a leather scarf. They tortured her until a kite dropped it back into their hands, proving her innocence.

title: Swearing Only by Allah
content: Ibn Umar said the Prophet told people to only swear oaths by God. People from Quraish used to take oaths by their family, but the Prophet said not to do that.

title: Walking Behind a Funeral
content: Al-Qasim would walk in front of a funeral procession. He wouldn't stand up when it passed by him. Al-Qasim said that his mother, Aisha, told him that people used to stand up for funerals before Islam came. When they saw a funeral, they'd say twice: 'You were important in your family. What happened to you now?'

title: Leaving Muzdalifa Early
content: Umar said that before Islam, people used to stay in Jam' until the sun rose over Thabir mountain. The Prophet (ﷺ) disagreed with them and left Jam' before sunrise.

title: Kasan Dihaqa: A Traditional Drink
content: Ikrima said that in the past, people would order a glass full of drink. Then they'd ask for another full glass, and another, until they had 3840 glasses like this. Ibn Abbas said he heard his father talking about ordering Kasan Dihaqa when he was young.

title: Labid's True Words
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said that Labid was a poet who said something true. He said everything in the world will eventually disappear, except Allah. Umaiya bin As-Salt almost became Muslim but did not.

title: Abu Bakr's Honest Decision
content: Abu Bakr had a slave who sometimes gave him money. One day the slave brought some food and Abu Bakr ate it. The slave then said, 'Do you know where this came from?' Abu Bakr asked what he meant. The slave explained that in the past, before Islam, he used to pretend to have special knowledge and would cheat people for money. He had done this with someone else who gave him some food as a reward. Abu Bakr was upset when he heard this and immediately threw up everything he had eaten.

title: Forbidden Deal on Camels
content: Before Islam, people used to sell camels in a strange way. They would buy a camel that had not yet been born. The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) forbade this kind of deal.

title: Anas bin Malik's Stories
content: Ghailan bin Jarir visited Anas bin Malik and talked about the Ansar. Anas said to Ghailan, 'My people did something on a certain day, and your people did something else on another day.'

title: Qasama: A Laborer's Death
content: In the time before Islam, a man from Banu Hashim was working for a Quraishi man. The laborer helped another man from Banu Hashim with his bag and then died under mysterious circumstances. Before he died, he asked someone to deliver a message when they reached Mecca. The messenger called out to the family of Quraish and then the family of Banu Hashim, asking for Abu Talib. He delivered the laborer's message, saying that the killer had murdered him for a camel's fetter. Abu Talib went to the killer and gave him three options: pay 100 camels as compensation, have 50 men take an oath that he did not kill the laborer, or face punishment in Qisas. The killer chose to have his people take an oath. However, one of them asked to be excused from taking the oath because he was Abu Talib's son-in-law and had a child with him. Another man offered two camels as compensation instead of taking the oath. In the end, 48 men took the oath, but by the end of that year, none of those who took the oath were still alive.

title: Allah's Plan for the Ansar
content: 'Aisha said that Allah made a battle called Buath happen before the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) arrived in Medina. When he got there, people were already fighting each other and their leaders had been hurt or killed. This way, when the Prophet came, the Ansar (people of Medina) could accept Islam.

title: Running between Safa and Marwa
content: Ibn 'Abbas said that running between the two mountains of Safa and Marwa was not a good practice in Islam. People used to run there before Islam, but they did it because they didn't want to get wet by crossing a stream.

title: Ibn Abbas' Advice on Tawaf
content: Ibn Abbas said: 'Listen carefully to what I say. If you want to walk around the Kaaba, go behind Al-Hijr and don't call it Al-Hatim. In the past, people used to throw their whip or shoes in a circle when they made an oath.'

title: Monkeys Stoning a Monkey
content: I saw a group of monkeys stoning another monkey. The monkey they were stoning had done something wrong. I joined in and stoned it with them.

title: Traits of Pre-Islamic People
content: Ibn Abbas said that people in the time before Islam used to do three things. They would lie about other families' ancestors, cry loudly when someone died, and think that rain comes from special stars in the sky.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Life in Mecca
content: When Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) was 40 years old, he received a message from Allah. He stayed in Mecca for 13 years and then got an order to move to Medina. He lived there for 10 years before passing away.

title: Prophet's Promise to Believers
content: I visited the Prophet while he was sitting in the shade of the Kaaba. We were being hurt by non-believers at that time. I asked him, 'Will you pray for us?' He sat up and said, 'People before us were punished severely with iron tools to remove their skin and flesh. They even used a saw on their heads, but they never left their faith. Allah will complete our religion so that anyone traveling from Sana to Hadramaut won't fear anyone except God.'

title: Prophet's Recitation and Prostration
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) recited Surat An-Najm. He prostrated while reading it. Everyone else followed his example, except one man who took a handful of pebbles, lifted them, and then prostrated on them. He said, 'This is enough for me.' Later, I saw him killed as a non-Muslim.

title: Prophet Muhammad Disrespected
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) was praying when some people from the Quraish tribe surrounded him. One of them, Uqba bin Abi Mu'ait, put a bag of camel intestines on the Prophet's back while he was still praying. The Prophet (ﷺ) didn't stop praying until his daughter Fatima came and took it off. She then cursed the person who did this. After finishing his prayer, the Prophet asked Allah to punish the leaders of Quraish: Abu Jahl bin Hisham, Utba bin Rabi'a, Shaiba bin Rabi'a, Umaiya bin Khalaf or Ubai bin Khalaf. Later, I saw some of these people killed in the Battle of Badr and thrown into a well.

title: Murder and Repentance
content: Sa'id bin Jubair asked Ibn 'Abbas about two verses in the Quran. The first verse says not to kill animals or people that Allah has made sacred, unless it's necessary. The second verse says that if someone kills a believer on purpose, they will go to Hell. Ibn 'Abbas explained that when the first verse was revealed, some people said they had killed animals and people that were sacred, but also worshipped other gods and committed adultery. Allah then revealed another verse saying that those who repent and believe in Him are forgiven. For the second verse, Ibn 'Abbas said that if someone kills after learning about Islam's laws, their punishment is to go to Hell forever. Mujahid added that even if someone regrets what they did, it might still be too late.

title: Prophet Throttled by Pagan
content: Ibn `Amr bin Al-As told me that while the Prophet was praying in a corner of the Ka`ba, `Uqba bin Abi Mu'ait came and wrapped his garment around the Prophet's neck. He throttled him tightly. Abu Bakr saw this and caught `Uqba by his shoulder and pushed him away from the Prophet. The reason for this attack was that the Prophet said, 'My Lord is Allah.'

title: Allah's Messenger with Early Converts
content: I saw the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) with five slaves who had converted to Islam. Two women and Abu Bakr were also among them.

title: Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas' Story
content: Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas said: I was the only person to convert to Islam on a specific day. For seven days, there were only three Muslims in total.

title: Prophet knew of Jinn's hearing
content: Abdur-Rahman asked Masruq who told the Prophet about the Jinns listening to the Quran at night. Masruq said his father Abdullah told him a tree informed the Prophet.

title: Prophet's Private Cleanliness
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) was with Abu Huraira. He asked who was carrying a water pot for him. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Bring me stones to clean myself.' Abu Huraira brought the stones and put them down. When the Prophet finished, he told Abu Huraira not to bring animal bones or dung. Abu Huraira asked why. The Prophet (ﷺ) explained that these were food for Jinns. He had once met some kind Jinns who came from a place called Nasibin.

title: Abu Dhar Meets the Prophet
content: Abu Dhar's brother went to see a man who claimed to be a prophet. He listened to some of his talks and said they were good, but not poetry. Abu Dhar was still unsure if this man was really a prophet. So he decided to go to Mecca himself to find out more. When he arrived, he didn't know where the Prophet was staying, so he waited in the mosque for three days. One day, `Ali saw him and took him to meet the Prophet. The Prophet (ﷺ) told Abu Dhar that if he promised to guide him, he would tell him why he had come. Abu Dhar agreed and the Prophet said he was a messenger of Allah. The next morning, the Prophet told Abu Dhar to follow him, but to be careful in case there was danger. When they reached the mosque, Abu Dhar went inside with the Prophet and listened to more talks. He became a Muslim right away. The Prophet (ﷺ) told him to go back home and tell his people about Islam. But Abu Dhar wanted to announce it loudly, so he did. Unfortunately, the people got angry and beat him up. Al-Abbas helped him by saying that Abu Dhar was from a tribe that was important for trade.

title: Sa'id bin Zaid's Story
content: I heard Sa'id bin Zaid say in the mosque of Al-Kufa. He said: 'By God, I saw myself being forced to leave Islam by Umar before Umar himself became a Muslim. If the mountain of Uhud could move because of the bad things you did to Uthman, it would move.'

title: Powerful Since Umar Converted
content: Abdullah bin Mas'ud said: We were strong since Umar became a Muslim.

title: Umar's Fear and Protection
content: `Abdullah bin `Umar said that one day, his friend Umar was at home feeling scared. Al-`As bin Wail came to visit him. He was wearing a fancy cloak and shirt with silk edges. Al-`As asked Umar what was wrong. Umar said he was worried because people were saying they would hurt him if he became Muslim. Al-`As told Umar that no one could harm him, as he had promised to protect him. Then Al-`As went outside and met a group of people coming from the valley. They said they wanted to kill Umar because he had become a Muslim. Al-`As stopped them and said they couldn't touch Umar.

title: Umar's Conversion to Islam
content: When Umar became a Muslim, people gathered outside his house. A boy on the roof saw a man wearing a silk cloak say that he was protecting Umar and no one could harm him. The boy asked who this man was and was told it was Al-`As bin Wail.

title: Umar Accuses a Man
content: Abdullah bin Umar said that he never heard Umar express an opinion without it being correct. One day, while Umar was sitting, a handsome man walked by him. Umar thought the man might still be following his old ways or maybe he was a fortune teller. He called the man over and asked him about it. The man said that he had been a fortune teller before Islam. Umar then asked him to tell him something amazing that one of his female spirits had told him. The man said that one day, while he was in the market, a spirit came to him looking scared and said that the Jinns were being punished for listening to news from heaven. They were now following humans who rode camels instead. Umar thought this was true. The man then told Umar about another time when he was near some idols. A person came with a calf and slaughtered it as a sacrifice. An unseen creature shouted at him, saying 'O evil-doer! A successful message has been given! A wise man is saying:

title: Sa'id bin Zaid's Story
content: I heard Sa'id bin Zaid say that Umar's sister was forced to leave Islam by her brother, who wasn't a Muslim yet. If the mountain of Uhud could move, it would be upset about how badly you've treated Uthman.

title: The Prophet Shows a Miracle
content: People from Mecca asked the Prophet to show them a miracle. He showed them the moon splitting into two parts with the Hira' mountain in between.

title: The Moon Was Split
content: Abdullah said that while he was with the Prophet in Mina, the moon split into two pieces. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked Abdullah and others to be witnesses. A piece of the moon then moved towards a nearby mountain.

title: Moon Split in Two
content: Abdullah bin Abbas said that during the lifetime of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ), the moon was split into two pieces.

title: The Moon Was Split
content: Abdullah said that the moon was split into two pieces.

title: Speaking up for Justice
content: 'Ubaidullah bin 'Adi went to his uncle 'Uthman and told him that people were talking against Al-Walid bin 'Uqba. He advised 'Uthman to punish Al-Walid according to the law. 'Uthman asked if he had met the Prophet, but 'Ubaidullah said no. 'Uthman then explained his own faith and actions, saying he had followed the Prophet's teachings and obeyed his successors. He agreed with 'Ubaidullah that he should punish Al-Walid for what he did. 'Uthman ordered 40 lashes for Al-Walid, and 'Ali was asked to carry out the punishment.

title: Pictures in Churches
content: Two women from Ethiopia told the Prophet about a church they had seen. It had pictures inside. The Prophet (ﷺ) said that these people make buildings over graves and paint pictures there. He said this will not help them on the Day of Judgment.

title: Allah's Messenger Helps a Girl
content: When I came to Medina from Ethiopia, I was a young girl. The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) made me wear a special sheet with patterns on it. He gently rubbed the patterns with his hands and said 'Good, good'.

title: Greeting the Prophet while Praying
content: We used to greet the Prophet when he was praying. He would answer us back. But after we came back from Ethiopia, we greeted him again while he was praying and he didn't respond. We asked him why. He said that his mind is focused on something more important during prayer.

title: Two Migrations Reward
content: Abu Musa and his friends were in Yemen when they heard the Prophet was leaving for Medina. They got on a ship to join him, but it took them to Ethiopia instead. There, they met Ja'far bin Abi Talib and stayed with him until they finally arrived in Medina after the Prophet had conquered Khaibar. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'You people who traveled by ship will get the reward of two migrations.'

title: Funeral Prayer for a Good Man
content: When Negus died, the Prophet said to his followers: 'Today a good man has passed away. Get up and offer a funeral prayer for your brother Ashama.'

title: Leading Funeral Prayer
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) led a funeral prayer for the Negus. He made us stand in rows behind him, and I was either second or third in line.

title: Prophet's Funeral Prayer
content: Jabir bin Abdullah said that the Prophet offered a funeral prayer for Ashama, the Negus. He made four big calls to Allah during the prayer.

title: Negus' Death Announced
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) told his companions that Negus, the king of Ethiopia, had died. He asked them to pray for forgiveness for their brother. The Prophet (ﷺ) led a prayer at the mosque and said 'God is great' four times.

title: Prophet's Message at Hunain
content: Abu Huraira said the Prophet was going to fight in a battle. He said, 'Tomorrow, if Allah wills, we'll camp near Khaif Bani Kinana. This is where the people of Quraish made an oath against Islam.'

title: Abu Talib's Fate
content: Al-Abbas bin `Abdul Muttalib asked the Prophet, 'You didn't help your uncle Abu Talib, even though he protected you and stood up for you.' The Prophet (ﷺ) replied, 'He will be in a mild punishment. If I hadn't been there, it would have been much worse for him'.

title: Abu Talib's Final Moments
content: When Abu Talib was dying, the Prophet went to visit him. Abu Jahl and Abdullah bin Umaiya were sitting with him. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Uncle, say that there is no god but Allah.' They tried to persuade Abu Talib to stay with his family's old religion instead. But he kept saying he would stick to what they believed. When the Prophet left, he prayed for Allah's forgiveness for his uncle. Then two verses of the Quran were revealed: it's not right for the Prophet or believers to ask forgiveness for non-believers who will go to Hell, and only Allah can guide someone to the truth.

title: The Prophet's Uncle
content: Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri said the Prophet talked about his uncle Abu Talib. The Prophet (ﷺ) said that on Judgment Day, he might be able to help him get into a small fire that only reaches up to his ankles.

title: Allah Showed Me Jerusalem
content: Jabir bin Abdullah said that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) stood up in Al-Hijr and Allah showed him Jerusalem. He described it to his people while he was looking at it, so they could believe him.

title: The Prophet's Night Journey
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) was lying in a place called Al-Hatim. Suddenly, someone came and cut open his body from the top of his chest to his pubic area. Then they took out his heart and washed it with gold. They put his heart back inside him and filled it with faith. A small white animal was brought to the Prophet, which was smaller than a mule but bigger than a donkey. This was called Buraq. Gabriel rode on Buraq with the Prophet and they went up to the first heaven. There, they met Adam, who greeted the Prophet warmly. They then moved on to the second heaven, where they met John and Jesus, who also greeted the Prophet. They continued this way, meeting prophets like Joseph, Idris, Aaron, and Moses in each of the heavens. When they reached the seventh heaven, they saw Abraham, who was the Prophet's father. The Prophet (ﷺ) was then taken to a special tree called Sidrat-ul-Muntaha, which had huge fruits and leaves. Gabriel explained that this tree marked the boundary between the heavens and the earth. The Prophet (ﷺ) was shown three containers: one with wine, one with milk, and one with honey. He chose the milk, which represented Islam. Then, the prayers were given to the Prophet, but they were too many for his followers to bear. So, he went back to Allah and asked for a reduction in the number of prayers. This was done three times until the number of prayers was reduced to five a day.

title: Ibn Abbas Explains the Ascension
content: Ibn `Abbas said: Allah showed His Messenger a real vision of the heavens. This was to test people's faith. The sights the Prophet saw on his Night Journey, when he visited Jerusalem, were really there. He didn't just dream them. The tree mentioned in the Quran as being cursed is actually the Zaqqum tree.

title: Ka'b bin Malik's Story
content: I'm Ka'b bin Malik. I was supposed to go with the Prophet on a trip called Tabuk, but I stayed behind. When I got older and blind, I remembered another important event: we took an oath at Al-'Aqaba to support Islam together. I said that if I had to choose between fighting in the Battle of Badr or taking this oath, I would choose the oath.

title: Jabir's Experience at Al-Aqaba
content: I was with my two uncles in a place called Al-'Aqaba. One of them was Al-Bara' bin Marur.

title: Jabir's Family at Aqaba
content: My father and two uncles were among those who made a promise to follow the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) in Makkah at Aqaba.

title: Pledge of Allegiance
content: 'Ubada bin As-Samit said: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) surrounded by his companions said: 'Give me your promise to not worship anything but Allah, not steal, not have sex outside marriage, not kill your children, and not spread false rumors. If you do something wrong and get punished here on earth, that's a punishment for it. But if you do something wrong and don't get caught, then only Allah knows what will happen to you.' I promised to follow these rules.

title: Pledge of Allegiance
content: 'Ubada bin As Samit was one of the people who made a promise to Allah's Messenger (ﷺ). They promised not to worship anything except Allah, not to steal, not to have sex outside marriage, and not to kill anyone unless it is allowed by law. They also promised not to take things that don't belong to them from each other. If they did any of these things, Allah would judge them for it.

title: Aisha's Marriage Story
content: When I was six years old, the Prophet married me. We moved to Medina and stayed with a family called Bani-al-Harith. I got sick and lost my hair. When it grew back, my mother took care of me and prepared me for marriage. The Prophet (ﷺ) came to visit us when I was nine years old.

title: The Prophet's Dream of Aisha
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) told Aisha that he had seen her twice in a dream. In the dream, she was on a piece of silk and someone said 'this is your wife'. When he uncovered the picture, it was really her. He said if this is from God, then it will happen.

title: Khadija's Death and Aisha's Marriage
content: Khadija died three years before the Prophet moved to Medina. He stayed there for two years, then married Aisha when she was six years old. They had a physical relationship when she was nine years old.

title: Migrants' Reward with Allah
content: Abu Wail said that Khabbab told him: 'We migrated to Medina with the Prophet for Allah's sake. Our reward is now certain with Allah. Some of us died without getting any reward in this life. One example was Mus`ab bin `Umair, who was killed at Uhud while wearing a striped cloak. When we covered his head, his feet were bare. And when we covered his feet, his head was bare. The Prophet (ﷺ) told us to cover his head and put some Idhkhir on his feet. Meanwhile, some of us have already received their rewards in this life and are collecting them'.

title: Intention Matters in Action
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: 'What you get from your actions depends on why you did them. If you moved to a new place for money or to get married, that's what it was really about. But if you moved because of Allah and His Messenger, then that's what it's still about.'

title: No More Migration After Mecca
content: Abdullah bin Umar said: 'There is no more Hijrah after the Conquest of Mecca.'

title: Migration is Not Needed
content: 'Ata bin Abi Rabah and 'Ubaid bin 'Umar visited Aisha. They asked about migration. Aisha said, 'Today, there's no need to migrate. In the past, a believer would leave their home for Allah and His Prophet to avoid trouble because of their faith. Now Islam is strong everywhere. Believers can worship anywhere they want. Instead of migrating, people should do good deeds like fighting for Islam and having good intentions.'

title: Sa'd's Prayer for Peace
content: Sa'd said to Allah: 'You know I want to fight those who rejected Your Prophet and forced him out of his home. I think You have stopped the fighting between us.'

title: Prophet Muhammad's Life
content: Ibn Abbas said that the Prophet started receiving messages from Allah when he was 40 years old. He stayed in Mecca for 13 years, getting these messages. Then he was told to move away and he lived as a refugee for 10 years before passing away at 63.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Stay in Mecca
content: Ibn Abbas said that the Prophet stayed in Mecca for thirteen years after he received his first message from Allah. He died at the age of sixty-three.

title: Abu Bakr's Emotional Response
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) sat on the pulpit and said that Allah had given one of His followers a choice: to have wealth and power in this life, or good things in the next life. The follower chose the good things with Allah. Abu Bakr was so moved by this that he started crying and said 'Our parents be sacrificed for you.' People were surprised because they thought Abu Bakr didn't understand what was happening. But actually, it was the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) who had been given the choice, not the other follower. The Prophet (ﷺ) then praised Abu Bakr, saying he owed him more than anyone else for being a good friend and companion. He also said that if he could choose someone to be close to him like a brother, it would be Abu Bakr. But instead, he chose to have a special bond with all Muslims through Islam.

title: Abu Bakr and the Prophet
content: Aisha said her parents were always good Muslims. The Prophet (ﷺ) visited them every day. When Abu Bakr was forced to leave Mecca, he went to Ethiopia with his friend Ibn Ad-Daghina. The chief of Quraish asked Ibn Ad-Daghina to protect Abu Bakr and let him worship in his house. But when the people of Quraish saw how many women and children were gathering around Abu Bakr's mosque, they complained to Ibn Ad-Daghina. He told them that Abu Bakr should only worship at home. The Prophet (ﷺ) was still in Mecca. When he got permission to leave, he asked Abu Bakr to wait a little longer. Abu Bakr stayed with his two camels for four months. One day, the Prophet came to Abu Bakr's house and said it was time to go. They left their homes secretly, guided by a man from Bani Ad-Dail. When they were near Medina, Suraqa bin Ju'shum saw them but decided not to harm them after drawing lots with divining arrows. He told the Prophet about the plans of the people in Mecca and offered him food and goods, but the Prophet refused. The Prophet (ﷺ) wrote a statement of security for Suraqa and then continued on his way. When the Muslims of Medina heard that the Prophet was coming, they went to the Harra every morning to meet him. One day, they saw him emerging from the desert mirage with Abu Bakr. They welcomed him warmly and he stayed at Bani 'Amr bin 'Auf for ten nights. He built a mosque there and then continued on his way to Medina.

title: Asma Prepares Journey Food
content: Asma was preparing food for the Prophet and Abu Bakr when they were going to Medina. Asma told her father, 'I don't have anything to tie the container with except my waist belt.' Her father said, 'Cut it in half so you can use both parts as ties.' Because of this, Asma got the nickname 'Dhat-un-Nitaqain', which means 'the owner of two belts'.

title: Prophet's Journey to Medina
content: When the Prophet moved to Medina, a man named Suraqa chased him. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked Allah to harm Suraqa's horse. This happened and the horse got stuck in the ground. Suraqa then said he wouldn't hurt the Prophet if he prayed for his release. The Prophet (ﷺ) prayed for Suraqa. Later, the Prophet was thirsty and met a shepherd. Abu Bakr gave him some milk from the sheep to drink.

title: Prophet's Blessing for Abdullah
content: Asma was pregnant with her son Abdullah. She gave birth in Medina and took him to the Prophet. He asked for a date, chewed it, and put some of its juice in Abdullah's mouth. This was the first thing that went into his stomach. The Prophet (ﷺ) then rubbed Abdullah's tongue with a piece of date.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Blessing
content: When Abdullah bin Az-Zubair was born in Medina, the first child of the Emigrants, his parents brought him to the Prophet. The Prophet (ﷺ) took a date, chewed it, and then put its juice into the baby's mouth. This was the first thing that went into the baby's stomach.

title: Abu Bakr and the Prophet
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) arrived in Medina with Abu Bakr. People didn't know who the Prophet was, but they knew Abu Bakr. They asked Abu Bakr about the Prophet, and he said 'He shows me the right path.' A horse rider was chasing them, so the Prophet prayed for him to fall down. The horse threw the rider and got up neighing. Suraqa, the rider, became a protector of the Prophet. Later, the Ansar came with their arms to protect the Prophet and Abu Bakr. When they arrived at Abu Ayub's house, Abdullah bin Salam heard about it and went there. He testified that the Prophet was Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) and had come with truth. The Jews were asked to confirm this, but they refused. They said 'Abdullah bin Salam can't be a Muslim.' The Prophet (ﷺ) ordered them out of his presence.

title: Umar's Grants to Emigrants
content: Ibn Umar told me that Umar gave 4000 Dirhams to each Early Emigrant. He gave Ibn Umar only 3500 Dirhams. Someone asked, 'Why did you give him less?' Umar replied, 'His parents took him with them when they migrated.'

title: Khabbab Migrated with the Prophet
content: Khabbab said he migrated with Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) to a new place.

title: Migrants' Rewards and Martyrdom
content: We migrated with the Prophet to please Allah. Our rewards were guaranteed. Some of us died without enjoying them in this life. Musab bin Umair was martyred at Uhud. We didn't have a shroud for him, so we used a striped cloak. The Prophet (ﷺ) told us to cover his head and put grass on his feet instead.

title: Reward for Good Deeds
content: Abdullah bin Umar asked me if I knew what his father said to my father once. I said no, so he told me that his father said to my father: 'Will it please you that our good deeds with the Prophet are rewarded, but all our other good and bad deeds after he died are ignored?' My father replied: 'No, by Allah, we did many good things after the Prophet's death. Many people became Muslim because of us, and we expect rewards from Allah.' Abdullah's father said: 'I wish that what we did with the Prophet is still rewarded, but our other deeds can save us from punishment if they balance out the bad ones.'

title: Ibn Umar's Pledge of Allegiance
content: Abu Uthman told me that Ibn Umar got angry if someone said he migrated before his father, Umar. He said: 'Umar and I went to the Prophet when he was resting. We left and came back home. Then Umar sent me again to check if the Prophet was awake. I went in and gave him my pledge of allegiance. I told Umar that the Prophet was awake. So both of us went, slowly running, and gave our pledge of allegiance.

title: Abu Bakr's Journey with the Prophet
content: Abu Bakr bought a saddle from Azib. I helped him carry it. Azib asked Abu Bakr about the journey of the Prophet's migration. Abu Bakr said they had to be careful because their enemies were watching them. They left at night and traveled until noon. Then they found a rock with some shade. Abu Bakr spread his cloak for the Prophet to lie on. I went out to guard him. A shepherd came with his sheep looking for the same spot. I asked him who he belonged to, and if he had milk in his sheep. He said yes. I asked him to milk one of the sheep. He did, and I poured some water over the milk container to cool it down. Then I brought the milk to the Prophet and told him to drink. The Prophet (ﷺ) drank until I thought he was satisfied. We left and our pursuers followed us. Later, Abu Bakr took me home with the saddle. His daughter Aisha was lying in bed with a fever. Her father kissed her cheek and asked how she was.

title: Abu Bakr's Hair Colour
content: When the Prophet arrived in Medina, Abu Bakr was the oldest companion. He dyed his hair with Henna and Katam to make it darker. At that time, no other companions had grey and black hair except for Abu Bakr.

title: Abu Bakr in the Cave
content: I was with the Prophet in a cave. I looked up and saw people's feet. I said to the Prophet, 'If they look down, they'll see us.' The Prophet (ﷺ) told me to be quiet, saying we're two and Allah is with us.

title: Migration: A Difficult Task
content: A bedouin asked the Prophet about migration. The Prophet (ﷺ) said it's a hard thing to do. The bedouin said he had camels, so the Prophet asked if he gave them their zakat (charity). The bedouin said yes. Then the Prophet asked if others could drink their milk for free and if they shared milk with the poor on certain days. The bedouin said yes to both. The Prophet (ﷺ) told him to keep doing this and that Allah would reward his good deeds.

title: First Companions Arrive in Medina
content: Two men, Mus'ab bin 'Umair and Ibn Um Maktum, were the first to come to us in Medina. Later, 'Ammar bin Yasir and Bilal also arrived.

title: Prophet's Arrival in Medina
content: When the Prophet arrived in Medina, he was greeted with great joy. Before his arrival, some of his companions had already come to teach people about the Quran. These included Mus'ab bin 'Umair and Ibn Um Maktum. Later, Bilal, Sa'd, and Ammar bin Yasir also came. Then 'Umar bin Al-Khattab arrived with 20 other companions. When the Prophet finally arrived, everyone was happy. Even slave girls were saying,

title: Abu Bakr and Bilal's Fever
content: When the Prophet arrived in Medina, Abu Bakr and Bilal got sick. I visited them both and asked how they felt. When Abu Bakr's fever was bad, he said death is closer to him than his shoelaces. When Bilal's fever went away, he wished he could return to Mecca and see certain places again. I told the Prophet about this. He prayed: 'Make us love Medina more than Mecca. Make it healthy and prosperous, and take its sicknesses to Al-Juhfa'.

title: Uthman's Testimony of Faith
content: 'Ubaidullah bin Adi visited Uthman. After saying 'Tashah-hud', Uthman said, 'Then Allah sent Muhammad (ﷺ) with the truth. I was one of those who answered Allah's call and believed in Muhammad 's (ﷺ) message. I took part in two migrations to Medina. I married the Prophet's daughter and gave him my loyalty. I never disobeyed or deceived him until he passed away.'

title: Umar's Hajj Advice
content: `Abdur-Rahman bin `Auf met Umar at Mina during the last Hajj led by Umar. He said, 'O leader of believers, many bad people come to Hajj with good ones. I think you should wait until you get back to Medina.' In Medina, there are wise scholars and leaders who can help make good decisions. Umar replied, 'I will talk about this in my first sermon when I return to Medina'.

title: Uthman's Death and Legacy
content: An Ansari woman told the Prophet that her family had taken in Uthman bin Maz'un to live with them. He fell ill and died, so she covered his body with clothes. The Prophet (ﷺ) came to visit and she said goodbye to Uthman, saying 'May Allah have mercy on you.' She asked the Prophet if he thought Uthman was being honored by Allah. The Prophet (ﷺ) replied that death had caught up with him, but maybe he would be okay. He also said that even though he's the Messenger of Allah, he doesn't know what will happen to anyone after they die. This made her sad because she wanted to think well of others. She then had a dream where Uthman was shown as having good deeds. The Prophet (ﷺ) explained that this meant Uthman did have good things going for him.

title: Aisha Remembers a Battle
content: Aisha told me that before the Prophet came to Medina, there was a big fight called Bu'ath. Many important people were killed in this battle. This made it easier for the tribes to become Muslim when the Prophet arrived.

title: Abu Bakr and the Singers
content: One time Abu Bakr visited Aisha on a special day. The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) was with her and two girls were singing songs about the Ansar tribe's victory at Buath. Abu Bakr said, 'These instruments are from Satan.' But the Prophet replied, 'Let them be, every nation has its own celebrations, and this is our special day'.

title: Arrival in Medina
content: When Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) arrived at Medina, he stayed with the people of Bani `Amr bin `Auf for fourteen nights. He then sent for the leaders of Bani An-Najjar and they came with their swords. The Prophet (ﷺ) would pray wherever it was time to do so, even in sheepfolds. He ordered a mosque to be built and asked the leaders of Banu An-Najjar about the price of a nearby garden. They said they wouldn't sell it except to Allah. In that garden were graves of pagans, uneven land with holes, and date-palm trees. The Prophet (ﷺ) ordered the graves to be dug up, the land leveled, and the trees cut down. He used the tree trunks to build walls facing Mecca. Stone pillars were built at the gate, and the companions carried stones while reciting a prayer, with Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) among them.

title: Hajj: Staying in Mecca
content: `Umar bin `Abdul-Aziz asked As-Sa'ib about staying in Mecca after Hajj. As-Sa'ib said he heard the Prophet say an Emigrant can stay in Mecca for three days after leaving Mina.

title: Prophet's Arrival in Medina
content: The Prophet 's (ﷺ) companions didn't use the day he became a messenger or the day he died as the start of the Muslim calendar. Instead, they used the day he arrived in Medina.

title: Prayer Raka'at in Medina
content: Aisha told me that when the Prophet first came to Medina, he was asked to pray four raka'at for each prayer. But for journeys, two raka'at were still enough.

title: Giving Charity and Leaving a Legacy
content: One day, the Prophet visited me when I was ill. I said, 'I'm very sick and have no one to inherit my wealth except my daughter. Should I give two-thirds of it in charity?' He said, 'No.' Then he suggested giving one-third instead. He told me that leaving my children with some money is better than leaving them poor and begging for help. He also said that Allah will reward me for any good deed I do, even if it's just a small gift to my wife. I asked the Prophet if I would be left behind in Mecca after my friends had gone on their journey. He replied that if this happened, I would be rewarded for every good action I did with a desire to please Allah. The Prophet (ﷺ) hoped that I would live long and help some people while also causing harm to others. He then said a prayer for his companions, asking Allah not to make them turn back from their journey. Unfortunately, the Prophet was sad about the death of another companion named Sa'd bin Khaulah.

title: Abdur-Rahman's Marriage and Gift
content: When Abdur-Rahman came to Medina, the Prophet paired him with Sa'd bin Ar-Rabi. Sa'd suggested that Abdur-Rahman take half of his property and family. But Abdur-Rahman said he wanted to make a living on his own. He went into business and made some money from selling yoghurt and butter. A few days later, the Prophet saw him wearing perfume-stained clothes. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked what was going on, and Abdur-Rahman said he had married an Ansari woman. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked how much he gave her as a gift, and Abdur-Rahman said it was a small piece of gold worth about the weight of a date stone. Then the Prophet told him to give a banquet, even if it's just with a sheep.

title: Abdullah bin Salam Converts
content: Abdullah bin Salam met the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) in Medina. He asked the Prophet three questions: What is the first sign of The Hour? What food will people eat in Paradise? Why do children look like their parents? The Prophet (ﷺ) said Gabriel had just told him these answers. Abdullah then converted to Islam, saying 'I testify that there's no God but Allah and Muhammad (ﷺ) is His Messenger.' He asked the Prophet to ask the Jews about him before they knew he'd become a Muslim. When the Jews came, the Prophet asked them about Abdullah. They said he was one of their best people. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked again after Abdullah had converted, and they replied that they hoped he wouldn't become a Muslim. Abdullah then stood up in front of them and declared his faith again. They insulted him, saying he was wicked. Abdullah said this is what he'd been afraid of.

title: Credit Sales in Islam
content: Abu Al-Minhal asked a friend about selling goods on credit. His friend said it was okay because no one objected when he did it. Abu Al-Minhal then asked another man, Al-Bara', who replied that they used to do this before the Prophet came to Medina. The Prophet (ﷺ) said there's no problem with selling from hand to hand, but not on credit. A third man, Zaid bin Al-Arqam, also confirmed this.

title: Credit Sales in Islam
content: Abu Al-Minhal asked about selling goods on credit. His friend said it was okay because no one objected when he sold them that way. Abu Al-Minhal then asked Al-Bara' bin Azib, who replied that they used to make such transactions before the Prophet came to Medina. The Prophet (ﷺ) said there's no harm in selling from hand to hand, but selling on credit is not allowed. Abu Al-Minhal was told to ask Zaid bin Al-Arqam about it because he was a great trader. Zaid confirmed what Al-Bara' had said.

title: Ten Jewish Leaders
content: Abu Huraira said the Prophet said: If only ten Jewish leaders had believed in me, all Jews would have believed in me.

title: Fasting on Ashura Day
content: When the Prophet arrived in Medina, he saw that some Jews used to respect and fast on a special day called Ashura. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'We Muslims should also fast on this day.' He ordered everyone to start fasting on Ashura.

title: Fasting on Ashura
content: When the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) arrived in Medina, he saw that the Jews were fasting on a special day called 'Ashura'. They told him it was to remember when Moses and his people defeated Pharaoh. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'We are closer to Moses than you.' He then ordered Muslims to fast on this day too.

title: Prophet's Hair Style Changes
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) used to wear his hair loose. The pagans and people from the Scripture used to do the same. But later, he started parting his hair like they did.

title: People of Scriptures Divided
content: Ibn Abbas said that people who follow other religions divided the Quran into parts. Some of them believed in some parts, but not others.

title: Salman Sold as a Slave
content: Salman Al-Farisi was sold from one master to another for more than ten times the original price. This happened between 13 and 19 times.

title: Salman's Origin
content: Salman said he was from Ram-Hurmuz, a town in Persia.

title: Jesus to Prophet Muhammad
content: Salman said that there were 600 years between Jesus and the time of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ).

title: Zaid's Experience with the Prophet
content: I was sitting next to Zaid bin Al-Arqam when someone asked him how many battles the Prophet went on. He said nineteen. They then asked him which ones he joined, and he replied seventeen. I asked him which one was first, and he said either Al-`Ashira or Al-`Ashiru.

title: Sa'd bin Mu'adh's Umra
content: Sa'd bin Mu'adh went to Mecca for Umra. He asked Umaiya, his friend, to take him to the empty mosque so he could walk around the Kaaba. When they arrived, Abu Jahl met them and said Sa'd was safe in Mecca because of Umaiya's help. Sa'd replied that if Abu Jahl stopped him from walking around the Kaaba, he would stop Abu Jahl from passing through Medina. Umaiya told Sa'd to be quiet when talking to Abu Jahl. Sa'd said he had heard Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) say the Muslims would kill Umaiya. Umaiya was scared and decided not to leave Mecca. But when the battle of Badr came, Abu Jahl forced him to go with the army. Umaiya pretended to join them but actually planned to stay behind. He tied his camel wherever they camped. Eventually, Allah caused Umaiya to be killed at Badr.

title: Ka'b bin Malik's Absence
content: I, Ka'b bin Malik, never missed any of the Prophet Muhammad 's (ﷺ) battles. But I did miss one battle - Tabuk. And another was Badr, but no one got blamed for missing it because the Prophet had gone to meet Quraish caravans unexpectedly.

title: Al-Miqdad's Brave Words
content: Ibn Masud saw Al-Miqdad talking to the Prophet. The Prophet (ﷺ) wanted Muslims to fight against pagans, but Al-Miqdad said: 'We'll fight alongside you, not just you and Allah.' He meant they would be on his right, left, front, and back. The Prophet (ﷺ) was very happy with what Al-Miqdad said.

title: The Battle of Badr
content: On the day of the battle of Badr, the Prophet said to Allah, 'I ask you to keep your promise.' He then asked for victory for the pagans if that was Allah's will. Abu Bakr stopped him and said, 'That's enough.' The Prophet (ﷺ) came out and said, 'The enemy will run away and turn their backs'.

title: Believers Not Equal
content: Ibn Abbas said that people who missed the battle of Badr and those who fought in it are not equal in reward.

title: Too Young for Battle
content: Al-Bara and Ibn Umar were thought to be too young to join the battle of Badr

title: Too Young for Badr
content: Al-Bara and Ibn Umar were not old enough to fight in the Battle of Badr. There were over sixty Emigrant warriors and more than two hundred forty-nine Ansar fighters.

title: Companions of Badr
content: Al-Bara told me that the companions who fought in Badr were over 310 men. They all crossed a river with their leader, and none of them was an unbeliever.

title: Badr Battle Companions
content: We, the companions of Muhammad (ﷺ), said that the number of warriors at Badr was the same as Saul's companions who crossed the river with him. Only believers crossed the river, and there were over 310 men.

title: Badr Warriors Were Over 310
content: Al-Bara said that the warriors who fought in Badr were more than 310. He compared them to the companions of Saul, a prophet from the Bible, who crossed a river with him. Only those who believed in God crossed the river with Saul.

title: Prophet's Prayer for Enemies
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) faced the Kaaba and prayed against some people from Quraish. They were Shaiba bin Rabi'a, Utba bin Rabi'a, Al-Walid bin Utba, and Abu Jahl bin Hisham. Abdullah bin Mas'ud says he saw them all dead on a very hot day. Later, he met Abu Jahl at Badr while Abu Jahl was dying. Abu Jahl said, 'Don't be proud of killing me, and I'm not ashamed to die by my own people.'

title: Abu Jahl's Final Moments
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) asked who would go and see what had happened to Abu Jahl. Ibn Masud went and found him badly hurt. He asked if Abu Jahl was okay, took his beard, and said, 'You're the one we killed?' Abu Jahl replied, 'Is there anyone better than someone you've killed or their own family has killed?'

title: Prophet Seeks News of Enemy
content: On the day of Badr, the Prophet asked who would go and see what had happened to Abu Jahl. Ibn Mas'ud went and found that two men from Abu Jahl's family had hurt him badly. Ibn Mas'ud grabbed his beard and asked if he was Abu Jahl. He replied, 'Is there anyone more important than someone killed by their own people?'

title: Badr Battle Story
content: Abdur-Rahman bin Auf told the story of Badr. It's about the sons of 'Afra'.

title: Ali's Promise to Allah
content: Ali said he would be the first person to kneel before Allah on Judgment Day. A verse in the Quran talks about two groups: believers and disbelievers, who argue with each other about their Lord. These people were some of those who fought at Badr, including Hamza, Ali, Ubaida, Shaiba, Utba, and Al-Walid.

title: Ali and the Quraish Men
content: Abu Dhar said that a verse in the Quran was revealed about six men from the Quraish tribe. The verse says: 'These two groups argue with each other about their Lord.' The six men were Ali, Hamza, Ubaida bin Al-Harith, Shaiba bin Rabi'a, Utba bin Rabi'a, and Al-Walid bin Utba.

title: Ali Explains a Verse
content: I, Ali, said that the verse 'These two opponents dispute with each other about their Lord' was revealed about us. It means believers and non-believers argue about God's existence.

title: Abu Dhar's Story
content: Qais bin Ubad heard Abu Dhar say that the Holy Verses were revealed about six people on the day of Badr.

title: Abu Dhar's Story
content: Qais said he heard Abu Dhar swear that a verse from the Quran was about some men who fought at Badr. These men were Hamza, Ali, Ubaida bin Al-Harith, Utba and Shaiba, sons of Rabi'a, and Al-Walid bin Utba.

title: Ali's bravery at Badr
content: A man asked Al-Bara' if Ali was in the battle of Badr. Al-Bara' said yes, and that Ali even fought a duel with his enemies while wearing two sets of armor.

title: Abdur-Rahman's Agreement
content: `Abdur-Rahman bin `Auf had an agreement with Umaiya bin Khalaf. They would help each other's families and property in Mecca and Medina. But then, on the day of Badr, Umaiya and his son were killed. Bilal was worried that Umaiya might still be alive.

title: Prophet Recites Surah Najm
content: 'Abdullah said that the Prophet recited Surat-an-Najm and then prostrated. Everyone with him also prostrated, except for an old man who said he didn't need to because a little dust on his forehead was enough. Later, I saw this old man being killed as an unbeliever.

title: Az-Zubair's Sword
content: 'Urwa told me that his father Az-Zubair had three scars from a sword. Two of these wounds happened on the day of Badr and one on the day of Al-Yarmuk. When 'Abdullah bin Zubair was killed, the ruler asked 'Urwa if he knew the sword's marks. 'Urwa said it had a dent in its edge, which happened at Badr. The ruler agreed and returned the sword to 'Urwa.

title: Az-Zubair's Sword Decorated
content: Hisham's father said Az-Zubair's sword had silver decorations. Hisham also said his own family member 'Urwa's sword was decorated with silver too.

title: Az-Zubair's Brave Attack
content: During a battle called Al-Yarmuk, Az-Zubair's friends asked him to lead an attack on the enemy. He said he wouldn't go alone, but they promised to support him. So Az-Zubair attacked and broke through the enemy lines. But when he went too far ahead, his horse was caught by the enemy and struck twice. Az-Zubair had a scar from a previous battle that made it harder for them to hurt him. His brother Abdullah, who was 10 years old at the time, was with him on another horse.

title: Prophet Speaks to Dead Leaders
content: On the day of Badr, the Prophet ordered that the bodies of twenty-four Quraish leaders be thrown into a well. He then went there with his companions and spoke to their bodies by name and family name. He asked them if they would have obeyed Allah and him if they had lived. The Prophet (ﷺ) said he was speaking to them as if they could hear, even though they didn't have souls.

title: Quraysh's Disbelief
content: Ibn `Abbas said: Allah is talking about the people of Quraysh. They rejected Allah's blessings and were disbelievers. This means they would go to a place of great suffering, the Fire, on the day of Badr.

title: Punishment in the Grave
content: Ibn Umar said that the Prophet said: 'The dead person is punished for their sins and wrongdoings, not because of their family's crying.' Aisha agreed with this. She also reminded us that when the Prophet stood by a well where many people had died at Badr, he said they could hear him. But then he added that now they knew what was true. The Quran says we can't make the dead listen to us.

title: Punishment in the Grave
content: `Aisha said that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: 'When someone dies, they are punished for their own sins and mistakes. Their family crying doesn't affect them.' He also said that when he stood by a well with bodies of people who were killed at Badr, he told them, 'You can hear me now.' But then he said, 'They know I was telling the truth all along.' The Quran says we cannot make the dead hear us.

title: Prophet at Well of Badr
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) stood by the well where many pagans had died. He asked if they believed what Allah promised them. Then he said, 'Now they can hear me.' Aisha remembered this and said it was true when she recited a verse from the Quran: 'You cannot make the dead hear...'

title: The Prophet at Badr
content: Ibn Umar said that the Prophet stood by a well in Badr where many pagans had died. He asked, 'Have you seen what your Lord promised?' Then he said, 'They can now hear me.' Aisha remembered this and said that the Prophet also said, 'Now they know I was telling the truth.' She then recited a verse from the Quran: 'You cannot make the dead hear...'

title: Mother's Concern about Haritha
content: Anas said that a mother came to the Prophet and asked if her son Haritha was in Paradise. He had been killed at Badr when he was still young. The Prophet (ﷺ) told her, 'Don't worry, there are many Paradises, and your son is in Al-Firdaus, the best one.'

title: Hatib's Letter is Found
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) sent Ali, Abu Marthad, and Az-Zubair to find a woman carrying a letter from Hatib bin Abi Balta'a. They found her riding a camel and asked for the letter. She denied having it, but they searched her and eventually found it hidden under her belt. When they brought her back to the Prophet, Umar was angry with Hatib and wanted to punish him. But the Prophet asked Hatib why he did it and Hatib explained that he wanted to protect his family and property by being influential among the Meccans. The Prophet (ﷺ) said Hatib spoke the truth and should be treated kindly.

title: Use Arrows Wisely
content: On the day of Badr, Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said to us: 'When the enemy comes near, shoot at them. But use your arrows carefully so they don't run out.'

title: Use Arrows Wisely in Battle
content: Abu Usaid said the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) told us: When our enemy is close to us and we're outnumbered, shoot at them but use only a few arrows.

title: Uhud Battle: Lessons Learned
content: On the day of Uhud, the Prophet appointed Abdullah bin Jubair as leader of the archers. Unfortunately, many Muslims were hurt or killed in this battle. In comparison, at Badr, we had defeated our enemies and taken some prisoners. Abu Sufyan said that this was a revenge for what happened at Badr, but the outcome of the war was still uncertain.

title: Good Things Come Later
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said that the good things in our lives came after a difficult time. He also said that being truthful is rewarded, and we saw this reward after the battle of Badr.

title: Two Brave Young Boys
content: I was fighting in the front line at the Battle of Badr. I looked around and saw two young boys on either side of me, which made me feel uneasy. One of them asked me secretly to show him Abu Jahl. He said he had promised Allah that if he saw Abu Jahl, he would kill or be killed before killing him. The other boy also wanted to see Abu Jahl. I pointed him out to the boys, and they attacked him like two birds until they knocked him down. Those two brave young boys were the sons of an Ansari woman.

title: Ten Muslim Spies Sent
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) sent ten spies to a place called Al-Hadah. They were led by Asim bin Thabit. When the enemy found them, they said, 'Come down and surrender.' But Asim refused, saying he wouldn't take protection from an infidel. The enemy killed him. Three of his companions surrendered. One of them was Khubaib. He was taken to Mecca and sold as a slave. Later, he was imprisoned by the sons of Al-Harith bin 'Amr. They decided to kill him. Before they did, he borrowed a razor from their daughter and she saw her son playing with it. She was scared but Khubaib reassured her. When they took him out to be martyred, he asked for permission to pray two rak'at. He prayed and then said, 'I wish I had prayed more.' Then he invoked evil upon his killers. They killed him anyway.

title: Ibn Umar Misses Friday Prayer
content: Nafi told me that Ibn 'Umar visited a sick friend on a Friday. The time for the Friday prayer was near, but Ibn 'Umar didn't join in the prayer to visit his friend.

title: Marriage After a Husband's Death
content: Subaia was married to Sa'd bin Khaula. He died during Hajjat-ul-Wada' while she was pregnant. She gave birth to a child after his death. When she recovered from childbirth, Abu As-Sanabil told her that she couldn't marry again for four months and ten days. Subaia went to the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) and asked about this rule. The Prophet (ﷺ) said it's okay for her to marry because she had already given birth to her child.

title: Gabriel's Message about Badr
content: Gabriel came to the Prophet and asked how he saw the warriors of Badr. The Prophet (ﷺ) said they were the best Muslims. Gabriel replied that the Angels who fought in Badr were also considered the best.

title: Mu'adh's Father's Wish
content: Rafi', a man from Al-'Aqaba, said to his son Mu'adh: 'I wish I had fought in the Battle of Badr instead of giving my pledge at Al-'Aqaba.'

title: Gabriel Asks the Prophet
content: Mu`adh asked who was asking the Prophet a question. The Prophet (ﷺ) replied that it was Gabriel.

title: Gabriel at Battle of Badr
content: Ibn Abbas said that on the day of the battle of Badr, the Prophet said: 'This is Gabriel. He's holding his horse's head and has arms for fighting.'

title: Abu Zaid's Death
content: Anas said that Abu Zaid died without any children. He was one of the people who fought in the Battle of Badr.

title: Eating Sacrifice Meat
content: Abu Sa'id bin Malik Al-Khudri came home from a trip and his family gave him some meat from the Id ul Adha sacrifices. He said, 'I won't eat it until I ask if it's allowed.' So he went to his uncle Qatada bin Nu'man, who was one of the Badr warriors. Qatada told Abu Sa'id that after he left on his trip, the Prophet had cancelled a rule about not eating sacrifice meat for three days.

title: Az-Zubair's Battle Story
content: I met Ubaida bin Sa'id on the day of Badr. He was covered in armor and only his eyes were visible. I attacked him with a spear and hurt his eye. He died. After that, Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) asked me for the spear. When he passed away, I took it back. Then Abu Bakr asked for it, then `Umar, then `Uthman. Each time, I gave it to them. But when `Uthman was killed, the spear stayed with my family until Abdullah bin Az-Zubair had it taken from him.

title: Pledge of Allegiance
content: 'Ubada bin As-Samit was a warrior who fought in the Battle of Badr. The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said to him, 'Give me your pledge of allegiance'.

title: Adopting Sons in Islam
content: The Prophet Muhammad 's (ﷺ) adopted son Salim was a freed slave. He married his niece Hind to Salim and called him by the name of his adoptive father. The Prophet (ﷺ) also adopted Zaid as his son. Before Islam, people used to call adopted sons by their adoptive father's name, but Allah revealed that they should be called by their biological father's name.

title: The Prophet's Visit After Marriage
content: One night, after my marriage was completed, the Prophet came to me and sat on my bed. Some girls were singing and beating a drum in memory of my father who had been killed at Badr. One girl said, 'There is a Prophet with us who knows what will happen tomorrow.' The Prophet (ﷺ) told her, 'Don't say that. Keep saying what you've already said'.

title: Angels Don't Enter Homes
content: Abu Talha told me that the Prophet said: 'Angels don't enter a house with a dog or pictures.' He meant images of living things, like animals and people.

title: Hamza Cuts Off Ali's Camels
content: Ali had two camels that he got from the battle of Badr. He wanted to sell them to buy food for his wedding to Fatima, the Prophet's daughter. But when he went to get some ropes and sacks, he found that someone had cut off their humps and opened their bellies. Ali asked who did it and was told it was Hamza bin Abdul Muttalib. He was with some friends in a house, drinking and listening to music. The singer had said 'Get the fat camels!' and Hamza had rushed out and hurt Ali's camels. Ali went to tell the Prophet, who put on his cloak and went with Zaid to find Hamza. When they got there, the Prophet scolded Hamza for what he did. But Hamza was drunk and said 'You're just my father's slaves.' The Prophet (ﷺ) realized Hamza was drunk, so he left without doing anything else.

title: Ali Leads Funeral Prayer
content: Ali led a prayer for Sahl bin Hunaif's funeral. He said Sahl was one of the fighters at Badr.

title: Umar's Proposal for Hafsa
content: `Umar bin Al-Khattab wanted to marry his daughter Hafsa bint `Umar. He asked `Uthman if he would like to marry her, but `Uthman said no. Then `Umar asked Abu Bakr, but Abu Bakr didn't say anything. Later, the Prophet asked for Hafsa's hand in marriage and `Umar married her to him. When Abu Bakr found out, he explained that if the Prophet had given up on marrying Hafsa, he would have accepted the proposal.

title: Spending on Family is Charity
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: A man's spending on his family is like doing a good deed for Allah.

title: Al-Mughira's Delayed Prayer
content: I heard `Urwa bin Az-Zubair talking to `Umar bin `Abdul `Aziz. He said Al-Mughira delayed the afternoon prayer when he was in charge of Kufa. Abu Mas`ud came in and reminded him that Gabriel had come down and prayed with the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ). Gabriel told the Prophet that he was ordered to pray five times a day at specific hours.

title: Reciting Two Verses Before Sleep
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: 'It is enough for one person to recite the last two verses of Surat-al-Baqara at night.'

title: Companion Visits the Prophet
content: Mahmud bin Ar-Rabi said that Itban bin Malik came to see Allah's Messenger (ﷺ). Itban was a companion of the Prophet and had fought in the battle of Badr.

title: Ibn Shihab Asks About Hadith
content: Ibn Shihab asked Al-Husain about a story from Mahmud bin Ar-Rabi. Al-Husain said it was true, he confirmed it.

title: Prophet's Battle Companions
content: `Abdullah bin `Amr bin Rabi`a was a leader from the tribe of Bani `Adi. His father fought alongside the Prophet in the battle of Badr. Later, `Umar appointed Qudama bin Maz'un as ruler of Bahrain. Qudama had also fought at Badr and was related to Abdullah bin `Umar and Hafsa.

title: Renting Fields is Forbidden
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) forbade renting fields. Two of his companions, who fought in the Battle of Badr, told Abdullah bin Umar that they heard Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) say this. Salim said he rents his land, but thinks Rafi' made a mistake.

title: Allah's Messenger forbids renting land
content: Abdullah bin Umar was told by his uncles that the Prophet said it's not allowed to rent fields. Salim, a student of Abdullah, rented his own land and said Rafi' made a mistake.

title: Rifa'a bin Rafi' at Badr
content: I saw Rifa`a bin Rafi` Al-Ansari. He was a fighter in the Battle of Badr.

title: Allah's Messenger Warns the Ansar
content: Amr bin Auf told us that Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) sent Abu Ubaida to Bahrain to collect taxes. When Abu Ubaida returned with the money, the Ansar people came to see the Prophet after morning prayer. The Prophet (ﷺ) smiled and said, 'You've heard about the money?' They replied, 'Yes.' He said, 'Be happy, but I'm worried that you'll get too much wealth like those before you. It will cause you to fight each other, just as they did, and it will destroy you like it destroyed them.'

title: Ibn Umar's Snake Rule
content: Nafi' told me that Ibn 'Umar used to kill all kinds of snakes. But then Abu Lubaba Al-Badri reminded him that the Prophet had said it's not allowed to hurt harmless snakes living in homes. So, Ibn 'Umar stopped killing them.

title: Ibn Umar's Snake Rule
content: Ibn `Umar used to kill all snakes. But Abu Lubaba told him the Prophet had said it's not allowed to kill harmless snakes that live in houses, called Jinnan. So Ibn `Umar stopped killing them.

title: Ansar Ask to See the Prophet
content: Some Ansari men asked the Prophet if they could see him. They wanted permission to forgive a debt owed by their sister's son, Abbas. The Prophet (ﷺ) said no, he wouldn't let them keep any of it.

title: Killing a Muslim Convert
content: 'Ubaidullah bin 'Adi asked Al-Miqdad about fighting an enemy who became Muslim after cutting off his hand. Al-Miqdad said the Prophet told him not to kill him, because if he killed him, they would be in each other's positions before and after the conversion.

title: Abu Jahl's Final Moments
content: On the day of Badr, Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) asked if anyone knew what had happened to Abu Jahl. Ibn Mas'ud went to find him and saw that he was badly hurt by two men from the tribe of 'Afra. When Ibn Mas'ud asked if he was Abu Jahl, he replied, 'Is there a man more important than the one you've killed?' Abu Jahl said he wished he had been killed by someone else.

title: Umar's Visit to Ansari Companions
content: After the Prophet died, Umar said to Abu Bakr, 'Let's go visit our friends from Ansar.' They met two good men who had fought in a battle called Badr. Umar told Urwa bin Az-Zubair about this and he said those two men were named Uwaim bin Sa'ida and Ma'n bin Adi.

title: Companions of Badr Receive Reward
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) gave each of the soldiers who fought in the Battle of Badr five thousand Dirhams every year. Umar said, 'I will give them more than I give to others.'

title: Forgiveness for Badr Prisoners
content: Jubair bin Mut'im said the Prophet recited Surat-at-Tur during Maghrib prayer. This was when Jubair first believed in Islam. The Prophet (ﷺ) talked about prisoners from the Battle of Badr. He said that if Al-Mutim bin Adi were alive, he would forgive them because of him.

title: Three Wars Leave Many Dead
content: When a big fight broke out in Islam because 'Uthman was killed, all the people who fought at Badr were gone. Then another big fight happened and all the people who made peace with the Prophet at Hudaibiya died too. After that, there was another big fight that didn't stop until everyone's strength was used up.

title: Aisha's Mistake at Badr
content: Aisha and her friend Um Mistah were walking. Um Mistah tripped on her robe. She said, 'Mistah is ruined.' Aisha replied, 'You shouldn't say that. He fought in the Battle of Badr.'

title: Prophet Muhammad's Battles
content: Ibn Shihab said the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) fought many battles. He talked about one battle called Badr. While throwing away the bodies of the enemy, he asked them if they found what their Lord promised to be true. Some companions said, 'You're talking to dead people.' The Prophet (ﷺ) replied that they didn't hear him better than the dead did. There were 81 men from the Quraish tribe who fought in Badr and got a share of the money. Az-Zubair said there were actually 101 men, but Allah knows best.

title: War Booty at Badr
content: On the day of Badr, the Emigrants from Quraish received 100 shares of the war booty.

title: Prophet's Deal with Jews
content: Ibn Umar said: The Prophet (ﷺ) dealt with the Jews of Bani An-Nadir and Bani Quraiza. He made them leave their homes in Medina after they broke a peace agreement. Some were allowed to stay, but later fought against him again. He then killed their men and gave their families and belongings to the Muslims. However, some Jewish leaders came to the Prophet and he spared their lives, allowing them to convert to Islam. Eventually, all Jews were asked to leave Medina.

title: Ibn Abbas Explains a Verse
content: Sa'id bin Jubair mentioned the Surah Hashr to Ibn Abbas. He said, 'You can call it Surat-an-Nadir instead'.

title: Returning Date Palms
content: Some people gave the Prophet some date palm trees as a gift. He took them back after conquering Banu Quraiza and Bani An-Nadir, and returned them to their owners.

title: Burning Date Palm Trees
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) ordered the date palm trees of Bani Al-Nadir to be cut down and burned at a place called Al-Buwaira. Later, Allah revealed a verse saying that this was done with His permission.

title: Burning Date Palm Trees
content: Ibn Umar said the Prophet burned the date palm trees of Bani An-Nadir. Hassan bin Thabit wrote some poetry about it, saying the nobles didn't care. Abu Sufyan responded with more poetry, wishing Allah would burn Medina and show who was safe.

title: Umar Resolves a Dispute
content: Umar called Malik bin Aus and asked him to let some people in. When they came in, Abbas said to Umar, 'Judge between me and Ali.' They had a dispute about the property of Bani An-Nadir, which Allah had given to His Prophet as Fai (booty). Umar said, 'Wait! Do you know that the Prophet said,

title: Umar Resolves a Dispute
content: `Umar bin Al-Khattab was sitting with Malik bin Aus when his gatekeeper, Yarfa, came in. He said that `Uthman, `Abdur-Rahman bin `Auf, Az-Zubair, and Sa`d were waiting to see him. `Umar said yes, let them come in. Later, Yarfa came again and said that `Ali and `Abbas wanted to see him. `Umar said yes, let them come in too. When they all sat down, `Abbas asked `Umar to judge between him and `Ali about some property. They had a dispute over the Fai (booty) given by Allah to His Prophet without fighting. The others who were present said that `Umar should give his verdict. `Umar said wait, I want to remind you of something important. He asked if they knew that the Prophet said our properties are not inherited, and whatever we leave is to be spent in charity. They said yes, he did say that. `Umar then turned to `Ali and `Abbas and said do you both remember this? They replied yes. `Umar explained that Allah gave some of the Fai to His Prophet without him fighting for it. The Prophet (ﷺ) used to spend his share on his family and what was left, he would give in charity. When the Prophet died, Abu Bakr took charge of the property and disposed of it in the same way as the Prophet did. `Umar said I followed this example when I became Caliph. He told `Ali and `Abbas that they both agreed to manage the property in the same way as he had done. `Umar said he would never give a different decision about this matter.

title: Abu Bakr's Decision on Fadak
content: Fatima and Al-'Abbas went to Abu Bakr. They wanted the land of Fadak, which was the Prophet's property, and his share from Khaibar. Abu Bakr said he remembered the Prophet saying that their belongings are not for inheritance. Whatever they leave should be given to charity. But the Prophet's family can use some of this money for themselves. Abu Bakr wanted to help the Prophet's relatives more than his own family.

title: Abu Bakr Decides on Fadak
content: Fatima and Al-'Abbas went to Abu Bakr. They wanted the land of Fadak, which was left by the Prophet, and a share from Khaibar. Abu Bakr said he remembered the Prophet saying that their property is not inherited. Whatever they leave should be given in charity. But the Prophet's family can use some of this property for themselves.

title: Muhammad Bin Maslama's Mission
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) asked who would kill Ka'b bin Al-Ashraf for hurting Allah and the Prophet. Muhammad (ﷺ) bin Maslama volunteered to do it. The Prophet (ﷺ) said yes, but only if he could say a false thing (lie) to deceive Ka'b. Muhammad (ﷺ) went to Ka'b's house with two men and told him they needed food. Ka'b agreed to lend them food if they mortgaged something in return. They offered their arms instead of their sons or wives. The next night, Muhammad (ﷺ) went back to Ka'b's house with his companion Abu Na'ila. When Ka'b came down, Muhammad (ﷺ) pretended to smell his head and then killed him.

title: Killing Abu Rafi`
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) sent some people to kill a man named Abu Rafi`. One of them, `Abdullah bin Atik, went into his house at night and killed him while he was asleep.

title: Abu Rafi' is Killed
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) sent some men to kill Abu Rafi', a Jew who hurt the Prophet and helped his enemies. Abdullah bin Atik led them. They approached the castle after sunset, when people had gone home with their animals. Abdullah covered himself with clothes and pretended to answer nature's call. The gatekeeper let him in. When everyone was inside, Abdullah took the keys and opened the gate. He went to Abu Rafi', who was sleeping in a dark house. Abdullah shouted his name, but couldn't find him. He hit him with a sword, but didn't kill him. Abu Rafi' cried out for help, so Abdullah went back and killed him by pressing the sword into his belly until it reached his back. Then he opened doors one by one to leave. As he stepped out, he fell down and broke his leg in the moonlight. He tied his leg with a turban and waited till morning. When the announcer said Abu Rafi' was dead, Abdullah went back to the Prophet and told him what happened. The Prophet (ﷺ) stretched out Abdullah's broken leg and rubbed it, making it better.

title: Abdullah Kills Abu Rafi'
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) sent Abdullah bin Atik and his friends to kill a man named Abu Rafi'. They went to his castle, but the gatekeeper wouldn't let them in. Abdullah came up with a plan. He covered himself and pretended to answer nature's call. When the gatekeeper opened the door, Abdullah snuck in and hid. He took the key from the wall and unlocked the gate. Then he locked all the doors of their houses from outside. He went upstairs and found Abu Rafi' sleeping. He called out to him, but Abu Rafi' didn't answer. So Abdullah hit him with a sword. But his blow was weak. He pretended to help Abu Rafi', but when he saw that his first blow hadn't worked, he hit him again. This time, Abu Rafi' cried loudly and his wife got up. Abdullah came back, changed his voice, and found Abu Rafi' lying on the floor. He drove the sword into his belly until he heard a bone break. Then he went out, but fell down from the stairs and hurt his leg. He bandaged it and went to meet his friends. They told Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) that Abdullah had killed Abu Rafi'. Abdullah was happy and didn't feel any pain as he walked with his friends.

title: Gabriel at Uhud
content: Ibn Abbas said the Prophet saw Gabriel on the day of Uhud. He was holding his horse's head and had equipment for war with him.

title: The Prophet's Last Look
content: Eight years after the Battle of Uhud, the Prophet led a funeral prayer for those who died. He then stood on the pulpit and said: 'I will meet you all again at Al-Haud (a tank) on Judgment Day. I'm not worried that you'll forget Allah, but I'm afraid that life's temptations might make you compete with each other.' This was his last look at us.

title: Battle of Uhud: A Lesson
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) placed some archers in a special place and told them not to leave. He said if they saw the Muslims winning, don't help us, and if we were losing, stay where you are. The enemy ran away, but the Muslim archers left their position. Allah confused them so they didn't know what to do, and many of them got hurt. Abu Sufyan asked about the Prophet's presence, but he told his companions not to answer. When Abu Sufyan mentioned the Prophet's father and another companion, the Prophet still said don't answer. Umar couldn't help saying something back to Abu Sufyan. The Prophet (ﷺ) then told his companions to reply to Abu Sufyan. They asked what to say, and the Prophet said 'Allah is Greater'. Abu Sufyan mentioned their idol Al-Uzza, but the Prophet's companions replied that Allah is their Helper.

title: Battle of Uhud: A Warning
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) placed some archers at a special place and told them not to leave. He said if the Muslims were winning, they should stay there, but if the pagans were winning, they shouldn't help. But his companions left anyway. As a result, many of them died in battle. Abu Sufyan, the enemy leader, asked if Muhammad (ﷺ) was present, and the Prophet told his men not to answer. When Abu Sufyan mentioned the Prophet's father and brother, the Prophet still said not to reply. Eventually, the Prophet allowed his men to respond to Abu Sufyan's claims that their gods were better than Allah. The Prophet (ﷺ) told them to say 'Allah is greater' and that He is their helper.

title: Abdur-Rahman's Fears
content: Abdur-Rahman bin Auf was fasting when a meal was brought to him. He said that Mus'ab bin Umair, who had been martyred, was better than he was. When his body was wrapped in a sheet for burial, if his head was covered, his feet were exposed, and vice versa. Abdur-Rahman also mentioned that Hamza, another martyr, was better than him. He then said that they had received too much wealth in this life and feared that their good deeds would be rewarded here instead of in the afterlife. This made Abdur-Rahman very sad and he left his food.

title: Martyr's Reward in Paradise
content: Jabir bin Abdullah said the Prophet told him that if he died as a martyr in battle, he would go to Paradise. A man asked the Prophet this question on the day of the Battle of Uhud. The man then threw away some dates and fought until he was killed.
