title: Migrating for Allah's Pleasure
content: We migrated with the Prophet to please Allah. Our reward was guaranteed. Some of us died without enjoying it, like Mus'ab bin 'Umar who was martyred at Uhud. He didn't leave anything except a simple cloth. The Prophet (ﷺ) said: 'Cover his head with it and put some grass on his feet.' But others have enjoyed the fruits of their labor.

title: Anas' Uncle at Uhud
content: Anas bin An-Nadr's uncle was absent from the first battle of Badr. He said he wanted to fight with the Prophet if Allah allowed him. So, he joined the battle of Uhud. When the Muslims ran away, he prayed: 'O Allah, forgive me for what these people did.' Then he went forward and met Sad bin Mu'adh running away. He asked where Sad was going. Anas said he smelled Paradise near Uhud. He kept fighting until he got martyred. His sister later identified him by a mole on his body or the tips of his fingers. He had over 80 wounds from being stabbed, hit with swords, or shot with arrows.

title: Missing Verse Found Again
content: Zaid bin Thabit said: When we were writing the Quran, I forgot a verse from Surat-al-Ahzab. We looked for it and found it with Khuza'ima bin Thabit Al-Ansari. The verse was: 'Among believers are those who keep their promises to Allah. Some have been killed in His cause, and some are still waiting.' We put this verse back into the Quran.

title: Divided Companions and Revelation
content: Some companions of the Prophet went back from the battle of Uhud. The remaining companions were divided into two groups: one wanted to fight, while the other didn't want to fight. Allah sent a message saying that He had rejected those who refused to fight because of their own mistakes. The Prophet (ﷺ) said that Medina is like a fire that cleanses people of their sins.

title: Allah Protects His Believers
content: Jabir said that a verse was revealed about two groups of Muslims, Bani Salama and Bani Haritha. The verse was about people who were almost going to leave each other. Allah protected them.

title: Marriage and Family Advice
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) asked Jabir if he had married. Jabir said yes. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked if the wife was a young girl or an older woman. Jabir replied that she was not a virgin but an older woman. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked why he didn't marry a younger girl who could be playful with him. Jabir explained that his father died in battle and left nine daughters, so he wanted to care for them by marrying an older woman who could help look after them. The Prophet (ﷺ) said this was the right decision.

title: Jabir's Debt Paid Off
content: My father was killed in the battle of Uhud and left us with a lot of debt. I went to the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) and told him about our situation. He said, 'Go and separate all the dates.' I did that and then called him back. When he saw the creditors being harsh with me, he walked around the biggest heap of dates three times and sat on it. Then he asked me to call them again. He started measuring out the dates to pay off our debt. Allah helped us and paid off all the debts. I was so happy that we didn't have to keep any of the dates for ourselves. But amazingly, when we looked at where the Prophet had been sitting, it seemed like not a single date was missing.

title: Two Brave Fighters with the Prophet
content: I saw the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) at the Battle of Uhud. He was fighting alongside two men who were wearing white clothes and fighting very bravely. I had never seen them before or after that day.

title: Prophet's Trust in Sa'd
content: On the day of Uhud, the Prophet gave me a quiver with arrows and said, 'Throw these for me. I sacrifice my parents for you.'

title: Allah's Messenger Mentions Parents
content: Sa'd said that the Prophet mentioned his father and mother to him on the day of the Battle of Uhud.

title: Prophet's Love for His Parents
content: Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas said that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) mentioned his father and mother to him during a battle. He said, 'Let my father and mother be sacrificed for you.' This meant he loved them very much.

title: Prophet's Kindness to Sad
content: Ali said he never heard the Prophet mention his parents for anyone except Sad. The Prophet (ﷺ) had a special kindness towards Sad.

title: Prophet's Praise for Sa'd
content: Ali said he never heard the Prophet mention his parents' names except when talking about Sa'd bin Malik. On the day of Uhud, the Prophet said to Sa'd: 'Throw arrows! My father and mother sacrifice themselves for you.'

title: Who stayed with the Prophet
content: Mu'tamir's father said that `Uthman told him that on the day of the battle of Uhud, only Talha and Sa'd remained with the Prophet.

title: Battle of Uhud - Who Stayed
content: Mu'tamir's father said that `Uthman told him that on the day of the battle of Uhud, only Talha and Sa'd stayed with the Prophet.

title: Talha Remembers Uhud
content: I was with AbdurRahman bin Auf, Talha, Al-Miqdad and Sa'd. I only heard one of them talk about the Prophet. It was Talha who told me about the day we fought at Uhud.

title: Talha's Paralyzed Hand
content: Qais saw Talha with a paralyzed hand that had protected the Prophet on the day of Uhud.

title: Abu Talha Protects the Prophet
content: On the day of Uhud, people left the Prophet while Abu Talha stood in front of him with a leather shield. He was a skilled archer who broke two or three bowstrings that day. When someone passed by with arrows, the Prophet would ask them to scatter their contents for Abu Talha. The Prophet (ﷺ) would look up at the enemy, but Abu Talha would say, 'Don't raise your head, it's safer.' I saw Aisha and Um Sulaim helping the wounded people by carrying water skins on their backs and giving them water.

title: Satan's Deception at Uhud
content: On the day of the battle of Uhud, the pagans were defeated. Satan shouted to the Muslims, 'Be careful behind you!' The front lines turned around and started fighting with the back lines. Hudhaifa saw his father Al-Yaman being killed and cried out, 'My father! My father!' But he couldn't stop them from killing him. Hudhaifa then said, 'May Allah forgive you.' He kept asking for forgiveness for his father's killers until he died.

title: Ibn Umar's Explanation
content: A man came to Mecca for Hajj. He saw some people sitting and asked who they were. They said it was the Quraish tribe. He then asked about an old man, Ibn Umar. The man went to him and asked questions about someone named `Uthman bin Affan. He wanted to know if `Uthman had fled on the day of Uhud. Ibn Umar said yes. Then he asked if `Uthman was absent from the Badr battle. Again, Ibn Umar said yes. The man then asked if `Uthman missed the Ridwan Pledge of allegiance. Ibn Umar said yes again. The man exclaimed 'Allahu Akbar!' (God is great!). Ibn Umar explained that Allah forgave `Uthman for fleeing on Uhud. He also explained why `Uthman was absent from Badr and Ridwan. Ibn Umar told the man that if anyone else had been more respected than `Uthman, the Prophet would have sent them instead. The Prophet (ﷺ) did send `Uthman to Mecca after the Pledge of allegiance took place. When `Uthman returned, the Prophet raised his right hand and said 'This is for `Uthman.' Ibn Umar told the man he could go now that he had this information.

title: Uhud Battle: A Lesson Learned
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) appointed Abdullah bin Jubair as the commander of the cavalry archers during the battle of Uhud. However, they were defeated and returned. The Quran mentions this event when it says 'And the Apostle was in your rear calling you back...' Some people fell asleep during the battle, including Abu Talha. He kept waking up to pick up his sword after it had fallen from his hand several times.

title: Prophet's Prayer and Curse
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) was praying. When he stood up after bowing in the first part of the morning prayer, he said: 'O Allah, curse so-and-so' (he mentioned some names). He had already said: 'Allah hears whoever praises Him.' A verse from the Quran was revealed to say that it is not for him to curse others. Instead, he should pray for them.

title: Umar's Distribution of Clothes
content: Some women in Medina were given woolen clothes by Umar. A nice garment was left over. Some people suggested giving it to Um Kulthum, the daughter of Ali. But Umar said no, because Um Salit had a stronger claim. She was one of the Ansari women who had promised to follow Allah's Messenger (ﷺ). In fact, she used to carry heavy water skins for them on the day of the battle of Uhud.

title: Wahshi tells the story of Hamza
content: Jafar bin 'Amr went with Ubaidullah to Hims. They wanted to ask Wahshi about killing Hamza. When they found him, Ubaidullah said, 'Do you know me?' Wahshi replied, 'No, but I see your feet and eyes.' He then recognized Ubaidullah's child that he had looked after. Wahshi agreed to tell them the story of Hamza's death. He said that Hamza killed his uncle at Badr, so his master Jubair freed him if he killed Hamza in revenge. At Uhud, Wahshi hid under a rock and threw a spear at Hamza when he came near. He died from this wound. After Islam spread, Wahshi left Mecca for Taif. When the Prophet's messengers came to Taif, Wahshi went with them to meet the Prophet. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked if it was him who killed Hamza. Wahshi said yes and hid his face. Later, when Musailamah appeared as a prophet, Wahshi wanted to kill him to make amends for killing Hamza. He fought in this battle and saw Musailamah standing near a wall. He threw a spear at Musailamah, which went into his chest, and then an Ansari man struck him with a sword.

title: Allah's Wrath on Harmers
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: Allah is very angry with people who hurt me. He is also very angry with anyone killed by me while fighting for Allah's cause.

title: Severe Anger from Allah
content: Ibn Abbas said that when the Prophet killed someone in a battle for Allah's cause, Allah became very angry with him. Allah also became very angry with people who hurt the Prophet's face.

title: Fatima Cares for the Prophet
content: Abu Hazim said he heard Sahl bin Sa'd talk about how they cared for the Prophet's wounds. He said Fatima, the Prophet's daughter, washed his wounds and Ali poured water from a shield to clean them. But when the bleeding got worse, Fatima used ashes from a burnt mat to stop the blood. The Prophet (ﷺ) had a broken tooth and was hurt on his face and head.

title: Severe Wrath for Killing a Prophet
content: Ibn Abbas said that if someone is killed by a prophet, Allah's anger becomes very strong against them. And if someone hurts the face of the Messenger of Allah, Allah's anger also becomes very strong against them.

title: Responding to Allah's Call
content: Aisha told her nephew `Urwa that his father Az-Zubair and Abu Bakr were among those who fought alongside the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) after being injured. When the Prophet was hurt on the day of Uhud, he feared the enemy might return. He asked for volunteers to chase them, and 70 men, including Az-Zubair and Abu Bakr, went with him.

title: Ansar's Sacrifice and Reward
content: The Ansar tribe lost many fighters in battles. Anas bin Malik said that seventy Ansar were killed at Uhud, Bir Ma'una, and Al-Yamama. The battle of Bir Ma'una happened during the Prophet's lifetime, and Al-Yamama was during Abu Bakr's rule when Musailamah Al-Kadhdhab was defeated.

title: Burial of Martyrs
content: Jabir bin Abdullah said that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) used to wrap two martyrs in one cloth. He would then ask which one knew more Quran. The one who knew more Quran was buried first. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'I will be a witness for them on Judgment Day.' They were buried with their blood still on their bodies. No funeral prayer or washing was done for them. When Jabir's father was martyred, the Prophet allowed him to uncover his face and weep.

title: Martyrs' Burial and Prayer
content: Jabir bin Abdullah said that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) used to wrap two martyrs from Uhud in one cloth. He would then ask which of them knew more Quran. The one who knew more was put first in the grave. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'I will be a witness for them on Judgment Day.' They were buried with their blood still on their bodies. No funeral prayer was held for them and they weren't washed before burial. When Jabir's father was martyred, he started crying and removing his face cloth. The companions stopped him but the Prophet didn't. He said, 'Don't cry over him. Angels covered him with their wings until his body was taken away.'

title: Dreams and Battles
content: Abu Musa said that the Prophet told him: 'I had a dream where I moved a sword. Its blade broke, which meant many believers were hurt on the day of Uhud. But when I moved it again, its blade was whole again. This showed us winning Mecca with Allah's help and all believers becoming one. In my dream, I also saw cows, which are good things. They reminded me of the brave believers who died at Uhud.'

title: Martyr Mus'ab's Reward
content: We migrated with the Prophet for Allah's Cause. Some of us died without getting our reward. One of them was Mus'ab bin Umair, who was killed at Uhud. He didn't leave anything behind except a small woolen cloth. If we covered his head, his feet were naked, and if we covered his feet, his head was naked. The Prophet (ﷺ) said to cover his head with the cloth and put some grass on his feet.

title: Mountains Love Us
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said that this mountain loves us and we love it.

title: Uhud Mountain's Special Status
content: When the mountain of Uhud appeared to the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ), he said it was a mountain that loved and was loved by them. He then made Medina, between its two mountains, a sacred place like Mecca.

title: Prophet's Concern at Uhud
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) went out to pray for the people who died in battle. After praying, he stood on a high place and said: 'I will come before you in death. I am a witness that you are doing what is right. Right now, I have been given control of the world's wealth. I'm not worried about you worshipping other gods after me. But I worry that you might fight over worldly things.'

title: Asim and Khubaib's Martyrdom
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) sent a group of spies led by Asim bin Thabit to gather information. They were discovered by the Lihyan tribe, who followed them and attacked. Asim refused to come down from his position, saying he wouldn't trust an infidel. The attackers killed him with arrows along with seven companions. Three men remained: Khubaib, Zaid, and another man who was given a promise of safety. When the attackers gave their word, they came down. However, when they tried to tie them up, one of the men said that was breaking their promise and refused to go with them. They killed him. The remaining two were taken to Mecca and sold as slaves. Khubaib was bought by the sons of Al-Harith bin 'Amr, who had been killed by Khubaib at Badr. Eventually, they decided to kill Khubaib too. Before his execution, he borrowed a razor from one of their daughters to shave his pubic hair. He then asked for permission to pray two rak'at and did so. When it was time for him to be killed, he said 'Count them one by one.' He accepted death as a martyr in Allah's cause.

title: Khubaib's Killer Identified
content: Jabir said that Abu Sirwa', whose real name is `Uqba bin Al-Harith, was the person who killed Khubaib.

title: Killing of Al-Qurra Men
content: Anas said that the Prophet sent a group of seventy men to do something. They met two groups near a well called Bir Ma'una, but those groups killed them. The Prophet (ﷺ) prayed against them for a month during morning prayer. This was the start of saying Qunut in prayer. A man asked Anas when to say Qunut: after finishing the reading or after bowing? Anas said it's after finishing the reading.

title: Al-Qunut Prayer
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: After bowing down in prayer, Al-Qunut was recited for one month. It asked Allah to punish some Arab tribes.

title: Killing of Ansar Men
content: Seventy men from the Ansar tribe were sent to help their friends against an enemy. They collected wood during the day and prayed at night. However, the enemy killed them while they were at a well called Ma'una. When this news reached the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ), he decided to say a special prayer for one month. In this prayer, he asked Allah to punish some Arab tribes who had helped the enemy. The Prophet (ﷺ) said: 'Tell your people that we have met our Lord and He is pleased with us.' However, this verse was later cancelled.

title: Prophet's Uncle Meets Martyrdom
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) sent his uncle, the brother of Um Sulaim, to talk to a group of pagans. One of them, 'Amir bin at-Tufail, proposed three options: he could be in charge of the townspeople and the Prophet would be in charge of the bedouins; or 'Amir would be the Prophet's successor; or he would attack the Prophet with 2,000 men. But 'Amir got sick with a plague while staying at Um Sulaim's house. He said, 'Get me my horse' and died on it. Then his brother Haram went to talk to the pagans. They killed him, but not before he said, 'Allahu Akbar! I have succeeded!' The Prophet (ﷺ) was sad about this and invoked evil upon the tribes that disobeyed Allah and His Apostle for 30 days.

title: Haram's Last Words
content: Anas bin Malik said that when Haram bin Milhan was stabbed on the day of Bir Ma'una, he sprinkled his own blood on his face and head. Then he said, 'I have succeeded, by the Lord of the Kaaba'.

title: Abu Bakr Waits for the Prophet
content: Abu Bakr asked the Prophet to leave Mecca with him. The Prophet (ﷺ) said to wait. Abu Bakr waited until the Prophet was allowed to go out. When they left, Abu Bakr gave one of his camels to the Prophet and they rode together to a cave where they hid. A slave named Amir helped them by taking turns riding at the back of their camels. They eventually reached Medina. Later, when some Muslims were killed in battle, Amir was martyred too. The Prophet (ﷺ) learned about the death of his companions and announced it to Abu Bakr, saying that they had been killed but were happy with Allah's will.

title: The Prophet's Prayer Against Enemies
content: Anas said the Prophet prayed Al-Qunut after bowing for one month. He asked Allah to punish tribes Ril and Dhakwan because they disobeyed Allah and His Messenger, Usaiya.

title: Prophet's Prayer for Martyrs
content: Anas bin Malik said the Prophet prayed against people who killed his friends at Bir Mauna. He also prayed against tribes Ril, Lihyan and Usaiya because they disobeyed Allah and His message. A Quranic verse was revealed about those who were killed, saying that Muslims who died at Bir Ma'una met their Lord and are happy with Him.

title: Al-Qunut in Prayer
content: I asked Anas bin Malik about Al-Qunut. He said the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) used it in prayer. I asked where to say it - before or after bowing down? Anas said before. But someone else told me you said it's after bowing, so I was confused. Anas said that person made a mistake. The Prophet (ﷺ) said Al-Qunut for one month after bowing because some people broke their peace treaty with him and killed 70 men he sent to them. So the Prophet prayed against them.

title: Ibn Umar's Battle Age
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) inspected Ibn Umar on the day of Uhud when he was 14 years old. The Prophet (ﷺ) did not let him fight in that battle. Later, at the age of 15, during the battle of Al-Khandaq, the Prophet allowed him to join the fight.

title: Carrying Earth in Trench
content: We were with Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) in a trench. Some people were digging while others carried the dirt on our shoulders. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'God, there's no life except what comes after death. Forgive the Emigrants and the Ansar.'

title: Prophet's Visit to the Trench
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) went out to see people digging a trench in cold weather. They were doing it themselves because they didn't have any slaves to help. He saw how hard they were working and how hungry they were. So he said, 'God, forgive these Emigrants and Ansar.' They replied, 'We're the ones who promised Muhammad (ﷺ) we'd fight for Islam as long as we live.'

title: Digging the Trench
content: Anas told me that when the Emigrants and Ansar were digging a trench around Medina, they carried heavy loads on their backs. They said, 'We've promised to follow Muhammad 's (ﷺ) teachings until we die.' The Prophet (ﷺ) replied, 'O Allah, only good things come from You in the afterlife. Bless the Emigrants and Ansar.' People brought small amounts of barley, which was cooked with oil or fat. The food was given to hungry workers who were struggling to eat it because of its strong smell.

title: Prophet Muhammad Helps Dig Trench
content: Jabir said that during the Battle of Al-Khandaq, they were digging a trench and found a big rock in their way. They told the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) about it, who came down to help. He was very hungry because they hadn't eaten for three days. The Prophet (ﷺ) took a spade and hit the rock until it turned into sand. Jabir asked if he could go home, but first prepared some food with his wife. When the Prophet arrived, he said that the food was plenty and good. He told Jabir's wife not to take the pot off the fire or any bread out of the oven yet. The Prophet (ﷺ) then invited all the companions to eat, and they sat down together. He cut the bread and gave meat to each person until everyone had enough to eat. Some food remained over.

title: Jabir's Meal for the Prophet
content: Jabir saw the Prophet in a state of great hunger while they were digging a trench. He went home and told his wife about it. They had some barley and a kid, so Jabir slaughtered the animal and cooked the meat with the barley. His wife was worried that he would be embarrassed if she gave him the food to take to the Prophet. So Jabir secretly asked the Prophet to come and eat with him. The Prophet (ﷺ) announced to everyone in the trench that they were having a meal, and many people came. When they arrived at Jabir's house, his wife brought out some dough for baking, and the Prophet spat on it and blessed it. He also spat on the pot of meat and blessed it. Then he told them to bake more bread and take turns eating from the pot. In the end, a thousand people ate from the food, but the pot was still full when they left.

title: Battle of the Trench
content: Aisha said that a verse in the Quran (33:10) refers to a battle where the enemy came from both sides and people were so scared their eyes went wide and they thought they would be attacked.

title: Prophet's Courage in Battle
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) was carrying earth on the day of Al-Khandaq. He got very dirty and said: 'We wouldn't be guided, give charity or pray without Allah.' He asked for calmness and strength to face the enemy if they attacked.

title: Victory from the Wind
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: 'I have been given victory by a strong east wind. The people of Ad were destroyed by a strong west wind.'

title: The Prophet Digs a Trench
content: One day, Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) was digging a trench. I saw him carrying earth out of the trench and heard him reciting some verses from Ibn Rawaha: 'We wouldn't be guided or give charity without You. Please send us calmness and make our feet strong if we meet the enemy.' The Prophet (ﷺ) would say these words loudly.

title: Ibn Umar's First Battle
content: Ibn Umar said that his first time fighting with the Prophet was on the day of Al-Khandaq, also known as the Trench.

title: Ibn Umar's Decision
content: Ibn Umar visited his wife Hafsa while she was washing her hair. He told her that the people were waiting for him, but he didn't want to go because it might cause problems. Hafsa said, 'You should go and calm them down.' So they went together. When they arrived, Muawiya stood up and said, 'If anyone has a problem with who's in charge, speak up!' Habib bin Masalama asked Ibn Umar why he didn't say anything back to Muawiya. Ibn Umar was about to respond, but then he thought better of it. He remembered that Allah rewards those who are patient and prefer the afterlife over this world. So he stayed quiet. Habib said, 'You did the right thing.'

title: After Battle of Ahzab
content: On the day of Al-Ahzab, the Prophet said: 'We will go and attack the enemy. They won't come to fight us.'

title: Prophet's New Strategy
content: After being forced out of their homes, the Prophet said: 'From now on, we will go and attack our enemies. They won't come to us anymore, but we'll go to them.'

title: Prophet's Prayer Wish
content: Ali narrated that on the day of Al-Khandaq, the Prophet said: 'May Allah fill their houses and graves with fire. They stopped us from praying when the sun was high until it set.'

title: Umar's Delayed Prayer
content: Umar bin Al-Khattab came to the Prophet after sunset. He said he couldn't pray the afternoon prayer until just before sunset. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'I didn't pray it.' They went down to Buthan and performed ablution for the prayer together. Then the Prophet prayed the afternoon prayer after sunset. After that, he prayed the evening prayer.

title: Prophet's Trust in Zubair
content: Jabir said the Prophet asked who would bring news of the Quraish clans. Az-Zubair volunteered each time. The Prophet (ﷺ) then said, 'Every prophet has a special helper, and mine is Az-Zubair.'

title: Allah's Messenger's Prayer
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) used to say: 'There is no one worthy of worship except Allah. He gives strength to His followers and makes them victorious, and He defeats those who don't believe in Him.'

title: Prophet's Prayer for Clans
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) said to Allah: 'O Allah, the One who reveals Your Book and knows everything. Defeat these clans and make them weak.'

title: Prophet's Return from Journey
content: When Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) came back from a trip or pilgrimage, he would say 'God is great' three times. Then he'd say: 'Only God deserves our worship, with no partners. He has all power and control. We're returning to Him, worshipping and praising Him. God kept His promise and helped us win.'

title: Gabriel's Message to the Prophet
content: After a long battle, the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) came back home and took a bath. Then Gabriel appeared and said, 'You've stopped fighting? We angels haven't finished yet.' The Prophet (ﷺ) asked where they should go next. Gabriel pointed towards Banu Quraiza. So the Prophet went there with his army.

title: Gabriel's Regiment Marches
content: I remember looking at the dust on the street in Medina. It was because of Gabriel's army marching by when the Prophet went to fight against Banu Quraiza.

title: Praying at Banu Quraiza
content: Ibn Umar said the Prophet told Muslims to pray 'Asr prayer only at Banu Quraiza's place. Some people prayed when they reached it, but others prayed on their way because they thought that was what the Prophet meant. The Prophet (ﷺ) didn't scold either group.

title: Prophet Muhammad Returns Date Palms
content: Anas said that some people from the Ansar gave date palm trees to the Prophet. When Banu Quraiza and Banu An-Nadir were conquered, the Prophet returned their date palms. The Ansar asked the Prophet to return some of theirs too, but he had given them to a woman named Um Aiman. She refused to give them back, saying she wouldn't return the trees unless the Prophet gave her ten times as many in exchange.

title: Banu Quraiza Agree to Verdict
content: Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri said: The people of Banu Quraiza agreed to accept a decision from Sa'd bin Mu'adh. The Prophet (ﷺ) sent for Sa'd, who came on a donkey. When he arrived at the mosque, the Prophet asked the Ansar to stand up for their leader. Then the Prophet told Sa'd that the people of Banu Quraiza had agreed to follow his judgment. Sa'd said they should kill the men and take the children as prisoners. The Prophet (ﷺ) approved this decision.

title: Sa'd is Wounded and Dies
content: Aisha told us about Sa'd. He was hurt by an arrow on the day of the Battle of Khandaq. The Prophet (ﷺ) pitched a tent for him in the Mosque so he could be near to visit. After the battle, Gabriel came to the Prophet while shaking dust off his head and said, 'Have you stopped fighting?' The Prophet (ﷺ) replied, 'No.' Gabriel told him to go back out to fight, pointing towards Bani Quraiza. The Prophet (ﷺ) went there and besieged them. They surrendered and asked for judgment. Sa'd gave his verdict: their warriors should be killed, women and children taken as captives, and properties distributed. Sa'd then prayed, 'O Allah, I wish to fight in Your Cause against those who disbelieved You.' He said if the war with Quraish wasn't over yet, keep him alive to fight again. If it was finished, let his wound kill him. His wound burst out and he died.

title: The Prophet Supports Hassan's Poetry
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) told Hassan bin Thabit to write poems that criticize the enemies. He said Gabriel is with him, which means he has Allah's support.

title: Fear Prayer During Battle
content: Jabir said the Prophet led his companions in a special prayer called Fear Prayer during the battle of Dhat-ur-Riqa. This was on a day when they were afraid, but there was no fighting. The Prophet (ﷺ) prayed two units of this special prayer.

title: Walking in the Desert
content: Abu Musa said: The Prophet (ﷺ) and I went on a trip with five other people. We had only one camel to share, so we took turns riding it. Because of all the walking, our feet got very sore and my toenail fell off. To make them feel better, we wrapped our feet in cloth pieces. This is why that trip was called Dhat-ur-Riqa.

title: Prayer in Battle Situation
content: During a battle, the Prophet led two groups of people in prayer. One group was with him and the other faced the enemy. He prayed one rak'a (unit of prayer) with his group, then let them finish their prayer while he stayed standing. Meanwhile, the other group came to join him, so he prayed another rak'a with them. When they finished their prayer, he sat down and completed his own prayer.

title: Fear Prayer During Battle
content: Jabir said the Prophet was with him at Nakhl. They performed a special prayer called Fear prayer during a battle against Banu Anmar. The Prophet (ﷺ) also offered this prayer in another battle, Ghazwa of Banu Anmar.

title: Fear Prayer in Battle
content: During a battle, the Imam stands facing the Qibla. One group of soldiers prays with him first, then they leave and go to relieve another group. The second group comes forward and prays with the Imam. The Imam leads two rak'ahs (units of prayer) in total. After each rak'ah, the soldiers bow and prostrate twice.

title: Ibn Umar's Experience in Najd
content: Ibn Umar went on a trip with the Prophet to Najd. They fought against their enemies and stood ready for battle.

title: Leading Prayer in Battle
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) led a prayer for protection while one group of soldiers was facing the enemy. When that group left, they took their place and he led another part of the prayer with them. After finishing the prayer, each group completed what they had missed.

title: Jabir Participated in a Battle
content: Jabir went on a trip with the Prophet to Najd. He was one of those who took part in this journey.

title: Prophet's Sword Incident
content: Jabir bin Abdullah said he fought in a battle with the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ). When they stopped to rest, the Prophet dismounted and people scattered for shade. The Prophet (ﷺ) sat under a tree and hung his sword on it. He fell asleep and when he woke up, a bedouin was sitting next to him holding the naked sword. The bedouin said 'Who can save you?' The Prophet (ﷺ) replied 'Allah.' When asked why he didn't punish the man, the Prophet said nothing happened.

title: Coitus Interruptus with the Prophet
content: Ibn Muhairiz said he saw Abu Sa`id Al-Khudri in the Mosque and asked him about coitus interruptus. Abu Sa`id explained that during a battle, they took Arab captives and wanted to have sex but not make children. They decided to ask Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) first. He said it's better not to do coitus interruptus because if a child is meant to be born, it will be born.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Encounter
content: We went on a trip with the Prophet to Najd. When it was time for rest, we found him under a tree in a valley with thorny trees. He hung his sword and rested. The people spread out among the trees to find shade. The Prophet (ﷺ) called us over and said, 'A Bedouin came while I was asleep. He took my sword without its sheath. When he saw me wake up, he stood by my head and said,

title: Prophet's Night Prayer
content: Jabir bin Abdullah saw the Prophet praying at night on his mount, facing east during a battle in Anmar.

title: Aisha's Story: The Slander
content: When the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) wanted to go on a journey, he would draw lots among his wives. One day, the lot fell on Aisha, and she went with him to a battle. After they returned to Medina, some people started spreading false rumors about Aisha. They said she had been seen with another man. The Prophet (ﷺ) was sad and didn't talk much to Aisha for a month. She became ill and felt that the Prophet wasn't treating her as well as before. One day, while Aisha was out with her friend Um Mistah, they talked about the rumors. Um Mistah told Aisha what people were saying. Aisha's parents came to visit her, but she didn't tell them what was happening. She wanted to talk to the Prophet herself. When the Prophet came to see Aisha, he said that he had heard some bad things about her and asked if she was guilty. Aisha replied that she knew the rumors were false, but people believed them because they had already been planted in their minds. The Prophet (ﷺ) then went away, and soon Allah revealed a message declaring Aisha's innocence. The Prophet (ﷺ) came back to Aisha and told her that Allah had declared her innocent. He also asked Zainab bint Jahsh about the rumors, and she said she knew nothing but good about Aisha. In the end, the man who started spreading the false rumors was punished, and Aisha was cleared of any wrongdoing.

title: Al-Walid questions Ali
content: Al-Walid bin Abdul Malik asked me if I knew that Ali was one of those who spoke badly about Aisha. I said no, but two men from his people told me that Aisha had said Ali didn't say anything to defend her.

title: Aisha's Innocence Proved
content: `Aisha and her mother were sitting when an Ansari woman came in. She said something bad about `Aisha's husband, Abu Bakr. The woman told Um Ruman that people had been talking about a story involving Abu Bakr. `Aisha heard this and fainted from shock. When she woke up, she was sick with fever. The Prophet (ﷺ) came to visit her and asked what was wrong. Her mother said it might be because of the story. The Prophet (ﷺ) said maybe. `Aisha got up and said that if she took an oath saying she was innocent, people wouldn't believe her. And if she said she wasn't innocent, they wouldn't forgive her. She said her situation was like Jacob's sons when he said only Allah can help them. The Prophet (ﷺ) left without speaking. Then Allah proved `Aisha's innocence. `Aisha thanked Allah alone.

title: Aisha's Knowledge of the Quran
content: Aisha used to read a verse from the Quran that says 'As you tell lies with your tongues.' She explained that this verse is about telling lies. This verse was revealed specifically about her, and she knew it better than anyone else.

title: Hassan Defends the Prophet
content: I was criticizing Hassan in front of Aisha. She said not to criticize him because he used to defend the Prophet against his enemies. Aisha told me that once Hassan asked the Prophet's permission to speak out against non-believers. The Prophet (ﷺ) replied, 'How can you exclude my ancestors from this?' Hassan said, 'I will take you out of them like one removes a hair from dough.' I criticized Hassan again because he spoke against Aisha.

title: Hassan's Poetry at Aisha's House
content: Masruq visited Aisha with Hassan bin Thabit. He was reciting poetry to her, saying she was a chaste and wise lady who didn't eat meat from suspicious women. Aisha told him he wasn't like that. Masruq asked why she let him in, quoting the Quran: 'Those who get the most blame will face a severe punishment.' Aisha replied, 'Blindness is worse than any other punishment.' She added that Hassan used to defend the Prophet with his poetry.

title: Rain on the Night Journey
content: One night it rained during a trip with the Prophet. He led us in morning prayer and asked if we knew what Allah had said. We didn't know, so he told us: 'Some of my followers believed in me, but some disbelieved. If someone says rain comes from Allah's mercy, they believe in me and not in stars. But if they say it's because of a star, they don't believe in me.'

title: Prophet's Four Umras
content: Anas said: The Prophet (ﷺ) performed four special trips around the Kaaba. He did one in Dhul-Qa'da, another in the next year in Dhul-Qa'da, a third from Al-Jirana in Dhul-Qa'da after distributing war spoils, and the fourth was with his Hajj.

title: Abu Qatada's Story
content: We went on a journey with the Prophet. All his friends decided to follow Islamic rules for pilgrimage. But I didn't, because I wasn't ready yet.

title: Conquest of Mecca was not the greatest victory
content: Al-Bara said: 'Do you think the conquest of Mecca was a great victory? We actually consider it to be the Ar-Ridwan Pledge we gave to the Prophet at Al-Hudaibiya. On that day, there were 1,400 men with the Prophet. The well at Al-Hudaibiya ran dry because we used all its water. When the Prophet found out, he sat on the edge of the well and asked for a container. He washed his face, rinsed his mouth, prayed, and poured the remaining water back into the well. We stayed there for a while and then the well filled up again with enough water for us and our animals.'

title: Allah's Messenger at Al-Hudaibiya
content: One day, the Prophet was with his companions near a well. They used all its water until it ran out. The Prophet (ﷺ) told them to bring him some of the remaining water. He spat into it and then said, 'Leave it alone for now.' Later, they drank from it and gave water to their animals before leaving.

title: Prophet's Miraculous Water
content: On the day of Al-Hudaibiya, many people were thirsty. The Prophet (ﷺ) had a container with water. He used it to wash his hands and face for prayer. Then he put his hand in the container again and water started coming out between his fingers. People drank from it and washed their hands and faces too.

title: Jabir's Account of Hudaibiya
content: I asked Sa'id bin Al-Musaiyab about the number of Muslims at Hudaibiya. He told me that Jabir said there were 1,500 who took an oath to follow the Prophet.

title: The Best People on Earth
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) told his companions: 'You are the best people on earth.' At that time, there were about 1,400 of them. He said he wished he could show them a special place where they had made a promise to follow him.

title: Pious People Will Die
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) said: 'Good people will die one by one. Only the bad people will be left, like rotten dates and barley. Allah won't care about them.'

title: Prophet's Journey to Al-Hudaibiya
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) went out with about 1,300 of his companions. When they reached a place called Dhul-Hulaifa, he prepared for the Hajj by putting garlands on himself and his animal, and marking them as special animals for sacrifice.

title: Prophet's Journey to Al-Hudaibiya
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) went out with about 1,300 of his companions. When they reached a place called Dhul-Hulaifa, he decorated and marked the animal he was taking for sacrifice, then put on special clothes for pilgrimage.

title: Prophet Muhammad Helps a Widow
content: One day, the Prophet saw Ka'b bin Ujra with lice on his face. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked if the lice were bothering him and Ka'b said yes. The Prophet (ﷺ) told Ka'b to shave his head because they were at Al-Hudaibiya and there was no sign that they would be able to enter Mecca soon. Later, a new rule was revealed allowing people in this situation to either feed six poor people, slaughter a sheep, or fast for three days instead of shaving their heads. Meanwhile, Umar bin Al-Khattab saw a young widow who had lost her husband and was struggling to care for her children. She didn't have enough food or money. Umar gave her a strong camel with two sacks of food, some money, and clothes, telling her that the provision would last until Allah provided more.

title: Sa'id's Father Sees a Tree
content: Sa'id bin Al-Musaiyab's father said he saw a tree where people made a promise to Allah. Later, when he went back, he couldn't find it and forgot what the tree looked like.

title: Recognizing the Tree of Pledge
content: Tariq bin `Abdur-Rahman went on Hajj and saw people praying near a tree. He asked what it was, and they said it's where Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) took an important pledge with his companions. Tariq told Sa`id bin Musaiyab about this, who said his father was one of those who gave the pledge there. But when they went back next year, they couldn't find the tree again.

title: Finding the Pledge Tree
content: Sa'id's father was one of those who made a promise to follow the Prophet under a tree. The next year, they went back but couldn't find the same tree.

title: Sa'id's Father Saw It
content: Tariq told Sa'id about a tree where the Prophet took an important promise from his followers. Sa'id smiled and said, 'My father told me about it too. He was there when it happened.'

title: Blessing Zakat Donors
content: Abdullah bin Abi Aufa said: When people brought charity to the Prophet, he would say, 'God bless them.' My father once gave his charity to the Prophet and he said, 'God bless Abu Aufa's family'.

title: Ibn Zaid's Pledge of Allegiance
content: On the day of Al-Harra, people were giving their pledge to Abdullah bin Hanzala. Ibn Zaid asked why they were doing this. He was told it was for death. Ibn Zaid said he would never give his pledge to anyone else after Allah's Messenger (ﷺ). Ibn Zaid had been present at the battle of Al-Hudaibiya with the Prophet.

title: My Father's Story of Jumu'ah
content: My father was one of the people who gave their promise to follow the Prophet. He told me that they would pray together on Fridays and then leave when there was no shade from the sun.

title: Yazid's Question to Salama
content: I asked Salama bin Al-Akwa', 'What did you pledge to do for Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) on the day of Al-Hudaibiya?' He said, 'I pledged to die in the way of Islam.'

title: Al-Bara' bin Azib's Story
content: I met Al-Bara' and said, 'May you live well. You were with the Prophet and gave him your loyalty under a tree.' He replied, 'You don't know what we did after he passed away'.

title: Thabit's Story at Hudaibiya
content: Abu Qilaba told me that Thabit bin Ad-Dahhak was one of the people who gave their promise to Allah under a tree during the pledge of allegiance in Al-Hudaibiya.

title: Victory and Reward for Believers
content: After the Al-Hudaibiya Pledge, Allah said to Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ): 'You have been given a great victory.' The companions were happy for him but asked what reward they would get. In response, Allah revealed that He will give believers men and women a special place in heaven where rivers flow.

title: Donkey Meat Forbidden
content: Zahir Al-Aslami was making fire for cooking. The announcer said that the Prophet forbids eating donkey meat.

title: Prophet's Companions Eat Sawiq
content: Suwaid bin An-Nu'man said: The Prophet (ﷺ) and his friends were given something called Sawiq to eat. They chewed it, but didn't swallow it.

title: Witr Prayer at Night
content: Abu Jamra asked Aidh bin 'Amr, a companion of the Prophet, if you offer witr prayer early in the night, don't repeat it late at night.

title: Umar's Question to the Prophet
content: One night, the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) was traveling with Umar bin Al-Khattab. Umar asked him a question three times, but the Prophet didn't answer. Umar got upset and said, 'May your mother be sad if you don't answer me.' He then rode his camel fast to get ahead of the others. When he stopped, someone called out to him. Umar went back to the Prophet and greeted him. The Prophet (ﷺ) said that a special chapter had been revealed to him tonight, one that was more precious than all the wealth in the world. He recited: 'We have given you a clear victory.'

title: The Prophet's Decision at Hudaibiya
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) went with over a thousand companions to the year of Al-Hudaibiya. When they reached Dhul-Hulaifa, he prepared his animal for sacrifice and put on special clothes for Umra (a type of pilgrimage). He sent a scout ahead to see what was happening. The scout came back and said that the Quraish people had gathered many others against them, including Ethiopians. They wanted to stop the Prophet from entering the Kaaba. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked his companions for advice. Some suggested fighting back, but Abu Bakr said, 'We didn't come here to fight or kill anyone. We want to visit the Kaaba peacefully.' The Prophet (ﷺ) agreed and said, 'Let's go on in Allah's name'.

title: The Prophet's Decision at Hudaibiya
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) went to Mecca with over a thousand companions. When he reached Dhul-Hulaifa, he prepared for the Umra pilgrimage and sent a spy to check on the Quraish tribe. The spy said they had gathered many people against them, including Ethiopians, who would stop them from entering the Kaaba. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked his companions what to do. Some suggested fighting back, but Abu Bakr said it was not their intention to fight or harm anyone. They should proceed to Mecca and whoever stopped them, they would defend themselves.

title: Returning Converts to Their Families
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) made a peace treaty with Suhail bin 'Amr. One condition was that if someone from the other side came to him and became Muslim, he would send them back to their family. The believers didn't like this condition. But Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) agreed to it anyway. He sent Abu Jandal, who had come to him as a Muslim, back to his father Suhail. During this time, he also returned every man who came from the other side, even if they were Muslims. Some believing women emigrants came to Medina, including Um Kulthum. When her relatives asked Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) to send her back, Allah revealed some new rules about what happens to believing women in these situations.

title: Returning Emigrants to Their Families
content: When Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) made a peace agreement with Suhail bin `Amr at Hudaibiya, one condition was that anyone who left their family and came to the Prophet would be sent back. The believers didn't like this condition. But the Prophet agreed to it anyway. He returned Abu Jandal to his father, Suhail, and also sent back every man from their group who came to him during that time, even if he was a Muslim. When believing women, including Um Kulthum, daughter of `Uqba bin Abi Mu'ait, arrived in Medina, the Prophet's relatives asked him to send them back too. This led to Allah revealing a verse about the believing women who came to give their pledge of allegiance.

title: Abdullah bin Umar's Umra
content: Nafi' said that Abdullah bin Umar went to perform a special pilgrimage called Umra during a difficult time. He said, 'If I'm not allowed to visit the Kaaba, I'll do what we did when we were with the Prophet.' So he put on special clothes for Umra in the year of Al-Hudaibiya.

title: Ibn Umar's Ihram Decision
content: Nafi' said that Ibn 'Umar put on the special clothes for Hajj. He said, 'If something stops me from going to the Ka'ba, I will do what the Prophet did when the Quraish people blocked his way.' Then Ibn 'Umar recited a verse: 'You have indeed in Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) a good example to follow'.

title: Abdullah bin Umar's Decision
content: `Abdullah bin `Umar was asked by his son to stay home and not go for Hajj. His son was worried that they might not reach the Ka`ba safely. Abdullah said, 'When we went with the Prophet for Umra, the Quraish stopped us from reaching the Ka`ba. The Prophet (ﷺ) sacrificed his animal and shaved his head. If I'm allowed to reach the Ka`ba, I'll do the same Tawaf (walk around) as in Umra. But if something stops me, I'll follow what the Prophet did.' After a while, Abdullah said, 'I've decided to combine both Umra and Hajj. So, I'll only do one walk around the Ka`ba and one Sai (between Safa and Marwa), then finish my Ihram for both Umra and Hajj.'

title: Ibn Umar's Story
content: People thought Ibn Umar became Muslim before his father. But it wasn't true. `Umar sent Abdullah to get a horse from an Ansari man for fighting. At that time, people were giving their promise to Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) near a tree. Abdullah gave his promise and went back to get the horse. When `Umar was getting ready to fight, Abdullah told him about the people promising allegiance to the Prophet. So `Umar went with Abdullah and promised allegiance too. This made people think Ibn Umar became Muslim before his father.

title: Prophet's Umra Visit
content: I was with the Prophet when he went for a special pilgrimage called Umra. He walked around the Kaaba, and we did the same. Then he prayed, and we prayed with him. After that, he walked quickly between two hills, Safa and Marwa. Some of us were protecting him from people who might try to harm him.

title: Sahl bin Hunaif's Return
content: Abu Wail asked Sahl bin Hunaif why he returned from the battle of Siffin. Sahl said, 'Don't think I'm a coward. It was because of your opinions. On the day of Abu Jandal, I wanted to fight, but if I could have refused the Prophet's order, I would have. Allah and His Messenger know what's best. When we prepare for battle with our swords, it usually leads to an easy solution. But when we fix a problem on one side, another issue opens up, and we don't know how to deal with it.'

title: Shaving for Lice
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) came to me at Al-Hudaibiya. I had lice on my face. He asked if they were bothering me. I said yes. He told me to shave my head or do one of three things: fast for three days, feed six poor people, or sacrifice a sheep.

title: Prophet's Advice on Ihram
content: At Al-Hudaibiya, the Prophet was with us. We were in a state of Ihram but couldn't go to the Ka'ba because the pagans wouldn't let us. I had lice in my hair and they were bothering me. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked if the lice were troubling me. I said yes. Then Allah revealed a verse: If you're ill or have an issue with your scalp, pay a fine by fasting, feeding the poor, or sacrificing an animal.

title: Bedouins Return to Disbelief
content: Some people from the tribes of 'Ukl and 'Uraina came to Medina. They became Muslim, but said they were nomads, not farmers. They found Medina's climate hard for them. The Prophet (ﷺ) helped them with milk camels and a shepherd. He told them to leave Medina and drink camel milk and urine as medicine. But when they got to Al-Harra, they went back to being non-Muslims. They killed the Prophet's shepherd and took his camels. When this happened, the Prophet sent people after them. The people were caught and brought back. The Prophet (ﷺ) decided what to do with them. He had their eyes branded with hot iron and cut off their hands and legs. They were left in Harra until they died.

title: Umar's Question About Qasama
content: Abu Raja was a freed slave of Abu Qilaba. He said that Umar bin Abdul Aziz asked people for their opinion about Qasama. They said it was a right decision, like what the Prophet and previous leaders did. Abu Qilaba was behind Umar's bed when he heard this conversation. Anbasa bin Said spoke up and mentioned a story from Anas bin Malik.

title: Salama's Brave Rescue
content: I was traveling from Medina to Al-Ghaba when I met a slave who told me that the Prophet Muhammad 's (ﷺ) she-camels had been taken by force. The people of Ghatafan were responsible. I shouted for help and rushed towards them, throwing arrows at them until they returned the camels. I also took thirty garments from them. When the Prophet arrived with his companions, he forgave the robbers because I had overpowered them.

title: Prophet's Journey Food
content: I went on a trip with the Prophet. When we reached Khaibar, he prayed Asr prayer. Then he asked us to gather food for our journey. We only had dry bread called Sawiq. He told us to soak it in water and eat it. After eating, he washed his face and mouth, then we did too. Finally, he prayed Maghrib prayer without washing again.

title: 'Amir's Poetry and Martyrdom
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) went to Khaibar with his companions. One of them, 'Amir bin Al-Akwa`, was a poet. He recited poetry while walking, saying that without Allah's guidance they wouldn't be on the right path or give charity or pray. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked who was reciting and was told it was 'Amir. He said,

title: Prophet Muhammad's Battle Plan
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) arrived at Khaibar one night. He usually waited till morning to attack the enemy. The next day, the Jews came out with tools and baskets when they saw him. They said, 'Muhammad (ﷺ) is here!' The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Khaibar will be defeated because evil comes to those who are warned.'

title: Khaibar: The Prophet's Warning
content: We arrived at Khaibar early in the morning. The people of Khaibar came out with their tools. When they saw the Prophet, they said, 'It's Muhammad (ﷺ) and his army!' The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'God is great! Khaibar will be destroyed.' We were about to eat donkey meat, but then a message was announced: 'The Prophet (ﷺ) says God and he forbid eating donkey meat - it's not clean.'

title: Prophet Forbids Eating Donkeys
content: Someone came to the Prophet and said, 'The donkeys have been eaten.' The Prophet (ﷺ) stayed quiet. The man came again and said, 'The donkeys have been eaten.' Again, the Prophet stayed quiet. The man came a third time and said, 'The donkeys have been consumed.' The Prophet (ﷺ) then ordered an announcer to tell people not to eat donkey meat. As soon as this was announced, people threw away their cooking pots with still-boiling donkey meat.

title: Prophet's Conquest of Khaibar
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) prayed near Khaibar at dawn. He said, 'God is great! Khaibar will be destroyed.' The people came out running. The Prophet (ﷺ) killed the warriors and took their families as prisoners. A woman named Safiya was among them. She was first given to a man named Dihya, but later became the Prophet's wife. The Prophet (ﷺ) freed her as part of her marriage gift.

title: Prophet Muhammad Marries Safiya
content: Anas bin Malik said the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) took Safiya as a prisoner. He then freed her and married her. Thabit asked Anas, 'What did he give her as a gift when they got married?' Anas replied, 'Her freedom was her gift, because he had already set her free'.

title: The Prophet's Warning
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) and his army fought against the pagans. One of his companions was so eager to fight that he kept chasing after a single enemy soldier, trying to strike him with his sword. The Prophet (ﷺ) said this man would go to Hell. A Muslim followed him to see what would happen. The companion got severely hurt and killed himself by throwing his sword at his chest. When the follower told the Prophet about this, the Prophet said: 'A person can do good things but still be from Hell, and another person can do bad things but still be from Paradise.'

title: Man from Hell-Fire
content: Abu Huraira said that the Prophet saw us at Khaibar. He said about a man who claimed to be Muslim, 'This man is from the people of Hell.' During the battle, this man fought very bravely and got many wounds. Some people doubted what the Prophet had said, but the man put his hand in his quiver and took out some arrows. He used them to kill himself. The Prophet (ﷺ) then said, 'Get up and announce that only a true believer will enter Paradise. Allah can support Islam with an evil person.'

title: Lower Your Voices
content: When the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) went to fight a battle called Khaibar, his followers would shout 'God is Great' when they saw a valley below. The Prophet (ﷺ) told them to speak softly because God was with them and could hear them clearly. One day, I was riding behind the Prophet and said out loud 'There's no power except from God'. He turned around and asked me if I wanted to hear a secret phrase that is like a treasure in Paradise. I said yes, so he told me to say 'There's no power except from God' whenever I needed help.

title: Prophet's Healing Touch
content: Yazid bin Abi Ubaid saw a wound on Salama's leg. He asked Salama about it, and Salama said he got hurt at Khaibar. Salama went to the Prophet and showed him the wound. The Prophet (ﷺ) spat in the wound three times, and after that, Salama felt no more pain.

title: Bravery and True Faith
content: During a battle, the Prophet met some pagans. One brave Muslim was praised for fighting well. The Prophet (ﷺ) said this man would go to Hell. People wondered how someone so brave could be from Hell. A man volunteered to follow him and see what he did. The brave man got hurt and wanted to die quickly. He put his sword on the ground and fell on it, killing himself. The other man went back to the Prophet and said he believed in him as a messenger of Allah. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked why. The man told him about the brave man's actions. The Prophet (ﷺ) explained that people can do good things but still go to Hell if their hearts are not right. And someone can do bad things, but still be on the path to Paradise.

title: Anas and Jewish Visitors
content: Anas saw people wearing special head coverings. He said they looked like the Jews from Khaibar.

title: Ali Receives the Flag
content: During the battle of Khaibar, Ali stayed behind because he had eye trouble. He wanted to join the Prophet, so he followed him. The next night, after they conquered Khaibar, the Prophet said that he would give the flag to someone who was loved by Allah and Him. Everyone thought it might be them, but then the Prophet gave the flag to Ali.

title: Ali Receives the Flag
content: On the day of Khaibar, the Prophet said that he would give a flag to someone who loved Allah and His Messenger. The people wondered who it would be. In the morning, they asked the Prophet for the flag, but he sent for Ali instead. Ali was suffering from eye trouble, so the Prophet spat in his eye and prayed for him. Ali was cured instantly. Then the Prophet gave him the flag. Ali said he would fight until everyone surrendered to Islam. The Prophet (ﷺ) told him to be patient and call the people to Islam when they entered their territory.

title: The Prophet Marries Safiya
content: We arrived at Khaibar and Allah helped the Prophet conquer the fort. The Prophet (ﷺ) saw a woman named Safiya, whose husband had been killed. He chose her as his wife. When we reached a place called Sidd-as-Sahba, Safiya's period ended. Then the Prophet married her. We prepared food on a small mat. The Prophet (ﷺ) invited everyone to join us for the wedding feast. After that, we traveled to Medina. I saw the Prophet making a cushion with his cloak behind him. He sat beside his camel and helped Safiya onto it.

title: Marriage to Safiya bint Huyai
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) stayed with Safiya for three days on the way to Khaibar. He married her during this time. Safiya was told to wear a veil as part of her new role.

title: Prophet's Marriage to Safiya
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) stayed in a place between Khaibar and Medina for three nights. He was married to a woman named Safiya during this time. I, Anas, invited people to his wedding celebration. There wasn't much food at the party, but the Prophet asked Bilal to put out some dates, dried yogurt, and butter on leather mats. Some people wondered if Safiya would be treated like one of the Prophet's wives or just a slave. When they left, the Prophet made Safiya sit behind him on his camel and told her to wear a veil.

title: Taking Food from the Enemy
content: We were fighting in Khaibar. Someone threw a container with fat into our camp. I was about to pick it up when I saw the Prophet there. I felt shy and didn't take it then.

title: Forbidden Foods at Khaiber
content: Ibn Umar said that on the day of the battle of Khaiber, the Prophet forbade eating garlic and donkey meat.

title: Prohibition on Temporary Marriage
content: On the day of Khaibar, Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) forbade temporary marriage and eating donkey meat.

title: Prohibition on Donkey Meat
content: Ibn Umar said that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) forbade eating donkey meat on the day of Khaibar.

title: Prohibition on Eating Donkey Meat
content: Ibn Umar said that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) forbade eating donkey meat.

title: Donkeys' Meat Forbidden
content: On the day of Khaibar, Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) forbade eating donkey meat. He allowed eating horse meat.

title: Prophet's Warning at Khaibar
content: We were very hungry on the day of Khaibar. The Prophet 's (ﷺ) announcer came and said, 'Don't eat donkey meat or stir up the pots.' We thought maybe it was because we hadn't taken some food for charity. Others said maybe he just didn't like eating donkeys because they eat dirty things.

title: Donkeys and Food for the Prophet
content: Some of my friends, Al-Bara and Abdullah bin Abi Aufa, were with me. We got some donkeys and cooked their meat. Then a messenger came from me and said, 'Throw away the food.'

title: Prophet Orders Food to be Thrown Away
content: Two companions of the Prophet had some donkeys. They slaughtered them and cooked the meat. The Prophet 's (ﷺ) announcer told them to throw away the food.

title: Turning Cooking Pots Upside Down
content: On the day of Khaibar, when food was being cooked, the Prophet said to turn the cooking pots upside down.

title: Turning Cooking Pots Upside Down
content: On the day of Khaibar, when food was being cooked, the Prophet said to turn the cooking pots upside down.

title: Walking around the Ka'ba
content: Al-Bara said: We went on a battle with the Prophet. He told us to walk around the Ka'ba seven times, and then pray near it.

title: Donkey Meat During Ghazwa
content: During the battle of Khaibar, the Prophet ordered us to throw away donkey meat. It didn't matter if it was raw or cooked - we couldn't eat it later on.

title: Prophet's Advice about Donkeys
content: Ibn Abbas said: The Prophet (ﷺ) might have forbidden eating donkey meat because they were used for work. Or he might have forbidden it forever on the day of Khaibar.

title: War Booty Distribution
content: On the day of Khaibar, the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) divided the war spoils. Those who had horses got two shares for their horse and one share for themselves. If someone didn't have a horse, they just got one share.

title: Uthman and Jubair's Concern
content: Uthman bin Affan and I went to the Prophet. We said, 'You gave money from a battle to Banu Al-Muttalib, but not to us.' The Prophet (ﷺ) replied, 'Banu Hashim and Banu Al-Muttalib are like brothers.' He didn't give any of that money to our family groups.

title: Asma' and the Boat People
content: Abu Musa and his two brothers traveled from Yemen to meet the Prophet in Medina. They sailed to Ethiopia, where they met Ja`far bin Abi Talib. Later, they all went to Medina together. Some people said that those who had sailed to Ethiopia had migrated first. Asma' bint 'Umais, a woman who had also traveled to Ethiopia, visited Hafsa, the Prophet's wife. `Umar saw her and asked who she was. He said that his group had migrated before hers, so they deserved more respect from the Prophet. Asma' got angry and promised not to eat or drink until she told the Prophet what `Umar had said. When the Prophet came, Asma' told him about it. The Prophet (ﷺ) explained that `Umar's group only had one migration reward, but Asma's group had two because they sailed across the sea.

title: Prophet Recognizes Reciters
content: Abu Musa said the Prophet said: I can tell when Al-Ashariyun are reciting the Quran at home. Their voices sound the same day and night, even though I don't see their houses during the day. One of them is Hakim who says to enemy forces: Wait for my companions.

title: Sharing Spoils of War
content: After conquering Khaibar, the Prophet gave us a share from the captured goods. But he only shared with those who were present during the battle.

title: Conquering Khaibar and the Prophet's Warning
content: When we took over Khaibar, we got cows, camels, goods, and gardens as spoils of war. We left with the Prophet to a place called Al-Qura. During this time, one of his slaves named Mid'am was hit by an arrow. People said he was lucky for being martyred. But the Prophet said that Mid'am's trouble came from taking something from the Khaibar booty before it was shared fairly. He had taken some cloth without permission, and now it was burning him like fire. A man then brought some leather straps to the Prophet and said they were things he took unfairly. The Prophet (ﷺ) replied, 'This is one strap of Fire' or 'These are two straps of Fire'.

title: Umar's Decision on Conquered Land
content: Umar said: 'If I wasn't worried about leaving other Muslims poor, I'd divide the land of any village we conquer. But instead, I'll keep it as a shared fund and give its money to everyone equally, like the Prophet did with Khaibar.'

title: Conquered Land Distribution
content: Umar said that if he didn't have to think about future Muslims, he would divide the land of villages conquered by Muslims among the fighters as the Prophet divided Khaibar's land.

title: Abu Huraira's Request
content: Abu Huraira asked the Prophet for a share from the Khaibar booty. One of Sa'id bin Al-'As' sons said, 'Don't give him anything.' Abu Huraira replied, 'This is the man who killed Ibn Qauqal.' The son said, 'A person from Qadum Ad-Dan coming here is strange.'

title: Abu Huraira's Story
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) sent Abu Huraira to Najd as a commander. When Abu Huraira and his team returned from Khaibar, their horse reins were made of date palm tree fibers. I told the Prophet not to give them any share of the war spoils. Abu Huraira was surprised by my suggestion. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked him to sit down and didn't give them any share.

title: Aban's Defense of Himself
content: Aban bin Sa'id met the Prophet. Abu Huraira said, 'This man killed Ibn Qauqal.' Aban replied to Abu Huraira, 'You're strange! You come from a family that was once lowly, but you blame me for killing someone Allah chose as a martyr with my own hand. And He stopped this person from hurting me with his hand.

title: Fatima's Inheritance Dispute
content: Fatima, the Prophet Muhammad 's (ﷺ) daughter, asked Abu Bakr for her share of property left by her father. She wanted Fadak and other land given to him as a gift from Allah. But Abu Bakr said that this property was not inherited, it was charity. He refused to give Fatima anything. This made Fatima angry and she stopped talking to Abu Bakr until she died six months later. After her death, Ali buried her at night without telling Abu Bakr. When people changed their behavior towards Ali, he gave an oath of allegiance to Abu Bakr. Later, Ali invited Abu Bakr to come alone, but Abu Bakr refused and brought Umar with him. They talked about the dispute over the Prophet's property and Ali explained that they didn't want to cause trouble, but felt they had a right in the matter because of their family connection to the Prophet. Abu Bakr promised to spend the property wisely and follow the Prophet's example. Ali then gave an oath of allegiance to Abu Bakr, and Muslims were happy with this decision.

title: Fatima's Inheritance Dispute
content: Fatima, the Prophet Muhammad 's (ﷺ) daughter, asked Abu Bakr, the new caliph, for her share of the property left by her father. Abu Bakr said that their property is not inherited and should be used as charity. He refused to give Fatima any money or land from this property. This made Fatima angry with Abu Bakr and she stopped talking to him until she died six months after her father's death. After Fatima died, her husband Ali buried her at night without telling Abu Bakr. When people saw how Abu Bakr treated Fatima, they started to dislike Ali too. So Ali went to Abu Bakr and gave him an oath of allegiance, saying that he was not jealous of Abu Bakr's position but wanted to follow the Prophet's rules. Abu Bakr accepted Ali's apology and said he would continue to use the property as charity. The Muslims were happy with this resolution and became friendly with Ali again.

title: Conquering Khaibar
content: When the town of Khaibar was captured, Aisha said to herself, 'Now we can eat dates freely.'

title: Conquering Khaibar
content: Ibn Umar said: We didn't eat a full meal until after we took over Khaibar.

title: Fair Trade in Dates
content: The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) told a man who brought him good-quality dates from Khaibar. The man said that they used to mix these with lower-quality dates and take one good date for two or three bad ones. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Don't do this. Sell the bad dates for money and then use that money to buy the good dates.'

title: Fair Trade in Dates
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) appointed a man to be the leader of Khaibar. He brought some good-quality dates to the Prophet. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked, 'Are all the dates in Khaibar like this?' The man replied, 'No, we take one Sa of these good dates for two or three Sa of poorer dates.' The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Don't do that. Sell the poor-quality dates and use the money to buy the good-quality ones instead.'

title: Khaibar Land Deal
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) gave the land to the Jews of Khaibar. They had to work on it and grow crops. In return, they would get half of what they produced.

title: Poisoned Gift to the Prophet
content: When Khaibar was conquered, a sheep with poison in it was given as a gift to Allah's Messenger (ﷺ). He received this poisoned food as a present after conquering Khaibar.

title: Respecting a Leader's Choice
content: Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) appointed Usama bin Zaid as the leader of some people. Some people didn't like his leadership style. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'If you criticize him, it's the same as criticizing me.' He added that Usama was very capable and one of his favorite companions.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Peace Treaty
content: When Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) went to Mecca for a special visit called Umra, the people of Mecca wouldn't let him in. They wanted him to agree to a peace treaty that said he could only stay there for three days. The Muslims wrote the treaty, but it said 'Muhammad (ﷺ), Apostle of Allah' had agreed to it. The people of Mecca didn't want this title, so they asked Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) to change it. He told Ali to erase it, but Ali refused. Then Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) took the paper and rewrote it himself. It said that he could bring only sheathed swords into Mecca and couldn't take anyone from there with him. When the allowed time was over, the people of Mecca asked Ali to tell Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) to leave. He left, and his daughter-in-law Fatima gave her horse to the daughter of Hamza so she could follow him. Later, when they got back to Medina, three men argued about who should take care of the girl. They were Ali, Zaid, and Ja'far. The Prophet (ﷺ) said that the aunt is like a mother, so he gave the girl to her aunt. He also told each man something special: Ali was from him and he was from Ali; Ja'far looked like him and had his character; and Zaid was their brother and freed slave. Ali asked if he could marry the daughter of Hamza, but the Prophet said no because she was the daughter of his foster brother.

title: Prophet's Peace Treaty with Quraish
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) went to perform Umra but the people of Quraish stopped him. He agreed to a treaty: he would come back next year, not carry arms except swords, and leave Mecca after three days. The next year, he came back as promised and stayed for three days before leaving.

title: Abdullah bin Umar's Umras
content: Urwa and I went to the Mosque. We found Abdullah bin Umar sitting near Aisha's house. Urwa asked him, 'How many extra pilgrimages did the Prophet make?' Abdullah said, 'Four. One was in Rajab.' We then heard Aisha brushing her teeth. Urwa told her, 'Aisha, don't you hear what Abdullah is saying? He says the Prophet made four extra pilgrimages, one in Rajab.' Aisha replied, 'The Prophet (ﷺ) didn't make any extra pilgrimages. But he did see one. And he never made an extra pilgrimage in Rajab'.

title: Abdullah bin Umar's Umra
content: Urwa and I went to the Mosque. We found Abdullah bin Umar sitting near Aisha's home. Urwa asked, 'How many extra pilgrimages did the Prophet make?' Abdullah replied, 'Four. One was in Rajab.' We heard Aisha brushing her teeth. Urwa said, 'Aisha, don't you hear what Abdullah is saying? He says the Prophet made four extra pilgrimages, one of them in Rajab.' Aisha said, 'The Prophet (ﷺ) didn't make any extra pilgrimage. But he did witness it. And he never made an extra pilgrimage in Rajab.'

title: Allah's Messenger Protected
content: Ibn Abi Aufa said that when Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) performed a special pilgrimage to the Kaaba, we stood guard around him to protect him from harm by non-Muslims and their children.

title: Prophet's Order for Ramal
content: When the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) and his friends arrived in Mecca, some people said they looked weak from a fever. The Prophet (ﷺ) ordered his friends to walk quickly around the Kaaba for the first three times, but not all the way around. He didn't want them to get too tired.

title: The Prophet's Visit to Mecca
content: When the Prophet arrived in Mecca after a treaty with the pagans, he wanted to show them his strength. He ordered his companions to walk quickly around the Ka'ba and between Safa and Marwa hills. This was so the pagans watching from Quaiqan hill could see they were strong.

title: Prophet's Marriage in Ihram
content: Ibn Abbas said: The Prophet (ﷺ) married Maimuna when he was on a special pilgrimage journey called Ihram. He didn't have sex with her while he was still in this state. After the pilgrimage ended, they had sex for the first time. Maimuna died near Mecca at a place called Sarif. Ibn Abbas added that the Prophet married Maimuna during a special Umra (pilgrimage) that replaced another one that was cancelled because of some people who didn't let him do it.

title: Ibn Umar's Story of Ja'far
content: Abdullah bin Umar told me that he saw Ja'far after the battle. He had been killed and had over 50 wounds on his body, but none were in his back. The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) had chosen Zaid to lead the army at Mu'tah. If Zaid was killed, Ja'far should take over, and if Ja'far was killed, Abdullah bin Rawaha would be in charge. I saw Ja'far's body after he was killed. He had more than 90 wounds on his body from arrows or swords.

title: Prophet's Words About Martyrs
content: The Prophet (ﷺ) told people that Zaid was killed while leading the army. Then Ja`far took over and was also killed. After that, Ibn Rawaha led the army but he too was martyred. The Prophet (ﷺ) was sad when he said this. He then said Khalid took the flag next and Allah helped the Muslims win.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Reaction
content: `Aisha told me that when the Prophet heard about the death of three companions - Ibn Haritha, Ja`far bin Abi Talib and `Abdullah bin Rawaha - he looked very sad. I was watching from behind a door when a man came to him and said, 'The women of Ja`far are crying.' The Prophet (ﷺ) told him to stop them from crying. But the man went back and said they didn't listen. The Prophet (ﷺ) ordered him again to go and tell them not to cry. This time the man said he couldn't control them. The Prophet (ﷺ) then said, 'Go and tell them to calm down.' `Aisha was upset with the man for not doing what the Prophet told him.

title: Greeting the Son of Ja'far
content: 'Amir said that whenever Ibn 'Umar met the son of Ja'far, he would say to him: 'Peace be on you. You are the son of someone who was a companion.'

title: Khalid's Broken Swords
content: Khalid bin Al-Walid was in a battle at Mu'tah. His swords kept breaking until he only had one left, which was from Yemen.

title: Khalid bin Al-Walid's Story
content: At the battle of Mu'tah, Khalid bin Al-Walid broke nine swords with his hand. Only one sword from Yemen remained in his hand.

title: Abdullah's Sister Seeks Help
content: Abdullah bin Rawaha fell down unconscious. His sister Amra cried out for help, calling him by his good qualities. When he came to, he asked her, 'Is what you said really true?'

title: Abdullah bin Rawaha's Death
content: An Nu'man bin Bashir said that Abdullah bin Rawaha fell down unconscious. When he died, his sister did not cry over him.

title: Usama's Questionable Action
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) sent Usama and another man to fight against Al-Huraqa. They won the battle, but during it, Usama killed a man who said 'There is no god except Allah'. When they returned, the Prophet asked Usama why he had killed him after hearing those words. Usama replied that the man was just trying to save himself. The Prophet (ﷺ) kept repeating that Usama should not have killed him.

title: Salama's Battles with the Prophet
content: I fought in seven battles with the Prophet. I also fought in nine battles led by other commanders: Abu Bakr and Usama.

title: Salama Fought with the Prophet
content: I fought seven battles with the Prophet. I also fought in nine battles led by armies sent by him. Once Abu Bakr was our leader, and another time it was Usama.

title: Salama's Battles with the Prophet
content: I fought in nine battles with the Prophet. I also fought under Ibn Haritha when the Prophet made him our leader.

title: Salama's Battles with the Prophet
content: Salama bin Al-Akwa` said he fought in seven battles with the Prophet. He mentioned Khaibar, Hudaibiya, Hunain, and Qarad. He forgot the names of the other three battles.

title: Hatib's Letter to Mecca
content: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) sent Ali, Zubair, and Miqdad on a mission. They rode their horses fast until they reached Rawdat Khakh. There, they found a woman carrying a letter. The Prophet (ﷺ) had told them to get the letter from her. She said she didn't have one, but they kept asking until she took it out of her hair. They brought the letter back to the Prophet. It was from Hatib bin Abi Balta'a to some people in Mecca. He wrote about what the Prophet planned to do. The Prophet (ﷺ) asked Hatib why he did this. Hatib explained that he wanted to help his friends in Mecca, even though they weren't related to him. He didn't want them to hurt his family. The Prophet (ﷺ) said Hatib was telling the truth. Some of the companions wanted to punish Hatib, but the Prophet stopped them. He reminded them that Hatib had fought with them at Badr and was forgiven by Allah. Later, a verse from the Quran was revealed about not being friends with enemies of Islam.

title: Prophet Muhammad's Ramadan Fasting
content: Ibn Abbas said the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) fought battles in Ramadan. He also fasted during this time. When he reached a place called Al-Kadid, he broke his fast and didn't fast again until the month was over.
